## 1 The Gambit system {#The-Gambit-system-1 .chapter}

[]{#index-Gambit-1 .index-entry-id} []{#index-Scheme .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-gsi .index-entry-id} []{#index-gsc .index-entry-id}

The Gambit programming system is a full implementation of the Scheme
language which conforms to the R4RS, R5RS, R7RS and IEEE Scheme
standards. It consists of two main programs: `gsi`{.code}, the Gambit
Scheme interpreter, and `gsc`{.code}, the Gambit Scheme compiler.

The Gambit Scheme compiler translates Scheme code to another target
language, currently C or JavaScript. The C target is the most mature and
it offers portability and fast execution. The JavaScript target allows
writing web apps in Scheme.

Most of the Gambit system, including the interpreter and compiler, is
written in Scheme and compiled to portable C code using the compiler.
The high portability of the generated C code allows the interpreter,
compiler and user programs to be easily compiled and executed on any
platform for which a C compiler is available. With appropriate
declarations in the source code the compiled Scheme programs run roughly
as fast as equivalent C programs.

For the most up to date information on Gambit and related resources
please visit the Gambit web page at
[https://gambitscheme.org](https://gambitscheme.org){.uref}. Issues
should be reported on the github source code repository
[https://github.com/gambit/gambit](https://github.com/gambit/gambit){.uref}.

-   [Accessing the system
    files](#Accessing-the-system-files){accesskey="1"}

### 1.1 Accessing the system files {#Accessing-the-system-files-1 .section}

Files related to Gambit, such as executables, libraries and header
files, are stored in multiple *Gambit installation directories*. Gambit
may be installed on a system according to two different installation
models.

In the first model there is a single directory where all the Gambit
installation directories are stored. This *central installation
directory* is typically `/usr/local/Gambit`{.code} under UNIX,
`/Library/Gambit`{.code} under macOS and
`C:/Program Files/Gambit`{.code} under Microsoft Windows. This may have
been overridden when the system was built with the command
'`configure --prefix=/my/Gambit`{.sample .samp}'. If the system was
built with the command '`configure --enable-multiple-versions`{.sample
.samp}' then the central installation directory is
[*`prefix`{.code}*]{.r}`/`{.code}[*`version`{.code}*]{.r}, where
[*`version`{.code}*]{.r} is the system version string (e.g.
`v4.9.5`{.code} for Gambit v4.9.5). Moreover,
[*`prefix`{.code}*]{.r}`/current`{.code} will be a symbolic link which
points to the central installation directory. In this model, the Gambit
installation directory named `X`{.variable .var} is simply the
subdirectory `X`{.variable .var} of the central installation directory.

In the second model some or all of the Gambit installation directories
are stored in installation specific directories. The location of these
directories is assigned when the system is built using the command
'`configure --bindir=/my/bin --includedir=/my/include --libdir=/my/lib`{.sample
.samp}'.

The advantage of the first model is that it is easy to have multiple
versions of Gambit coexist and to remove all the files of a given
version. However, the second model may be necessary to conform to the
package installation conventions of some operating systems.

Executable programs such as the interpreter `gsi`{.code} and compiler
`gsc`{.code} can be found in the `bin`{.code} installation directory.
Adding this directory to the `PATH`{.code} environment variable allows
these programs to be started by simply entering their name. This is done
automatically by the macOS and Microsoft Windows installers.

The runtime library is located in the `lib`{.code} installation
directory. When the system's runtime library is built as a
shared-library (with the command '`configure --enable-shared`{.sample
.samp}') all programs built with Gambit, including the interpreter and
compiler, need to find this library when they are executed and
consequently this directory must be in the path searched by the system
for shared-libraries. This path is normally specified through an
environment variable which is `LD_LIBRARY_PATH`{.code} on most versions
of UNIX, `LIBPATH`{.code} on AIX, `SHLIB_PATH`{.code} on HPUX,
`DYLD_LIBRARY_PATH`{.code} on macOS, and `PATH`{.code} on Microsoft
Windows. If the shell is `sh`{.code}, the setting of the path can be
made for a single execution by prefixing the program name with the
environment variable assignment, as in:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/local/Gambit/lib gsi
```
:::

A similar problem exists with the Gambit header file `gambit.h`{.code},
located in the `include`{.code} installation directory. This header file
is needed for compiling Scheme programs with the Gambit compiler. When
the C compiler is being called explicitly it may be necessary to use a
`-I`{.code}`<dir>`{.variable .var} command line option to indicate where
to find header files and a `-L`{.code}`<dir>`{.variable .var} command
line option to indicate where to find libraries.

Access to both of these files can be simplified by creating a link to
them in the appropriate system directories (special privileges may
however be required):

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ ln -s /usr/local/Gambit/lib/libgambit.a /usr/lib # name may vary
$ ln -s /usr/local/Gambit/include/gambit.h /usr/include
```
:::

Alternatively these files can be copied or linked in the directory where
the C compiler is invoked (this requires no special privileges).

Another approach is to set some environment variables which are used to
tell the C compiler where to find header files and libraries. For
example, the following settings can be used for the `gcc`{.code} C
compiler:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ export LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/local/Gambit/lib
$ export CPATH=/usr/local/Gambit/include
```
:::

Note that this may have been done by the installation process. In
particular, the macOS and Microsoft Windows prebuilt installers set up
the environment so that the `gcc`{.code} compiler finds these files
automatically.

## 2 The Gambit Scheme interpreter {#The-Gambit-Scheme-interpreter .chapter}

[]{#index-interpreter .index-entry-id}

Synopsis:

::: example
``` example-preformatted
gsi [-:runtimeoption,…] [-i] [-f] [-h] [-help] [-v]
    [[-] [-e expressions] [-install] [-uninstall] [-update]
     [search-directory-or-module-or-file]]…
```
:::

[]{#index-gsi-1 .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002d .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002de .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002df .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002di .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002dh .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002dhelp .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002dv .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002dinstall .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002duninstall
.index-entry-id} []{#index-_002dupdate .index-entry-id}

The interpreter is executed in *batch mode* when the command line
contains a module or file or a '`-`{.sample .samp}', or '`-e`{.sample
.samp}' option. The interpreter is executed in *module management mode*
when the command line contains the '`-install`{.sample .samp}',
'`-uninstall`{.sample .samp}', or '`-update`{.sample .samp}' option.
Otherwise the interpreter is executed in *interactive mode*. The
'`-i`{.sample .samp}' option is ignored by the interpreter. The
initialization file will be examined unless the '`-f`{.sample .samp}'
option is present (see [Customization](#GSI-customization){.pxref}). The
'`-h`{.sample .samp}' and '`-help`{.sample .samp}' options print brief
usage information on standard output and exit. The '`-v`{.sample .samp}'
option prints the system version string, system time stamp, operating
system type, and configure script options on standard output and exits.
Runtime options are explained in [Runtime
options](#Runtime-options){.ref}.

-   [Interactive mode](#GSI-interactive-mode){accesskey="1"}

    mode](#GSI-package-management-mode){accesskey="3"}

### 2.1 Interactive mode {#Interactive-mode .section}

In interactive mode a read-eval-print loop (REPL) is started for the
user to interact with the interpreter. At each iteration of this loop
the interpreter displays a prompt, reads a command and executes it. The
commands can be expressions to evaluate (the typical case) or special
commands related to debugging, for example '`,q`{.sample .samp}' to
terminate the process (for a complete list of commands see
[Debugging](#Debugging){.ref} or use the '`,help`{.sample .samp}'
command). Most commands produce some output, such as the value or error
message resulting from an evaluation.

The input and output of the interaction is done on the *interaction
channel*. The interaction channel can be specified through the runtime
options but if none is specified the system uses a reasonable default
that depends on the system's configuration. Typically the program's
standard input and output are used as the interaction channel. When
using the runtime option '`-:debug=c`{.sample .samp}', the interaction
channel is the user's *console*, also known as the *controlling
terminal* in the UNIX world.

When the REPL starts, the ports associated with
'`(current-input-port)`{.sample .samp}',
'`(current-output-port)`{.sample .samp}' and
'`(current-error-port)`{.sample .samp}' all refer to the interaction
channel.

Expressions are evaluated in the global *interaction environment*. The
interpreter adds to this environment any definition entered using the
`define`{.code} and `define-macro`{.code} special forms. Once the
evaluation of an expression is completed, the value or values resulting
from the evaluation are output to the interaction channel by the pretty
printer. The special *void object* is not output. This object is
returned by most procedures and special forms which are defined as
returning an unspecified value (e.g. `write`{.code}, `set!`{.code},
`define`{.code}).

Here is a sample interaction with `gsi`{.code}:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ gsi
Gambit v4.9.5

> (define (fact n) (if (< n 2) 1 (* n (fact (- n 1)))))
> (map fact '(1 2 3 4 5 6))
(1 2 6 24 120 720)
> (values (fact 10) (fact 40))
3628800
815915283247897734345611269596115894272000000000
> ,q
```
:::

What happens when errors occur is explained in
[Debugging](#Debugging){.ref}.

### 2.2 Batch mode {#Batch-mode .section}

[]{#index-_002d-1 .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002de-1 .index-entry-id}

In batch mode the command line arguments denote modules and files to
execute, REPL interactions to start ('`-`{.sample .samp}' option), and
expressions to be evaluated ('`-e`{.sample .samp}' option). Those
options can be interspersed with the search directories, modules, and
files on the command line and can occur multiple times.

In addition to these options the command line may contain 3 types of
non-options: *search directories*, *modules*, and *files*.

*Search directories*

:   Search directories are locations in the file system that are
    searched to resolve references to modules. Any command line argument
    that ends with a path separator or a '`.`{.sample .samp}' is treated
    as a search directory. By default the module search order is
    initially `~~lib`{.code} (which contains builtin modules) followed
    by `~~userlib`{.code} (which contains user installed modules and is
    typically the directory `.gambit_userlib`{.code} in the user's home
    directory). Search directories on the command line are added to the
    front of the search order, and thus take precedence over the default
    module search order.

*Modules*

:   Modules are either *unversioned* or *versioned* (managed by the
    `git`{.code} version-control system). There are two flavors of
    versioned modules: *hosted* modules have a `git`{.code} repository
    on a network accessible repository manager site such as
    `github.com`{.code} and `gitlab.com`{.code}, and *local* modules
    have a `git`{.code} repository on the local file system. Module
    names have a syntax similar to the paths used to identify files.
    They consist of one or more non-empty parts separated by
    '`/`{.sample .samp}'. The last part may end with a suffix of the
    form `@`{.code}[`version`{.variable .var}]{.r}. Only the first part
    and version may contain '`.`{.sample .samp}', otherwise only the
    characters a-z, A-Z, 0-9, '`-`{.sample .samp}', and '`_`{.sample
    .samp}' are permitted. If there are at least 3 parts and the first
    part contains at least one '`.`{.sample .samp}' and no '`_`{.sample
    .samp}', then it refers to a hosted module (1st part = host, 2nd
    part = account, 3rd part = repository name). For example
    `github.com/gambit/hello@1.0`{.code} is a hosted module reference.
    Otherwise it refers to a local versioned module or an unversioned
    module, for example `foobar`{.code} or `A/B/C/D`{.code}.

*Files*

:   Files are simple code containers located on the local file system.
    They are also identified by a path. If a path is a valid module or
    file, it is interpreted as a module. Note that a path with a last
    component containing an extension, such as '`.scm`{.sample .samp}',
    and no `@`{.code}, is always interpreted as a file.

The interpreter processes the command line arguments from left to right.
Search directories are added to the head of the module search order.
Files are executed using the `load`{.code} procedure. Modules are
requested using the `##demand-module`{.code} special form (this form is
explained in [Modules](#Modules){.ref}, but essentially it causes that
module to be searched in the module search order and executed once). The
'`-e`{.sample .samp}' option uses the `eval`{.code} procedure to
evaluate expressions in the global interaction environment. After this
processing the interpreter exits.

The ports associated with '`(current-input-port)`{.sample .samp}',
'`(current-output-port)`{.sample .samp}' and
'`(current-error-port)`{.sample .samp}' initially refer respectively to
the standard input ('`stdin`{.sample .samp}'), standard output
('`stdout`{.sample .samp}') and the standard error ('`stderr`{.sample
.samp}') of the interpreter. This is true even in REPLs started with the
'`-`{.sample .samp}' option. The usual interaction channel is still used
to read expressions and commands and to display results. This makes it
possible to use REPLs to debug programs which read the standard input
and write to the standard output, even when these have been redirected.

Here is a sample use of the interpreter in batch mode, under UNIX:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ cat h.scm
(display "hello") (newline)
$ cat w.six
display("world"); newline();
$ gsi h.scm - w.six -e "(pretty-print 1)(pretty-print 2)"
hello
> (define (display x) (write (reverse (string->list x))))
> ,c
(#\d #\l #\r #\o #\w)
1
2
$ gsi . h w   # add . to search order to load modules h and w
hello
world
```
:::

### 2.3 Module management mode {#Module-management-mode .section}

[]{#index-_002dinstall-1 .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002duninstall-1
.index-entry-id} []{#index-_002dupgrade .index-entry-id}

Package management operations are executed using the command line
options '`-install`{.sample .samp}', '`-uninstall`{.sample .samp}', and
'`-update`{.sample .samp}' which respectively install, uninstall and
update packages. Package installation is explained in detail in
[Modules](#Modules){.ref}, but here are a few examples:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ gsi -install github.com/gambit/hello
installing github.com/gambit/hello to /Users/feeley/.gambit_userlib/
$ gsi github.com/gambit/hello@1.0
hello world!
$ gsi -uninstall github.com/gambit/hello
uninstalling github.com/gambit/hello from /Users/feeley/.gambit_userlib/
```
:::

### 2.4 Customization {#Customization .section}

There are two ways to customize the interpreter. When the interpreter
starts off it tries to execute a '`(load "~~lib/gambext")`{.sample
.samp}' (for an explanation of how file names are interpreted see [Host
environment](#Host-environment){.ref}). An error is not signaled when
the file does not exist. Interpreter extensions and patches that are
meant to apply to all users and all modes should go in that file.

Extensions which are meant to apply to a single user or to a specific
working directory are best placed in the *initialization file*, which is
a file containing Scheme code. In all modes, the interpreter first tries
to locate the initialization file by searching the following locations:
`.gambini`{.sample .file} and `~/.gambini`{.sample .file} (with no
extension, a '`.sld`{.sample .samp}' extension, a '`.scm`{.sample
.samp}' extension, and a '`.six`{.sample .samp}' extension in that
order). The first file that is found is examined as though the
expression `(include `{.code}`initialization-file`{.variable
.var}`)`{.code} had been entered at the read-eval-print loop where
`initialization-file`{.variable .var} is the file that was found. Note
that by using an `include`{.code} the macros defined in the
initialization file will be visible from the read-eval-print loop (this
would not have been the case if `load`{.code} had been used). The
initialization file is not searched for or examined when the
'`-f`{.sample .samp}' option is specified.

### 2.5 Process exit status {#Process-exit-status .section}

The status is zero when the interpreter exits normally and is nonzero
when the interpreter exits due to an error. Here is the meaning of the
exit statuses:

`0`{.code}

:   The execution of the primordial thread (i.e. the main thread) did
    not encounter any error. It is however possible that other threads
    terminated abnormally (by default threads other than the primordial
    thread terminate silently when they raise an exception that is not
    handled).

`64`{.code}

:   The runtime options or the environment variable '`GAMBOPT`{.sample
    .samp}' contained a syntax error or were invalid.

`70`{.code}

:   This normally indicates that an exception was raised in the
    primordial thread and the exception was not handled.

`71`{.code}

:   There was a problem initializing the runtime system, for example
    insufficient memory to allocate critical tables.

For example, if the shell is `sh`{.code}:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ gsi -e "(pretty-print (expt 2 100))"
1267650600228229401496703205376
$ echo $?
0
$ gsi -e "(pretty-print (expo 2 100))"
*** ERROR IN (string)@1.16 -- Unbound variable: expo
$ echo $?
70
$ gsi -:debug=0 -e "(pretty-print (expo 2 100))"
$ echo $?
70
$ gsi -:debug=0,unknown # try to use an unknown runtime option
$ echo $?
64
$ gsi -:debug=0 nonexistent.scm # try to load a file that does not exist
$ echo $?
70
$ gsi nonexistent.scm
*** ERROR IN ##load-module-or-file -- No such file or directory
(load "nonexistent.scm")
$ echo $?
70
```
:::

Note the use of the runtime option '`-:debug=0`{.sample .samp}' that
prevents error messages from being output.

### 2.6 Scheme scripts {#Scheme-scripts-1 .section}

The `load`{.code} procedure treats specially files that begin with the
two characters '`#!`{.sample .samp}' and '`@;`{.sample .samp}'. Such
files are called *script files* and the first line is called the *script
line*. In addition to indicating that the file is a script, the script
line provides information about the source code language to be used by
the `load`{.code} procedure. After the two characters '`#!`{.sample
.samp}' and '`@;`{.sample .samp}' the system will search for the first
substring matching one of the following language specifying tokens:

`scheme-r4rs`{.code} [¶](#index-scheme_002dr4rs){.copiable-link}

:   R4RS language with prefix syntax, case-insensitivity, keyword syntax
    not supported

`scheme-r5rs`{.code} [¶](#index-scheme_002dr5rs){.copiable-link}

:   R5RS language with prefix syntax, case-insensitivity, keyword syntax
    not supported

`scheme-ieee-1178-1990`{.code} [¶](#index-scheme_002dieee_002d1178_002d1990){.copiable-link}

:   IEEE 1178-1990 language with prefix syntax, case-insensitivity,
    keyword syntax not supported

`scheme-srfi-0`{.code} [¶](#index-scheme_002dsrfi_002d0){.copiable-link}

:   R5RS language with prefix syntax and SRFI 0 support (i.e.
    `cond-expand`{.code} special form), case-insensitivity, keyword
    syntax not supported

`gsi-script`{.code} [¶](#index-gsi_002dscript){.copiable-link}

:   Full Gambit Scheme language with prefix syntax, case-sensitivity,
    keyword syntax supported

`gsc-script`{.code} [¶](#index-gsc_002dscript){.copiable-link}

:   Full Gambit Scheme language with prefix syntax, case-sensitivity,
    keyword syntax supported

`six-script`{.code} [¶](#index-six_002dscript){.copiable-link}

:   Full Gambit Scheme language with infix syntax, case-sensitivity,
    keyword syntax supported

If a language specifying token is not found, `load`{.code} will use the
same language as a nonscript file (i.e. it uses the file extension and
runtime system options to determine the language).

After processing the script line, `load`{.code} will parse the rest of
the file (using the syntax of the language indicated) and then execute
it. When the file is being loaded because it is an argument on the
interpreter's command line, the interpreter will:

-   []{#index-command_002dline .index-entry-id} Setup the
    `command-line`{.code} procedure so that it returns a list containing
    the expanded file name of the script file and the arguments
    following the script file on the command line. This is done before
    the script is executed. The expanded file name of the script file
    can be used to determine the directory that contains the script
    (i.e. `(path-directory (car (command-line)))`{.code}).
-   After the script is loaded the procedure `main`{.code} is called
    with the command line arguments. The way this is done depends on the
    language specifying token. For `scheme-r4rs`{.code},
    `scheme-r5rs`{.code}, `scheme-ieee-1178-1990`{.code}, and
    `scheme-srfi-0`{.code}, the `main`{.code} procedure is called with
    the equivalent of `(main (cdr (command-line)))`{.code} and
    `main`{.code} is expected to return a process exit status code in
    the range 0 to 255. This conforms to the "Running Scheme Scripts on
    Unix SRFI" (SRFI 22). For `gsi-script`{.code} and
    `six-script`{.code} the `main`{.code} procedure is called with the
    equivalent of `(apply main (cdr (command-line)))`{.code} and the
    process exit status code is 0 (`main`{.code}'s result is ignored).
    The Gambit system has a predefined `main`{.code} procedure which
    accepts any number of arguments and returns 0, so it is perfectly
    valid for a script to not define `main`{.code} and to do all its
    processing with top-level expressions (examples are given in the
    next section).
-   When `main`{.code} returns, the interpreter exits. The command line
    arguments after a script file are consequently not processed
    (however they do appear in the list returned by the
    `command-line`{.code} procedure, after the script file's expanded
    file name, so it is up to the script to process them).

#### 2.6.1 Scripts under UNIX and macOS {#Scripts-under-UNIX-and-macOS-1 .subsection}

Under UNIX and macOS, the Gambit installation process creates the
executable '`gsi`{.sample .samp}' and also the executables
'`six`{.sample .samp}', '`gsi-script`{.sample .samp}',
'`six-script`{.sample .samp}', '`scheme-r5rs`{.sample .samp}',
'`scheme-srfi-0`{.sample .samp}', etc as links to '`gsi`{.sample
.samp}'. A Scheme script need only start with the name of the desired
Scheme language variant prefixed with '`#!`{.sample .samp}' and the
directory where the Gambit executables are stored. This script should be
made executable by setting the execute permission bits (with a
'`chmod +x `{.sample .samp}`script`{.variable .var}'). Here is an
example of a script which lists on standard output the files in the
current directory:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
#!/usr/local/Gambit/bin/gsi-script
(for-each pretty-print (directory-files))
```
:::

Here is another UNIX script, using the Scheme infix syntax extension,
which takes a single integer argument and prints on standard output the
numbers from 1 to that integer:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
#!/usr/local/Gambit/bin/six-script

function main(n_str)
{
  scmobj n = \string->number(n_str);
  for (scmobj i=1; i<=n; i++)
    \pretty-print(i);
}
```
:::

For maximal portability it is a good idea to start scripts indirectly
through the '`/usr/bin/env`{.sample .samp}' program, so that the
executable of the interpreter will be searched in the user's
'`PATH`{.sample .samp}'. This is what SRFI 22 recommends. For example
here is a script that mimics the UNIX '`cat`{.sample .samp}' utility for
text files:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
#!/usr/bin/env gsi-script

(define (display-file filename)
  (display (call-with-input-file filename
             (lambda (port)
               (read-line port #f)))))

(for-each display-file (cdr (command-line)))
```
:::

#### 2.6.2 Scripts under Microsoft Windows {#Scripts-under-Microsoft-Windows-1 .subsection}

Under Microsoft Windows, the Gambit installation process creates the
executable '`gsi.exe`{.sample .samp}' and '`six.exe`{.sample .samp}' and
also the batch files '`gsi-script.bat`{.sample .samp}',
'`six-script.bat`{.sample .samp}', '`scheme-r5rs.bat`{.sample .samp}',
'`scheme-srfi-0.bat`{.sample .samp}', etc which simply invoke
'`gsi.exe`{.sample .samp}' with the same command line arguments. A
Scheme script need only start with the name of the desired Scheme
language variant prefixed with '`@;`{.sample .samp}'. A UNIX script can
be converted to a Microsoft Windows script simply by changing the script
line and storing the script in a file whose name has a '`.bat`{.sample
.samp}' or '`.cmd`{.sample .samp}' extension:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
@;gsi-script %~f0 %*
(display "files:\n")
(pretty-print (directory-files))
```
:::

Note that Microsoft Windows always searches executables in the user's
'`PATH`{.sample .samp}', so there is no need for an indirection such as
the UNIX '`/usr/bin/env`{.sample .samp}'. However the script line must
end with '`%~f0 %*`{.sample .samp}' to pass the expanded filename of the
script and command line arguments to the interpreter.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

#### 2.6.3 Compiling scripts {#Compiling-scripts-1 .subsection}

A script file can be compiled using the Gambit Scheme compiler (see [The
Gambit Scheme compiler](#GSC){.pxref}) into a standalone executable. The
script line will provide information to the compiler on which language
to use. The script line also provides information on which runtime
options to use when executing the compiled script. This is useful to set
the default runtime options of an executable program.

The compiled script will be executed similarly to an interpreted script
(i.e. the list of command line arguments returned by the
`command-line`{.code} procedure and the invocation of the `main`{.code}
procedure).

For example:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ cat square.scm
#!/usr/local/Gambit/bin/gsi-script -:debug=0
(define (main arg)
  (pretty-print (expt (string->number arg) 2)))
$ gsi square 30        # gsi will load square.scm
900
$ gsc -exe square      # compile the script to a standalone program
$ ./square 30
900
$ ./square 1 2 3       # too many arguments to main
$ echo $?
70
$ ./square -:debug=1 1 2 3  # ask for error message
*** ERROR IN ##start-main -- Wrong number of arguments passed to procedure
(main "1" "2" "3")
```
:::

:::

``` example-preformatted
gsc [-:runtimeoption,…] [-i] [-f] [-h] [-help] [-v]
    [-target target]
    [-prelude expressions] [-postlude expressions]
    [-dynamic] [-exe] [-obj]
    [-nb-gvm-regs n] [-nb-arg-regs n] [-compactness level]
    [-cc compiler] [-cc-options options]
    [-ld-options-prelude options] [-ld-options options]

    [-warnings] [-verbose] [-report] [-expansion] [-gvm] [-cfg] [-dg]

    [-debug-environments] [-track-scheme]
    [-o output] [-c] [-keep-temp] [-link] [-flat] [-l base]
    [-module-ref module-ref] [-linker-name linker-name]

     [search-directory-or-module-or-file]]…
```

[]{#index-_002dh-1 .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002dhelp-1
.index-entry-id} []{#index-_002dv-1 .index-entry-id}

The '`-h`{.sample .samp}' and '`-help`{.sample .samp}' options print
brief usage information on standard output and exit. The '`-v`{.sample
.samp}' option prints the system version string, system time stamp,
operating system type, and configure script options on standard output
and exits.

[]{#index-_002di-1 .index-entry-id}

The '`-i`{.sample .samp}' option can be used to force `gsc`{.code} to
process the command line like the interpreter. The only difference with
the interpreter is that the compilation related procedures listed in
this chapter are also available (i.e. `compile-file`{.code},
`compile-file-to-target`{.code}, etc).

-   [Interactive mode](#GSC-interactive-mode){accesskey="1"}

-   [Batch mode](#GSC-batch-mode){accesskey="3"}
-   [Link files](#Link-files){accesskey="4"}
-   [Procedures specific to
    compiler](#Procedures-specific-to-compiler){accesskey="5"}

### 3.3 Batch mode {#Batch-mode-1 .section}

[]{#index-gsc-1 .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002escm .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002esld .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002esix .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002ec .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002ejs .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-file_002escm .index-entry-id} []{#index-file_002esld
.index-entry-id} []{#index-file_002esix .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-file_002ec .index-entry-id} []{#index-file_002ejs
.index-entry-id}

In batch mode `gsc`{.code} accepts on the command line 3 types of
non-options which are processed from left to right: *search
directories*, *modules*, and *files*. Search directories are added to
the list of module search order directories. Every command line argument
that is the name of a module that is found in the list of module search
order directories will cause that module to be compiled. Similarly, file
names (with either no extension, or a C file extension, or some other
extension) on the command line will cause that file to be compiled. The
compilation is done for the target language specified with the
`-target`{.code} `target`{.variable .var} option. `target`{.variable
.var} is either `js`{.code}, for JavaScript, or `C`{.code}, which is the
default if no target language is specified.

The recognized C file extensions are '`.c`{.sample .samp}',
'`.C`{.sample .samp}', '`.cc`{.sample .samp}', '`.cp`{.sample .samp}',
'`.cpp`{.sample .samp}', '`.CPP`{.sample .samp}', '`.cxx`{.sample
.samp}', '`.c++`{.sample .samp}', '`.m`{.sample .samp}', '`.M`{.sample
.samp}', and '`.mm`{.sample .samp}'.

The extension can be omitted from a file name when the Scheme file has a
'`.scm`{.sample .samp}', '`.sld`{.sample .samp}' or '`.six`{.sample
.samp}' extension. When the extension of the Scheme file is
'`.six`{.sample .samp}' the content of the file will be parsed using the
Scheme infix syntax extension (see [Scheme infix syntax
extension](#Scheme-infix-syntax-extension){.ref}). Otherwise,
`gsc`{.code} will parse the Scheme file using the normal Scheme prefix
syntax. Files with a C file extension must have been previously produced
by `gsc`{.code} with the `C`{.code} target and the '`-c`{.sample .samp}'
option, and are used by the `C`{.code} target Gambit linker.

For each Scheme file the compiler creates a file of target code, either
'`file`{.variable .var}`.c`{.sample .samp}' or '`file`{.variable
.var}`.js`{.sample .samp}' for the `C`{.code} and `js`{.code} targets
respectively. The file's name is the same as the Scheme file, but the
extension is changed to '`.c`{.sample .samp}' or '`.js`{.sample .samp}'
as appropriate. By default the file is created in the same directory as
the Scheme file. This default can be overridden with the compiler's
'`-o`{.sample .samp}' option.

The files of target code produced by the compiler serve two purposes.
They will be processed by a C compiler or JavaScript VM, and they also
contain information to be read by Gambit's linker to generate a *link
file*. The link file is a file of target code that collects various
linking information for a group of modules, such as the set of all
symbols and global variables used by the modules. []{#index-_002dlink
.index-entry-id} []{#index-_002dexe .index-entry-id} The linker is only
invoked when the '`-link`{.sample .samp}' or '`-exe`{.sample .samp}'
options appear on the command line.

Compiler options must be specified before the first file name and after
the '`-:`{.sample .samp}' runtime option (see [Runtime
options](#Runtime-options){.pxref}). If present, the '`-i`{.sample
.samp}', '`-f`{.sample .samp}', and '`-v`{.sample .samp}' compiler
options must come first. The available options are:

[]{#index-compiler-options .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-options_002c-compiler .index-entry-id}

`-i`{.code}

:   Force interpreter mode.

`-f`{.code}

:   Do not examine the initialization file.

`-h / -help`{.code}

:   Print brief usage information on standard output and exit.

`-v`{.code}

:   Print the system version string, system time stamp, operating system
    type, and configure script options on standard output and exit.

`-target `{.code}`target`{.variable .var}

:   Select the target language.

`-prelude `{.code}`expressions`{.variable .var}

:   Add expressions to the top of the source code being compiled.

`-postlude `{.code}`expressions`{.variable .var}

:   Add expressions to the bottom of the source code being compiled.

`-cc `{.code}`compiler`{.variable .var}

:   Select specific C compiler.

`-cc-options `{.code}`options`{.variable .var}

:   Add options to the command that invokes the C compiler.

`-ld-options-prelude `{.code}`options`{.variable .var}

:   Add options to the command that invokes the C linker.

`-ld-options `{.code}`options`{.variable .var}

:   Add options to the command that invokes the C linker.

`-pkg-config `{.code}`pkg-config-args`{.variable .var}

:   Use the `pkg-config`{.code} program to determine options for the C
    compiler and C linker.

`-pkg-config-path `{.code}`pkg-config-path`{.variable .var}

:   Add a path to the `PKG_CONFIG_PATH`{.code} environment variable.

`-warnings`{.code}

:   Display warnings.

`-verbose`{.code}

:   Display a trace of the compiler's activity.

`-report`{.code}

:   Display a global variable usage report.

`-expansion`{.code}

:   Display the source code after expansion.

`-gvm`{.code}

:   Generate a listing of the GVM code.

`-cfg`{.code}

:   Generate a control flow graph of the GVM code.

`-dg`{.code}

:   Generate a dependency graph.

`-debug`{.code}

:   Include all debugging information in the code generated.

`-debug-location`{.code}

:   Include source code location debugging information in the code
    generated.

`-debug-source`{.code}

:   Include the source code debugging information in the code generated.

`-debug-environments`{.code}

:   Include environment debugging information in the code generated.

`-track-scheme`{.code}

:   Generate '`#line`{.sample .samp}' directives referring back to the
    Scheme code.

`-o `{.code}`output`{.variable .var}

:   Set name of output file or directory where output file(s) are
    written.

`-dynamic`{.code}

:   Compile Scheme source files to dynamically loadable object files
    (this is the default).

`-exe`{.code}

:   Compile Scheme source files to an executable program (machine code
    or script).

`-obj`{.code}

:   Compile Scheme source files to object files by invoking the C
    compiler.

`-keep-temp`{.code}

:   Keep any intermediate files that are generated.

`-c`{.code}

:   Compile Scheme source files to target code without generating a link
    file.

`-link`{.code}

:   Compile Scheme source files to target code and generate a link file.

`-flat`{.code}

:   Generate a flat link file instead of the default incremental link
    file.

`-l `{.code}`base`{.variable .var}

:   Specify the link file of the base library to use for the link.

`-module-ref `{.code}`module-ref`{.variable .var}

:   Specify the reference of the generated module.

`-linker-name `{.code}`linker-name`{.variable .var}

:   Specify the name of the low-level initialization function exported
    by the module.

`-preload`{.code}

:   Turn on '`preload`{.sample .samp}' linker bit.

`-nopreload`{.code}

:   Turn off '`preload`{.sample .samp}' linker bit. Start REPL
    interaction.

`-e `{.code}`expressions`{.variable .var}

:   Evaluate expressions in the interaction environment.

`-nb-gvm-regs `{.code}[`n`{.variable .var}]{.r}

:   Specify the number of available Gambit virtual machine registers.

`-nb-arg-regs `{.code}[`n`{.variable .var}]{.r}

:   Specify the number of procedure call parameters passed in Gambit
    virtual machine registers.

`-compactness `{.code}[`level`{.variable .var}]{.r}

:   Specify the compactness of the generated code.

[]{#index-_002di-2 .index-entry-id}

The '`-i`{.sample .samp}' option forces the compiler to process the
remaining command line arguments like the interpreter.

[]{#index-_002dtarget .index-entry-id}

The '`-target`{.sample .samp}' option selects the target language of the
compilation. It is either `js`{.code} for JavaScript, or `C`{.code} for
C (which is the default).

[]{#index-_002dprelude .index-entry-id}

The '`-prelude`{.sample .samp}' option adds the specified expressions to
the top of the source code being compiled. It can appear multiple times.
The main use of this option is to supply declarations on the command
line. For example the following invocation of the compiler will compile
the file '`bench.scm`{.sample .samp}' in unsafe mode:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ gsc -prelude "(declare (not safe))" bench.scm
```
:::

[]{#index-_002dpostlude .index-entry-id}

The '`-postlude`{.sample .samp}' option adds the specified expressions
to the bottom of the source code being compiled. It can appear multiple
times. The main use of this option is to supply the expression that will
start the execution of the program. For example:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ gsc -postlude "(start-bench)" bench.scm
```
:::

[]{#index-_002dcc .index-entry-id}

The '`-cc`{.sample .samp}' option is only meaningful when the `C`{.code}
target is selected. The '`-cc`{.sample .samp}' option selects the
specified C compiler for compiling the generated C code. When this
option is used, the default C compiler options that were determined to
be needed by the configure script are nullified because they are very
likely to be invalid for the specified C compiler. Any options needed
for this C compiler should be specified explicitly using the
'`-cc-options`{.sample .samp}', '`-ld-options-prelude`{.sample .samp}',
and '`-ld-options`{.sample .samp}' options. For example:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ gsc -cc clang -cc-options "-O0 -bundle" bench.scm # clang on macOS
$ gsc -cc tcc -cc-options -shared bench.scm         # tcc on linux
```
:::

[]{#index-_002dcc_002doptions .index-entry-id}

The '`-cc-options`{.sample .samp}' option is only meaningful when the
`C`{.code} target is selected and a dynamically loadable object file is
being generated (neither the '`-c`{.sample .samp}' or '`-link`{.sample
.samp}' options are used). It can appear multiple times. The
'`-cc-options`{.sample .samp}' option adds the specified options to the
command that invokes the C compiler. The main use of this option is to
specify the include path, some symbols to define or undefine, the
optimization level, or any C compiler option that is different from the
default. For example:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ gsc -cc-options "-U___SINGLE_HOST -O2 -I../include" bench.scm
```
:::

[]{#index-_002dld_002doptions_002dprelude .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002dld_002doptions .index-entry-id}

The '`-ld-options-prelude`{.sample .samp}' and '`-ld-options`{.sample
.samp}' options are only meaningful when the `C`{.code} target is
selected and a dynamically loadable object file is being generated
(neither the '`-c`{.sample .samp}' or '`-link`{.sample .samp}' options
are used). They can appear multiple times. The
'`-ld-options-prelude`{.sample .samp}' and '`-ld-options`{.sample
.samp}' options add the specified options to the command that invokes
the C linker (the options in `ld-options-prelude`{.variable .var} are
passed to the C linker before the input file and the options in
`ld-options`{.variable .var} are passed after). The main use of this
option is to specify additional object files or libraries that need to
be linked, or any C linker option that is different from the default
(such as the library search path and flags to select between static and
dynamic linking). For example:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ gsc -ld-options "-L/usr/X11R6/lib -lX11 -dynamic" app.scm
```
:::

[]{#index-_002dpkg_002dconfig .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002dpkg_002dconfig_002dpath .index-entry-id}

The '`-pkg-config`{.sample .samp}' is only meaningful when the
`C`{.code} target is selected. The '`-pkg-config`{.sample .samp}' option
will cause the `pkg-config`{.code} program to be invoked to determine
the options to add to the command that invokes the C compiler and C
linker. It can appear multiple times. The `pkg-config`{.code} program is
passed the arguments in the string `pkg-config-args`{.variable .var} in
addition to either `--cflags`{.code} or `--libs`{.code}. It is typical
for `pkg-config-args`{.variable .var} to be the name of a system
library, such as `"sqlite3"`{.code}, but other `pkg-config`{.code}
options can be specified, such as `"--static sqlite3"`{.code}. The
'`-pkg-config-path`{.sample .samp}' option adds a path to the
`PKG_CONFIG_PATH`{.code} environment variable for use by the
`pkg-config`{.code} program to find '`.pc`{.sample .samp}' files. For
example:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ gsc -pkg-config "x11" -pkg-config-path "/usr/share/pkgconfig" app.scm
```
:::

[]{#index-_002dwarnings .index-entry-id}

The '`-warnings`{.sample .samp}' option displays on standard output all
warnings that the compiler may have.

[]{#index-_002dverbose .index-entry-id}

The '`-verbose`{.sample .samp}' option displays on standard output a
trace of the compiler's activity.

[]{#index-_002dreport .index-entry-id}

The '`-report`{.sample .samp}' option displays on standard output a
global variable usage report. Each global variable used in the program
is listed with 4 flags that indicate whether the global variable is
defined, referenced, mutated and called.

[]{#index-_002dexpansion .index-entry-id}

The '`-expansion`{.sample .samp}' option displays on standard output the
source code after expansion and inlining by the front end.

[]{#index-_002dgvm .index-entry-id}

The '`-gvm`{.sample .samp}' option generates a listing of the
intermediate code for the "Gambit Virtual Machine" (GVM) of each Scheme
file on '`file`{.variable .var}`.gvm`{.sample .samp}'.

[]{#index-_002dcfg .index-entry-id}

The '`-cfg`{.sample .samp}' option generates a visual representation of
the control flow graph of the intermediate code for the "Gambit Virtual
Machine" (GVM) of each Scheme file on '`file`{.variable
.var}`.cfg`{.sample .samp}'. The file is suitable for processing with
the "dot" program. For example, to generate the PDF file
'`file`{.variable .var}`.cfg.pdf`{.sample .samp}' from '`file`{.variable
.var}`.cfg`{.sample .samp}' the following command can be used:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ dot -O -Tpdf file.cfg
```
:::

[]{#index-_002ddg .index-entry-id}

The '`-dg`{.sample .samp}' option generates a visual representation of
the dependency graph of each Scheme file on '`file`{.variable
.var}`.dg`{.sample .samp}'. The file is suitable for processing with the
"dot" program. For example, to generate the PDF file '`file`{.variable
.var}`.dg.pdf`{.sample .samp}' from '`file`{.variable .var}`.dg`{.sample
.samp}' the following command can be used:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ dot -O -Tpdf file.dg
```
:::

[]{#index-_002ddebug .index-entry-id} []{#index-debug .index-entry-id}

The '`-debug`{.sample .samp}' option causes all kinds of debugging
information to be saved in the code generated. See the documentation of
the '`debug`{.sample .samp}' declaration for details.

[]{#index-_002ddebug_002dlocation .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-debug_002dlocation .index-entry-id}

The '`-debug-location`{.sample .samp}' option causes source code
location debugging information to be saved in the code generated. See
the documentation of the '`debug-location`{.sample .samp}' declaration
for details.

[]{#index-_002ddebug_002dsource .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-debug_002dsource .index-entry-id}

The '`-debug-source`{.sample .samp}' option causes source code debugging
information to be saved in the code generated. See the documentation of
the '`debug-source`{.sample .samp}' declaration for details.

[]{#index-_002ddebug_002denvironments .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-debug_002denvironments .index-entry-id}

The '`-debug-environments`{.sample .samp}' option causes environment
debugging information to be saved in the code generated. See the
documentation of the '`debug-environments`{.sample .samp}' declaration
for details.

[]{#index-_002dtrack_002dscheme .index-entry-id}

The '`-track-scheme`{.sample .samp}' option is only meaningful when the
`C`{.code} target is selected. The '`-track-scheme`{.sample .samp}'
option causes the generation of '`#line`{.sample .samp}' directives that
refer back to the Scheme source code. This allows the use of a C
debugger or profiler to debug Scheme code.

[]{#index-_002do-output .index-entry-id}

The '`-o`{.sample .samp}' option sets the filename of the output file,
or the directory in which the output file(s) generated by the compiler
are written.

[]{#index-_002dc .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002ddynamic
.index-entry-id} []{#index-_002dexe-1 .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002dobj .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002dlink-1
.index-entry-id} []{#index-_002dkeep_002dtemp .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-last_005f_002ec .index-entry-id} []{#index-last_005f_002ejs
.index-entry-id}

If the '`-link`{.sample .samp}' or '`-exe`{.sample .samp}' options
appear on the command line, the Gambit linker is invoked to generate the
link file from the set of files specified on the command line or
produced by the Gambit compiler. By default the link file is named after
the last file on the compiler's command line. If the last file stripped
of it's extension is '`last`{.variable .var}' then the link file is
'`last`{.variable .var}`_.c`{.sample .samp}' for the `C`{.code} target
and '`last`{.variable .var}`_.js`{.sample .samp}' for the `js`{.code}
target. When the '`-c`{.sample .samp}' option is specified, the Scheme
source files are compiled to target files without invoking the linker,
which is useful for separate compilation of modules. When the
'`-exe`{.sample .samp}' option is specified, the generated target files
and link file are combined to produce an executable program whose name
defaults to '`last`{.variable .var}' on Unix, and '`last`{.variable
.var}`.exe`{.sample .samp}' or '`last`{.variable .var}`.bat`{.sample
.samp}' on Windows depending on whether a machine code executable or
script is produced. When the `C`{.code} target is selected and the
'`-obj`{.sample .samp}' option is specified, the generated C files are
compiled using the C compiler to produce object files ('`.o`{.sample
.samp}' or '`.obj`{.sample .samp}' extensions). If neither the
'`-link`{.sample .samp}', '`-c`{.sample .samp}', '`-exe`{.sample
.samp}', or '`-obj`{.sample .samp}' options appear on the command line,
the Scheme source files are compiled to dynamically loadable object
files ('`.o`{.sample .samp}`n`{.variable .var}' extension). The
'`-keep-temp`{.sample .samp}' option will prevent the deletion of any
intermediate files that are generated. Note that in this case the
intermediate file will be generated in the same directory as the Scheme
source file even if the '`-o`{.sample .samp}' option is used.

[]{#index-_002dflat .index-entry-id}

The '`-flat`{.sample .samp}' option is only meaningful when a link file
is being generated (i.e. the '`-link`{.sample .samp}' or '`-exe`{.sample
.samp}' options also appear on the command line). The '`-flat`{.sample
.samp}' option directs the Gambit linker to generate a flat link file.
By default, the linker generates an incremental link file (see the next
section for a description of the two types of link files).

[]{#index-_002dl-base .index-entry-id}

The '`-l`{.sample .samp}' option is only meaningful when an incremental
link file is being generated (i.e. the '`-link`{.sample .samp}' or
'`-exe`{.sample .samp}' options appear on the command line and the
'`-flat`{.sample .samp}' option is absent). The '`-l`{.sample .samp}'
option specifies the link file (without the '`.c`{.sample .samp}' or
'`.js`{.sample .samp}' extension) of the base library to use for the
incremental link. By default the link file of the Gambit runtime library
is used (i.e. '`~~lib/_gambit`{.sample .samp}').

[]{#index-_002dpreload .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002dnopreload
.index-entry-id}

The '`-preload`{.sample .samp}' and '`-nopreload`{.sample .samp}'
options are only meaningful when a link file is being generated. The
'`-preload`{.sample .samp}' option turns on the '`preload`{.sample
.samp}' linker bit for the modules that follow on the command line. The
following modules will be loaded unconditionally at program startup and
in command line order (this is the default for compatibility with how
legacy modules have been handled in the past). The '`-nopreload`{.sample
.samp}' option turns off the '`preload`{.sample .samp}' linker bit. The
following modules will be loaded only to satisfy the module dependencies
of the `##demand-module`{.code} form.

[]{#index-_002d-2 .index-entry-id}

The '`-`{.sample .samp}' option starts a REPL interaction.

[]{#index-_002de-2 .index-entry-id}

The '`-e`{.sample .samp}' option evaluates the specified expressions in
the interaction environment.

[]{#index-_002dnb_002dgvm_002dregs-n .index-entry-id}

The '`-nb-gvm-regs`{.sample .samp}' option specifies the number of
Gambit virtual machine registers that are available for the generated
code. The default number depends on configuration options and the target
but it is typically 5. All modules and the runtime library must be
compiled with the same setting. This option exists mainly for
experimentation by the developers. For example:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ gsc -nb-gvm-regs 10 -c bench.scm
```
:::

[]{#index-_002dnb_002darg_002dregs-n .index-entry-id}

The '`-nb-arg-regs`{.sample .samp}' option specifies the number of
procedure call parameters passed in Gambit virtual machine registers.
The default number depends on configuration options and the target but
it is typically 3. All modules and the runtime library must be compiled
with the same setting. This option exists mainly for experimentation by
the developers. For example:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ gsc -nb-arg-regs 2 -c bench.scm
```
:::

[]{#index-_002dcompactness-level .index-entry-id}

The '`-compactness`{.sample .samp}' option selects the level of
compactness of the generated code. The default level depends on
configuration options and the target but it is typically 5. Levels from
0 to 5 cause the generation of increasingly compact code with little or
no impact on execution speed. Lower values tend to make the generated
code more humanly readable. Above a level of 5 the compiler will trade
execution speed for saving code space. The detailed meaning of this
option depends on the target, some targets may ignore it and some
targets may require all modules and the runtime library to be compiled
with the same compactness level. For example:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ gsc -target js -compactness 0 -c bench.scm
```
:::

### 3.4 Link files {#Link-files-1 .section}

Gambit can be used to create programs and libraries of Scheme modules.
This section explains the steps required to do so and the role played by
the link files.

In general, a program is composed of a set of Scheme modules and modules
in the target language. Some of the modules are part of the Gambit
runtime library and the other modules are supplied by the user. When the
program is started it must setup various global tables (including the
symbol table and the global variable table) and then sequentially
execute the Scheme modules (more or less as though they were being
loaded one after another). The information required for this is
contained in one or more *link files* generated by the Gambit linker
from the target files produced by the Gambit compiler.

The order of execution of the Scheme modules corresponds to the order of
the modules on the command line which produced the link file. The order
is usually important because most modules define variables and
procedures which are used by other modules (for this reason the
program's main computation is normally started by the last module).

When a single link file is used to contain the linking information of
all the Scheme modules it is called a *flat link file*. Thus a program
built with a flat link file contains in its link file both information
on the user modules and on the runtime library. This is fine if the
program is to be statically linked but is wasteful in a shared-library
context because the linking information of the runtime library can't be
shared and will be duplicated in all programs (this linking information
typically takes hundreds of kilobytes).

Flat link files are mainly useful to bundle multiple Scheme modules to
make a runtime library (such as the Gambit runtime library) or to make a
single file that can be loaded with the `load`{.code} procedure.

An *incremental link file* contains only the linking information that is
not already contained in a second link file (the "base" link file).
Assuming that a flat link file was produced when the runtime library was
linked, a program can be built by linking the user modules with the
runtime library's link file, producing an incremental link file. This
allows the creation of a shared-library which contains the modules of
the runtime library and its flat link file. The program is dynamically
linked with this shared-library and only contains the user modules and
the incremental link file. For small programs this approach greatly
reduces the size of the program because the incremental link file is
small. A "hello world" program built this way can be as small as 5
Kbytes. Note that it is perfectly fine to use an incremental link file
for statically linked programs (there is very little loss compared to a
single flat link file).

Incremental link files may be built from other incremental link files.
This allows the creation of shared-libraries which extend the
functionality of the Gambit runtime library.

-   [Building an executable
    program](#Building-an-executable-program){accesskey="1"}
-   [Building a loadable
    library](#Building-a-loadable-library){accesskey="2"}

    shared-library](#Building-a-shared_002dlibrary){accesskey="3"}

#### 3.4.1 Building an executable program {#Building-an-executable-program-1 .subsection}

The simplest way to create an executable program is to invoke
`gsc`{.code} with the '`-exe`{.sample .samp}' option. The compiler will
transparently perform all the steps necessary, including compiling
Scheme source files to target files, generating the link file, and (when
the `C`{.code} target is selected) compiling the C files generated to
object files and creating the final executable file using the C linker.
The following example shows how to use the `C`{.code} target to build
the executable program '`hello.exe`{.sample .samp}' which contains the
two Scheme modules '`h.scm`{.sample .samp}' and '`w.six`{.sample
.samp}'.

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ cat h.scm
(display "hello") (newline)
$ cat w.six
display("world"); newline();
$ gsc -o hello.exe -exe h.scm w.six
h.scm:
/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/h.c:
w.six:
/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/w.c:
/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/w_.c:
$ ./hello.exe
hello
world
```
:::

The detailed steps which are performed can be viewed by setting the
'`GAMBUILD_VERBOSE`{.sample .samp}' environment variable to a nonnull
value. Alternatively, `gsc`{.code}'s '`-verbose`{.sample .samp}' option
can be used (it implicitly sets the '`GAMBUILD_VERBOSE`{.sample .samp}'
environment variable). For example:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ export GAMBUILD_VERBOSE=yes
$ gsc -o hello.exe -exe h.scm w.six
h.scm:
/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/h.c:
gcc  -O1    -Wno-unused -Wno-write-strings -Wdisabled-optimization
fwrapv -fno-strict-aliasing -fno-trapping-math -fno-math-errno
-fschedule-insns2 -foptimize-sibling-calls -fomit-frame-pointer -fPIC
-fno-common -mpc64   -D___SINGLE_HOST  -I"/usr/local/Gambit/include"
-c -o 'h.o'  'h.c'
w.six:
/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/w.c:
gcc  -O1    -Wno-unused -Wno-write-strings -Wdisabled-optimization
-fwrapv -fno-strict-aliasing -fno-trapping-math -fno-math-errno
-fschedule-insns2 -foptimize-sibling-calls -fomit-frame-pointer -fPIC
-fno-common -mpc64   -D___SINGLE_HOST  -I"/usr/local/Gambit/include"
-c -o 'w.o'  'w.c'
/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/w_.c:
gcc  -O1    -Wno-unused -Wno-write-strings -Wdisabled-optimization
-fwrapv -fno-strict-aliasing -fno-trapping-math -fno-math-errno
-fschedule-insns2 -foptimize-sibling-calls -fomit-frame-pointer -fPIC
-fno-common -mpc64   -D___SINGLE_HOST  -I"/usr/local/Gambit/include"
-c -o 'w_.o'  'w_.c'
gcc     -Wno-unused -Wno-write-strings -Wdisabled-optimization
-fwrapv -fno-strict-aliasing -fno-trapping-math -fno-math-errno
-fschedule-insns2 -foptimize-sibling-calls -fomit-frame-pointer -fPIC
-fno-common -mpc64    -D___SINGLE_HOST  -I"/usr/local/Gambit/include"
-o 'hello.exe'   'w_.o' 'h.o' 'w.o' "/usr/local/Gambit/lib/libgambit.a"
```
:::

Here is the same example using the `js`{.code} target showing the
creation of a shell script invoking nodejs:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ export GAMBUILD_VERBOSE=yes
$ gsc -target js -o hello.exe -exe h.scm w.six
h.scm:
/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/h.js:
cat h.js > "h.o"
w.six:
/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/w.js:
cat w.js > "w.o"
/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/w_.js:
cat w_.js > "w_.o"
echo "#! /usr/bin/env node" > "hello.exe"
cat w_.o h.o w.o "/usr/local/Gambit/lib/_gambit.js" >> "hello.exe"
chmod +x "hello.exe"
```
:::

Using a single invocation of `gsc`{.code} with the '`-exe`{.sample
.samp}' option is sometimes inappropriate when the build process is more
complex, for example when the program is composed of several separately
compiled modules. In such a case it is useful to decompose the build
process into smaller compilation steps. The '`hello.exe`{.sample .samp}'
executable program could have been built with the `C`{.code} target by
separating the generation of C files from the C compilation and linking:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ gsc -c h.scm
$ gsc -c w.six
$ gsc -o hello.exe -exe h.c w.c
```
:::

When even finer control is desired the `C`{.code} target's build process
can be decomposed into smaller steps that invoke the C compiler and
linker explicitly. This is described in the rest of this section.

The `gsc`{.code} compiler can be invoked to compile each Scheme module
into a C file and to create an incremental link file. The C files and
the link file must then be compiled with a C compiler and linked (at the
object file level) with the Gambit runtime library and possibly other
libraries (such as the math library and the dynamic loading library).

Here is for example how a program with three modules (one in C and two
in Scheme) can be built. The content of the three source files
('`m1.c`{.sample .samp}', '`m2.scm`{.sample .samp}' and
'`m3.scm`{.sample .samp}') is:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
/* File: "m1.c" */
int power_of_2 (int x) { return 1<<x; }

; File: "m2.scm"
(c-declare "extern int power_of_2 ();")
(define pow2 (c-lambda (int) int "power_of_2"))
(define (twice x) (cons x x))

; File: "m3.scm"
(write (map twice (map pow2 '(1 2 3 4)))) (newline)
```
:::

The compilation of the two Scheme source files can be done with three
invocations of `gsc`{.code}:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ gsc -c m2.scm        # create m2.c (note: .scm is optional)
$ gsc -c m3.scm        # create m3.c (note: .scm is optional)
$ gsc -link m2.c m3.c  # create the incremental link file m3_.c
```
:::

Alternatively, the three invocations of `gsc`{.code} can be replaced by
a single invocation:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ gsc -link m2 m3
m2:
m3:
```
:::

At this point there will be 4 C files: '`m1.c`{.sample .samp}',
'`m2.c`{.sample .samp}', '`m3.c`{.sample .samp}', and '`m3_.c`{.sample
.samp}'. To produce an executable program these files must be compiled
with a C compiler and linked with the Gambit runtime library. The C
compiler options needed will depend on the C compiler and the operating
system (in particular it may be necessary to add the options
'`-I/usr/local/Gambit/include -L/usr/local/Gambit/lib`{.sample .samp}'
to access the '`gambit.h`{.sample .samp}' header file and the Gambit
runtime library).

Here is an example under macOS:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ uname -srmp
Darwin 20.6.0 x86_64 i386
$ gsc -obj m1.c m2.c m3.c m3_.c
m1.c:
m2.c:
m3.c:
m3_.c:
$ gcc m1.o m2.o m3.o m3_.o -lgambit
$ ./a.out
((2 . 2) (4 . 4) (8 . 8) (16 . 16))
```
:::

Here is an example under Linux:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ uname -srmp
Linux 5.10.0-9-amd64 x86_64 unknown
$ gsc -obj m1.c m2.c m3.c m3_.c
m1.c:
m2.c:
m3.c:
m3_.c:
$ gcc m1.o m2.o m3.o m3_.o -lgambit -lm -ldl -lutil
$ ./a.out
((2 . 2) (4 . 4) (8 . 8) (16 . 16))
```
:::

#### 3.4.2 Building a loadable library {#Building-a-loadable-library-1 .subsection}

[]{#index-_002dD_005f_005f_005fDYNAMIC .index-entry-id}

To bundle multiple modules into a single object file that can be
dynamically loaded with the `load`{.code} procedure, a flat link file is
needed. The compiler's '`-o`{.sample .samp}' option must be used to name
the C file generated as follows. If the dynamically loadable object file
is to be named '`myfile`{.variable .var}`.o`{.sample .samp}`n`{.variable
.var}' then the '`-o`{.sample .samp}' option must set the name of the
link file generated to '`myfile`{.variable .var}`.o`{.sample
.samp}`n`{.variable .var}`.c`{.sample .samp}' (note that the
'`.c`{.sample .samp}' extension could also be '`.cc`{.sample .samp}',
'`.cpp`{.sample .samp}' or whatever extension is appropriate for C/C++
source files). The three modules of the previous example can be bundled
by generating a link file in this way:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ gsc -link -flat -o foo.o1.c m2 m3
m2:
m3:
*** WARNING -- "cons" is not defined,
***            referenced in: ("m2.c")
*** WARNING -- "map" is not defined,
***            referenced in: ("m3.c")
*** WARNING -- "newline" is not defined,
***            referenced in: ("m3.c")
*** WARNING -- "write" is not defined,
***            referenced in: ("m3.c")
```
:::

The warnings indicate that there are no definitions (`define`{.code}s or
`set!`{.code}s) of the variables `cons`{.code}, `map`{.code},
`newline`{.code} and `write`{.code} in the set of modules being linked.
Before '`foo.o1`{.sample .samp}' is loaded, these variables will have to
be bound; either implicitly (by the runtime library) or explicitly.

When compiling the C files and link file generated, the flag
'`-D___DYNAMIC`{.sample .samp}' must be passed to the C compiler and the
C compiler and linker must be told to generate a dynamically loadable
shared library.

Here is an example under macOS:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ uname -srmp
Darwin 20.6.0 x86_64 i386
$ gsc -link -flat -o foo.o1.c m2 m3 > /dev/null
m2:
m3:
$ gsc -cc-options "-D___DYNAMIC" -obj m1.c m2.c m3.c foo.o1.c
m1.c:
m2.c:
m3.c:
foo.o1.c:
$ gcc -bundle m1.o m2.o m3.o foo.o1.o -o foo.o1
$ gsi foo.o1
((2 . 2) (4 . 4) (8 . 8) (16 . 16))
```
:::

Here is an example under Linux:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ uname -srmp
Linux 5.10.0-9-amd64 x86_64 unknown
$ gsc -link -flat -o foo.o1.c m2 m3 > /dev/null
m2:
m3:
$ gsc -cc-options "-D___DYNAMIC" -obj m1.c m2.c m3.c foo.o1.c
m1.c:
m2.c:
m3.c:
foo.o1.c:
$ gcc -shared m1.o m2.o m3.o foo.o1.o -o foo.o1
$ gsi foo.o1
((2 . 2) (4 . 4) (8 . 8) (16 . 16))
```
:::

Here is a more complex example, under Solaris, which shows how to build
a loadable library '`mymod.o1`{.sample .samp}' composed of the files
'`m4.scm`{.sample .samp}', '`m5.scm`{.sample .samp}' and '`x.c`{.sample
.samp}' that links to system shared libraries (for X-windows):

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ uname -srmp
SunOS ungava 5.6 Generic_105181-05 sun4m sparc SUNW,SPARCstation-20
$ gsc -link -flat -o mymod.o1.c m4 m5
m4:
m5:
*** WARNING -- "*" is not defined,
***            referenced in: ("m4.c")
*** WARNING -- "+" is not defined,
***            referenced in: ("m5.c")
*** WARNING -- "display" is not defined,
***            referenced in: ("m5.c" "m4.c")
*** WARNING -- "newline" is not defined,
***            referenced in: ("m5.c" "m4.c")
*** WARNING -- "write" is not defined,
***            referenced in: ("m5.c")
$ gsc -cc-options "-D___DYNAMIC" -obj m4.c m5.c x.c mymod.o1.c
m4.c:
m5.c:
x.c:
mymod.o1.c:
$ /usr/ccs/bin/ld -G -o mymod.o1 mymod.o1.o m4.o m5.o x.o -lX11 -lsocket
$ gsi mymod.o1
hello from m4
hello from m5
(f1 10) = 22
$ cat m4.scm
(define (f1 x) (* 2 (f2 x)))
(display "hello from m4")
(newline)

(c-declare #<<c-declare-end
#include "x.h"
c-declare-end
)
(define x-initialize (c-lambda (char-string) bool "x_initialize"))
(define x-display-name (c-lambda () char-string "x_display_name"))
(define x-bell (c-lambda (int) void "x_bell"))
$ cat m5.scm
(define (f2 x) (+ x 1))
(display "hello from m5")
(newline)

(display "(f1 10) = ")
(write (f1 10))
(newline)

(x-initialize (x-display-name))
(x-bell 50) ; sound the bell at 50%
$ cat x.c
#include <X11/Xlib.h>

static Display *display;

int x_initialize (char *display_name)
{
  display = XOpenDisplay (display_name);
  return display != NULL;
}

char *x_display_name (void)
{
  return XDisplayName (NULL);
}

void x_bell (int volume)
{
  XBell (display, volume);
  XFlush (display);
}
$ cat x.h
int x_initialize (char *display_name);
char *x_display_name (void);
void x_bell (int);
```
:::

#### 3.4.3 Building a shared-library {#Building-a-shared_002dlibrary-1 .subsection}

[]{#index-_002dD_005f_005f_005fPRIMAL .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002dD_005f_005f_005fLIBRARY .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002dD_005f_005f_005fSHARED .index-entry-id}

A shared-library can be built using an incremental link file or a flat
link file. An incremental link file is normally used when the Gambit
runtime library (or some other library) is to be extended with new
procedures. A flat link file is mainly useful when building a "primal"
runtime library, which is a library (such as the Gambit runtime library)
that does not extend another library. When compiling the C files and
link file generated, the flags '`-D___LIBRARY`{.sample .samp}' and
'`-D___SHARED`{.sample .samp}' must be passed to the C compiler. The
flag '`-D___PRIMAL`{.sample .samp}' must also be passed to the C
compiler when a primal library is being built.

A shared-library '`mylib.so`{.sample .samp}' containing the two first
modules of the previous example can be built this way:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ uname -srmp
Linux 5.10.0-9-amd64 x86_64 unknown
$ gsc -link -o mylib.c m2
$ gsc -obj -cc-options "-D___SHARED" m1.c m2.c mylib.c
m1.c:
m2.c:
mylib.c:
$ gcc -shared  m1.o m2.o mylib.o -o mylib.so
```
:::

Note that this shared-library is built using an incremental link file
(it extends the Gambit runtime library with the procedures `pow2`{.code}
and `twice`{.code}). This shared-library can in turn be used to build an
executable program from the third module of the previous example:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ gsc -link -l mylib m3
$ gsc -obj m3.c m3_.c
m3.c:
m3_.c:
$ gcc m3.o m3_.o mylib.so -lgambit
$ LD_LIBRARY_PATH=.:/usr/local/lib ./a.out
((2 . 2) (4 . 4) (8 . 8) (16 . 16))
```
:::

#### 3.4.4 Other compilation options {#Other-compilation-options-1 .subsection}

[]{#index-_002dD_005f_005f_005fSINGLE_005fHOST .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002dO .index-entry-id}

The performance of the code can be increased by passing the
'`-D___SINGLE_HOST`{.sample .samp}' flag to the C compiler. This will
merge all the procedures of a module into a single C procedure, which
reduces the cost of intra-module procedure calls. In addition the
'`-O2`{.sample .samp}' option can be passed to the C compiler. For large
modules, it will not be practical to specify both '`-O2`{.sample .samp}'
and '`-D___SINGLE_HOST`{.sample .samp}' for typical C compilers because
the compile time will be high and the C compiler might even fail to
compile the program for lack of memory. It has been observed that lower
levels of optimization (e.g. '`-O1`{.sample .samp}') often give faster
compilation and also generate faster code. It is a good idea to
experiment.

[]{#index-_002dI_002fusr_002flocal_002fGambit_002finclude
.index-entry-id} []{#index-_002dL_002fusr_002flocal_002fGambit_002flib
.index-entry-id}

Normally C compilers will not automatically search
'`/usr/local/Gambit/include`{.sample .samp}' for header files so the
flag '`-I/usr/local/Gambit/include`{.sample .samp}' should be passed to
the C compiler. Similarly, C compilers/linkers will not automatically
search '`/usr/local/Gambit/lib`{.sample .samp}' for libraries so the
flag '`-L/usr/local/Gambit/lib`{.sample .samp}' should be passed to the
C compiler/linker. Alternatives are given in [Accessing the system
files](#Accessing-the-system-files){.ref}.

[]{#index-_002dshared .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002dcall_005fshared
.index-entry-id} []{#index-_002drdynamic .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002dfpic .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002dfPIC
.index-entry-id} []{#index-_002dKpic .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002dKPIC .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002dpic .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002bz .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002dG .index-entry-id}

A variety of flags are needed by some C compilers when compiling a
shared-library or a dynamically loadable library. Some of these flags
are: '`-shared`{.sample .samp}', '`-call_shared`{.sample .samp}',
'`-rdynamic`{.sample .samp}', '`-fpic`{.sample .samp}', '`-fPIC`{.sample
.samp}', '`-Kpic`{.sample .samp}', '`-KPIC`{.sample .samp}',
'`-pic`{.sample .samp}', '`+z`{.sample .samp}', '`-G`{.sample .samp}'.
Check your compiler's documentation to see which flag you need.

:::
