### 3.5 Procedures specific to compiler {#Procedures-specific-to-compiler-1 .section}

The Gambit Scheme compiler features the following procedures that are
not available in the Gambit Scheme interpreter.

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**compile-file-to-target** `file`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`options:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`options`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`output:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`output`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`expression:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`expression`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-compile_002dfile_002dto_002dtarget){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-gsc-2 .index-entry-id}

    The `file`{.variable .var} parameter must be a string. If
    `expression`{.variable .var} is not specified, `file`{.variable
    .var} must name an existing file containing Scheme source code. The
    extension can be omitted from `file`{.variable .var} when the Scheme
    file has a '`.scm`{.sample .samp}', '`.sld`{.sample .samp}' or
    '`.six`{.sample .samp}' extension. By default, this procedure
    compiles the source file into a file containing C code. A different
    target language can be selected in the `options`{.variable .var}.
    The generated file is named after `file`{.variable .var} with the
    extension replaced with '`.c`{.sample .samp}' or '`.js`{.sample
    .samp}', as appropriate for the target selected. The name of the
    generated file can also be specified directly with the
    `output`{.variable .var} parameter. If `output`{.variable .var} is a
    string naming a directory then the generated file is created in that
    directory. Otherwise the name of the generated file is
    `output`{.variable .var}.

    Compilation options are specified through the `options`{.variable
    .var} parameter which must be an association list. Any combination
    of the following options can be used: '`target`{.sample .samp}',
    '`verbose`{.sample .samp}', '`report`{.sample .samp}',
    '`expansion`{.sample .samp}', '`gvm`{.sample .samp}',
    '`debug`{.sample .samp}', '`module-ref`{.sample .samp}', and
    '`linker-name`{.sample .samp}'.

    When `expression`{.variable .var} is specified, the `file`{.variable
    .var} parameter is not open or read. Instead, `expression`{.variable
    .var} is used as though it was the content of the file. This makes
    it possible to compile source code without having to create a file
    to contain the code. Note that `file`{.variable .var} is used in
    error messages and to determine the output file name if
    `output`{.variable .var} is not specified.

    When the compilation is successful, `compile-file-to-target`{.code}
    returns the name of the file generated. When there is a compilation
    error, `#f`{.code} is returned.

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    $ cat h.scm
    (display "hello") (newline)
    $ gsc
    Gambit v4.9.5

    > (compile-file-to-target "h")
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/h.c"
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**compile-file** `file`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`options:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`options`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`output:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`output`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`base:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`base`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`expression:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`expression`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`cc-options:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`cc-options`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`ld-options-prelude:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`ld-options-prelude`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`ld-options:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`ld-options`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-compile_002dfile){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-gsc-3 .index-entry-id} []{#index-load .index-entry-id}
    []{#index-object-file .index-entry-id}

    The `file`{.variable .var}, `options`{.variable .var},
    `output`{.variable .var}, and `expression`{.variable .var}
    parameters have the same meaning as for the
    `compile-file-to-target`{.code} procedure, except that
    `file`{.variable .var} may be a Scheme source file or a file
    possibly generated by the Gambit Scheme compiler (for example with
    the `compile-file-to-target`{.code} procedure). The
    `cc-options`{.variable .var} parameter is a string containing the
    options to pass to the C compiler and the
    `ld-options-prelude`{.variable .var} and `ld-options`{.variable
    .var} parameters are strings containing the options to pass to the C
    linker (the options in `ld-options-prelude`{.variable .var} are
    passed to the C linker before the input file and the options in
    `ld-options`{.variable .var} are passed after).

    The `compile-file`{.code} procedure compiles the source file
    `file`{.variable .var} into an object file, which is either a file
    dynamically loadable using the `load`{.code} procedure, or a C
    linkable object file destined to be linked with the C linker (for
    example to create a standalone executable program). The presence of
    the `obj`{.code} option in `options`{.variable .var} will cause the
    creation of a C linkable object file and therefore the options
    `ld-options-prelude`{.variable .var} and `ld-options`{.variable
    .var} are ignored, otherwise a dynamically loadable file is created.
    In both cases, if `file`{.variable .var} is a Scheme source file,
    the compiler first compiles `file`{.variable .var} to a C file which
    is created in the same directory as `file`{.variable .var}
    regardless of the `output`{.variable .var} parameter. Then the C
    file is compiled with the C compiler.

    When the compilation is successful, `compile-file`{.code} returns
    the name of the object file generated. When there is a compilation
    error, `#f`{.code} is returned.

    The name of the object file can be specified with the
    `output`{.variable .var} parameter. If `output`{.variable .var} is a
    string naming a directory then the object file is created in that
    directory. Otherwise the name of the object file is
    `output`{.variable .var}.

    In the case of a dynamically loadable object file, by default the
    object file is named after `file`{.variable .var} with the extension
    replaced with '`.o`{.sample .samp}`n`{.variable .var}', where
    `n`{.variable .var} is a positive integer that acts as a version
    number. The next available version number is generated automatically
    by `compile-file`{.code}.

    When dynamically loaded object files are loaded using the
    `load`{.code} procedure, the '`.o`{.sample .samp}`n`{.variable
    .var}' extension can be specified (to select a particular version)
    or omitted (to load the file with a '`.o`{.sample
    .samp}`n`{.variable .var}' extension with the highest `n`{.variable
    .var} consecutively from 1). When the '`.o`{.sample
    .samp}`n`{.variable .var}' extension is not specified and older
    versions are no longer needed, all versions must be deleted and the
    compilation must be repeated (this is necessary because the file
    name, including the extension, is used to name some of the exported
    symbols of the object file).

    Note that dynamically loadable object files can only be generated on
    host operating systems that support dynamic loading.

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    $ cat h.scm
    (display "hello") (newline)
    $ gsc
    Gambit v4.9.5

    > (compile-file "h")
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/h.o1"
    > (load "h")
    hello
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/h.o1"
    > (compile-file-to-target "h" output: "h.o99.c")
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/h.o99.c"
    > (compile-file "h.o99.c")
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/h.o99"
    > (load "h.o99")
    hello
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/h.o99"
    > (compile-file-to-target "h")
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/h.c"
    > (compile-file "h.c" options: '(obj))
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/h.o"
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**link-incremental** `module-list`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`output:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`output`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`linker-name:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`linker-name`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`base:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`base`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`warnings?:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`warnings?`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-link_002dincremental){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-gsc-4 .index-entry-id}

    The first parameter must be a non empty list of strings naming
    Scheme modules to link (the file extension may be omitted). An
    incremental link file is generated for the modules specified in
    `module-list`{.variable .var}. By default the link file generated is
    named '`last`{.variable .var}`_.`{.sample .samp}`ext`{.variable
    .var}', where `last`{.variable .var} is the name of the last module,
    without the file extension, and `ext`{.variable .var} is the
    appropriate extension for the target. The name of the generated link
    file can be specified with the `output`{.variable .var} parameter.
    If `output`{.variable .var} is a string naming a directory then the
    link file is created in that directory. Otherwise the name of the
    link file is `output`{.variable .var}.

    The base link file is specified by the `base`{.variable .var}
    parameter, which must be a string. By default the base link file is
    the Gambit runtime library link file '`~~lib/_gambit`{.sample
    .samp}' (with extension appropriate for the target). However, when
    `base`{.variable .var} is supplied it is the name of the base link
    file (the file extension may be omitted).

    The `warnings?`{.variable .var} parameter controls whether warnings
    are generated for undefined references.

    The following example shows how to build the executable program
    '`hello`{.sample .samp}' which contains the two Scheme modules
    '`h.scm`{.sample .samp}' and '`w.six`{.sample .samp}'.

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    $ uname -srmp
    Darwin 8.1.0 Power Macintosh powerpc
    $ cat h.scm
    (display "hello") (newline)
    $ cat w.six
    display("world"); newline();
    $ gsc
    Gambit v4.9.5

    > (compile-file-to-target "h")
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/h.c"
    > (compile-file-to-target "w")
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/w.c"
    > (link-incremental '("h" "w") output: "hello.c")
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/hello_.c"
    > ,q
    $ gsc -obj h.c w.c hello.c
    h.c:
    w.c:
    hello.c:
    $ gcc h.o w.o hello.o -lgambit -o hello
    $ ./hello
    hello
    world
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**link-flat** `module-list`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`output:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`output`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`linker-name:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`linker-name`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`warnings?:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`warnings?`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-link_002dflat){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-gsc-5 .index-entry-id}

    The first parameter must be a non empty list of strings naming
    Scheme modules to link (the file extension may be omitted). The
    first string must be the name of a Scheme module or the name of a
    link file and the remaining strings must name Scheme modules. A flat
    link file is generated for the modules specified in
    `module-list`{.variable .var}. By default the link file generated is
    named '`last`{.variable .var}`_.`{.sample .samp}`ext`{.variable
    .var}', where `last`{.variable .var} is the name of the last module,
    without the file extension, and `ext`{.variable .var} is the
    appropriate extension for the target. The name of the generated link
    file can be specified with the `output`{.variable .var} parameter.
    If `output`{.variable .var} is a string naming a directory then the
    link file is created in that directory. Otherwise the name of the
    link file is `output`{.variable .var}. If a dynamically loadable
    object file is produced from the link file '`output`{.variable
    .var}', then the name of the dynamically loadable object file must
    be '`output`{.variable .var}' stripped of its file extension.

    The `warnings?`{.variable .var} parameter controls whether warnings
    are generated for undefined references.

    The following example shows how to build the dynamically loadable
    object file '`lib.o1`{.sample .samp}' which contains the two Scheme
    modules '`m6.scm`{.sample .samp}' and '`m7.scm`{.sample .samp}'.

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    $ uname -srmp
    Darwin 8.1.0 Power Macintosh powerpc
    $ cat m6.scm
    (define (f x) (g (* x x)))
    $ cat m7.scm
    (define (g y) (+ n y))
    $ gsc
    Gambit v4.9.5

    > (compile-file-to-target "m6")
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/m6.c"
    > (compile-file-to-target "m7")
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/m7.c"
    > (link-flat '("m6" "m7") output: "lib.o1.c")
    *** WARNING -- "*" is not defined,
    ***            referenced in: ("m6.c")
    *** WARNING -- "+" is not defined,
    ***            referenced in: ("m7.c")
    *** WARNING -- "n" is not defined,
    ***            referenced in: ("m7.c")
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/lib.o1.c"
    > ,q
    $ gcc -bundle -D___DYNAMIC m6.c m7.c lib.o1.c -o lib.o1
    $ gsc
    Gambit v4.9.5

    > (load "lib")
    *** WARNING -- Variable "n" used in module "m7" is undefined
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/lib.o1"
    > (define n 10)
    > (f 5)
    35
    > ,q
    ```
    :::

    The warnings indicate that there are no definitions
    (`define`{.code}s or `set!`{.code}s) of the variables `*`{.code},
    `+`{.code} and `n`{.code} in the modules contained in the library.
    Before the library is used, these variables will have to be bound;
    either implicitly (by the runtime library) or explicitly.

## 4 Runtime options {#Runtime-options-1 .chapter}

[]{#index-runtime-options .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-options_002c-runtime .index-entry-id} []{#index-gsc-6
.index-entry-id} []{#index-gsi-2 .index-entry-id}

Both `gsi`{.code} and `gsc`{.code} as well as executable programs
compiled and linked using `gsc`{.code} take a '`-:`{.sample .samp}'
option which supplies parameters to the runtime system. This option must
appear first on the command line. The colon is followed by a comma
separated list of options with no intervening spaces. The available
options are:

[**`min-heap=`{.code}**`SIZE`{.variable .var} or the shorthand **`m`{.code}**`SIZE`{.variable .var}]{.r}

:   Set minimum heap size.

[**`max-heap=`{.code}**`SIZE`{.variable .var} or the shorthand **`h`{.code}**`SIZE`{.variable .var}]{.r}

:   Set maximum heap size.

[**`live-ratio=`{.code}**`RATIO`{.variable .var} or the shorthand **`l`{.code}**`RATIO`{.variable .var}]{.r}

:   Set the ratio of heap that is live after a garbage collection.

[**`gambit`{.code}** or the (deprecated) shorthand **`S`{.code}**]{.r}

:   Select Gambit Scheme mode. This is the default mode.

[**`r5rs`{.code}** or the (deprecated) shorthand **`s`{.code}**]{.r}

:   Select R5RS Scheme mode.

[**`r7rs`{.code}**]{.r}

:   Select R7RS Scheme mode.

[**`debug`{.code}**[\[]{.r}**`=`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`OPT`{.variable .var}\...[\]\]]{.r} or the shorthand **`d`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`OPT`{.variable .var}\...[\]]{.r}]{.r}

:   Set debugging options.

[**`~~`{.code}**`NAME`{.variable .var}**`=`{.code}**`DIRECTORY`{.variable .var}]{.r}

:   Override the `NAME`{.variable .var} installation directory.

[**`add-arg=`{.code}**`ARGUMENT`{.variable .var} or the shorthand **`+`{.code}**`ARGUMENT`{.variable .var}]{.r}

:   Add `ARGUMENT`{.variable .var} to the command line before other
    arguments.

[**`io-settings=`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`IO`{.variable .var}\...[\]]{.r} or the shorthand **`i`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`IO`{.variable .var}\...[\]]{.r}]{.r}

:   Set general I/O settings.

[**`file-settings=`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`IO`{.variable .var}\...[\]]{.r} or the shorthand **`f`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`IO`{.variable .var}\...[\]]{.r}]{.r}

:   Set general file I/O settings.

[**`stdio-settings=`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`IO`{.variable .var}\...[\]]{.r} or the shorthand **`-`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`IO`{.variable .var}\...[\]]{.r}]{.r}

:   Set general stdio settings.

[**`0`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`IO`{.variable .var}\...[\]]{.r}]{.r}

:   Set stdin settings.

[**`1`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`IO`{.variable .var}\...[\]]{.r}]{.r}

:   Set stdout settings.

[**`2`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`IO`{.variable .var}\...[\]]{.r}]{.r}

:   Set stderr settings.

[**`terminal-settings=`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`IO`{.variable .var}\...[\]]{.r} or the shorthand **`t`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`IO`{.variable .var}\...[\]]{.r}]{.r}

:   Set terminal I/O settings.

[**`search`{.code}**[\[]{.r}**`=`{.code}**`DIR`{.variable .var}[\]]{.r}]{.r}

:   Set or reset module search order.

[**`whitelist`{.code}**[\[]{.r}**`=`{.code}**`SOURCE`{.variable .var}[\]]{.r}]{.r}

:   Set or reset the whitelist of trusted sources for automatic
    installation of hosted modules.

[**`ask-install=`{.code}**`WHEN`{.variable .var}]{.r}

:   Set automatic installation confirmation mode.

[]{#index-_002d_003amin_002dheap_003dSIZE .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002d_003amSIZE .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002d_003amax_002dheap_003dSIZE .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002d_003ahSIZE .index-entry-id}

The **`min-heap=`{.code}**`SIZE`{.variable .var} and
**`max-heap=`{.code}**`SIZE`{.variable .var} options set limits on the
size of the heap. The `SIZE`{.variable .var} is an integer that may be
followed by **`G`{.code}** (gigabytes), **`M`{.code}** (megabytes), or
**`K`{.code}** or nothing (kilobytes). The heap will not shrink lower
than the minimum heap size which defaults to 0. The heap will not grow
larger than the maximum heap size if it is set (by default the heap may
grow until the virtual memory is exhausted).

[]{#index-_002d_003alive_002dratio_003dRATIO .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002d_003alRATIO .index-entry-id}

The **`live-ratio=`{.code}**`RATIO`{.variable .var} option sets the
percentage of the heap that will be occupied with live objects after the
heap is resized at the end of a garbage collection. `RATIO`{.variable
.var} is an integer between 1 and 100 inclusively indicating the desired
percentage. The garbage collector resizes the heap to reach this
percentage occupation (roughly), within the limits of the
`min-heap`{.code} and `max-heap`{.code} options. By default, the
percentage is 50.

[]{#index-_002d_003agambit .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002d_003ar5rs
.index-entry-id} []{#index-_002d_003ar7rs .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002d_003as .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002d_003aS
.index-entry-id}

The **`gambit`{.code}**, **`r5rs`{.code}** and **`r7rs`{.code}** options
configure the runtime system to conform to Gambit Scheme, R5RS Scheme
and R7RS Scheme respectively. The reader is case-insensitive in
**`r5rs`{.code}** mode, and is case-sensitive in **`r7rs`{.code}** and
**`gambit`{.code}** modes. The reader supports keywords only in
**`gambit`{.code}** mode, which is the default mode.

[]{#index-_002d_003adebug .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002d_003ad
.index-entry-id}

The **`debug=`{.code}**`OPT`{.variable .var},\... option sets various
debugging options. The equal sign is followed by a sequence of letters
indicating suboptions.

[**`p`{.code}**]{.r} [¶](#index-_002d_003adebug_003dp){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-_002d_003adp .index-entry-id}

    Uncaught exceptions will be treated as "errors" in the primordial
    thread only.

[**`a`{.code}**]{.r} [¶](#index-_002d_003adebug_003da){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-_002d_003ada .index-entry-id}

    Uncaught exceptions will be treated as "errors" in all threads.

[**`r`{.code}**]{.r} [¶](#index-_002d_003adebug_003dr){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-_002d_003adr .index-entry-id}

    When an "error" occurs a new REPL will be started.

[**`s`{.code}**]{.r} [¶](#index-_002d_003adebug_003ds){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-_002d_003ads .index-entry-id}

    When an "error" occurs a new REPL will be started. Moreover the
    program starts in single-stepping mode.

[**`q`{.code}**]{.r} [¶](#index-_002d_003adebug_003dq){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-_002d_003adq .index-entry-id}

    When an "error" occurs the program will terminate with a nonzero
    exit status.

[**`R`{.code}**]{.r} [¶](#index-_002d_003adebug_003dR){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-_002d_003adR .index-entry-id} []{#index-_005eC
    .index-entry-id}

    When a user interrupt occurs a new REPL will be started. User
    interrupts are typically obtained by typing [\^C]{.kbd .key}. Note
    that with some system configurations [\^C]{.kbd .key} abruptly
    terminates the process. For example, under Microsoft Windows,
    [\^C]{.kbd .key} works fine with the standard console but with the
    MSYS terminal window it terminates the process.

[**`D`{.code}**]{.r} [¶](#index-_002d_003adebug_003dD){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-_002d_003adD .index-entry-id}

    When a user interrupt occurs it will be deferred until the parameter
    object `current-user-interrupt-handler`{.code} is set or bound.

[**`Q`{.code}**]{.r} [¶](#index-_002d_003adebug_003dQ){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-_002d_003adQ .index-entry-id}

    When a user interrupt occurs the program will terminate with a
    nonzero exit status.

[`LEVEL`{.variable .var}]{.r} [¶](#index-_002d_003adebug_003dLEVEL){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-_002d_003adLEVEL .index-entry-id}

    The verbosity level is set to `LEVEL`{.variable .var}, a digit from
    0 to 9. At level 0 the runtime system will not display error
    messages and warnings. At level 1 and above error messages and
    warnings are displayed. At level 2 and above a backtrace is
    displayed. At level 3 and above variable bindings are displayed in
    the backtrace. At level 5 and above garbage collection reports are
    displayed during program execution.

[**`c`{.code}**]{.r} [¶](#index-_002d_003adebug_003dc){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-_002d_003adc .index-entry-id}

    The REPL interaction channel will be the console.

[**`-`{.code}**]{.r} [¶](#index-_002d_003adebug_003d_002d){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-_002d_003ad_002d .index-entry-id}

    The REPL interaction channel will be standard input and standard
    output.

[**`+`{.code}**]{.r} [¶](#index-_002d_003adebug_003d_002b){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-_002d_003ad_002b .index-entry-id}

    The REPL interaction channel will be standard input and standard
    output and standard error.

[**`@`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`HOST`{.variable .var}[\]]{.r}[\[]{.r}**`:`{.code}**`PORT`{.variable .var}[\]]{.r}]{.r} [¶](#index-_002d_003adebug_003d_0040_005bHOST_005d_005b_003aPORT_005d){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-_002d_003ad_0040_005bHOST_005d_005b_003aPORT_005d
    .index-entry-id}

    When a REPL is started by a thread a connection will be established
    with the address `HOST`{.variable .var}:`PORT`{.variable .var} and
    that will be the REPL's interaction channel. The default
    `HOST`{.variable .var} is 127.0.0.1 and the default `PORT`{.variable
    .var} is 44556.

[**`$`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`INTF`{.variable .var}[\]]{.r}[\[]{.r}**`:`{.code}**`PORT`{.variable .var}[\]]{.r}]{.r} [¶](#index-_002d_003adebug_003d_0024_005bINTF_005d_005b_003aPORT_005d){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-_002d_003ad_0024_005bINTF_005d_005b_003aPORT_005d
    .index-entry-id}

    The runtime system will open a socket to listen on port number
    `PORT`{.variable .var} for incoming connections on the network
    interface with address `INTF`{.variable .var}. The default
    `INTF`{.variable .var} is 127.0.0.1 and the default `PORT`{.variable
    .var} is 44555.

The default debugging options are equivalent to `debug=pqQ1-`{.code}
(i.e. an uncaught exception in the primordial thread terminates the
program after displaying an error message). When the option
`debug`{.code} is used without suboptions it is equivalent to
`debug=prR1-`{.code} (i.e. a new REPL is started only when an uncaught
exception occurs in the primordial thread). When `gsi`{.code} and
`gsc`{.code} are running the main REPL, the debugging options are
changed to cause errors in the primordial thread and user interrupts to
start a nested REPL.

[]{#index-_002d_003a_007e_007eNAME_003dDIRECTORY .index-entry-id}

The **`~~`{.code}**`NAME`{.variable
.var}**`=`{.code}**`DIRECTORY`{.variable .var} option overrides the
setting of the `NAME`{.variable .var} installation directory. If
`NAME`{.variable .var} is empty, it will override the central
installation directory.

[]{#index-_002d_003aadd_002darg_003dARGUMENT .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002d_003a_002bARGUMENT .index-entry-id}

The **`add-arg=`{.code}**`ARGUMENT`{.variable .var} option adds the text
that follows to the command line before other arguments.

[]{#index-_002d_003aio_002dsettings_003d_005bIO_002e_002e_002e_005d
.index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002d_003afile_002dsettings_003d_005bIO_002e_002e_002e_005d
.index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002d_003astdio_002dsettings_003d_005bIO_002e_002e_002e_005d
.index-entry-id}
[]{#index-_002d_003aterminal_002dsettings_003d_005bIO_002e_002e_002e_005d
.index-entry-id} []{#index-_002d_003ai_005bIO_002e_002e_002e_005d
.index-entry-id} []{#index-_002d_003af_005bIO_002e_002e_002e_005d
.index-entry-id} []{#index-_002d_003a_002d_005bIO_002e_002e_002e_005d
.index-entry-id} []{#index-_002d_003a0_005bIO_002e_002e_002e_005d
.index-entry-id} []{#index-_002d_003a1_005bIO_002e_002e_002e_005d
.index-entry-id} []{#index-_002d_003a2_005bIO_002e_002e_002e_005d
.index-entry-id} []{#index-_002d_003at_005bIO_002e_002e_002e_005d
.index-entry-id}

The option **`io-settings=`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`IO`{.variable
.var}\...[\]]{.r} sets the default I/O settings of all types of ports.
The option **`file-settings=`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`IO`{.variable
.var}\...[\]]{.r} sets the default I/O settings for ports associated to
files. The option **`stdio-settings=`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`IO`{.variable
.var}\...[\]]{.r} sets the default I/O settings for ports associated to
stdio (but finer control is possible with
**`0`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`IO`{.variable .var}\...[\]]{.r},
**`1`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`IO`{.variable .var}\...[\]]{.r}, and
**`2`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`IO`{.variable .var}\...[\]]{.r} that set the I/O
settings of stdin, stdout, and stderr respectively). The option
**`terminal-settings=`{.code}**[\[]{.r}`IO`{.variable .var}\...[\]]{.r}
overrides the default I/O settings for ports associated to terminals.
The default character encoding, end-of-line encoding and buffering can
be set. Moreover, for terminals the line-editing feature can be enabled
or disabled. Each `IO`{.variable .var} is a one or two letter code as
follows:

`A`{.code}

:   ASCII character encoding.

`1`{.code}

:   ISO-8859-1 character encoding.

`2`{.code}

:   UCS-2 character encoding.

`4`{.code}

:   UCS-4 character encoding.

`6`{.code}

:   UTF-16 character encoding.

`8`{.code}

:   UTF-8 character encoding.

`U`{.code}

:   UTF character encoding with fallback to UTF-8 on input if no BOM is
    present.

`UA`{.code}

:   UTF character encoding with fallback to ASCII on input if no BOM is
    present.

`U1`{.code}

:   UTF character encoding with fallback to ISO-8859-1 on input if no
    BOM is present.

`U6`{.code}

:   UTF character encoding with fallback to UTF-16 on input if no BOM is
    present.

`U8`{.code}

:   UTF character encoding with fallback to UTF-8 on input if no BOM is
    present.

`L`{.code}

:   If the `LC_ALL`{.code} or `LC_CTYPE`{.code} or `LANG`{.code}
    environment variables end with '`.UTF-8`{.sample .samp}' or
    '`.ISO-8859-1`{.sample .samp}' or '`.LATIN-1`{.sample .samp}' (or a
    variation) set the character encoding accordingly.

`c`{.code}

:   End-of-line is encoded as CR (carriage-return).

`l`{.code}

:   End-of-line is encoded as LF (linefeed)

`cl`{.code}

:   End-of-line is encoded as CR-LF.

`u`{.code}

:   Unbuffered I/O.

`n`{.code}

:   Line buffered I/O ('`n`{.sample .samp}' for "at newline").

`f`{.code}

:   Fully buffered I/O.

`r`{.code}

:   Illegal character encoding is treated as an error (exception
    raised).

`R`{.code}

:   Silently replace illegal character encodings with Unicode character
    #xfffd (replacement character).

`e`{.code}

:   Enable line-editing (applies to terminals only).

`E`{.code}

:   Disable line-editing (applies to terminals only).

[]{#index-_002d_003asearch_005b_003dDIR_005d .index-entry-id}

The **`search`{.code}**[\[]{.r}**`=`{.code}**`DIR`{.variable
.var}[\]]{.r} option adds `DIR`{.variable .var} to the tail of the list
of module search order directories, unless the
**`=`{.code}**`DIR`{.variable .var} part is absent, in which case it is
set to the empty list. The initial setting of the list of module search
order directories is `~~lib`{.code} followed by `~~userlib`{.code}.

[]{#index-_002d_003awhitelist_005b_003dSOURCE_005d .index-entry-id}

When a hosted module can't be found in the directories on the list of
module search order directories it will be automatically installed if it
is from a source on the whitelist of trusted sources, which initially
contains only `github.com/gambit`{.code}. The
**`whitelist`{.code}**[\[]{.r}**`=`{.code}**`SOURCE`{.variable
.var}[\]]{.r} option adds `SOURCE`{.variable .var} to the whitelist,
unless the **`=`{.code}**`SOURCE`{.variable .var} part is absent in
which case the whitelist will be set to the empty list (no source is
trusted).

[]{#index-_002d_003aask_002dinstall_003dWHEN .index-entry-id}

The **`ask-install=`{.code}**`WHEN`{.variable .var} option sets the
automatic installation mode confirmation mode to `WHEN`{.variable .var},
which is one of `always`{.code}, `repl`{.code}, and `never`{.code}. When
a hosted module can't be found in the directories on the list of module
search order directories and it is from a source not on the whitelist
the runtime system will ask for installation confirmation when
`WHEN`{.variable .var} is `always`{.code}, or when a REPL has already
been started for the current thread and `WHEN`{.variable .var} is
`repl`{.code}. In the `never`{.code} mode the runtime system will not
install the module automatically. The default mode is `repl`{.code}.

[]{#index-_002d_003a_002c .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-GAMBOPT_002c-environment-variable .index-entry-id}

When a program's execution starts, the runtime system obtains the
runtime options by processing in turn various sources of runtime
options: the defaults, the environment variable '`GAMBOPT`{.sample
.samp}', the script line of the source code, and, unless the program is
an interpreted script, the first command line argument of the program.
Any runtime option can be overriden by a subsequent source of runtime
options. It is sometimes useful to prevent overriding the runtime
options of the script line. This can be achieved by starting the script
line runtime options with '`-:,`{.sample .samp}'. In this case the
environment variable '`GAMBOPT`{.sample .samp}' is ignored, and the
first command line argument of the program is not used for runtime
options (it is treated like a normal command line argument even if it
starts with '`-:`{.sample .samp}').

For example:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ export GAMBOPT=debug=0,~~=~/my-gambit2
$ gsi -e '(pretty-print (path-expand "~~")) (/ 1 0)'
"/Users/feeley/my-gambit2/"
$ echo $?
70
$ gsi -:debug=1 -e '(pretty-print (path-expand "~~")) (/ 1 0)'
"/Users/feeley/my-gambit2/"
*** ERROR IN (string)@1.35 -- Divide by zero
(/ 1 0)
```
:::

### 5.1 Debugging model {#Debugging-model-1 .section}

The evaluation of an expression may stop before it is completed for the
following reasons:

a.  An evaluation error has occured, such as attempting to divide by
    zero.
b.  []{#index-_005eC-1 .index-entry-id} The user has interrupted the
    evaluation (usually by typing [\^C]{.kbd .key}).
c.  A breakpoint has been reached or `(step)`{.code} was evaluated.
d.  Single-stepping mode is enabled.

When an evaluation stops, a message is displayed indicating the reason
and location where the evaluation was stopped. The location information
includes, if known, the name of the procedure where the evaluation was
stopped and the source code location in the format '`stream`{.variable
.var}`@`{.sample .samp}`line`{.variable .var}`.`{.sample
.samp}`column`{.variable .var}', where `stream`{.variable .var} is
either a string naming a file or a symbol within parentheses, such as
'`(console)`{.sample .samp}'.

A *nested REPL* is then initiated in the context of the point of
execution where the evaluation was stopped. The nested REPL's
continuation and evaluation environment are the same as the point where
the evaluation was stopped. For example when evaluating the expression
'`(let ((y (- 1 1))) (* (/ x y) 2))`{.sample .samp}', a "divide by zero"
error is reported and the nested REPL's continuation is the one that
takes the result and multiplies it by two. The REPL's lexical
environment includes the lexical variable '`y`{.sample .samp}'. This
allows the inspection of the evaluation context (i.e. the lexical and
dynamic environments and continuation), which is particularly useful to
determine the exact location and cause of an error.

[]{#index-_005eD .index-entry-id}

The prompt of nested REPLs includes the nesting level; '`1>`{.sample
.samp}' is the prompt at the first nesting level, '`2>`{.sample .samp}'
at the second nesting level, and so on. An end of file (usually
[\^D]{.kbd .key}) will cause the current REPL to be terminated and the
enclosing REPL (one nesting level less) to be resumed.

At any time the user can examine the frames in the REPL's continuation,
which is useful to determine which chain of procedure calls lead to an
error. A backtrace that lists the chain of active continuation frames in
the REPL's continuation can be obtained with the '`,b`{.sample .samp}'
command. The frames are numbered from 0, that is frame 0 is the most
recent frame of the continuation where execution stopped, frame 1 is the
parent frame of frame 0, and so on. It is also possible to move the REPL
to a specific parent continuation (i.e. a specific frame of the
continuation where execution stopped) with the '`,`{.sample
.samp}`N`{.variable .var}', '`,`{.sample .samp}`N`{.variable
.var}`+`{.sample .samp}', '`,`{.sample .samp}`N`{.variable
.var}`-`{.sample .samp}', '`,+`{.sample .samp}', '`,-`{.sample .samp}',
'`,++`{.sample .samp}', and '`,--`{.sample .samp}' commands. When the
frame number of the frame being examined is not zero, it is shown in the
prompt after the nesting level, for example '`1\5>`{.sample .samp}' is
the prompt when the REPL nesting level is 1 and the frame number is 5.

Expressions entered at a nested REPL are evaluated in the environment
(both lexical and dynamic) of the continuation frame currently being
examined if that frame was created by interpreted Scheme code. If the
frame was created by compiled Scheme code then expressions get evaluated
in the global interaction environment. This feature may be used in
interpreted code to fetch the value of a variable in the current frame
or to change its value with `set!`{.code}. Note that some special forms
(`define`{.code} in particular) can only be evaluated in the global
interaction environment.

### 5.2 Debugging commands {#Debugging-commands-1 .section}

In addition to expressions, the REPL accepts the following special
"comma" commands:

`,? `{.code}[`and`{.code}]{.r}` ,help`{.code} [¶](#index-_002c_003f){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-_002chelp .index-entry-id}

    Give a summary of the REPL commands.

`,(h `{.code}`subject`{.variable .var}`)`{.code} [¶](#index-_002c_0028h-subject_0029){.copiable-link}

:   This command will show the section of the Gambit manual with the
    definition of the procedure or special form `subject`{.variable
    .var}, which must be a symbol. For example '`,(h time)`{.sample
    .samp}' will show the section documenting the `time`{.code} special
    form. Please see the `help`{.code} procedure for additional
    information.

`,h`{.code} [¶](#index-_002ch){.copiable-link}

:   This command will show the section of the Gambit manual with the
    definition of the procedure which raised the exception for which
    this REPL was started.

`,q`{.code} [¶](#index-_002cq){.copiable-link}

:   Terminate the process with exit status 0. This is equivalent to
    calling `(exit 0)`{.code}.

`,qt`{.code} [¶](#index-_002cqt){.copiable-link}

:   Terminate the current thread (note that terminating the primordial
    thread terminates the process).

`,t`{.code} [¶](#index-_002ct){.copiable-link}

:   Return to the outermost REPL, also known as the "top-level REPL".

`,d`{.code} [¶](#index-_002cd){.copiable-link}

:   Leave the current REPL and resume the enclosing REPL. This command
    does nothing in the top-level REPL.

`,(c `{.code}`expr`{.variable .var}`)`{.code} [¶](#index-_002c_0028c-expr_0029){.copiable-link}

:   Leave the current REPL and continue the computation that initiated
    the REPL with a specific value. This command can only be used to
    continue a computation that signaled an error. The expression
    `expr`{.variable .var} is evaluated in the current context and the
    resulting value is returned as the value of the expression which
    signaled the error. For example, if the evaluation of the expression
    '`(* (/ x y) 2)`{.sample .samp}' signaled an error because
    '`y`{.sample .samp}' is zero, then in the nested REPL a
    '`,(c (+ 4 y))`{.sample .samp}' will resume the computation of
    '`(* (/ x y) 2)`{.sample .samp}' as though the value of
    '`(/ x y)`{.sample .samp}' was 4. This command must be used
    carefully because the context where the error occured may rely on
    the result being of a particular type. For instance a
    '`,(c #f)`{.sample .samp}' in the previous example will cause
    '`*`{.sample .samp}' to signal a type error (this problem is the
    most troublesome when debugging Scheme code that was compiled with
    type checking turned off so be careful).

`,c`{.code} [¶](#index-_002cc){.copiable-link}

:   Leave the current REPL and continue the computation that initiated
    the REPL. This command can only be used to continue a computation
    that was stopped due to a user interrupt, breakpoint or a
    single-step.

`,s`{.code} [¶](#index-_002cs){.copiable-link}

:   Leave the current REPL and continue the computation that initiated
    the REPL in single-stepping mode. The computation will perform an
    evaluation step (as defined by `step-level-set!`{.code}) and then
    stop, causing a nested REPL to be entered. Just before the
    evaluation step is performed, a line is displayed (in the same
    format as `trace`{.code}) which indicates the expression that is
    being evaluated. If the evaluation step produces a result, the
    result is also displayed on another line. A nested REPL is then
    entered after displaying a message which describes the next step of
    the computation. This command can only be used to continue a
    computation that was stopped due to a user interrupt, breakpoint or
    a single-step.

`,l`{.code} [¶](#index-_002cl){.copiable-link}

:   This command is similar to '`,s`{.sample .samp}' except that it
    "leaps" over procedure calls, that is procedure calls are treated
    like a single step. Single-stepping mode will resume when the
    procedure call returns, or if and when the execution of the called
    procedure encounters a breakpoint.

`,`{.code}`N`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-_002cN){.copiable-link}

:   Move to frame number `N`{.variable .var} of the continuation. After
    changing the current frame, a one-line summary of the frame is
    displayed as if the '`,y`{.sample .samp}' command was entered.

`,`{.code}`N`{.variable .var}`+`{.code} [¶](#index-_002cN_002b){.copiable-link}

:   Move forward by `N`{.variable .var} frames in the chain of
    continuation frames (i.e. towards older continuation frames). After
    changing the current frame, a one-line summary of the frame is
    displayed as if the '`,y`{.sample .samp}' command was entered.

`,`{.code}`N`{.variable .var}`-`{.code} [¶](#index-_002cN_002d){.copiable-link}

:   Move backward by `N`{.variable .var} frames in the chain of
    continuation frames (i.e. towards more recent continuation frames).
    After changing the current frame, a one-line summary of the frame is
    displayed as if the '`,y`{.sample .samp}' command was entered.

`,+`{.code} [¶](#index-_002c_002b){.copiable-link}

:   Equivalent to '`,1+`{.sample .samp}'.

`,-`{.code} [¶](#index-_002c_002d){.copiable-link}

:   Equivalent to '`,1-`{.sample .samp}'.

`,++`{.code} [¶](#index-_002c_002b_002b){.copiable-link}

:   Equivalent to '`,`{.sample .samp}`N`{.variable .var}`+`{.sample
    .samp}' where `N`{.variable .var} is the number of continuation
    frames displayed at the head of a backtrace.

`,--`{.code} [¶](#index-_002c_002d_002d){.copiable-link}

:   Equivalent to '`,`{.sample .samp}`N`{.variable .var}`-`{.sample
    .samp}' where `N`{.variable .var} is the number of continuation
    frames displayed at the head of a backtrace.

`,y`{.code} [¶](#index-_002cy){.copiable-link}

:   Display a one-line summary of the current frame. The information is
    displayed in four fields. The first field is the frame number. The
    second field is the procedure that created the frame or
    '`(interaction)`{.sample .samp}' if the frame was created by an
    expression entered at the REPL. The remaining fields describe the
    subproblem associated with the frame, that is the expression whose
    value is being computed. The third field is the location of the
    subproblem's source code and the fourth field is a reproduction of
    the source code, possibly truncated to fit on the line. The last two
    fields may be missing if that information is not available. In
    particular, the third field is missing when the frame was created by
    a user call to the '`eval`{.sample .samp}' procedure or by a
    compiled procedure not compiled with the declaration
    '`debug-location`{.sample .samp}', and the last field is missing
    when the frame was created by a compiled procedure not compiled with
    the declaration '`debug-source`{.sample .samp}'.

`,b`{.code} [¶](#index-_002cb){.copiable-link}

:   Display a backtrace summarizing each frame in the chain of
    continuation frames starting with the current frame. For each frame,
    the same information as for the '`,y`{.sample .samp}' command is
    displayed (except that location information is displayed in the
    format '`stream`{.variable .var}`@`{.sample .samp}`line`{.variable
    .var}`:`{.sample .samp}`column`{.variable .var}'). If there are more
    than 15 frames in the chain of continuation frames, some of the
    middle frames will be omitted.

`,be`{.code} [¶](#index-_002cbe){.copiable-link}

:   Like the '`,b`{.sample .samp}' command but also display the
    environment.

`,bed`{.code} [¶](#index-_002cbed){.copiable-link}

:   Like the '`,be`{.sample .samp}' command but also display the dynamic
    environment.

`,(b `{.code}`expr`{.variable .var}`)`{.code} [¶](#index-_002c_0028b-expr_0029){.copiable-link}

:   Display the backtrace of `expr`{.variable .var}'s value,
    `X`{.variable .var}, which is obtained by evaluating
    `expr`{.variable .var} in the current frame. `X`{.variable .var}
    must be a continuation or a thread. When `X`{.variable .var} is a
    continuation, the frames in that continuation are displayed. When
    `X`{.variable .var} is a thread, the backtrace of the current
    continuation of that thread is displayed.

`,(be `{.code}`expr`{.variable .var}`)`{.code} [¶](#index-_002c_0028be-expr_0029){.copiable-link}

:   Like the '`,(b `{.sample .samp}`expr`{.variable .var}`)`{.sample
    .samp}' command but also display the environment.

`,(bed `{.code}`expr`{.variable .var}`)`{.code} [¶](#index-_002c_0028bed-expr_0029){.copiable-link}

:   Like the '`,(be `{.sample .samp}`expr`{.variable .var}`)`{.sample
    .samp}' command but also display the dynamic environment.

`,i`{.code} [¶](#index-_002ci){.copiable-link}

:   Pretty print the procedure that created the current frame or
    '`(interaction)`{.sample .samp}' if the frame was created by an
    expression entered at the REPL. Compiled procedures will only be
    pretty printed when they are compiled with the declaration
    '`debug-source`{.sample .samp}'.

`,e`{.code} [¶](#index-_002ce){.copiable-link}

:   Display the environment which is accessible from the current frame.
    The lexical environment is displayed, followed by the dynamic
    environment if the parameter object
    `repl-display-dynamic-environment?`{.code} is not false. Global
    lexical variables are not displayed. Moreover the frame must have
    been created by interpreted code or code compiled with the
    declaration '`debug-environments`{.sample .samp}'. Due to space
    safety considerations and compiler optimizations, some of the
    lexical variable bindings may be missing. Lexical variable bindings
    are displayed using the format '`variable`{.variable
    .var}` = `{.sample .samp}`expression`{.variable .var}' (when
    `variable`{.variable .var} is mutable) or '`variable`{.variable
    .var}` == `{.sample .samp}`expression`{.variable .var}' (when
    `variable`{.variable .var} is immutable, which may happen in
    compiled code due to compiler optimization) and dynamically-bound
    parameter bindings are displayed using the format '`(`{.sample
    .samp}`parameter`{.variable .var}`) = `{.sample
    .samp}`expression`{.variable .var}'. Note that
    `expression`{.variable .var} can be a self-evaluating expression
    (number, string, boolean, character, \...), a quoted expression, a
    lambda expression or a global variable (the last two cases, which
    are only used when the value of the variable or parameter is a
    procedure, simplifies the debugging of higher-order procedures). A
    `parameter`{.variable .var} can be a quoted expression or a global
    variable. Lexical bindings are displayed in inverse binding order
    (most deeply nested first) and shadowed variables are included in
    the list.

`,ed`{.code} [¶](#index-_002ced){.copiable-link}

:   Like the '`,e`{.sample .samp}' command but the dynamic environment
    is always displayed.

`,(e `{.code}`expr`{.variable .var}`)`{.code} [¶](#index-_002c_0028e-expr_0029){.copiable-link}

:   Display the environment of `expr`{.variable .var}'s value,
    `X`{.variable .var}, which is obtained by evaluating
    `expr`{.variable .var} in the current frame. `X`{.variable .var}
    must be a continuation, a thread, a procedure, or a nonnegative
    integer. When `X`{.variable .var} is a continuation, the environment
    at that point in the code is displayed. When `X`{.variable .var} is
    a thread, the environment of the current continuation of that thread
    is displayed. When `X`{.variable .var} is a procedure, the lexical
    environment where `X`{.variable .var} was created is combined with
    the current continuation and this combined environment is displayed.
    When `X`{.variable .var} is an integer, the environment at frame
    number `X`{.variable .var} of the continuation is displayed.

`,(ed `{.code}`expr`{.variable .var}`)`{.code} [¶](#index-_002c_0028ed-expr_0029){.copiable-link}

:   Like the '`,(e `{.sample .samp}`expr`{.variable .var}`)`{.sample
    .samp}' command but the dynamic environment is always displayed.

`,st`{.code} [¶](#index-_002cst){.copiable-link}

:   Display the state of the threads in the current thread's thread
    group. A thread can be: uninitialized, initialized, active, and
    terminated (normally or abnormally). Active threads can be running,
    sleeping and waiting on a synchronization object (mutex, condition
    variable or port) possibly with a timeout.

`,(st `{.code}`expr`{.variable .var}`)`{.code} [¶](#index-_002c_0028st-expr_0029){.copiable-link}

:   Display the state of a specific thread or thread group. The value of
    `expr`{.variable .var} must be a thread or thread group.

`,(v `{.code}`expr`{.variable .var}`)`{.code} [¶](#index-_002c_0028v-expr_0029){.copiable-link}

:   Start a new REPL visiting `expr`{.variable .var}'s value,
    `X`{.variable .var}, which is obtained by evaluating
    `expr`{.variable .var} in the current frame. `X`{.variable .var}
    must be a continuation, a thread, a procedure, or a nonnegative
    integer. When `X`{.variable .var} is a continuation, the new REPL's
    continuation is `X`{.variable .var} and evaluations are done in the
    environment at that point in the code. When `X`{.variable .var} is a
    thread, the thread is interrupted and the new REPL's continuation is
    the point where the thread was interrupted. When `X`{.variable .var}
    is a procedure, the lexical environment where `X`{.variable .var}
    was created is combined with the current continuation and
    evaluations are done in this combined environment. When
    `X`{.variable .var} is an integer, the REPL is started in frame
    number `X`{.variable .var} of the continuation.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### 5.3 Debugging example {#Debugging-example-1 .section}

Here is a sample interaction with `gsi`{.code}:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ gsi
Gambit v4.9.5

> (define (invsqr x) (/ 1 (expt x 2)))
> (define (mymap fn lst)
    (define (mm in)
      (if (null? in)
          '()
          (cons (fn (car in)) (mm (cdr in)))))
    (mm lst))
> (mymap invsqr '(5 2 hello 9 1))
*** ERROR IN invsqr, (console)@1.25 -- (Argument 1) NUMBER expected
(expt 'hello 2)
1> ,i
#<procedure #2 invsqr> =
(lambda (x) (/ 1 (expt x 2)))
1> ,e
x = 'hello
1> ,b
0  invsqr                    (console)@1:25          (expt x 2)
1  #<procedure #4>           (console)@6:17          (fn (car in))
2  #<procedure #4>           (console)@6:31          (mm (cdr in))
3  #<procedure #4>           (console)@6:31          (mm (cdr in))
4  (interaction)             (console)@8:1           (mymap invsqr '(5 2 hel...
1> ,+
1  #<procedure #4>           (console)@6.17          (fn (car in))
1\1> (pp #4)
(lambda (in) (if (null? in) '() (cons (fn (car in)) (mm (cdr in)))))
1\1> ,e
in = '(hello 9 1)
mm = (lambda (in) (if (null? in) '() (cons (fn (car in)) (mm (cdr in)))))
fn = invsqr
lst = '(5 2 hello 9 1)
1\1> ,(e mm)
mm = (lambda (in) (if (null? in) '() (cons (fn (car in)) (mm (cdr in)))))
fn = invsqr
lst = '(5 2 hello 9 1)
1\1> fn
#<procedure #2 invsqr>
1\1> (pp fn)
(lambda (x) (/ 1 (expt x 2)))
1\1> ,+
2  #<procedure #4>           (console)@6.31          (mm (cdr in))
1\2> ,e
in = '(2 hello 9 1)
mm = (lambda (in) (if (null? in) '() (cons (fn (car in)) (mm (cdr in)))))
fn = invsqr
lst = '(5 2 hello 9 1)
1\2> ,(c (list 3 4 5))
(1/25 1/4 3 4 5)
> ,q
```

### 5.4 Procedures related to debugging {#Procedures-related-to-debugging-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**help** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`subject`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-help){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**help-browser** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`new-value`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-help_002dbrowser){.copiable-link}

:   The `help`{.code} procedure displays the section of the Gambit
    manual with the definition of the procedure or special form
    `subject`{.variable .var}, which must be a procedure or symbol. For
    example the call `(help gensym)`{.code} will show the section
    documenting the `gensym`{.code} procedure and the call
    `(help 'time)`{.code} will show the section documenting the
    `time`{.code} special form. When the `subject`{.variable .var} is
    absent, the documentation of the `help`{.code} procedure is shown.
    The `help`{.code} procedure returns the void object.

    The parameter object `help-browser`{.code} is bound to a string
    naming the external program that is used by the `help`{.code}
    procedure to view the documentation. Initially it is bound to the
    empty string. In normal circumstances when `help-browser`{.code} is
    bound to an empty string the `help`{.code} procedure runs the script
    `~~bin/gambdoc.bat`{.code} which searches for a suitable web browser
    to open the documentation in HTML format. Unless the system was
    built with the command
    '`configure --enable-help-browser=...`{.sample .samp}', the
    text-only browser '`lynx`{.sample .samp}' (see
    [http://lynx.isc.org/](http://lynx.isc.org/){.uref}) will be used by
    default if it is available. We highly recommend that you install
    this browser if you are interested in viewing the documentation
    within the console in which the REPL is running. You can exit
    '`lynx`{.sample .samp}' conveniently by typing an end of file
    (usually [\^D]{.kbd .key}).

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (help-browser "firefox") ; use firefox instead of lynx
    > (help 'gensym)
    > (help gensym) ; OK because gensym is a procedure
    > (help 'time)
    > (help time) ; not OK because time is a special form
    *** ERROR IN (console)@5.7 -- Macro name can't be used as a variable: time
    >
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**apropos** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`substring`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`port`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-apropos){.copiable-link}

:   The `apropos`{.code} procedure writes to the port `port`{.variable
    .var} a report of all the global variables whose name contains
    `substring`{.variable .var}, a string or symbol. If
    `substring`{.variable .var} is not specified the report contains all
    the global variables. If it is not specified, `port`{.variable .var}
    defaults to the interaction channel (i.e. the output will appear at
    the REPL). The `apropos`{.code} procedure returns the void object.

    The global variables are grouped into namespaces. The empty
    namespace, if it is relevant, is last. This reduces the likelihood
    it will scroll off the screen if there are several global variables
    in other namespaces, which are typically less interesting.

    Note that with the `apropos`{.code} procedure it is possible to
    reveal the existence of procedures of the runtime system and modules
    that are not intended to be called by user code. These procedures
    often avoid type checking their arguments or must be called in a
    specific context, so calling them incorrectly may crash the system.
    On the other hand it also allows discovering the existence of
    certain functionalities that may have gone unnoticed.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (apropos "cons")
    "##" namespace:
      10^-constants, cons, cons*, cons*-aux, console-port,
      constant-expression-value, constant-expression?,
      cprc-quasi-cons, deconstruct-call,
      define-type-construct-constant, degen-quasi-cons,
      gen-quasi-cons, quasi-cons, stdio/console-repl-channel,
      void-constant?, xcons
    empty namespace:
      cons, cons*, console-port, xcons
    > (import (srfi 69))
    > (apropos "table?")
    "##" namespace:
      gc-hash-table?, mutable?, readtable?, table?
    "srfi/69#" namespace:
      hash-table?
    empty namespace:
      readtable?, table?
    > (apropos "srfi/69#")
    "srfi/69#" namespace:
      ||, alist->hash-table, hash, hash-by-identity,
      hash-table->alist, hash-table-copy, hash-table-delete!,
      hash-table-equivalence-function, hash-table-exists?,
      hash-table-fold, hash-table-hash-function,
      hash-table-keys, hash-table-merge!, hash-table-ref,
      hash-table-ref/default, hash-table-set!, hash-table-size,
      hash-table-update!, hash-table-update!/default,
      hash-table-values, hash-table-walk, hash-table?,
      make-hash-table, string-ci-hash, string-hash
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**repl-result-history-ref** `i`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-repl_002dresult_002dhistory_002dref){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**repl-result-history-max-length-set!** `n`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-repl_002dresult_002dhistory_002dmax_002dlength_002dset_0021){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-_0023 .index-entry-id} []{#index-_0023_0023
    .index-entry-id}

    The REPL keeps a history of the last few results printed by the
    REPL. The call `(repl-result-history-ref `{.code}`i`{.variable
    .var}`)`{.code} returns the `i`{.variable .var}th previous result
    (the last for `i`{.variable .var}=0, the next to last for
    `i`{.variable .var}=1, etc). By default the REPL result history
    remembers up to 3 results. The maximal length of the history can be
    set to `n`{.variable .var} between 0 and 10 by a call to
    `(repl-result-history-max-length-set! `{.code}`n`{.variable
    .var}`)`{.code}.

    For convenience the reader defines an abbreviation for calling
    `repl-result-history-ref`{.code}. Tokens formed by a sequence of one
    or more hash signs, such as '`#`{.code}', '`##`{.code}', etc, are
    expanded by the reader into the list
    `(repl-result-history-ref `{.code}`i`{.variable .var}`)`{.code},
    where `i`{.variable .var} is the number of hash signs minus 1. In
    other words, '`#`{.code}' will return the last result printed by the
    REPL, '`##`{.code}' will return the next to last, etc.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (map (lambda (x) (* x x)) '(1 2 3))
    (1 4 9)
    > (reverse #)
    (9 4 1)
    > (append # ##)
    (9 4 1 1 4 9)
    > 1
    1
    > 1
    1
    > (+ # ##)
    2
    > (+ # ##)
    3
    > (+ # ##)
    5
    > ####
    *** ERROR IN (console)@9.1 -- (Argument 1) Out of range
    (repl-result-history-ref 3)
    1>
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**trace** `proc`{.variable .var}`…`{.variable .def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-trace){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**untrace** `proc`{.variable .var}`…`{.variable .def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-untrace){.copiable-link}

:   The `trace`{.code} procedure starts tracing calls to the specified
    procedures. When a traced procedure is called, a line containing the
    procedure and its arguments is displayed (using the procedure call
    expression syntax). The line is indented with a sequence of vertical
    bars which indicate the nesting depth of the procedure's
    continuation. After the vertical bars is a greater-than sign which
    indicates that the evaluation of the call is starting.

    When a traced procedure returns a result, it is displayed with the
    same indentation as the call but without the greater-than sign. This
    makes it easy to match calls and results (the result of a given call
    is the value at the same indentation as the greater-than sign). If a
    traced procedure P1 performs a tail call to a traced procedure P2,
    then P2 will use the same indentation as P1. This makes it easy to
    spot tail calls. The special handling for tail calls is needed to
    preserve the space complexity of the program (i.e. tail calls are
    implemented as required by Scheme even when they involve traced
    procedures).

    The `untrace`{.code} procedure stops tracing calls to the specified
    procedures. When no argument is passed to the `trace`{.code}
    procedure, the list of procedures currently being traced is
    returned. The void object is returned by the `trace`{.code}
    procedure when it is passed one or more arguments. When no argument
    is passed to the `untrace`{.code} procedure stops all tracing and
    returns the void object. A compiled procedure may be traced but only
    if it is bound to a global variable.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (fact n) (if (< n 2) 1 (* n (fact (- n 1)))))
    > (trace fact)
    > (fact 5)
    | > (fact 5)
    | | > (fact 4)
    | | | > (fact 3)
    | | | | > (fact 2)
    | | | | | > (fact 1)
    | | | | | 1
    | | | | 2
    | | | 6
    | | 24
    | 120
    120
    > (trace -)
    *** WARNING -- Rebinding global variable "-" to an interpreted procedure
    > (define (fact-iter n r) (if (< n 2) r (fact-iter (- n 1) (* n r))))
    > (trace fact-iter)
    > (fact-iter 5 1)
    | > (fact-iter 5 1)
    | | > (- 5 1)
    | | 4
    | > (fact-iter 4 5)
    | | > (- 4 1)
    | | 3
    | > (fact-iter 3 20)
    | | > (- 3 1)
    | | 2
    | > (fact-iter 2 60)
    | | > (- 2 1)
    | | 1
    | > (fact-iter 1 120)
    | 120
    120
    > (trace)
    (#<procedure #2 fact-iter> #<procedure #3 -> #<procedure #4 fact>)
    > (untrace)
    > (fact 5)
    120
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**step** [¶](#index-step){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**step-level-set!** `level`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-step_002dlevel_002dset_0021){.copiable-link}

:   The `step`{.code} procedure enables single-stepping mode. After the
    call to `step`{.code} the computation will stop just before the
    interpreter executes the next evaluation step (as defined by
    `step-level-set!`{.code}). A nested REPL is then started. Note that
    because single-stepping is stopped by the REPL whenever the prompt
    is displayed it is pointless to enter `(step)`{.code} by itself. On
    the other hand entering `(begin (step) `{.code}`expr`{.variable
    .var}`)`{.code} will evaluate `expr`{.variable .var} in
    single-stepping mode.

    The procedure `step-level-set!`{.code} sets the stepping level which
    determines the granularity of the evaluation steps when
    single-stepping is enabled. The stepping level `level`{.variable
    .var} must be an exact integer in the range 0 to 7. At a level of 0,
    the interpreter ignores single-stepping mode. At higher levels the
    interpreter stops the computation just before it performs the
    following operations, depending on the stepping level:

    1.  procedure call
    2.  `delay`{.code} special form and operations at lower levels
    3.  `lambda`{.code} special form and operations at lower levels
    4.  `define`{.code} special form and operations at lower levels
    5.  `set!`{.code} special form and operations at lower levels
    6.  variable reference and operations at lower levels
    7.  constant reference and operations at lower levels

    The default stepping level is 7.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (fact n) (if (< n 2) 1 (* n (fact (- n 1)))))
    > (step-level-set! 1)
    > (begin (step) (fact 5))
    *** STOPPED IN (console)@3.15
    1> ,s
    | > (fact 5)
    *** STOPPED IN fact, (console)@1.22
    1> ,s
    | | > (< n 2)
    | | #f
    *** STOPPED IN fact, (console)@1.43
    1> ,s
    | | > (- n 1)
    | | 4
    *** STOPPED IN fact, (console)@1.37
    1> ,s
    | | > (fact (- n 1))
    *** STOPPED IN fact, (console)@1.22
    1> ,s
    | | | > (< n 2)
    | | | #f
    *** STOPPED IN fact, (console)@1.43
    1> ,s
    | | | > (- n 1)
    | | | 3
    *** STOPPED IN fact, (console)@1.37
    1> ,l
    | | | > (fact (- n 1))
    *** STOPPED IN fact, (console)@1.22
    1> ,l
    | | > (* n (fact (- n 1)))
    | | 24
    *** STOPPED IN fact, (console)@1.32
    1> ,l
    | > (* n (fact (- n 1)))
    | 120
    120
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**break** `proc`{.variable .var}`…`{.variable .def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-break){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**unbreak** `proc`{.variable .var}`…`{.variable .def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-unbreak){.copiable-link}

:   The `break`{.code} procedure places a breakpoint on each of the
    specified procedures. When a procedure is called that has a
    breakpoint, the interpreter will enable single-stepping mode (as if
    `step`{.code} had been called). This typically causes the
    computation to stop soon inside the procedure if the stepping level
    is high enough.

    The `unbreak`{.code} procedure removes the breakpoints on the
    specified procedures. With no argument, `break`{.code} returns the
    list of procedures currently containing breakpoints. The void object
    is returned by `break`{.code} if it is passed one or more arguments.
    With no argument `unbreak`{.code} removes all the breakpoints and
    returns the void object. A breakpoint can be placed on a compiled
    procedure but only if it is bound to a global variable.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (double x) (+ x x))
    > (define (triple y) (- (double (double y)) y))
    > (define (f z) (* (triple z) 10))
    > (break double)
    > (break -)
    *** WARNING -- Rebinding global variable "-" to an interpreted procedure
    > (f 5)
    *** STOPPED IN double, (console)@1.21
    1> ,b
    0  double                    (console)@1:21          +
    1  triple                    (console)@2:31          (double y)
    2  f                         (console)@3:18          (triple z)
    3  (interaction)             (console)@6:1           (f 5)
    1> ,e
    x = 5
    1> ,c
    *** STOPPED IN double, (console)@1.21
    1> ,c
    *** STOPPED IN f, (console)@3.29
    1> ,c
    150
    > (break)
    (#<procedure #3 -> #<procedure #4 double>)
    > (unbreak)
    > (f 5)
    150
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**generate-proper-tail-calls** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`new-value`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-generate_002dproper_002dtail_002dcalls){.copiable-link}

    \[Note: this procedure is DEPRECATED and will be removed in a future
    version of Gambit. Use the '`proper-tail-calls`{.sample .samp}'
    declaration instead.\]

    The parameter object `generate-proper-tail-calls`{.code} is bound to
    a boolean value controlling how the interpreter handles tail calls.
    When it is bound to `#f`{.code} the interpreter will treat tail
    calls like nontail calls, that is a new continuation will be created
    for the call. This setting is useful for debugging, because when a
    primitive signals an error the location information will point to
    the call site of the primitive even if this primitive was called
    with a tail call. The initial value of this parameter object is
    `#t`{.code}, which means that a tail call will reuse the
    continuation of the calling function.

    This parameter object only affects code that is subsequently
    processed by `load`{.code} or `eval`{.code}, or entered at the REPL.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}

:   This procedure pretty-prints `obj`{.variable .var} on the port
    `port`{.variable .var}. When `obj`{.variable .var} is a procedure
    created by the interpreter or a procedure created by code compiled
    with the declaration '`debug-source`{.sample .samp}', the
    procedure's source code is displayed. If it is not specified,
    `port`{.variable .var} defaults to the interaction channel (i.e. the
    output will appear at the REPL).

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (f g) (+ (time (g 100)) (time (g 1000))))
    > (pp f)
    (lambda (g)
      (+ (##time (lambda () (g 100)) '(g 100))
         (##time (lambda () (g 1000)) '(g 1000))))
    ```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**gc-report-set!** `report?`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-gc_002dreport_002dset_0021){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-GC .index-entry-id}

    This procedure controls the generation of reports during garbage
    collections. If the argument is true, a brief report of memory usage
    is generated after every garbage collection. It contains: the time
    taken for this garbage collection, the amount of memory allocated in
    megabytes since the program was started, the size of the heap in
    megabytes, the heap memory in megabytes occupied by live data, the
    proportion of the heap occupied by live data, and the number of
    bytes occupied by movable and nonmovable objects.

### 5.5 Console line-editing {#Console-line_002dediting-1 .section}

The console implements a simple Scheme-friendly line-editing
user-interface that is enabled by default. It offers parentheses
balancing, a history of previous commands, symbol completion, and
several emacs-compatible keyboard commands. The user's input is
displayed in a bold font and the output produced by the system is in a
plain font. The history of previous commands is saved in the file
`~/.gambit_history`{.sample .file}. It is restored when a REPL is
started.

Symbol completion is triggered with the tab key. When the cursor is
after a sequence of characters that can form a symbol, typing the tab
key will search the symbol table for the first symbol (in alphabetical
order) that begins with that sequence and insert that symbol. Typing the
tab key in succession will cycle through all symbols with that prefix.
When all possible symbols have been shown or there are no possible
completions, the text reverts to the uncompleted symbol and the bell is
rung.

Here are the keyboard commands available (where the '`M-`{.code}' prefix
means the escape key is typed and the '`C-`{.code}' prefix means the
control key is pressed):

`C-d`{.code}

:   Generate an end-of-file when the line is empty, otherwise delete
    character at cursor.

`delete `{.code}[`or backspace`{.code}]{.r}

:   Delete character before cursor.

`M-C-d`{.code}

:   Delete word forward and keep a copy of this text on the clipboard.

`M-delete`{.code}

:   Delete word backward and keep a copy of this text on the clipboard.

`M-backspace`{.code}

:   Delete S-expression backward and keep a copy of this text on the
    clipboard.

`C-a`{.code}

:   Move cursor to beginning of line.

`C-e`{.code}

:   Move cursor to end of line.

`C-b `{.code}[`or `{.code}*`left-arrow`{.code}*]{.r}

:   Move cursor left one character.

`M-b`{.code}

:   Move cursor left one word.

`M-C-b `{.code}[`or `{.code}`M-`{.code}*`left-arrow`{.code}*]{.r}

:   Move cursor left one S-expression.

`C-f `{.code}[`or `{.code}*`right-arrow`{.code}*]{.r}

:   Move cursor right one character.

`M-f`{.code}

:   Move cursor right one word.

`M-C-f `{.code}[`or `{.code}`M-`{.code}*`right-arrow`{.code}*]{.r}

:   Move cursor right one S-expression.

`C-p `{.code}[`or `{.code}`M-p`{.code}` or `{.code}*`up-arrow`{.code}*]{.r}

:   Move to previous line in history.

`C-n `{.code}[`or `{.code}`M-n`{.code}` or `{.code}*`down-arrow`{.code}*]{.r}

:   Move to next line in history.

`C-t`{.code}

:   Transpose character at cursor with previous character.

`M-t`{.code}

:   Transpose word after cursor with previous word.

`M-C-t`{.code}

:   Transpose S-expression after cursor with previous S-expression.

`C-l`{.code}

:   Clear console and redraw line being edited.

`C-`{.code}*`nul`{.code}*

:   Set the mark to the cursor.

`C-w`{.code}

:   Delete the text between the cursor and the mark and keep a copy of
    this text on the clipboard.

`C-k`{.code}

:   Delete the text from the cursor to the end of the line and keep a
    copy of this text on the clipboard.

`C-y`{.code}

:   Paste the text that is on the clipboard.

`F8`{.code}

:   Same as typing '`#||#,c;`{.sample .samp}' (REPL command to continue
    the computation).

`F9`{.code}

:   Same as typing '`#||#,-;`{.sample .samp}' (REPL command to move to
    newer frame).

`F10`{.code}

:   Same as typing '`#||#,+;`{.sample .samp}' (REPL command to move to
    older frame).

`F11`{.code}

:   Same as typing '`#||#,s;`{.sample .samp}' (REPL command to step the
    computation).

`F12`{.code}

:   Same as typing '`#||#,l;`{.sample .samp}' (REPL command to leap the
    computation).

On macOS, depending on your configuration, you may have to press the
`fn`{.code} key to access the function key `F12`{.code} and the
`option`{.code} key to access the other function keys.

On Microsoft Windows the clipboard is the system clipboard. This allows
text to be copied and pasted between the program and other applications.
On other operating systems the clipboard is internal to the program (it
is not integrated with the operating system).

### 5.6 Emacs interface {#Emacs-interface-1 .section}

[]{#index-Emacs .index-entry-id} []{#index-gambit_002eel
.index-entry-id}

Gambit comes with the Emacs package '`gambit.el`{.sample .samp}' which
provides a nice environment for running Gambit from within the Emacs
editor. This package filters the standard output of the Gambit process
and when it intercepts a location information (in the format
'`stream`{.variable .var}`@`{.sample .samp}`line`{.variable
.var}`.`{.sample .samp}`column`{.variable .var}' where
`stream`{.variable .var} is either '`(stdin)`{.sample .samp}' when the
expression was obtained from standard input, '`(console)`{.sample
.samp}' when the expression was obtained from the console, or a string
naming a file) it opens a window to highlight the corresponding
expression.

To use this package, make sure the file '`gambit.el`{.sample .samp}' is
accessible from your load-path and that the following lines are in your
'`.emacs`{.sample .samp}' file:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
(autoload 'gambit-inferior-mode "gambit" "Hook Gambit mode into cmuscheme.")
(autoload 'gambit-mode "gambit" "Hook Gambit mode into scheme.")
(add-hook 'inferior-scheme-mode-hook (function gambit-inferior-mode))
(add-hook 'scheme-mode-hook (function gambit-mode))
(setq scheme-program-name "gsi -:debug=-")
```
:::

Alternatively, if you don't mind always loading this package, you can
simply add this line to your '`.emacs`{.sample .samp}' file:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
(require 'gambit)
```
:::

You can then start an inferior Gambit process by typing
'`M-x run-scheme`{.sample .samp}'. The commands provided in
'`cmuscheme`{.sample .samp}' mode will be available in the Gambit
interaction buffer (i.e. '`*scheme*`{.sample .samp}') and in buffers
attached to Scheme source files. Here is a list of the most useful
commands (for a complete list type '`C-h m`{.sample .samp}' in the
Gambit interaction buffer):

`C-x C-e`{.code}

:   Evaluate the expression which is before the cursor (the expression
    will be copied to the Gambit interaction buffer).

`C-c C-z`{.code}

:   Switch to Gambit interaction buffer.

`C-c C-l`{.code}

:   Load a file (file attached to current buffer is default) using
    `(load `{.code}`file`{.variable .var}`)`{.code}.

`C-c C-k`{.code}

:   Compile a file (file attached to current buffer is default) using
    `(compile-file `{.code}`file`{.variable .var}`)`{.code}.

The file '`gambit.el`{.sample .samp}' provides these additional
commands:

`F8 `{.code}[*`or`{.code}*]{.r}` C-c c`{.code}

:   Continue the computation (same as typing '`#||#,c;`{.sample .samp}'
    to the REPL).

`F9 `{.code}[*`or`{.code}*]{.r}` C-c ]`{.code}

:   Move to newer frame (same as typing '`#||#,-;`{.sample .samp}' to
    the REPL).

`F10 `{.code}[*`or`{.code}*]{.r}` C-c [`{.code}

:   Move to older frame (same as typing '`#||#,+;`{.sample .samp}' to
    the REPL).

`F11 `{.code}[*`or`{.code}*]{.r}` C-c s`{.code}

:   Step the computation (same as typing '`#||#,s;`{.sample .samp}' to
    the REPL).

`F12 `{.code}[*`or`{.code}*]{.r}` C-c l`{.code}

:   Leap the computation (same as typing '`#||#,l;`{.sample .samp}' to
    the REPL).

`C-c _`{.code}

:   Removes the last window that was opened to highlight an expression.

The two keystroke version of these commands can be shortened to
'`M-c`{.sample .samp}', '`M-[`{.sample .samp}', '`M-]`{.sample .samp}',
'`M-s`{.sample .samp}', '`M-l`{.sample .samp}', and '`M-_`{.sample
.samp}' respectively by adding this line to your '`.emacs`{.sample
.samp}' file:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
(setq gambit-repl-command-prefix "\e")
```
:::

This is more convenient to type than the two keystroke '`C-c`{.sample
.samp}' based sequences but the purist may not like this because it does
not follow normal Emacs conventions.

Here is what a typical '`.emacs`{.sample .samp}' file will look like:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
(setq load-path ; add directory containing gambit.el
  (cons "/usr/local/Gambit/share/emacs/site-lisp"
        load-path))
(setq scheme-program-name "/tmp/gsi -:debug=-") ; if gsi not in executable path
(setq gambit-highlight-color "gray") ; if you don't like the default
(setq gambit-repl-command-prefix "\e") ; if you want M-c, M-s, etc
(require 'gambit)
```
:::
