### 6.2 Extensions to standard special forms {#Extensions-to-standard-special-forms-1 .section}

[special form: ]{.category-def}**lambda** [*`lambda-formals`{.variable .def-var-arguments}*]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[*`body`{.variable .def-var-arguments}*]{.r} [¶](#index-lambda){.copiable-link}\
[special form: ]{.category-def}**define** `(`{.variable .def-var-arguments}[*`variable`{.variable .def-var-arguments}*]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[*`define-formals`{.variable .def-var-arguments}*]{.r}`) `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[*`body`{.variable .def-var-arguments}*]{.r} [¶](#index-define){.copiable-link}

:   -   *lambda-formals* = `(`{.code} *formal-argument-list* `)`{.code}
        \| *r4rs-lambda-formals*
    -   *define-formals* = *formal-argument-list* \|
        *r4rs-define-formals*
    -   *formal-argument-list* = *dsssl-formal-argument-list* \|
        *rest-at-end-formal-argument-list*
    -   *dsssl-formal-argument-list* = *reqs* *opts* *rest* *keys*
    -   *rest-at-end-formal-argument-list* = *reqs* *opts* *keys* *rest*
        \| *reqs* *opts* *keys* `.`{.code} *rest-formal-argument*
    -   *reqs* = *required-formal-argument*\*
    -   *required-formal-argument* = *variable*
    -   *opts* = `#!optional`{.code} *optional-formal-argument*\* \|
        *empty*
    -   *optional-formal-argument* = *variable* \| `(`{.code} *variable*
        *initializer* `)`{.code}
    -   *rest* = `#!rest`{.code} *rest-formal-argument* \| *empty*
    -   *rest-formal-argument* = *variable*
    -   *keys* = `#!key`{.code} *keyword-formal-argument*\* \| *empty*
    -   *keyword-formal-argument* = *variable* \| `(`{.code} *variable*
        *initializer* `)`{.code}
    -   *initializer* = *expression*
    -   *r4rs-lambda-formals* = `(`{.code} *variable*\* `)`{.code} \|
        `(`{.code} *variable*+ `.`{.code} *variable* `)`{.code} \|
        *variable*
    -   *r4rs-define-formals* = *variable*\* \| *variable*\* `.`{.code}
        *variable*

    These forms are extended versions of the `lambda`{.code} and
    `define`{.code} special forms of standard Scheme. They allow the use
    of optional formal arguments, either positional or named, and
    support the syntax and semantics of the DSSSL standard.

    When the procedure introduced by a `lambda`{.code} (or
    `define`{.code}) is applied to a list of actual arguments, the
    formal and actual arguments are processed as specified in the R4RS
    if the *lambda-formals* (or *define-formals*) is a
    *r4rs-lambda-formals* (or *r4rs-define-formals*).

    If the *formal-argument-list* matches *dsssl-formal-argument-list*
    or *extended-formal-argument-list* they are processed as follows:

    a.  *Variable*s in *required-formal-argument*s are bound to
        successive actual arguments starting with the first actual
        argument. It shall be an error if there are fewer actual
        arguments than *required-formal-argument*s.
    b.  Next *variable*s in *optional-formal-argument*s are bound to
        remaining actual arguments. If there are fewer remaining actual
        arguments than *optional-formal-argument*s, then the variables
        are bound to the result of evaluating *initializer*, if one was
        specified, and otherwise to `#f`{.code}. The *initializer* is
        evaluated in an environment in which all previous formal
        arguments have been bound.
    c.  If `#!key`{.code} does not appear in the *formal-argument-list*
        and there is no *rest-formal-argument* then it shall be an error
        if there are any remaining actual arguments.
    d.  If `#!key`{.code} does not appear in the *formal-argument-list*
        and there is a *rest-formal-argument* then the
        *rest-formal-argument* is bound to a list of all remaining
        actual arguments.
    e.  If `#!key`{.code} appears in the *formal-argument-list* and
        there is no *rest-formal-argument* then there shall be an even
        number of remaining actual arguments. These are interpreted as a
        series of pairs, where the first member of each pair is a
        keyword specifying the argument name, and the second is the
        corresponding value. It shall be an error if the first member of
        a pair is not a keyword. It shall be an error if the argument
        name is not the same as a variable in a
        *keyword-formal-argument*. If the same argument name occurs more
        than once in the list of actual arguments, then the first value
        is used. If there is no actual argument for a particular
        *keyword-formal-argument*, then the variable is bound to the
        result of evaluating *initializer* if one was specified, and
        otherwise to `#f`{.code}. The *initializer* is evaluated in an
        environment in which all previous formal arguments have been
        bound.
    f.  If `#!key`{.code} appears in the *formal-argument-list* and
        there is a *rest-formal-argument* **before** the `#!key`{.code}
        then there may be an even or odd number of remaining actual
        arguments and the *rest-formal-argument* is bound to a list of
        all remaining actual arguments. Then, these remaining actual
        arguments are scanned from left to right in pairs, stopping at
        the first pair whose first element is not a keyword. Each pair
        whose first element is a keyword matching the name of a
        *keyword-formal-argument* gives the value (i.e. the second
        element of the pair) of the corresponding formal argument. If
        the same argument name occurs more than once in the list of
        actual arguments, then the first value is used. If there is no
        actual argument for a particular *keyword-formal-argument*, then
        the variable is bound to the result of evaluating *initializer*
        if one was specified, and otherwise to `#f`{.code}. The
        *initializer* is evaluated in an environment in which all
        previous formal arguments have been bound.
    g.  If `#!key`{.code} appears in the *formal-argument-list* and
        there is a *rest-formal-argument* **after** the `#!key`{.code}
        then there may be an even or odd number of remaining actual
        arguments. The remaining actual arguments are scanned from left
        to right in pairs, stopping at the first pair whose first
        element is not a keyword. Each pair shall have as its first
        element a keyword matching the name of a
        *keyword-formal-argument*; the second element gives the value of
        the corresponding formal argument. If the same argument name
        occurs more than once in the list of actual arguments, then the
        first value is used. If there is no actual argument for a
        particular *keyword-formal-argument*, then the variable is bound
        to the result of evaluating *initializer* if one was specified,
        and otherwise to `#f`{.code}. The *initializer* is evaluated in
        an environment in which all previous formal arguments have been
        bound. Finally, the *rest-formal-argument* is bound to the list
        of the actual arguments that were not scanned (i.e. after the
        last keyword/value pair).

    In all cases it is an error for a *variable* to appear more than
    once in a *formal-argument-list*.

    Note that this specification is compatible with the DSSSL language
    standard (i.e. a correct DSSSL program will have the same semantics
    when run with Gambit).

    It is unspecified whether variables receive their value by binding
    or by assignment. Currently the compiler and interpreter use
    different methods, which can lead to different semantics if
    `call-with-current-continuation`{.code} is used in an *initializer*.
    Note that this is irrelevant for DSSSL programs because
    `call-with-current-continuation`{.code} does not exist in DSSSL.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > ((lambda (#!rest x) x) 1 2 3)
    (1 2 3)
    > (define (f a #!optional b) (list a b))
    > (define (g a #!optional (b a) #!key (k (* a b))) (list a b k))
    > (define (h1 a #!rest r #!key k) (list a k r))
    > (define (h2 a #!key k #!rest r) (list a k r))
    > (f 1)
    (1 #f)
    > (f 1 2)
    (1 2)
    > (g 3)
    (3 3 9)
    > (g 3 4)
    (3 4 12)
    > (g 3 4 k: 5)
    (3 4 5)
    > (g 3 4 k: 5 k: 6)
    (3 4 5)
    > (h1 7)
    (7 #f ())
    > (h1 7 k: 8 9)
    (7 8 (k: 8 9))
    > (h1 7 k: 8 z: 9)
    (7 8 (k: 8 z: 9))
    > (h2 7)
    (7 #f ())
    > (h2 7 k: 8 9)
    (7 8 (9))
    > (h2 7 k: 8 z: 9)
    *** ERROR IN (console)@17.1 -- Unknown keyword argument passed to procedure
    (h2 7 k: 8 z: 9)
    ```
    :::

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### 6.3 Miscellaneous extensions {#Miscellaneous-extensions-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**subvector** `vector`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`start`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`end`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-subvector){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure is the vector analog of the `substring`{.code}
    procedure. It returns a newly allocated vector formed from the
    elements of the vector `vector`{.variable .var} beginning with index
    `start`{.variable .var} (inclusive) and ending with index
    `end`{.variable .var} (exclusive).

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (subvector '#(a b c d e f) 3 5)
    #(d e)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**vector-copy** `vector`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`start`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`end`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-vector_002dcopy){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure is like the procedure `subvector`{.code} except the
    parameter `start`{.variable .var} defaults to 0 and the parameter
    `end`{.variable .var} defaults to the length of the vector
    `vector`{.variable .var}. Note that the elements are not recursively
    copied.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define v1 '#(a b c d e f))
    > (define v2 (vector-copy v1))
    > v2
    #(a b c d e f)
    > (eq? v1 v2)
    #f
    > (vector-copy v1 3)
    #(d e f)
    > (vector-copy v1 3 5)
    #(d e)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**vector-copy!** `dest-vector`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`dest-start`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`vector`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`start`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`end`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-vector_002dcopy_0021){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure mutates the vector `dest-vector`{.variable .var}. It
    copies the elements of the vector `vector`{.variable .var} beginning
    with index `start`{.variable .var} (inclusive) and ending with index
    `end`{.variable .var} (exclusive) to the vector
    `dest-vector`{.variable .var} at index `dest-start`{.variable .var}.
    The parameters `start`{.variable .var} and `end`{.variable .var}
    default respectively to 0 and the length of the vector
    `vector`{.variable .var}. It is an error to copy more elements than
    will fit in the tail of the vector `dest-vector`{.variable .var}
    starting at index `dest-start`{.variable .var}. Note that the
    elements are not recursively copied.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define v1 (vector 10 11 12 13 14 15))
    > (define v2 (vector 20 21 22 23))
    > (vector-copy! v1 1 v2)
    > v1
    #(10 20 21 22 23 15)
    > (vector-copy! v1 1 v2 3)
    > v1
    #(10 23 21 22 23 15)
    > (vector-copy! v1 1 v2 1 3)
    > v1
    #(10 21 22 22 23 15)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**vector-append** `vector`{.variable .var}`…`{.variable .def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-vector_002dappend){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure is the vector analog of the `string-append`{.code}
    procedure. It returns a newly allocated vector whose elements form
    the concatenation of the given vectors.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define v '#(1 2 3))
    > (vector-append v v v)
    #(1 2 3 1 2 3 1 2 3)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**vector-concatenate** `lst`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`separator`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-vector_002dconcatenate){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns a newly allocated vector whose elements form
    the concatenation of all the vectors in the list `lst`{.variable
    .var}. If the optional vector `separator`{.variable .var} argument
    is specified, it will be added between all the elements of
    `lst`{.variable .var}. Without the `separator`{.variable .var}
    argument the result is the same as
    `(apply vector-append `{.code}[`lst`{.variable .var}]{.r}`)`{.code}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define v '#(1 2 3))
    > (vector-concatenate (list v v v))
    #(1 2 3 1 2 3 1 2 3)
    > (vector-concatenate (list v v v) '#(88 99))
    #(1 2 3 88 99 1 2 3 88 99 1 2 3)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**subvector-fill!** `vector`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`start`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`end`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`fill`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-subvector_002dfill_0021){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure is like `vector-fill!`{.code}, but fills a selected
    part of the given vector. It sets the elements of the vector
    `vector`{.variable .var}, beginning with index `start`{.variable
    .var} (inclusive) and ending with index `end`{.variable .var}
    (exclusive) to `fill`{.variable .var}. The value returned is
    unspecified.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define v (vector 'a 'b 'c 'd 'e 'f))
    > (subvector-fill! v 3 5 'x)
    > v
    #(a b c x x f)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**subvector-move!** `src-vector`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`src-start`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`src-end`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`dst-vector`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`dst-start`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-subvector_002dmove_0021){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure replaces part of the contents of vector
    `dst-vector`{.variable .var} with part of the contents of vector
    `src-vector`{.variable .var}. It copies elements from
    `src-vector`{.variable .var}, beginning with index
    `src-start`{.variable .var} (inclusive) and ending with index
    `src-end`{.variable .var} (exclusive) to `dst-vector`{.variable
    .var} beginning with index `dst-start`{.variable .var} (inclusive).
    The value returned is unspecified.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define v1 '#(1 2 3 4 5 6))
    > (define v2 (vector 'a 'b 'c 'd 'e 'f))
    > (subvector-move! v1 3 5 v2 1)
    > v2
    #(a 4 5 d e f)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**vector-shrink!** `vector`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`k`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-vector_002dshrink_0021){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure shortens the vector `vector`{.variable .var} so that
    its new size is `k`{.variable .var}. The value returned is
    unspecified.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define v (vector 'a 'b 'c 'd 'e 'f))
    > v
    #(a b c d e f)
    > (vector-shrink! v 3)
    > v
    #(a b c)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**vector-cas!** `vector`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`k`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`new-value`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`old-value`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-vector_002dcas_0021){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `vector-cas!`{.code} performs an atomic
    compare-and-swap operation on the element of vector
    `vector`{.variable .var} at index `k`{.variable .var}. If the
    element's value is `eq?`{.code} to `old-value`{.variable .var} then
    the element is changed to `new-value`{.variable .var}, otherwise the
    value does not change. Regardless what happened, the element's value
    prior to any change is returned. It is thus possible to detect a
    change by an explicit `eq?`{.code} test of the result.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define v (vector 'a))
    > (eq? 'foo (vector-cas! v 0 'b 'foo))
    #f
    > v
    #(a)
    > (eq? 'a (vector-cas! v 0 'b 'a))
    #t
    > v
    #(b)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**vector-inc!** `vector`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`k`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`step`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-vector_002dinc_0021){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `vector-inc!`{.code} performs an atomic incrementation
    on the element of vector `vector`{.variable .var} at index
    `k`{.variable .var}, which must be a fixnum. The parameter
    `step`{.variable .var} defaults to 1 and it is the fixnum value that
    is added (with wraparound) to the element. The procedure returns the
    value of the element prior to the incrementation.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define v (vector 100))
    > (vector-inc! v 0)
    100
    > (vector-inc! v 0)
    101
    > (vector-inc! v 0 5)
    102
    > v
    #(107)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**vector-set** `vector`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`k`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-vector_002dset){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `vector-set`{.code} returns a new copy of the vector
    `vector`{.variable .var} with the element at index `k`{.variable

    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define v1 (vector 10 11 12 13))

    #(10 11 99 13)
    > (eq? v1 v2)
    #f
    ```
    :::

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**string-prefix-length-ci** `s1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`s2`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`start1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`end1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`start2`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`end2`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-string_002dprefix_002dlength_002dci){.copiable-link}

:   The procedures `string-prefix-length`{.code} and
    `string-prefix-length-ci`{.code} return an exact nonnegative integer
    indicating the length of the longest substring of the strings
    `s1`{.variable .var} and `s2`{.variable .var} at the start of those
    strings that are `string=?`{.code} (for
    `string-prefix-length`{.code}) or `string-ci=?`{.code} (for
    `string-prefix-length-ci`{.code}). The optional exact nonnegative
    integer parameters `start1`{.variable .var}, `end1`{.variable .var},
    `start2`{.variable .var}, and `end2`{.variable .var} delimit the
    sections of the strings `s1`{.variable .var} and `s2`{.variable
    .var} that are considered. The parameters `start1`{.variable .var}
    and `start2`{.variable .var} default to 0, and the parameters
    `end1`{.variable .var} and `end2`{.variable .var} default to the
    length of the strings `s1`{.variable .var} and `s2`{.variable .var}
    respectively.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (string-prefix-length "abracadabra" "abrac123")
    5
    > (string-prefix-length "abracadabra" "abrac123" 7)
    4
    > (string-prefix-length "abracadabra" "AbRaC123")
    0
    > (string-prefix-length-ci "abracadabra" "AbRaC123")
    5
    ```
    :::

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**box** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-box){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**box?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-box_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**unbox** `box`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-unbox){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**set-box!** `box`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-set_002dbox_0021){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-boxes .index-entry-id}

    These procedures implement the *box* data type. A box is a cell
    containing a single mutable field. The lexical syntax of a box
    containing the object `obj`{.variable .var} is
    `#&`{.code}`obj`{.variable .var} (see [Box
    syntax](#Box-syntax){.pxref}).

    The procedure `box`{.code} returns a new box object whose content is
    initialized to `obj`{.variable .var}. The procedure `box?`{.code}
    returns `#t`{.code} if `obj`{.variable .var} is a box, and otherwise
    returns `#f`{.code}. The procedure `unbox`{.code} returns the
    content of the box `box`{.variable .var}. The procedure
    `set-box!`{.code} changes the content of the box `box`{.variable
    .var} to `obj`{.variable .var}. The procedure `set-box!`{.code}
    returns an unspecified value.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define b (box 0))
    > b
    #&0
    > (define (inc!) (set-box! b (+ (unbox b) 1)))
    > (inc!)
    > b
    #&1
    > (unbox b)
    1
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**keyword?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-keyword_003f){.copiable-link}\

:   []{#index-keywords .index-entry-id}

    These procedures implement the *keyword* data type. Keywords are
    similar to symbols but are self evaluating and distinct from the
    symbol data type. The lexical syntax of keywords is specified in
    [Keyword syntax](#Keyword-syntax){.ref}.

    The procedure `keyword?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code} if
    `obj`{.variable .var} is a keyword, and otherwise returns
    `#f`{.code}. The procedure `keyword->string`{.code} returns the name
    of `keyword`{.variable .var} as a string. The procedure
    `string->keyword`{.code} returns the keyword whose name is
    `string`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (keyword? 'color)
    #f
    > (keyword? color:)
    #t
    > (keyword->string color:)
    "color"
    > (string->keyword "color")
    color:
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[special form: ]{.category-def}**define-macro** `(`{.variable .def-var-arguments}[*`name`{.variable .def-var-arguments}*]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[*`define-formals`{.variable .def-var-arguments}*]{.r}`) `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[*`body`{.variable .def-var-arguments}*]{.r} [¶](#index-define_002dmacro){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-include .index-entry-id} []{#index-import .index-entry-id}

    Define *name* as a macro special form which expands into *body*.
    This form can only appear where a `define`{.code} form is
    acceptable. Macros are lexically scoped. The scope of a local macro
    definition extends from the definition to the end of the body of the
    surrounding binding construct. Macros defined at the top level of a
    Scheme module are only visible in that module. To have access to the
    macro definitions contained in a file, that file must be included
    either directly using the `include`{.code} special form or
    indirectly with the `import`{.code} special form. Macros which are
    visible from the REPL are also visible during the compilation of
    Scheme source files.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    (define-macro (unless test . body)
      `(if ,test #f (begin ,@body)))

    (define-macro (push var #!optional val)
      `(set! ,var (cons ,val ,var)))
    ```
    :::

    To examine the code into which a macro expands you can use the
    compiler's '`-expansion`{.sample .samp}' option or the `pp`{.code}
    procedure. For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define-macro (push var #!optional val)
        `(set! ,var (cons ,val ,var)))
    > (pp (lambda () (push stack 1) (push stack) (push stack 3)))
    (lambda ()
      (set! stack (cons 1 stack))
      (set! stack (cons #f stack))
      (set! stack (cons 3 stack)))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[special form: ]{.category-def}**define-syntax** [*`name`{.variable .def-var-arguments}*]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[*`expander`{.variable .def-var-arguments}*]{.r} [¶](#index-define_002dsyntax){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-define_002dsyntax-1 .index-entry-id}
    []{#index-syntax_002drules .index-entry-id}
    []{#index-syntax_002dcase .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002d_003as-1
    .index-entry-id}

    Define *name* as a macro special form whose expansion is specified
    by *expander*. This form is available only when the runtime option
    '`-:s`{.sample .samp}' is used. This option causes the loading of
    the `~~lib/syntax-case`{.code} support library, which is the Hieb
    and Dybvig portable `syntax-case`{.code} implementation which has
    been ported to the Gambit interpreter and compiler. Note that this
    implementation of `syntax-case`{.code} does not support special
    forms that are specific to Gambit.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    $ gsi -:s
    Gambit v4.9.5

    > (define-syntax unless
        (syntax-rules ()
          ((unless test body ...)
           (if test #f (begin body ...)))))
    > (let ((test 111)) (unless (= 1 2) (list test test)))
    (111 111)
    > (pp (lambda () (let ((test 111)) (unless (= 1 2) (list test test)))))
    (lambda () ((lambda (%%test14) (if (= 1 2) #f (list %%test14 %%test14))) 111))
    > (unless #f (pp xxx))
    *** ERROR IN (console)@7.16 -- Unbound variable: xxx
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**compilation-target** [¶](#index-compilation_002dtarget){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure can only be executed during the phase of the Scheme
    code's processing (*compilation*) that corresponds to macro
    expansion. Calls to this procedure are typically contained in macro
    definitions but they can also be contained in procedures that are
    called from a macro definition's body directly or indirectly.

    The result returned by the `compilation-target`{.code} procedure
    gives an indication of the target language of the *compilation*.
    This can be used to write macros that depend on the type of
    *compilation* and the target language.

    When the result is the symbol `T`{.variable .var} the macro
    expansion is in the context of compiling to the target language
    `T`{.variable .var}, e.g. `C`{.code}, `js`{.code}, etc. When the
    result is a single element list `(`{.code}`T`{.variable
    .var}`)`{.code} the macro expansion is for the interpreter which
    itself was compiled for the target language `T`{.variable .var},
    e.g. `(C)`{.code}, `(js)`{.code}, etc.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    $ cat ct.scm
    (define (level-0)
      (string-append "0: " (object->string (compilation-target))))

    (define-macro (test)

      (define (level-1)
        (string-append "1: " (object->string (compilation-target))))

      (define-macro (level-2)
        (string-append "2: " (object->string (compilation-target))))

      `(list ,(level-1) ,(level-2)))

    (pp (test))

    (pp (level-0)) ;; run time exception
    $ gsi ct.scm
    ("1: (C)" "2: (C)")
    *** ERROR IN level-0, "ct.scm"@2.40 -- Not in compilation context
    (compilation-target)
    $ gsc -target js -exe ct.scm
    $ ./ct
    ("1: js" "2: (C)")
    *** ERROR IN level-0 -- Not in compilation context
    (compilation-target)
    ```
    :::

    Regardless of whether '`ct.scm`{.sample .samp}' is being processed
    by the interpreter or the compiler, the body of the `level-0`{.code}
    procedure is not in a compilation context and in the body of the
    `level-2`{.code} macro the compilation target is `(C)`{.code}
    indicating that the macro expansion is being done for
    interpretation.

    During the execution of the `level-1`{.code} procedure, the
    compilation target will correspond to what is processing
    '`ct.scm`{.sample .samp}' (interpreter or compiler).

    Note that the compilation target can also be tested by the
    `cond-expand`{.code} special form.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[special form: ]{.category-def}**cond-expand** `ce-clause`{.variable .var}` …`{.variable .def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-cond_002dexpand){.copiable-link}

:   The `cond-expand`{.code} expression type provides a way to
    statically expand different expressions depending on the presence or
    absence of a set of features. A `ce-clause`{.variable .var} takes
    the following form:

    ::: example
    ``` example-preformatted
    (feature-requirement expression …)
    ```
    :::

    The last clause can be an "else clause," which has the form

    ::: example
    ``` example-preformatted
    (else expression)
    ```
    :::

    A `feature-requirement`{.variable .var} takes one of the following
    forms:

    -   `feature-identifier`{.variable .var}
    -   `(library `{.code}`library-name`{.variable .var}`)`{.code}
    -   `(and `{.code}`feature-requirement`{.variable .var}` …)`{.code}
    -   `(or `{.code}`feature-requirement`{.variable .var}` …)`{.code}
    -   `(not `{.code}`feature-requirement`{.variable .var}`)`{.code}
    -   `(compilation-target `{.code}`target`{.variable
        .var}` …)`{.code}

    The runtime system maintains a list of feature identifiers which are
    present, as well as a list of libraries which can be imported. The
    value of a `feature-requirement`{.variable .var} is determined by
    replacing each `feature-identifier`{.variable .var} and
    `(library `{.code}`library-name`{.variable .var}`)`{.code} on the
    runtime system's lists with `#t`{.code}. Similarly, `#t`{.code}
    replaces each `(compilation-target `{.code}`target`{.variable
    .var}` …)`{.code} for which one of the `target`{.variable .var}
    matches the expansion time value of `(compilation-target)`{.code},
    with a `target`{.variable .var} of `(_)`{.code} matching any single
    element list (i.e. the interpreter). All other
    `feature-identifier`{.variable .var},
    `(library `{.code}`library-name`{.variable .var}`)`{.code}, and
    `(compilation-target `{.code}`target`{.variable .var}` …)`{.code}
    are replaced with `#f`{.code}. The resulting expression is then
    evaluated as a Scheme boolean expression under the normal
    interpretation of `and`{.code}, `or`{.code}, and `not`{.code}.

    A `cond-expand`{.code} is then expanded by evaluating the
    `feature-requirement`{.variable .var}s of successive
    `ce-clause`{.variable .var}s in order until one of them returns
    `#t`{.code}. When a true clause is found, the corresponding
    `expression`{.variable .var}s are expanded to a `begin`{.code}, and
    the remaining clauses are ignored. If none of the
    `feature-requirement`{.variable .var}s evaluate to `#t`{.code}, then
    if there is an else clause, its `expression`{.variable .var}s are
    included. Otherwise, an expansion time error is raised. Unlike
    `cond`{.code}, `cond-expand`{.code} does not depend on the value of
    any variables.

    The feature identifier `gambit`{.code} is always true when the
    `cond-expand`{.code} is expanded by the Gambit interpreter or
    compiler.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (cond-expand (foobar 111) (gambit 222) (else 333))
    222
    > (cond-expand ((compilation-target js) 111) (else 222))
    222
    > (cond-expand ((compilation-target (_)) 111) (else 222))
    111
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[special form: ]{.category-def}**define-cond-expand-feature** `feature-identifier`{.variable .var}` …`{.variable .def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-define_002dcond_002dexpand_002dfeature){.copiable-link}

:   The `define-cond-expand-feature`{.code} form can be used to add the
    feature identifiers `feature-identifier`{.variable .var} ... to the
    list of features maintained by the runtime system. These features
    are usable for the expansion of following `cond-expand`{.code} forms
    in the same file of source code, and the processing of other files
    and REPL interactions.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (cond-expand (foobar 111) (gambit 222) (else 333))
    222
    > (define-cond-expand-feature foobar)
    > (cond-expand (foobar 111) (gambit 222) (else 333))
    111
    ```
    :::

[special form: ]{.category-def}**declare** [*`declaration`{.variable .def-var-arguments}*]{.r}`…`{.variable .def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-declare){.copiable-link}

:   This form introduces declarations to be used by the compiler
    (currently the interpreter ignores the declarations). This form can
    only appear where a `define`{.code} form is acceptable. Declarations
    are lexically scoped in the same way as macros. The following
    declarations are accepted by the compiler:

    `(`{.code}`dialect`{.variable .var}`)`{.code} [¶](#index-ieee_002dscheme){.copiable-link}

    :   []{#index-r4rs_002dscheme .index-entry-id}
        []{#index-r5rs_002dscheme .index-entry-id}
        []{#index-gambit_002dscheme .index-entry-id}

        Use the given dialect's semantics. `dialect`{.variable .var} can
        be: '`ieee-scheme`{.sample .samp}', '`r4rs-scheme`{.sample
        .samp}', '`r5rs-scheme`{.sample .samp}' or
        '`gambit-scheme`{.sample .samp}'.

    `(`{.code}`strategy`{.variable .var}`)`{.code} [¶](#index-block){.copiable-link}

    :   []{#index-separate .index-entry-id}

        Select block compilation or separate compilation. In block
        compilation, the compiler assumes that global variables defined
        in the current file that are not mutated in the file will never
        be mutated. `strategy`{.variable .var} can be: '`block`{.sample
        .samp}' or '`separate`{.sample .samp}'.

    `(`{.code}[`[`{.code}]{.r}`not`{.code}[`]`{.code}]{.r}` inline)`{.code} [¶](#index-inline){.copiable-link}

    :   Allow (or disallow) inlining of user procedures.

    `(`{.code}[`[`{.code}]{.r}`not`{.code}[`]`{.code}]{.r}` inline-primitives `{.code}`primitive`{.variable .var}`…)`{.code} [¶](#index-inline_002dprimitives){.copiable-link}

    :   The given primitives should (or should not) be inlined if
        possible (all primitives if none specified).

    `(inlining-limit `{.code}`n`{.variable .var}`)`{.code} [¶](#index-inlining_002dlimit){.copiable-link}

    :   Select the degree to which the compiler inlines user procedures.
        `n`{.variable .var} is the upper-bound, in percent, on code
        expansion that will result from inlining. Thus, a value of 300
        indicates that the size of the program will not grow by more
        than 300 percent (i.e. it will be at most 4 times the size of
        the original). A value of 0 disables inlining. The size of a
        program is the total number of subexpressions it contains (i.e.
        the size of an expression is one plus the size of its immediate
        subexpressions). The following conditions must hold for a
        procedure to be inlined: inlining the procedure must not cause
        the size of the call site to grow more than specified by the
        inlining limit, the site of definition (the `define`{.code} or
        `lambda`{.code}) and the call site must be declared as
        `(inline)`{.code}, and the compiler must be able to find the
        definition of the procedure referred to at the call site (if the
        procedure is bound to a global variable, the definition site
        must have a `(block)`{.code} declaration). Note that inlining
        usually causes much less code expansion than specified by the
        inlining limit (an expansion around 10% is common for
        `n`{.variable .var}=370).

    `(allocation-limit `{.code}`n`{.variable .var}`)`{.code} [¶](#index-allocation_002dlimit){.copiable-link}

    :   Indicate the maximum size of objects allocated with
        `make-vector`{.code}, `make-string`{.code},
        `make-u8vector`{.code}, etc. Knowing the maximum size allows the
        compiler to inline calls to these allocators for small
        allocations. This is only supported by the C target and only up
        to a size that is allowed for *movable objects* (typically on
        the order of 1-2 KB). When `n`{.variable .var} is an exact
        nonnegative integer it is the upper-bound on the number of
        elements of the allocated objects. When `n`{.variable .var} is
        `#t`{.code} a dynamic test of the size is done. When
        `n`{.variable .var} is `#f`{.code} the allocation operation is
        not inlined.

    `(`{.code}[`[`{.code}]{.r}`not`{.code}[`]`{.code}]{.r}` lambda-lift)`{.code} [¶](#index-lambda_002dlift){.copiable-link}

    :   Lambda-lift (or don't lambda-lift) locally defined procedures.

    `(`{.code}[`[`{.code}]{.r}`not`{.code}[`]`{.code}]{.r}` constant-fold)`{.code} [¶](#index-constant_002dfold){.copiable-link}

    :   Allow (or disallow) constant-folding of primitive procedures.

    `(`{.code}[`[`{.code}]{.r}`not`{.code}[`]`{.code}]{.r}` standard-bindings `{.code}`var`{.variable .var}`…)`{.code} [¶](#index-standard_002dbindings){.copiable-link}

    :   The given global variables are known (or not known) to be equal
        to the value defined for them in the dialect (all variables
        defined in the standard if none specified).

    `(`{.code}[`[`{.code}]{.r}`not`{.code}[`]`{.code}]{.r}` extended-bindings `{.code}`var`{.variable .var}`…)`{.code} [¶](#index-extended_002dbindings){.copiable-link}

    :   The given global variables are known (or not known) to be equal
        to the value defined for them in the runtime system (all
        variables defined in the runtime if none specified).

    `(`{.code}[`[`{.code}]{.r}`not`{.code}[`]`{.code}]{.r}` run-time-bindings `{.code}`var`{.variable .var}`…)`{.code} [¶](#index-run_002dtime_002dbindings){.copiable-link}

    :   The given global variables will be tested at run time to see if
        they are equal to the value defined for them in the runtime
        system (all variables defined in the runtime if none specified).

    `(`{.code}[`[`{.code}]{.r}`not`{.code}[`]`{.code}]{.r}` safe)`{.code} [¶](#index-safe){.copiable-link}

    :   Generate (or don't generate) code that will prevent fatal errors
        at run time. Note that in '`safe`{.sample .samp}' mode certain
        semantic errors will not be checked as long as they can't crash
        the system. For example the primitive `char=?`{.code} may
        disregard the type of its arguments in '`safe`{.sample .samp}'
        as well as '`not safe`{.sample .samp}' mode.

    `(`{.code}[`[`{.code}]{.r}`not`{.code}[`]`{.code}]{.r}` interrupts-enabled)`{.code} [¶](#index-interrupts_002denabled){.copiable-link}

    :   Generate (or don't generate) interrupt checks. Interrupt checks
        are used to detect user interrupts and also to check for stack
        overflows. Interrupt checking should not be turned off casually.

    `(`{.code}[`[`{.code}]{.r}`not`{.code}[`]`{.code}]{.r}` poll-on-return)`{.code} [¶](#index-poll_002don_002dreturn){.copiable-link}

    :   Generate (or don't generate) interrupt checks on procedure
        returns (when interrupt checking is enabled). This declaration
        has no effect on the behavior of interrupt checking on procedure
        calls, which is needed to guarantee that stack overflows are
        handled properly.

    `(`{.code}[`[`{.code}]{.r}`not`{.code}[`]`{.code}]{.r}` debug)`{.code} [¶](#index-debug-1){.copiable-link}

    :   []{#index-_002ddebug-1 .index-entry-id}

        Enable (or disable) the generation of debugging information. The
        kind of debugging information that is generated depends on the
        declarations '`debug-location`{.sample .samp}',
        '`debug-source`{.sample .samp}', and
        '`debug-environments`{.sample .samp}'. If any of the command
        line options '`-debug`{.sample .samp}',
        '`-debug-location`{.sample .samp}', '`-debug-source`{.sample
        .samp}' and '`-debug-environments`{.sample .samp}' are present,
        the '`debug`{.sample .samp}' declaration is initially enabled,
        otherwise it is initially disabled. When all kinds of debugging
        information are generated there is a substantial increase in the
        C compilation time and the size of the generated code. When
        compiling a 3000 line Scheme file it was observed that the total
        compilation time is 500% longer and the executable code is 150%
        bigger.

    `(`{.code}[`[`{.code}]{.r}`not`{.code}[`]`{.code}]{.r}` debug-location)`{.code} [¶](#index-debug_002dlocation-1){.copiable-link}

    :   []{#index-_002ddebug_002dlocation-1 .index-entry-id}

        Select (or deselect) source code location debugging information.
        When this declaration and the '`debug`{.sample .samp}'
        declaration are in effect, run time error messages indicate the
        location of the error in the source code file. If any of the
        command line options '`-debug-source`{.sample .samp}' and
        '`-debug-environments`{.sample .samp}' are present and
        '`-debug-location`{.sample .samp}' is absent, the
        '`debug-location`{.sample .samp}' declaration is initially
        disabled, otherwise it is initially enabled. When compiling a
        3000 line Scheme file it was observed that the total compilation
        time is 200% longer and the executable code is 60% bigger.

    `(`{.code}[`[`{.code}]{.r}`not`{.code}[`]`{.code}]{.r}` debug-source)`{.code} [¶](#index-debug_002dsource-1){.copiable-link}

    :   []{#index-_002ddebug_002dsource-1 .index-entry-id}

        Select (or deselect) source code debugging information. When
        this declaration and the '`debug`{.sample .samp}' declaration
        are in effect, run time error messages indicate the source code,
        the backtraces are more precise, and the `pp`{.code} procedure
        will display the source code of compiled procedures. If any of
        the command line options '`-debug-location`{.sample .samp}' and
        '`-debug-environments`{.sample .samp}' are present and
        '`-debug-source`{.sample .samp}' is absent, the
        '`debug-source`{.sample .samp}' declaration is initially
        disabled, otherwise it is initially enabled. When compiling a
        3000 line Scheme file it was observed that the total compilation
        time is 90% longer and the executable code is 90% bigger.

    `(`{.code}[`[`{.code}]{.r}`not`{.code}[`]`{.code}]{.r}` debug-environments)`{.code} [¶](#index-debug_002denvironments-1){.copiable-link}

    :   []{#index-_002ddebug_002denvironments-1 .index-entry-id}

        Select (or deselect) environment debugging information. When
        this declaration and the '`debug`{.sample .samp}' declaration
        are in effect, the debugger will have access to the environments
        of the continuations. In other words the local variables defined
        in compiled procedures (and not optimized away by the compiler)
        will be shown by the '`,e`{.sample .samp}' REPL command. If any
        of the command line options '`-debug-location`{.sample .samp}'
        and '`-debug-source`{.sample .samp}' are present and
        '`-debug-environments`{.sample .samp}' is absent, the
        '`debug-environments`{.sample .samp}' declaration is initially
        disabled, otherwise it is initially enabled. When compiling a
        3000 line Scheme file it was observed that the total compilation
        time is 70% longer and the executable code is 40% bigger.

    `(`{.code}[`[`{.code}]{.r}`not`{.code}[`]`{.code}]{.r}` proper-tail-calls)`{.code} [¶](#index-proper_002dtail_002dcalls){.copiable-link}

    :   []{#index-proper-tail_002dcalls-1 .index-entry-id}
        []{#index-tail_002dcalls-1 .index-entry-id}

        Generate (or don't generate) proper tail calls. When proper tail
        calls are turned off, tail calls are handled like non-tail
        calls, that is a continuation frame will be created for all
        calls regardless of their kind. This is useful for debugging
        because the caller of a procedure will be visible in the
        backtrace produced by the REPL's '`,b`{.sample .samp}' command
        even when the call is a tail call. Be advised that this does
        cause stack space to be consumed for tail calls which may cause
        the stack to overflow when performing long iterations with tail
        calls (whether they are expressed with a `letrec`{.code}, named
        `let`{.code}, `do`{.code}, or other form).

    `(`{.code}[`[`{.code}]{.r}`not`{.code}[`]`{.code}]{.r}` generative-lambda)`{.code} [¶](#index-generative_002dlambda-1){.copiable-link}

    :   []{#index-generative_002dlambda .index-entry-id}

        Force (or don't force) the creation of fresh closures when
        evaluating lambda-expressions. A fresh closure is always created
        when a lambda-expression has at least one free variable (that
        has not been eliminated by dead-code elimination or other
        compiler optimization) or when the generative-lambda declaration
        is turned on. When a lambda-expression has no free variables and
        the generative-lambda declaration is turned off, the value of
        the lambda-expression may be the same procedure (in the sense of
        `eq?`{.code}).

    `(`{.code}[`[`{.code}]{.r}`not`{.code}[`]`{.code}]{.r}` optimize-dead-local-variables)`{.code} [¶](#index-optimize_002ddead_002dlocal_002dvariables){.copiable-link}

    :   Remove (or preserve) the dead local variables in the
        environment. Preserving the dead local variables is useful for
        debugging because continuations will contain the dead variables.
        Thus, if the code is also compiled with the declaration
        '`debug-environments`{.sample .samp}' the '`,e`{.sample .samp}',
        '`,ed`{.sample .samp}', '`,be`{.sample .samp}', and
        '`,bed`{.sample .samp}' REPL commands will display the dead
        variables. On the other hand, preserving the dead local
        variables may change the space complexity of the program (i.e.
        some of the data that would normally be reclaimed by the garbage
        collector will not be). Note that due to other compiler
        optimizations some dead local variables may be removed
        regardless of this declaration.

    `(`{.code}[`[`{.code}]{.r}`not`{.code}[`]`{.code}]{.r}` optimize-dead-definitions `{.code}`var`{.variable .var}`…)`{.code} [¶](#index-optimize_002ddead_002ddefinitions){.copiable-link}

    :   Remove (or preserve) the dead toplevel definitions of the given
        global variables (all global variables if none specified). A
        toplevel definition is dead if it is not referenced by toplevel
        expressions of the program or toplevel definitions that aren't
        dead (regardless of the evaluation of its expression causing a
        side-effect). When a module is separately compiled and some of
        its definitions are only used by other modules, this declaration
        must be used with care to keep definitions that are used by
        other modules, for example if `foo`{.code} is referenced in
        another module the following declaration should be used:
        '`(declare (not optimize-dead-definitions foo))`{.sample
        .samp}'.

    `(`{.code}`number-type`{.variable .var}` `{.code}`primitive`{.variable .var}`…)`{.code} [¶](#index-generic){.copiable-link}

    :   []{#index-fixnum .index-entry-id} []{#index-flonum
        .index-entry-id}

        Numeric arguments and result of the specified primitives are
        known to be of the given type (all primitives if none
        specified). `number-type`{.variable .var} can be:
        '`generic`{.sample .samp}', '`fixnum`{.sample .samp}', or
        '`flonum`{.sample .samp}'.

    `(`{.code}`mostly-number-type`{.variable .var}` `{.code}`primitive`{.variable .var}`…)`{.code} [¶](#index-mostly_002dgeneric){.copiable-link}

    :   []{#index-mostly_002dfixnum .index-entry-id}
        []{#index-mostly_002dfixnum_002dflonum .index-entry-id}
        []{#index-mostly_002dflonum .index-entry-id}
        []{#index-mostly_002dflonum_002dfixnum .index-entry-id}

        Numeric arguments and result of the specified primitives are
        expected to be most often of the given type (all primitives if
        none specified). `mostly-number-type`{.variable .var} can be:
        '`mostly-generic`{.sample .samp}', '`mostly-fixnum`{.sample
        .samp}', '`mostly-fixnum-flonum`{.sample .samp}',
        '`mostly-flonum`{.sample .samp}', or
        '`mostly-flonum-fixnum`{.sample .samp}'.

    The default declarations used by the compiler are equivalent to:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    (declare
      (gambit-scheme)
      (separate)
      (inline)
      (inline-primitives)
      (inlining-limit 370)
      (allocation-limit #t)
      (constant-fold)
      (lambda-lift)
      (not standard-bindings)
      (not extended-bindings)
      (run-time-bindings)
      (safe)
      (interrupts-enabled)
      (not poll-on-return)
      (not debug)           ;; depends on debugging command line options
      (debug-location)      ;; depends on debugging command line options
      (debug-source)        ;; depends on debugging command line options
      (debug-environments)  ;; depends on debugging command line options
      (proper-tail-calls)
      (not generative-lambda)
      (optimize-dead-local-variables)
      (not optimize-dead-definitions)
      (generic)
      (mostly-fixnum-flonum)
    )
    ```
    :::

    These declarations are compatible with the semantics of R5RS Scheme
    and includes a few procedures from R6RS (mainly fixnum specific and
    flonum specific procedures). Typically used declarations that
    enhance performance, at the cost of violating the R5RS Scheme
    semantics, are: `(standard-bindings)`{.code}, `(block)`{.code},
    `(not safe)`{.code} and `(fixnum)`{.code}.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**continuation?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-continuation_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**continuation-capture** `proc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-continuation_002dcapture){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**continuation-graft** `cont`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`proc`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`obj`{.variable .var}`…`{.variable .def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-continuation_002dgraft){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**continuation-return** `cont`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`obj`{.variable .var}`…`{.variable .def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-continuation_002dreturn){.copiable-link}

:   These procedures provide access to internal first-class
    continuations which are represented using continuation objects
    distinct from procedures.

    The procedure `continuation?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code} when
    `obj`{.variable .var} is a continuation object and `#f`{.code}
    otherwise.

    The procedure `continuation-capture`{.code} is similar to the
    `call/cc`{.code} procedure but it represents the continuation with a
    continuation object. The `proc`{.variable .var} parameter must be a
    procedure accepting a single argument. The procedure
    `continuation-capture`{.code} reifies its continuation and calls
    `proc`{.variable .var} with the corresponding continuation object as
    its sole argument. Like for `call/cc`{.code}, the implicit
    continuation of the call to `proc`{.variable .var} is the implicit
    continuation of the call to `continuation-capture`{.code}.

    The procedure `continuation-graft`{.code} performs a procedure call
    to the procedure `proc`{.variable .var} with arguments
    `obj`{.variable .var}... and the implicit continuation corresponding
    to the continuation object `cont`{.variable .var}. The current
    continuation of the call to procedure `continuation-graft`{.code} is
    ignored.

    The procedure `continuation-return`{.code} invokes the implicit
    continuation corresponding to the continuation object
    `cont`{.variable .var} with the result(s) `obj`{.variable .var}....
    This procedure can be easily defined in terms of
    `continuation-graft`{.code}:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    (define (continuation-return cont . objs)
      (continuation-graft cont apply values objs))
    ```
    :::

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define x #f)
    > (define p (make-parameter 11))
    > (pp (parameterize ((p 22))
            (cons 33 (continuation-capture
                      (lambda (c) (set! x c) 44)))))
    (33 . 44)
    > x
    #<continuation #2>
    > (continuation-return x 55)
    (33 . 55)
    > (continuation-graft x (lambda () (expt 2 10)))
    (33 . 1024)
    > (continuation-graft x expt 2 10)
    (33 . 1024)
    > (continuation-graft x (lambda () (p)))
    (33 . 22)
    > (define (map-sqrt1 lst)
        (call/cc
         (lambda (k)
           (map (lambda (x)
                  (if (< x 0)
                      (k 'error)
                      (sqrt x)))
                lst))))
    > (map-sqrt1 '(1 4 9))
    (1 2 3)
    > (map-sqrt1 '(1 -1 9))
    error
    > (define (map-sqrt2 lst)
        (continuation-capture
         (lambda (c)
           (map (lambda (x)
                  (if (< x 0)
                      (continuation-return c 'error)
                      (sqrt x)))
                lst))))
    > (map-sqrt2 '(1 4 9))
    (1 2 3)
    > (map-sqrt2 '(1 -1 9))
    error
    ```
    :::

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**display-exception-in-context**
`exc`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`cont`{.variable

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**display-continuation-backtrace** `cont`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`port`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`display-env?`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`all-frames?`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`max-head`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`max-tail`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`depth`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-display_002dcontinuation_002dbacktrace){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `display-continuation-backtrace`{.code} displays the
    frames of the continuation corresponding to the continuation object
    `cont`{.variable .var} on the port `port`{.variable .var}. If it is
    not specified, `port`{.variable .var} defaults to the current
    output-port. The frames are displayed in the same format as the
    REPL's '`,b`{.sample .samp}' command.

    The parameter `display-env?`{.variable .var}, which defaults to
    `#f`{.code}, controls if the frames are displayed with its
    environment (the variables accessible and their bindings).

    The parameter `all-frames?`{.variable .var}, which defaults to
    `#f`{.code}, controls which frames are displayed. Some frames of
    ancillary importance, such as internal frames created by the
    interpreter, are not displayed when `all-frames?`{.variable .var} is
    `#f`{.code}. Otherwise all frames are displayed.

    The parameters `max-head`{.variable .var} and `max-tail`{.variable
    .var}, which default to 10 and 4 respectively, control how many
    frames are displayed at the head and tail of the continuation.

    The parameter `depth`{.variable .var}, which defaults to 0, causes
    the frame numbers to be offset by that value.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define x #f)
    > (define (fib n)
        (if (< n 2)
            (continuation-capture
             (lambda (c) (set! x c) 1))
            (+ (fib (- n 1))
               (fib (- n 2)))))
    > (fib 10)
    89
    > (display-continuation-backtrace x)
    0  fib             (console)@7:12     (fib (- n 2))
    1  fib             (console)@7:12     (fib (- n 2))
    2  fib             (console)@7:12     (fib (- n 2))
    3  fib             (console)@7:12     (fib (- n 2))
    4  fib             (console)@7:12     (fib (- n 2))
    5  (interaction)   (console)@8:1      (fib 10)
    #f
    > (display-continuation-backtrace x (current-output-port) #f #t)
    0  fib             (console)@7:12     (fib (- n 2))
    1  fib             (console)@6:9      (+ (fib (- n 1)) (fib (- ...
    2  fib             (console)@7:12     (fib (- n 2))
    3  fib             (console)@6:9      (+ (fib (- n 1)) (fib (- ...
    4  fib             (console)@7:12     (fib (- n 2))
    5  fib             (console)@6:9      (+ (fib (- n 1)) (fib (- ...
    6  fib             (console)@7:12     (fib (- n 2))
    7  fib             (console)@6:9      (+ (fib (- n 1)) (fib (- ...
    8  fib             (console)@7:12     (fib (- n 2))
    9  fib             (console)@6:9      (+ (fib (- n 1)) (fib (- ...
    ...
    13 ##with-no-result-expected-toplevel
    14 ##repl-debug
    15 ##repl-debug-main
    16 ##kernel-handlers
    #f
    > (display-continuation-backtrace x (current-output-port) #t #f)
    0  fib             (console)@7:12     (fib (- n 2))
            n = 2
    1  fib             (console)@7:12     (fib (- n 2))
            n = 4
    2  fib             (console)@7:12     (fib (- n 2))
            n = 6
    3  fib             (console)@7:12     (fib (- n 2))
            n = 8
    4  fib             (console)@7:12     (fib (- n 2))
            n = 10
    5  (interaction)   (console)@8:1      (fib 10)
    #f
    > (display-continuation-backtrace x (current-output-port) #f #f 2 1 100)
    100 fib            (console)@7:12     (fib (- n 2))
    101 fib            (console)@7:12     (fib (- n 2))
    ...
    105 (interaction)  (console)@8:1      (fib 10)
    #f
    ```
    :::

## 7 Modules {#Modules-1 .chapter}

Gambit supports multiple modularization approaches and constructs:
legacy modules, primitive modules and R7RS compatible modules. These are
described in that order, which corresponds to increased abstraction
level. Unless there is a need for detailed control over the modules, it
is best to use the R7RS compatible module system for the development of
new code.

-   [Legacy Modules](#Legacy-Modules){accesskey="1"}
-   [Primitive Modules](#Primitive-Modules){accesskey="2"}
-   [Primitive Procedures](#Primitive-Procedures){accesskey="3"}
-   [R7RS Compatible Modules](#R7RS-Compatible-Modules){accesskey="4"}
-   [Installing Modules](#Installing-Modules){accesskey="5"}
-   [Compiling Modules](#Compiling-Modules){accesskey="6"}

### 7.1 Legacy Modules {#Legacy-Modules-1 .section}

The legacy way of modularizing code, which was popular up to R5RS, is
still supported by Gambit. It consists of using the `load`{.code}
procedure and the `include`{.code} form. We discuss it first to
introduce some useful terms and explain the shortcomings of this
modularization approach.

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**load** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-load-1){.copiable-link}

:   The `load`{.code} procedure's `path`{.variable .var} argument, a
    string, specifies the location in the file system of a file to load.
    Loading a file executes the code contained in the file, which is
    either source code or compiled code (a dynamically loadable *object
    file* created by the Gambit Scheme compiler, see the procedure
    `compile-file`{.code}). When `path`{.variable .var} has no extension
    the `load`{.code} procedure first attempts to load the file with no
    extension as a Scheme source file. If that file doesn't exist it
    will search for both a source file and an object file. The object
    file's path is obtained by adding to `path`{.variable .var} a
    '`.o`{.sample .samp}`n`{.variable .var}' extension with the highest
    consecutive version number starting with 1. The source file's path
    is obtained by adding to `path`{.variable .var} the file extensions
    '`.sld`{.sample .samp}', '`.scm`{.sample .samp}' and '`.six`{.sample
    .samp}' (the first found is the source file). If both a source file
    and an object file exist, then the one with the latest modification
    time is loaded. Otherwise the file that is found is loaded. When
    `path`{.variable .var} has an extension, the `load`{.code} procedure
    will only attempt to load the file with that specific extension.
    After executing the code contained in the file, the `load`{.code}
    procedure returns the path of the file that was loaded.

    When a source code file is loaded its extension is used to determine
    how it is parsed, unless the file's first line is a special script
    line (see [Scheme scripts](#Scheme-scripts){.ref}). When the
    extension is different from '`.six`{.sample .samp}' the content of
    the file is parsed using the normal Scheme prefix syntax. When the
    extension is '`.six`{.sample .samp}' the content of the file is
    parsed using the Scheme infix syntax extension (see [Scheme infix
    syntax extension](#Scheme-infix-syntax-extension){.ref}).

    Due to operating system limitations, loading a given '`.o`{.sample
    .samp}`n`{.variable .var}' object file more than once in the same
    process is not supported. It is possible however to recompile the
    source code file to create a new '`.o`{.sample .samp}`m`{.variable
    .var}' object file with `m`{.variable .var} \> `n`{.variable .var}
    and load that object file.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    $ cat my-mod.scm
    (define (double x) (* x 2))
    (display "my-mod has finished loading!!!\n")
    $ gsi
    Gambit v4.9.5

    > (load "my-mod")
    my-mod has finished loading!!!
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/my-mod.scm"
    > (double 21)
    42
    > (load "my-mod.scm")
    my-mod has finished loading!!!
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/my-mod.scm"
    > ,q
    $ gsc my-mod
    $ gsi
    Gambit v4.9.5

    > (load "my-mod")
    my-mod has finished loading!!!
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/my-mod.o1"
    > (double 21)
    42
    > (load "my-mod")
    *** ERROR IN (console)@3.1 -- Can't load a given object file more than once
    (load "my-mod")
    1>
    ```
    :::

    Note that any macro definition in the loaded file is local to the
    file and is not visible from the REPL or other files that loaded
    this file. The `include`{.code} form can be used to access the
    macros defined in another file.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[special form: ]{.category-def}**include** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-include-1){.copiable-link}\
[special form: ]{.category-def}**##include** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-_0023_0023include){.copiable-link}

:   The *path* argument must be a string specifying the location of an
    existing file containing Scheme source code. Relative paths are
    relative to the file that contains the `include`{.code} form. The
    `include`{.code} special form splices the content of the specified
    source file. This form can only appear where a `define`{.code} form
    is acceptable, i.e. at top level or in the body of a binding form.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    $ cat my-defs.scm
    (define-macro (double x) `(* ,x 2))
    (define (quad y) (double (double y)))
    (display "howdy!\n")
    $ cat my-includer.scm 
    (define (f x)
      (include "my-defs.scm")
      (+ 1 (quad x)))
    $ gsi
    Gambit v4.9.5

    > (load "my-includer")
    "/Users/feeley/udem-dlteam/gambit/my-includer.scm"
    > (f 10)
    howdy!
    41
    > (f 20)
    howdy!
    81
    ```
    :::

With legacy modularization, the code that implements the module's
functionality is put in a source code file and this module is accessed
by other code by using a `load`{.code} or `include`{.code} of that file.
Here is an example of an `angle0`{.code} module that is used by an
`app0`{.code} main program:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
;;;---------------------------------------- file: angle0/angle0.scm
(define factor (/ (atan 1) 45))
(define (deg->rad x) (* x factor))
(define (rad->deg x) (/ x factor))

;;;---------------------------------------- file: app0.scm
(load "angle0/angle0.scm")   ;; or (include "angle0/angle0.scm")
(println "90 degrees is " (deg->rad 90) " radians")

;; run with:  gsi app0.scm
```
:::

This modularization approach has a number of issues:

-   It hinders code sharing among different programs and users because a
    shared module's location in the filesystem must be known to all
    modules loading or including it. In the above example the path
    `"angle0/angle0.scm"`{.code} is relative so the `load`{.code}
    procedure will resolve the path incorrectly if the program executes
    `(current-directory "...")`{.code} before calling `load`{.code}.
-   When a module is needed by more than one other module there will be
    code duplication, redundant evaluation/compilation, and probably
    incorrect execution if the module has side effects that should only
    happen once (displaying a message, opening a database on the
    filesystem, initializing the module's state, etc). Moreover, when
    the module has been compiled to an object file it can't be loaded
    more than once.
-   All the definitions of a module will be put in the global
    environment (including top level macro definitions when using a top
    level `include`{.code} but not when using `load`{.code}). This
    pollutes the global environment with definitions that were not
    intended to be exported by the module's designer, such as the
    variable `factor`{.code} in the above example that is only meant to
    be used by the `deg->rad`{.code} and `rad->deg`{.code} procedures.
    Other modules may also need a `factor`{.code} variable internally,
    for instance to convert distances from the metric to the english
    system. Nothing prevents such accidental clashes.

#### 7.2.1 `##demand-module`{.code} and `##supply-module`{.code} forms {#g_t_0023_0023demand_002dmodule-and-_0023_0023supply_002dmodule-forms-1 .subsection}

The `##demand-module`{.code} form offers a way to avoid the issues of
multiple loading and filesystem localization of modules. The sole
parameter of this form is an (unevaluated) symbol that identifies the
module on which the module containing the `##demand-module`{.code}
depends. When a module `A`{.code} contains a
`(##demand-module B)`{.code}, Gambit's runtime system will ensure that
module `B`{.code} is loaded before module `A`{.code} is loaded. It also
registers the module in a cache when it is loaded so that it is loaded
exactly once. In other words the `##demand-module`{.code} form expresses
the requirement that the current module needs the functionality of
another module. A module can contain multiple uses of
`##demand-module`{.code} and possibly more than once for a given module.
The `##demand-module`{.code} form can appear anywhere a `define`{.code}
can appear. There is also a related `##supply-module`{.code} form that
should appear in the module to declare the module's identity.

Gambit's runtime system searches for modules in various directories, by
default in `~~lib`{.code} then in `~~userlib`{.code} (which maps to
`~/.gambit_userlib`{.code} by default). These two directories are where
builtin modules and user installed modules are located respectively. The
source code for a module **`M`{.code}** is searched, in each of the
*module search order* directories, first in
**`M/M`{.code}**`.ext`{.variable .var} and then in
**`M`{.code}**`.ext`{.variable .var}, where `.ext`{.variable .var} is
one of the acceptable Scheme source code file extensions (`.sld`{.code},
`.scm`{.code}, `.six`{.code}, etc). The list of module search order
directories can be extended with the `-:search=`{.code}`DIR`{.variable
.var} runtime option or by a command line argument to `gsi`{.code} and
`gsc`{.code} that ends with a path separator or a '`.`{.sample .samp}'.

With `##demand-module`{.code} and `##supply-module`{.code} the previous
example can be rewritten like this:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
;;;---------------------------------------- file: angle1/angle1.scm
(##supply-module angle1) ;; declare that this is the module angle1
(define factor (/ (atan 1) 45))
(define (deg->rad x) (* x factor))
(define (rad->deg x) (/ x factor))

;;;---------------------------------------- file: app1.scm
(##demand-module angle1) ;; declare dependency on module angle1
(println "90 degrees is " (deg->rad 90) " radians")

;; run with either:  gsi . app1.scm
;;              or:  gsi -:search=. app1.scm
;;
;; or install the angle1 module to avoid the . and -:search=.
```
:::

#### 7.2.2 `##namespace`{.code} and `##import`{.code} forms {#g_t_0023_0023namespace-and-_0023_0023import-forms-1 .subsection}

[special form: ]{.category-def}**namespace** `…`{.variable
.def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-namespace){.copiable-link}

[special form: ]{.category-def}**##namespace** `…`{.variable
.def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-_0023_0023namespace){.copiable-link}

[special form: ]{.category-def}**import** `module-ref`{.variable .var}
[¶](#index-import-1){.copiable-link}

[special form: ]{.category-def}**##import** `module-ref`{.variable .var}
[¶](#index-_0023_0023import){.copiable-link}

The `##namespace`{.code} form offers a way to avoid name clashes by
specifying a mapping between identifiers. The mapping it specifies has
the same scope as a macro definition: it applies to the rest of a source
code file if it is at top level, or applies to the rest of the body of a
binding form if it is used in the body of a binding form. The call
`(##namespace ("foo#" a b))`{.code} specifies that a reference to
`a`{.code} becomes `foo#a`{.code} and a reference to `b`{.code} becomes
`foo#b`{.code}. Here `foo#`{.code} is the namespace. Finer control over
the mapping is possible by using aliases as in
`(##namespace ("foo#" (a bar) b))`{.code} which maps `a`{.code} to
`foo#bar`{.code} and `b`{.code} to `foo#b`{.code}. Multiple namespace
specifications can appear in the body of the `##namespace`{.code} form.
When no identifiers are specified, the mapping maps all identifiers not
containing `#`{.code} to the namespace. For example in the scope of
`(##namespace ("foo#"))`{.code} the reference `x`{.code} maps to
`foo#x`{.code} and the reference `bar#x`{.code} remains unchanged.

Given that modules are identified by a unique symbol, the global names
defined by a module `M`{.code} can be put in the namespace `M#`{.code}
to avoid name clashes with other modules. The source code of module
`M`{.code} and the modules depending on `M`{.code} can explicitly prefix
the global names defined by `M`{.code} with `M#`{.code} or use a
`##namespace`{.code} form to make this prefixing implicit. By convention
the namespace definition for the identifiers exported by module
`M`{.code} is specified in the source code file `M#.scm`{.code} in the
same directory as the `M.scm`{.code} file.

Using this convention and the `include`{.code} and `##namespace`{.code}
forms, the previous example can be rewritten like this:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
;;;---------------------------------------- file: angle2/angle2#.scm
(##namespace ("angle2#" deg->rad rad->deg))

;;;---------------------------------------- file: angle2/angle2.scm
(include "angle2#.scm")
(##namespace ("angle2#" factor))
(##supply-module angle2)
(define factor (/ (atan 1) 45))
(define (deg->rad x) (* x factor))
(define (rad->deg x) (/ x factor))

;;;---------------------------------------- file: app2.scm
(include "angle2/angle2#.scm")
(##demand-module angle2)
(println "90 degrees is " (deg->rad 90) " radians")
```
:::

Note that the parameters of the two `include`{.code} forms are
different, but this is correct because the paths are relative to the
file containing the `include`{.code} form. However the module
localization problem has been reintroduced for the file
`angle2/angle2#.scm`{.code}.

This problem can be solved using the `##import`{.code} form that
combines the semantics of the `include`{.code} and
`##demand-module`{.code} forms. The call `(##import M)`{.code} will use
the module search order directories to locate the source code file of
module `M`{.code} and will expand to an `include`{.code} of the "hash"
file `M#`{.code}`.ext`{.variable .var} if it exists in the same
directory, and a `(##demand-module M)`{.code}.

In addition, a builtin module `gambit`{.code} exists that contains all
the global names exported by the runtime library. The `gambit`{.code}
module's "hash" file `gambit#.scm`{.code} contains a
`##namespace`{.code} form that lists all the names exported by the
runtime library in an empty namespace:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
;;;---------------------------------------- file: ~~lib/gambit#.scm
(##namespace ("" define if quote set! cons car cdr + - * / ;; etc
```
:::

Using the `gambit`{.code} module and the `##import`{.code} form, the
previous example can be rewritten like this:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
;;;---------------------------------------- file: angle3/angle3#.scm
(##namespace ("angle3#" deg->rad rad->deg))

;;;---------------------------------------- file: angle3/angle3.scm
(##namespace ("angle3#")) ;; map all identifiers to angle3# namespace
(##import gambit)         ;; except those defined by Gambit's RTS
(##supply-module angle3)
(define factor (/ (atan 1) 45))
(define (deg->rad x) (* x factor))
(define (rad->deg x) (/ x factor))

;;;---------------------------------------- file: app3.scm
(##import angle3)
(println "90 degrees is " (deg->rad 90) " radians")
```
:::

In this example the `(##import angle3)`{.code} takes care of the
namespace mapping and the loading of `angle3.scm`{.code} because it is
equivalent to:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
(begin
 (##include "angle3/angle3#.scm")
 (##demand-module angle3))
```
:::

#### 7.2.3 Macros {#Macros-1 .subsection}

In addition to procedures, a module `M`{.code} may export macros. The
file `M#.scm`{.code} is the designated place to put exported macro
definitions. These macro definitions will essentially be copied at the
point where the `##import`{.code} of the module is done. Macros that are
needed strictly for the implementation of a module may be defined in the
file `M.scm`{.code} and these macro definitions will not be visible
elsewhere. Note that the macros defined with `define-macro`{.code} are
not hygienic, so the macro definition writer should take care to
explicitly indicate what identifiers resolve to using fully qualified
identifiers (i.e. containing a `#`{.code} sign).

To explain these issues, lets extend our example module in the following
ways. First we want the module to export the macros `sind`{.code} and
`asind`{.code} that are like the `sin`{.code} and `asin`{.code}
procedures but use degrees instead of radians. Note that it would be a
better design for `sind`{.code} and `asind`{.code} to be procedures, but
we'll implement them as macros for the sake of the example. Second we
want the procedures `deg->rad`{.code} and `rad->deg`{.code} to check
that their argument is a real number using a `check-real`{.code} macro.

In a setting where name clashes are not an issue these macros can be
defined as follows:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
(define-macro (sind x) `(sin (deg->rad ,x)))
(define-macro (asind x) `(rad->deg (asin ,x)))
(define-macro (check-real x y)
  `(if (real? ,x) ,y (error "not real!")))
```
:::

Name clashes will occur when the locations where these macros are called
are in the scope of new bindings for `sin`{.code}, `deg->rad`{.code},
`if`{.code}, `error`{.code}, etc which are identifiers used in the
expanded code. A name clash can also happen for the name
`define-macro`{.code} itself. To remove the possibility of name clashes
the `##namespace`{.code} form and fully qualified identifiers can be
used. All the Gambit special forms, such as `let`{.code}, `if`{.code},
and `define-macro`{.code}, have a fully qualified version
(`##let`{.code}, `##if`{.code}, and `##define-macro`{.code}). Gambit
predefined procedures, such as `sin`{.code}, `real?`{.code}, and
`error`{.code}, don't necessarily have a fully qualified version (some
do and some don't) but an empty namespace definition in a `##let`{.code}
form can be used to avoid the clash, i.e.
`(##let () (##namespace ("") sin))`{.code} refers to the global variable
`sin`{.code} whatever scope it is in. With these forms our example can
be written like this:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
;;;---------------------------------------- file: angle4/angle4#.scm
(##namespace ("angle4#" deg->rad rad->deg))
(##define-macro (sind x) `((##let () (##namespace ("")) sin)
                           (angle4#deg->rad ,x)))
(##define-macro (asind x) `(angle4#rad->deg
                            ((##let () (##namespace ("")) asin) ,x)))

;;;---------------------------------------- file: angle4/angle4.scm
(##namespace ("angle4#")) ;; map all identifiers to angle4# namespace
(##import gambit)         ;; except those defined by Gambit's RTS
(##supply-module angle4)
(##define-macro (check-real x y)
  `(##if ((##let () (##namespace ("")) real?) ,x)
         ,y
         ((##let () (##namespace ("")) error) "not real!")))
(define factor (/ (atan 1) 45))
(define (deg->rad x) (check-real x (* x factor)))
(define (rad->deg x) (check-real x (/ x factor)))

;;;---------------------------------------- file: app4.scm
(##import angle4)
(println "90 degrees is " (deg->rad 90) " radians")
(println "sind(90) is " (sind 90))
```
:::
