### 7.3 Primitive Procedures {#Primitive-Procedures-1 .section}

Identifiers with a `##`{.code} prefix are not valid identifiers
according to RnRS. This means that code containing `##`{.code} prefixed
identifiers cannot be processed by and shared with other Scheme
implementations. They are hard to read by people that aren't used to
that extension. Moreover the code lacks abstraction and safety because
using `##car`{.code} rather than `car`{.code} has a specific meaning:
avoiding type checks. Consequently it is hard to \"turn on\" safe
execution of the code when it needs to be debugged. Many parts of the
runtime library are expressed at a low level of abstraction (with
`##`{.code} prefixed identifiers) even when not required.

For those reasons `##`{.code} prefixed identifiers should be used
sparingly in new code, and existing code should gradually be rewritten
to avoid them. The primitive operations which are used to build
higher-level operations are all defined as procedures with a `##`{.code}
prefix.

The file `~~lib/_gambit#.scm`{.code} contains the definition of the
`primitive`{.code} macro whose purpose is to abstract from the
`##`{.code} prefix. The call `(primitive foo)`{.code} is equivalent to
`##foo`{.code} and `(primitive (foo a b))`{.code} is equivalent to
`(##foo a b)`{.code}. The file `~~lib/_gambit#.scm`{.code} also contains
the definition of the `standard`{.code} macro whose purpose is similar,
but forces the use of the empty namespace. The call
`(standard +)`{.code} is equivalent to
`(##let () (##namespace ("" +)) +)`{.code} and
`(standard (+ a b))`{.code} is equivalent to
`((##let () (##namespace ("" +)) +) a b)`{.code}. Code that uses the
`primitive`{.code} and `standard`{.code} macros can be ported to other
Scheme implementations by defining implementation specific
`primitive`{.code} and `standard`{.code} macros that implement the
appropriate mapping for that implementation.

The file `~~lib/_gambit#.scm`{.code} also contains definitions for the
`define-procedure`{.code} and `define-primitive`{.code} macros. The
`primitive`{.code} and `standard`{.code} macros work in tandem with the
`define-procedure`{.code} and `define-primitive`{.code} macros and the
`~~lib/gambit/prim/prim#.scm`{.code} file and `(gambit prim)`{.code}
library. The file `~~lib/gambit/prim/prim#.scm`{.code} contains
namespace declarations that map operations exported by the runtime
library without a `##`{.code} prefix to their `##`{.code} prefixed names
if this preserves the meaning of the operation but possibly (and
usually) with no type checking. The `(gambit prim)`{.code} library is
similar but in the form of a R7RS library. For example the following
code:

::: example
``` example-preformatted
(include "~~lib/gambit/prim/prim#.scm")
(define (foo x) (square (car x)))
(println (foo (bar 0.5)))
(pp "hello")
```
:::

is equivalent to this code:

::: example
``` example-preformatted
(##define (foo x) (##square (##car x)))
(##println (foo (bar 0.5)))
(##unimplemented#pp "hello")
```
:::

The namespace declarations in `~~lib/gambit/prim/prim#.scm`{.code} have
caused a mapping of `square`{.code} to `##square`{.code}, `car`{.code}
to `##car`{.code} and `println`{.code} to `##println`{.code} because
those primitives perform the same operations (when the code has no
errors). Note that `foo`{.code} and `bar`{.code} have remained the same,
because they are not procedures exported by the runtime library, and
`pp`{.code} has been mapped to `##unimplemented#pp`{.code} because
`pp`{.code} is a procedure exported by the runtime library but
`##pp`{.code} is not defined. Having `unimplemented`{.code} in the name
helps catch situations where the programmer expected a primitive
operation to exist but this isn't the case.

The `define-procedure`{.code} macro does two things. It supports type
annotations in the parameter list and it inserts a
`(include "~~lib/gambit/prim/prim#.scm")`{.code} in the body so that
primitive operations can be used without the `##`{.code} prefix. Type
checking and automatic forcing of promise arguments are also added
implicitly. The macro `define-primitive`{.code} is similar, but the
procedure defined is implicitly prefixed with `##`{.code}.

So all of these things work together to abstract away from the concept
of *primitive* operations. *Primitives* are implemented using procedures
with a `##`{.code} prefix, but other Scheme implementations could do it
differently.

Finally, there's the `(declare-safe-define-procedure <bool>)`{.code}
macro that can be used to enable/disable the mapping of names exported
by the runtime library to the corresponding primitives. This is useful
to enable type checks in the code. For example the following definition:

::: example
``` example-preformatted
(define-procedure (foo (x vector))
  (vector-ref x 5))
```
:::

which expands to

::: example
``` example-preformatted
(define (foo x)
  (macro-check-vector x '(1 . x) (foo x)
    (##vector-ref x 5)))
```
:::

which expands to

::: example
``` example-preformatted
(define (foo x)
    (if (##vector? x)
        (##vector-ref x 5)
        (##fail-check-vector '(1 . x) foo x)))
```
:::

If the code is in the scope of a
`(declare-safe-define-procedure #t)`{.code} then it is
`vector-ref`{.code} that is called instead of `##vector-ref`{.code}
which will both check that `x`{.variable .var} is a vector (redundantly)
and that the index is in range. However, the use of
`##vector-ref`{.code} can be forced by writing the code with an explicit
use of the `primitive`{.code} macro:

::: example
``` example-preformatted
(define-procedure (foo (x vector))
  (primitive (vector-ref x 5)))
```
:::

The expectation is that the `primitive`{.code} special form will be used
sparingly. Searching the source code for the pattern
`"(primitive"`{.code} is a good way to find potentially unsafe code.

-   [Type specifiers](#Type-specifiers){accesskey="1"}

::: {#Type-specifiers .subsection-level-extent}
#### 7.3.1 Type specifiers {#type-specifiers .subsection}

Here is a list of the available type specifiers for a
`define-procedure`{.code} parameter `x`{.variable .var} and the
associated constraint on the value of `x`{.variable .var}.

Note that there is no direct way for checking for a \"list\" or \"list
of elements of type T\". A procedure taking a list parameter will likely
iterate on the list's pairs going from cdr to cdr until a non-pair is
found. Then a check for the empty list with
`(macro-check-proper-list-null lst <arg-id> (<procedure-name> <args>...) <body>)`{.code}
will check that the parameter is a proper list (i.e. that it ends with
the empty list).

-   [Basic types (other than
    numbers)](#Basic-types-_0028other-than-numbers_0029){accesskey="1"}
-   [Numbers](#Numbers-1){accesskey="2"}
-   [Time types](#Time-types){accesskey="3"}
-   [Ports](#Ports){accesskey="4"}
-   [List and vector variants of
    above](#List-and-vector-variants-of-above){accesskey="5"}
-   [Gambit types](#Gambit-types){accesskey="6"}
-   [Others](#Others){accesskey="7"}

::: {#Basic-types-_0028other-than-numbers_0029 .subsubsection-level-extent}
#### 7.3.1.1 Basic types (other than numbers) {#basic-types-other-than-numbers .subsubsection}

`boolean`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is a boolean

`char`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is a character

`pair`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is a pair

`procedure`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is a procedure

`string`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is a string

`symbol`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is a symbol

`vector`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is a vector
:::

::: {#Numbers-1 .subsubsection-level-extent}
#### 7.3.1.2 Numbers {#numbers .subsubsection}

`number`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is a number (possibly complex, rational, etc)

`real`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is a real number (any number except complex)

`fixnum`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is a fixnum and -2\^(W-3) \<= `x`{.variable
    .var} \<= 2\^(W-3) - 1

`(fixnum-range lo hi)`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is a fixnum and lo \<= `x`{.variable .var} \< hi

`(fixnum-range-incl lo hi)`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is a fixnum and lo \<= `x`{.variable .var} \<=
    hi

`index`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is a fixnum and 0 \<= `x`{.variable .var}

`(index-range lo hi)`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is a fixnum and 0 \<= lo \<= `x`{.variable .var}
    \< hi

`(index-range-incl lo hi)`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is a fixnum and 0 \<= lo \<= `x`{.variable .var}
    \<= hi

`exact-signed-int8`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is an exact integer, -128 \<= `x`{.variable
    .var} \<= 127

`exact-signed-int16`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is an exact integer n, -32768 \<= `x`{.variable
    .var} \<= 32767

`exact-signed-int32`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is an exact integer n, -2\^31 \<= `x`{.variable
    .var} \<= 2\^31 - 1

`exact-signed-int64`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is an exact integer n, -2\^63 \<= `x`{.variable
    .var} \<= 2\^63 - 1

`exact-unsigned-int8`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is an exact integer n, 0 \<= `x`{.variable .var}
    \<= 255

`exact-unsigned-int16`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is an exact integer n, 0 \<= `x`{.variable .var}
    \<= 65535

`exact-unsigned-int32`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is an exact integer n, 0 \<= `x`{.variable .var}
    \<= 2\^32 - 1

`exact-unsigned-int64`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is an exact integer n, 0 \<= `x`{.variable .var}
    \<= 2\^64 - 1

`flonum`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is a flonum, exception mentions FLONUM

`inexact-real`{.code}

:   `x`{.variable .var} is a flonum, exception mentions Inexact REAL

`inexact-real-list`{.code}

### 7.4 R7RS Compatible Modules {#R7RS-Compatible-Modules-1 .section}

The R7RS Scheme standard specifies a modularization approach based on
the concept of library. A library is defined using the
`define-library`{.code} form. This form is implemented as a macro that
expands into the constructs used by primitive modules, in particular a
`##namespace`{.code} declaration with a namespace derived from the
library's name so that all variables defined by the library are in that
namespace. With the `define-library`{.code} form the `angle3`{.code}
module example given previously can be written like this:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
;;;---------------------------------------- file: angle3.sld
(define-library (angle3)

  (export deg->rad rad->deg)

  (import (scheme base)
          (scheme inexact))

  (begin
    (define factor (/ (atan 1) 45))
    (define (deg->rad x) (* x factor))
    (define (rad->deg x) (/ x factor))))
```
:::

For this library the expansion of the `define-library`{.code} form will
contain a `##namespace`{.code} declaration that causes the definition of
the global variables `angle3#factor`{.code}, `angle3#deg->rad`{.code},
and `angle3#rad->deg`{.code}. Meanwhile an `(import (angle3))`{.code} in
another library will generate a `##namespace`{.code} declaration that
maps uses of `deg->rad`{.code} and `rad->deg`{.code} to the global
variables `angle3#deg->rad`{.code} and `angle3#rad->deg`{.code}
respectively (note that the unexported global variable `factor`{.code}
is not included in the generated `##namespace`{.code} declaration).

For more complex libraries whose code is split into multiple files it is
convenient to put all the files in a dedicated subdirectory. This is the
preferred filesystem structure for a library but the runtime system
supports both styles. The previous module could be structured like this
instead:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
;;;---------------------------------------- file: angle3/angle3.sld
(define-library (angle3)

  (export deg->rad rad->deg)

  (import (scheme base)
          (scheme inexact))

  (include "angle3.scm")) ;; path is relative to angle3.sld file

;;;---------------------------------------- file: angle3/angle3.scm
(define factor (/ (atan 1) 45))
(define (deg->rad x) (* x factor))
(define (rad->deg x) (/ x factor))
```
:::

-   [Identifying libraries](#Identifying-libraries){accesskey="1"}
-   [The `define-library`{.code}
    form](#The-define_002dlibrary-form){accesskey="2"}

    .var}]{.r}` ...)`{.code}](#g_t_0028export-_003cexport-spec_003e-_002e_002e_002e_0029){accesskey="3"}

::: {#Identifying-libraries .subsection-level-extent}
#### 7.4.1 Identifying libraries {#identifying-libraries .subsection}

Each library is given a name so that it can be referred to in various
contexts, most notably in `import`{.code} forms and the interpreter's
and compiler's command line. The R7RS defines a library name as a list
whose members are identifiers and exact non-negative integers, for
example `(widget)`{.code}, `(_hamt)`{.code}, `(scheme base)`{.code}, and
`(srfi 64)`{.code}.

The system maps these R7RS library names to module identifiers that are
symbols formed by concatenating the parts of the library name separated
with `/`{.code}. The library name and module name are interchangeable.
Consequently, `(import srfi/64)`{.code} and `(import _hamt)`{.code} are
respectively equivalent to `(import (srfi 64))`{.code} and
`(import (_hamt))`{.code}. Using the module name to identify libraries
on the command line is convenient as it avoids having to escape
parentheses and spaces.
:::

::: {#The-define_002dlibrary-form .subsection-level-extent}
#### 7.4.2 The `define-library`{.code} form {#the-define-library-form .subsection}

[special form: ]{.category-def}**define-library** `name`{.variable
.var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`declaration`{.variable
.var}` …`{.variable .def-var-arguments}
[¶](#index-define_002dlibrary){.copiable-link}

In a library definition `name`{.variable .var} specifies the name of the
library and `declaration`{.variable .var} is one of:

::: example
``` example-preformatted
(export <export spec> ...)
(import <import set> ...)
(begin <command or definition> ...)
(include <filename> ...)
(include-ci <filename> ...)
(include-library-declarations <filename> ...)
(cond-expand <cond expand features> ...)
(namespace <namespace>)
(cc-options <options> ...)
(ld-options <options> ...)
(ld-options-prelude <options> ...)
(pkg-config <options> ...)
(pkg-config-path <path> ...)
```
:::
:::

::: {#g_t_0028export-_003cexport-spec_003e-_002e_002e_002e_0029 .subsection-level-extent}
#### 7.4.3 `(export `{.code}[`<export spec>`{.variable .var}]{.r}` ...)`{.code} {#export-export-spec-... .subsection}

An `export`{.code} declaration specifies a list of identifiers which can
be made visible to other libraries or programs. An
`<export spec>`{.variable .var} takes one of the following forms:

::: example
``` example-preformatted
<identifier>
(rename <identifier>1 <identifier>2)
```
:::

In an `<export spec>`{.variable .var}, an `<identifier>`{.variable .var}
names a single binding (variable or macro) defined within or imported
into the library, where the external name for the export is the same as
the name of the binding within the library. A `rename`{.code} spec
exports the binding defined within or imported into the library and
named by `<identifier>1`{.variable .var} in each
`(`{.code}[`<identifier>1`{.variable
.var}]{.r}` `{.code}[`<identifier>2`{.variable .var}]{.r}`)`{.code}
pairing, using `<identifier>2`{.variable .var} as the external name.
:::

::: {#g_t_0028import-_003cimport-set_003e-_002e_002e_002e_0029 .subsection-level-extent}
#### 7.4.4 `(import `{.code}[`<import set>`{.variable .var}]{.r}` ...)`{.code} {#import-import-set-... .subsection}

A library declares a dependency to another library with the
`import`{.code} declaration. The
`(import `{.code}[`<import set>`{.variable .var}]{.r}` ...)`{.code} form
identifies the imported library or libraries.

Each `<import set>`{.variable .var} names a set of bindings from a
library and possibly specifies local names for the imported bindings. An
`<import set>`{.variable .var} takes one of the following forms:

::: example
``` example-preformatted
<library name>
(only <import set> <identifier> ...)
(except <import set> <identifier> ...)
(prefix <import set> <identifier>)
(rename <import set> (<identifier>1 <identifier>2) ...)
```
:::

In the first form, all of the identifiers in the named library's
`export`{.code} clauses are imported with the same names (or the
exported names if exported with `rename`{.code}). The additional
`<import set>`{.variable .var} forms modify this set as follows:

-   `only`{.code} produces a subset of the given
    `<import set>`{.variable .var} including only the listed identifiers
    (after any renaming). It is an error if any of the listed
    identifiers are not found in the original set.
-   `except`{.code} produces a subset of the given
    `<import set>`{.variable .var}, excluding the listed identifiers
    (after any renaming). It is an error if any of the listed
    identifiers are not found in the original set.
-   `rename`{.code} modifies the given `<import set>`{.variable .var},
    replacing each instance of `<identifier>1`{.variable .var} with
    `<identifier>2`{.variable .var}. It is an error if any of the listed
    `<identifier>1`{.variable .var}s are not found in the original set.
-   `prefix`{.code} automatically renames all identifiers in the given
    `<import set>`{.variable .var}, prefixing each with the specified
    `<identifier>`{.variable .var}.

It is an error to import the same identifier more than once with
different bindings, or to redefine or mutate an imported binding with a
definition or with `set!`{.code}, or to refer to an identifier before it
is imported.

As an extension to the R7RS syntax it is allowed for a
`<library name>`{.variable .var} to contain a trailing
`@`{.code}[`version`{.variable .var}]{.r} when the library is hosted in
a `git`{.code} repository. The `version`{.variable .var} must match a
tag of that repository and it indicates the specific library version
required. For example, `(import (github.com/gambit hello @1.0))`{.code}
or equivalently `(import github.com/gambit/hello@1.0)`{.code}. Note that
the version specifier is not separated with a `/`{.code} in the module
name.

Another extension to the R7RS syntax when the library is hosted in a
`git`{.code} repository is the use of dots before the name of the
library to indicate a relative reference within the repository. The
number of dots indicates the number of parent hops. For example, in the
library `(github.com/gambit hello demo)`{.code} an
`(import (.. hello))`{.code} will resolve to the
`(github.com/gambit hello)`{.code} library. A relative library reference
should not contain an explicit `@`{.code}[`version`{.variable .var}]{.r}
because the `version`{.variable .var} is implicitly the same as the
referring module.
:::

::: {#g_t_0028begin-_003ccommand-or-definition_003e-_002e_002e_002e_0029_002c-_0028include-_003cfilename_003e-_002e_002e_002e_0029_002c-and-_0028include_002dci-_003cfilename_003e-_002e_002e_002e_0029 .subsection-level-extent}
#### 7.4.5 `(begin `{.code}[`<command or definition>`{.variable .var}]{.r}` ...)`{.code}, `(include `{.code}[`<filename>`{.variable .var}]{.r}` ...)`{.code}, and `(include-ci `{.code}[`<filename>`{.variable .var}]{.r}` ...)`{.code} {#begin-command-or-definition-...-include-filename-...-and-include-ci-filename-... .subsection}

The `begin`{.code}, `include`{.code}, and `include-ci`{.code}
declarations are used to specify the body of the library. They have the
same syntax and semantics as the corresponding expression types. This
form of `begin`{.code} is analogous to, but not the same as, the two
types of `begin`{.code} expressions.
:::

::: {#g_t_0028include_002dlibrary_002ddeclarations-_003cfilename_003e-_002e_002e_002e_0029 .subsection-level-extent}
#### 7.4.6 `(include-library-declarations `{.code}[`<filename>`{.variable .var}]{.r}` ...)`{.code} {#include-library-declarations-filename-... .subsection}

The `include-library-declarations`{.code} declaration is similar to
`include`{.code} except that the contents of the file are spliced
directly into the current library definition. This can be used, for
example, to share the same `export`{.code} declaration among multiple
libraries as a simple form of library interface.
:::

::: {#g_t_0028cond_002dexpand-_003ccond-expand-features_003e-_002e_002e_002e_0029 .subsection-level-extent}
#### 7.4.7 `(cond-expand `{.code}[`<cond expand features>`{.variable .var}]{.r}` ...)`{.code} {#cond-expand-cond-expand-features-... .subsection}

The `cond-expand`{.code} declaration has the same syntax and semantics
as the `cond-expand`{.code} expression type, except that it expands to
spliced-in library declarations rather than expressions enclosed in
`begin`{.code}.
:::

::: {#Extensions-to-the-R7RS-library-declarations .subsection-level-extent}
#### 7.4.8 Extensions to the R7RS library declarations {#extensions-to-the-r7rs-library-declarations .subsection}

The `(namespace `{.code}[`<namespace>`{.variable .var}]{.r}`)`{.code}
declaration allows overriding the namespace used for the library. This
is mainly useful for system libraries to prevent namespace prefixing
using a `(namespace "")`{.code} declaration.

The remaining declarations are relevant to the `C`{.code} target and
ignored otherwise. They provide information, in the form of strings, to
be passed to the compiler options of the same name when this library is
compiled:

-   `(cc-options `{.code}[`<options>`{.variable .var}]{.r}` ...)`{.code}
-   `(ld-options `{.code}[`<options>`{.variable .var}]{.r}` ...)`{.code}
-   `(ld-options-prelude `{.code}[`<options>`{.variable
    .var}]{.r}` ...)`{.code}
-   `(pkg-config `{.code}[`<options>`{.variable .var}]{.r}` ...)`{.code}
-   `(pkg-config-path `{.code}[`<path>`{.variable
    .var}]{.r}` ...)`{.code}

For example, a library could force the C compiler to generate machine
code for i386 with:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
(define-library (foo)
  (export bar)
  (import (scheme base))
  (cc-options "-march=i386") ;; request compilation for i386
  (begin (define (bar) 42)))
```
:::

### 7.5 Installing Modules {#Installing-Modules-1 .section}

When a module is imported, the processing of the `import`{.code} form
must locate and read the source code of the module at macro expansion
time to determine which names are exported and to what they are mapped.
The list of module search directories (`~~lib`{.code} followed by
`~~userlib`{.code} by default) is searched to find the module's source
code. At execution time the same search algorithm is used to locate and
load the module, either in source code form or compiled form. The
`~~lib`{.code} directory is where the system's builtin modules are put
when Gambit is installed. The `~~userlib`{.code} directory is a
convenient place where other modules can be installed by the user
because locating them does not require extending the list of module
search directories.

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**module-search-order-reset!** [¶](#index-module_002dsearch_002dorder_002dreset_0021){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**module-search-order-add!** `dir`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-module_002dsearch_002dorder_002dadd_0021){.copiable-link}

:   The list of module search directories can be modified using the
    procedures `module-search-order-reset!`{.code} and
    `module-search-order-add!`{.code} that respectively clear the list
    and extend the list with the directory `dir`{.variable .var} which
    must be a string. The list can also be extended by using the
    `-:search=`{.code}`DIR`{.variable .var} runtime option or by a
    command line argument to `gsi`{.code} and `gsc`{.code} that ends
    with a path separator or a '`.`{.sample .samp}' (see
    [`##demand-module`{.code} and `##supply-module`{.code}
    forms](#g_t_0023_0023demand_002dmodule-and-_0023_0023supply_002dmodule-forms){.pxref}).

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    $ cat foobar.sld
    (define-library (foobar)
      (import (scheme write))
      (begin (display "foobar library has executed\n")))
    $ gsi
    Gambit v4.9.5

    > (import (foobar))
    *** ERROR IN (stdin)@1.9 -- Cannot find library (foobar)
    > (module-search-order-add! ".")
    > (import (foobar))
    foobar library has executed
    > ,q
    $ gsi -:search=. foobar
    foobar library has executed
    $ gsi . foobar
    foobar library has executed
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**module-whitelist-reset!** [¶](#index-module_002dwhitelist_002dreset_0021){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**module-whitelist-add!** `source`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-module_002dwhitelist_002dadd_0021){.copiable-link}

:   When modules are installed it is done at the granularity of a
    *package*, which is defined as a `git`{.code} repository possibly
    containing more than one module. For example, if the hosted module
    `github.com/gambit/hello/demo`{.code} needs to be installed it is
    all of the code at `github.com/gambit/hello`{.code} that is
    installed (this includes the three modules
    `github.com/gambit/hello`{.code},
    `github.com/gambit/hello/demo`{.code}, and
    `github.com/gambit/hello/test`{.code}).

    For convenience the runtime system will automatically install in the
    `~~userlib`{.code} directory any hosted module that is from a
    trusted source. The whitelist of trusted sources, which initially
    contains only `github.com/gambit`{.code}, can be modified using the
    procedures `module-whitelist-reset!`{.code} and
    `module-whitelist-add!`{.code} that respectively clear the list and
    extend the list with the source `source`{.variable .var} which must
    be a string, symbol or list specifying a hosted module reference.
    The list can also be extended with the
    `-:whitelist=`{.code}`SOURCE`{.variable .var} runtime option.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    $ gsi github.com/gambit/hello/demo  # auto-install of github.com/gambit/hello package
    People customarily greet each other when they meet.
    In English you can say: hello Bob, nice to see you!
    In French you can say: bonjour Bob, je suis enchanté!
    Demo source code: /Users/feeley/.gambit_userlib/github.com/gambit/hello/@/demo.scm
    $ gsi github.com/feeley/roman/demo  # no auto-install because not on whitelist
    *** ERROR IN ##main -- No such file or directory
    (load "github.com/feeley/roman/demo")
    $ gsi -:whitelist=github.com/feeley github.com/feeley/roman/demo
    1 is I in roman numerals
    2 is II in roman numerals
    4 is IV in roman numerals
    8 is VIII in roman numerals
    16 is XVI in roman numerals
    32 is XXXII in roman numerals
    64 is LXIV in roman numerals
    $ gsi github.com/feeley/roman/demo   # OK because module is now installed
    1 is I in roman numerals
    2 is II in roman numerals
    4 is IV in roman numerals
    8 is VIII in roman numerals
    16 is XVI in roman numerals
    32 is XXXII in roman numerals
    64 is LXIV in roman numerals
    $ gsi github.com/feeley/roman/test   # the test module was also installed
    *** all tests passed out of a total of 19 tests
    ```
    :::

    The use of the runtime option `-:whitelist`{.code} (with no
    `=`{.code}`SOURCE`{.variable .var}) will disable the automatic
    installation of modules, even from `github.com/gambit`{.code}. For
    example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    $ gsi -:whitelist github.com/gambit/hello/demo
    *** ERROR IN ##main -- No such file or directory
    (load "github.com/gambit/hello/demo")
    ```
    :::

    []{#index-_002dinstall-2 .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002duninstall-2
    .index-entry-id} []{#index-_002dupgrade-1 .index-entry-id}

    A manual management of packages is nevertheless possible with the
    `gsi`{.code} package management operations. These are invoked with
    the command line options '`-install`{.sample .samp}',
    '`-uninstall`{.sample .samp}', and '`-update`{.sample .samp}' which
    respectively install, uninstall and update packages. The package
    management operations accept a list of packages. Packages are
    installed in `~~userlib`{.code} which is mapped to
    `~/.gambit_userlib`{.code} by default. An optional '`-dir `{.sample
    .samp}`dir`{.variable .var}' option can be used to install the
    package in some other directory.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    $ gsi -install github.com/feeley/roman
    installing github.com/feeley/roman to /Users/feeley/.gambit_userlib/
    $ gsi github.com/feeley/roman/demo
    1 is I in roman numerals
    2 is II in roman numerals
    4 is IV in roman numerals
    8 is VIII in roman numerals
    16 is XVI in roman numerals
    32 is XXXII in roman numerals
    64 is LXIV in roman numerals
    $ gsi -uninstall github.com/feeley/roman
    uninstalling github.com/feeley/roman from /Users/feeley/.gambit_userlib/
    $ gsi -install -dir ~/mylibs github.com/feeley/roman
    installing github.com/feeley/roman to /Users/feeley/mylibs
    $ gsi ~/mylibs/ github.com/feeley/roman/demo
    1 is I in roman numerals
    2 is II in roman numerals
    4 is IV in roman numerals
    8 is VIII in roman numerals
    16 is XVI in roman numerals
    32 is XXXII in roman numerals
    64 is LXIV in roman numerals
    ```
    :::

    Local `git`{.code} repositories can also be installed manually with
    the package management operations using a path to the local
    repository. This can be useful during the development phase before a
    library becomes hosted.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    $ mkdir some
    $ mkdir some/dir
    $ mkdir some/dir/mylib
    $ cd some/dir/mylib
    $ cat > mylib.sld
    (define-library (mylib)
      (import (scheme write))
      (begin (display "mylib library has executed\n")))
    $ git init
    Initialized empty Git repository in /Users/feeley/doc/some/dir/mylib/.git/
    $ git add mylib.sld
    $ git commit -m "first commit"
    [master (root-commit) c3f6aff] first commit
     1 file changed, 3 insertions(+)
     create mode 100644 mylib.sld
    $ cd ../../..
    $ gsi some/dir/ mylib   # execution of mylib without installation
    mylib library has executed
    $ gsi -install some/dir/mylib
    installing some/dir/mylib to /Users/feeley/.gambit_userlib/
    $ gsi mylib   # execution of mylib after installation
    mylib library has executed
    ```
    :::

### 7.6 Compiling Modules {#Compiling-Modules-1 .section}

When `gsc`{.code} finds a command line argument that is the name of a
module found on the list of module search order directories (after an
automatic installation if that is appropriate) that module's main source
code file will be compiled.

When a dynamic compilation is requested (which is the default
compilation mode and when the command line option `-dynamic`{.code} is
used) the compiler will compile for the selected target the main source
code file to a target file and a dynamically loadable object file with a
'`.o1`{.sample .samp}' extension. These files will be created in a
directory next to the module's main source code file, with the same name
stripped of it's extension and suffixed with the Gambit version and the
target name. This naming strategy aims to avoid loading the compiled
file in an inappropriate context. The module loading algorithm knows it
should check this directory to find a compiled version of the module.

For example:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ mkdir lib1 lib2
$ cat > lib1/lib1.sld
(define-library (lib1)
  (export fact)
  (import (scheme base) (scheme write))
  (begin
    (define (fact n) (if (<= n 1) 1 (* n (fact (- n 1)))))
    (display "lib1 loaded\n")))
$ cat > lib2/lib2.sld
(define-library (lib2)
  (import (lib1) (scheme base) (scheme write))
  (begin
    (display
     (cond-expand
       ((compilation-target C)   "lib2 compiled to C\n")
       ((compilation-target (_)) "lib2 interpreted\n")
       (else                     "lib2 compiled to other\n")))
    (display (fact 10))
    (newline)))
$ gsi . lib2        # loads lib1.sld and lib2.sld
lib1 loaded
lib2 interpreted
3628800
lib1
$ tree --charset=ascii --noreport lib1 lib2
`-- lib1.sld
lib2
`-- lib2.sld
$ gsc . lib1 lib2   # compile lib1.sld and lib2.sld using C target
$ gsi . lib2        # loads generated lib1.o1 and lib2.o1
lib1 loaded
lib2 compiled to C
3628800
$ gsc -target js . lib1 lib2   # also compile them for js target
$ tree --charset=ascii --noreport lib1 lib2
lib1
|-- lib1.sld
|-- lib1@gambit409003@C
|   |-- lib1.c
|   `-- lib1.o1
`-- lib1@gambit409003@js
    |-- lib1.js
    `-- lib1.o1
lib2
|-- lib2.sld
|-- lib2@gambit409003@C
|   |-- lib2.c
|   `-- lib2.o1
`-- lib2@gambit409003@js
    |-- lib2.js
    `-- lib2.o1
```
:::

To create an executable program from a set of non-legacy modules it is
important to use the `-nopreload`{.code} linking option when linking so
that the modules will be initialized in an order that is consistent with
the module dependencies. If the default `-preload`{.code} linking option
is used some modules may be initialized out of order, leading to
incorrect execution.

Here is an example that extends the previous example:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
$ gsc -exe -nopreload . lib1/lib1.sld lib2/lib2.sld
$ lib2/lib2
lib1 loaded
lib2 compiled to C
3628800
$ gsc -target js -exe -nopreload . lib1/lib1.sld lib2/lib2.sld
$ lib2/lib2
lib1 loaded
lib2 compiled to other
3628800
```
:::

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**=** `z1`{.variable .var}`…`{.variable .def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-_003d){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**\<** `x1`{.variable .var}`…`{.variable .def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-_003c){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**\>** `x1`{.variable .var}`…`{.variable .def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-_003e){.copiable-link}\

#### 8.1.2 IEEE floating point arithmetic {#IEEE-floating-point-arithmetic-1 .subsection}

To better conform to IEEE floating point arithmetic the standard numeric
tower is extended with these special inexact reals:

`+inf.0`{.code}

:   positive infinity

`-inf.0`{.code}

:   negative infinity

`+nan.0`{.code}

:   "not a number"

`-0.`{.code}

:   negative zero ('`0.`{.sample .samp}' is the positive zero)

The infinities and "not a number" are reals (i.e.
`(real? +inf.0)`{.code} is `#t`{.code}) but are not rational (i.e.
`(rational? +inf.0)`{.code} is `#f`{.code}).

Both zeros are numerically equal (i.e. `(= -0. 0.)`{.code} is
`#t`{.code}) but are not equivalent (i.e. `(eqv? -0. 0.)`{.code} and
`(equal? -0. 0.)`{.code} are `#f`{.code}). All numerical comparisons
with "not a number", including `(= +nan.0 +nan.0)`{.code}, are
`#f`{.code}.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

#### 8.1.3 Integer square root and nth root {#Integer-square-root-and-nth-root-1 .subsection}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**integer-sqrt** `n`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-integer_002dsqrt){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the integer part of the square root of the
    nonnegative exact integer `n`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (integer-sqrt 123)
    11
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**integer-nth-root** `n1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n2`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-integer_002dnth_002droot){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the integer part of `n1`{.variable .var}
    raised to the power 1/`n2`{.variable .var}, where `n1`{.variable
    .var} is a nonnegative exact integer and `n2`{.variable .var} is a
    positive exact integer.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (integer-nth-root 100 3)
    4
    ```
    :::

#### 8.1.4 Bitwise-operations on exact integers {#Bitwise_002doperations-on-exact-integers-1 .subsection}

The procedures defined in this section are compatible with the withdrawn
"Integer Bitwise-operation Library SRFI" (SRFI 33). Note that some of
the procedures specified in SRFI 33 are not provided.

Most procedures in this section are specified in terms of the binary
representation of exact integers. The two's complement representation is
assumed where an integer is composed of an infinite number of bits. The
upper section of an integer (the most significant bits) are either an
infinite sequence of ones when the integer is negative, or they are an
infinite sequence of zeros when the integer is nonnegative.

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**arithmetic-shift** `n1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n2`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-arithmetic_002dshift){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns `n1`{.variable .var} shifted to the left by
    `n2`{.variable .var} bits, that is `(floor (* `{.code}`n1`{.variable
    .var}` (expt 2 `{.code}`n2`{.variable .var}`)))`{.code}. Both
    `n1`{.variable .var} and `n2`{.variable .var} must be exact
    integers.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (arithmetic-shift 1000 7)  ; n1=...0000001111101000
    128000
    > (arithmetic-shift 1000 -6) ; n1=...0000001111101000
    15
    > (arithmetic-shift -23 -3)  ; n1=...1111111111101001
    -3
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**bitwise-merge** `n1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n2`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n3`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-bitwise_002dmerge){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns an exact integer whose bits combine the bits
    from `n2`{.variable .var} and `n3`{.variable .var} depending on
    `n1`{.variable .var}. The bit at index `i`{.variable .var} of the
    result depends only on the bits at index `i`{.variable .var} in
    `n1`{.variable .var}, `n2`{.variable .var} and `n3`{.variable .var}:
    it is equal to the bit in `n2`{.variable .var} when the bit in
    `n1`{.variable .var} is 0 and it is equal to the bit in
    `n3`{.variable .var} when the bit in `n1`{.variable .var} is 1. All
    arguments must be exact integers.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (bitwise-merge -4 -11 10) ; ...11111100 ...11110101 ...00001010
    9
    > (bitwise-merge 12 -11 10) ; ...00001100 ...11110101 ...00001010
    -7
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**bitwise-and** `n`{.variable .var}`…`{.variable .def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-bitwise_002dand){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the bitwise "and" of the exact integers
    `n`{.variable .var}.... The value -1 is returned when there are no
    arguments.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (bitwise-and 6 12)  ; ...00000110 ...00001100
    4
    > (bitwise-and 6 -4)  ; ...00000110 ...11111100
    4
    > (bitwise-and -6 -4) ; ...11111010 ...11111100
    -8
    > (bitwise-and)
    -1
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**bitwise-andc1** `n1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n2`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-bitwise_002dandc1){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the bitwise "and" of the bitwise complement
    of the exact integer `n1`{.variable .var} and the exact integer
    `n2`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (bitwise-andc1 11 26)  ; ...00001011 ...00011010
    16
    > (bitwise-andc1 -12 26) ; ...11110100 ...00011010
    10
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**bitwise-andc2** `n1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n2`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-bitwise_002dandc2){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the bitwise "and" of the exact integer
    `n1`{.variable .var} and the bitwise complement of the exact integer
    `n2`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (bitwise-andc2 11 26)  ; ...00001011 ...00011010
    1
    > (bitwise-andc2 11 -27) ; ...00001011 ...11100101
    10
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**bitwise-eqv** `n`{.variable .var}`…`{.variable .def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-bitwise_002deqv){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the bitwise complement of the bitwise
    "exclusive-or" of the exact integers `n`{.variable .var}.... The
    value -1 is returned when there are no arguments.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (bitwise-eqv 6 12)  ; ...00000110 ...00001100
    -11
    > (bitwise-eqv 6 -4)  ; ...00000110 ...11111100
    5
    > (bitwise-eqv -6 -4) ; ...11111010 ...11111100
    -7
    > (bitwise-eqv)
    -1
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**bitwise-ior** `n`{.variable .var}`…`{.variable .def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-bitwise_002dior){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the bitwise "inclusive-or" of the exact
    integers `n`{.variable .var}.... The value 0 is returned when there
    are no arguments.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (bitwise-ior 6 12)  ; ...00000110 ...00001100
    14
    > (bitwise-ior 6 -4)  ; ...00000110 ...11111100
    -2
    > (bitwise-ior -6 -4) ; ...11111010 ...11111100
    -2
    > (bitwise-ior)
    0
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**bitwise-nand** `n1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n2`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-bitwise_002dnand){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the bitwise complement of the bitwise "and"
    of the exact integer `n1`{.variable .var} and the exact integer
    `n2`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (bitwise-nand 11 26)  ; ...00001011 ...00011010
    -11
    > (bitwise-nand 11 -27) ; ...00001011 ...11100101
    -2
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**bitwise-nor** `n1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n2`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-bitwise_002dnor){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the bitwise complement of the bitwise
    "inclusive-or" of the exact integer `n1`{.variable .var} and the
    exact integer `n2`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (bitwise-nor 11 26)  ; ...00001011 ...00011010
    -28
    > (bitwise-nor 11 -27) ; ...00001011 ...11100101
    16
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**bitwise-not** `n`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-bitwise_002dnot){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the bitwise complement of the exact integer
    `n`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (bitwise-not 3)  ; ...00000011
    -4
    > (bitwise-not -1) ; ...11111111
    0
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**bitwise-orc1** `n1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n2`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-bitwise_002dorc1){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the bitwise "inclusive-or" of the bitwise
    complement of the exact integer `n1`{.variable .var} and the exact
    integer `n2`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (bitwise-orc1 11 26)  ; ...00001011 ...00011010
    -2
    > (bitwise-orc1 -12 26) ; ...11110100 ...00011010
    27
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**bitwise-orc2** `n1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n2`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-bitwise_002dorc2){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the bitwise "inclusive-or" of the exact
    integer `n1`{.variable .var} and the bitwise complement of the exact
    integer `n2`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (bitwise-orc2 11 26)  ; ...00001011 ...00011010
    -17
    > (bitwise-orc2 11 -27) ; ...00001011 ...11100101
    27
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**bitwise-xor** `n`{.variable .var}`…`{.variable .def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-bitwise_002dxor){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the bitwise "exclusive-or" of the exact
    integers `n`{.variable .var}.... The value 0 is returned when there
    are no arguments.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (bitwise-xor 6 12)  ; ...00000110 ...00001100
    10
    > (bitwise-xor 6 -4)  ; ...00000110 ...11111100
    -6
    > (bitwise-xor -6 -4) ; ...11111010 ...11111100
    6
    > (bitwise-xor)
    0
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**bit-count** `n`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-bit_002dcount){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the bit count of the exact integer
    `n`{.variable .var}. If `n`{.variable .var} is nonnegative, the bit
    count is the number of 1 bits in the two's complement representation
    of `n`{.variable .var}. If `n`{.variable .var} is negative, the bit
    count is the number of 0 bits in the two's complement representation
    of `n`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (bit-count 0)   ; ...00000000
    0
    > (bit-count 1)   ; ...00000001
    1
    > (bit-count 2)   ; ...00000010
    1
    > (bit-count 3)   ; ...00000011
    2
    > (bit-count 4)   ; ...00000100
    1
    > (bit-count -23) ; ...11101001
    3
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**integer-length** `n`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-integer_002dlength){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the bit length of the exact integer
    `n`{.variable .var}. If `n`{.variable .var} is a positive integer
    the bit length is one more than the index of the highest 1 bit (the
    least significant bit is at index 0). If `n`{.variable .var} is a
    negative integer the bit length is one more than the index of the
    highest 0 bit. If `n`{.variable .var} is zero, the bit length is 0.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (integer-length 0)   ; ...00000000
    0
    > (integer-length 1)   ; ...00000001
    1
    > (integer-length 2)   ; ...00000010
    2
    > (integer-length 3)   ; ...00000011
    2
    > (integer-length 4)   ; ...00000100
    3
    > (integer-length -23) ; ...11101001
    5
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**bit-set?** `n1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n2`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-bit_002dset_003f){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns a boolean indicating if the bit at index
    `n1`{.variable .var} of `n2`{.variable .var} is set (i.e. equal
    to 1) or not. Both `n1`{.variable .var} and `n2`{.variable .var}
    must be exact integers, and `n1`{.variable .var} must be
    nonnegative.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (map (lambda (i) (bit-set? i -23)) ; ...11101001
           '(7 6 5 4 3 2 1 0))
    (#t #t #t #f #t #f #f #t)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**any-bits-set?** `n1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n2`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-any_002dbits_002dset_003f){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns a boolean indicating if the bitwise and of
    `n1`{.variable .var} and `n2`{.variable .var} is different from zero
    or not. This procedure is implemented more efficiently than the
    naive definition:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    (define (any-bits-set? n1 n2) (not (zero? (bitwise-and n1 n2))))
    ```
    :::

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (any-bits-set? 5 10)   ; ...00000101 ...00001010
    #f
    > (any-bits-set? -23 32) ; ...11101001 ...00100000
    #t
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**all-bits-set?** `n1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n2`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-all_002dbits_002dset_003f){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns a boolean indicating if the bitwise and of
    `n1`{.variable .var} and `n2`{.variable .var} is equal to
    `n1`{.variable .var} or not. This procedure is implemented more
    efficiently than the naive definition:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    (define (all-bits-set? n1 n2) (= n1 (bitwise-and n1 n2)))
    ```
    :::

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (all-bits-set? 1 3) ; ...00000001 ...00000011
    #t
    > (all-bits-set? 7 3) ; ...00000111 ...00000011
    #f
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**first-set-bit** `n`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-first_002dset_002dbit){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the bit index of the least significant bit of
    `n`{.variable .var} equal to 1 (which is also the number of 0 bits
    that are below the least significant 1 bit). This procedure returns
    `-1`{.code} when `n`{.variable .var} is zero.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (first-set-bit 24) ; ...00011000
    3
    > (first-set-bit 0)  ; ...00000000
    -1
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**extract-bit-field** `n1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n2`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n3`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-extract_002dbit_002dfield){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**test-bit-field?** `n1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n2`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n3`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-test_002dbit_002dfield_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**clear-bit-field** `n1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n2`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n3`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-clear_002dbit_002dfield){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**replace-bit-field** `n1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n2`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n3`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n4`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-replace_002dbit_002dfield){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**copy-bit-field** `n1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n2`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n3`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`n4`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-copy_002dbit_002dfield){.copiable-link}

:   These procedures operate on a bit-field which is `n1`{.variable
    .var} bits wide starting at bit index `n2`{.variable .var}. All
    arguments must be exact integers and `n1`{.variable .var} and
    `n2`{.variable .var} must be nonnegative.

    The procedure `extract-bit-field`{.code} returns the bit-field of
    `n3`{.variable .var} shifted to the right so that the least
    significant bit of the bit-field is the least significant bit of the
    result.

    The procedure `test-bit-field?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code} if any
    bit in the bit-field of `n3`{.variable .var} is equal to 1,
    otherwise `#f`{.code} is returned.

    The procedure `clear-bit-field`{.code} returns `n3`{.variable .var}
    with all bits in the bit-field replaced with 0.

    The procedure `replace-bit-field`{.code} returns `n4`{.variable
    .var} with the bit-field replaced with the least-significant
    `n1`{.variable .var} bits of `n3`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `copy-bit-field`{.code} returns `n4`{.variable .var}
    with the bit-field replaced with the (same index and size) bit-field
    in `n3`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (extract-bit-field 5 2 -37)    ; ...11011011
    22
    > (test-bit-field? 5 2 -37)      ; ...11011011
    #t
    > (test-bit-field? 1 2 -37)      ; ...11011011
    #f
    > (clear-bit-field 5 2 -37)      ; ...11011011
    -125
    > (replace-bit-field 5 2 -6 -37) ; ...11111010 ...11011011
    -21
    > (copy-bit-field 5 2 -6 -37)    ; ...11111010 ...11011011
    -5
    ```
    :::

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**fixnum-overflow-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-fixnum_002doverflow_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**fixnum-overflow-exception-procedure** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-fixnum_002doverflow_002dexception_002dprocedure){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**fixnum-overflow-exception-arguments** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-fixnum_002doverflow_002dexception_002darguments){.copiable-link}

:   Fixnum-overflow-exception objects are raised by some of the fixnum
    specific procedures when the result is larger than can fit in a
    fixnum. The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be a
    fixnum-overflow-exception object.

    The procedure `fixnum-overflow-exception?`{.code} returns
    `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is a
    fixnum-overflow-exception object and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `fixnum-overflow-exception-procedure`{.code} returns
    the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `fixnum-overflow-exception-arguments`{.code} returns
    the list of arguments of the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable
    .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (fixnum-overflow-exception? exc)
            (list (fixnum-overflow-exception-procedure exc)
                  (fixnum-overflow-exception-arguments exc))
            'not-fixnum-overflow-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (fx* 100000 100000)))
    (#<procedure #2 fx*> (100000 100000))
    ```
    :::

#### 8.1.7 Pseudo random numbers {#Pseudo-random-numbers-1 .subsection}

The procedures and variables defined in this section are compatible with
the "Sources of Random Bits SRFI" (SRFI 27). The implementation is based
on Pierre L'Ecuyer's MRG32k3a pseudo random number generator. At the
heart of SRFI 27's interface is the random source type which
encapsulates the state of a pseudo random number generator. The state of
a random source object changes every time a pseudo random number is
generated from this random source object.

[variable: ]{.category-def}**default-random-source** [¶](#index-default_002drandom_002dsource){.copiable-link}

:   The global variable `default-random-source`{.code} is bound to the
    random source object which is used by the `random-integer`{.code},
    `random-real`{.code}, `random-u8vector`{.code} and
    `random-f64vector`{.code} procedures.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**random-integer** `n`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-random_002dinteger){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns a pseudo random exact integer in the range 0
    to `n`{.variable .var}-1. The random source object in the global
    variable `default-random-source`{.code} is used to generate this
    number. The parameter `n`{.variable .var} must be a positive exact
    integer.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (random-integer 100)
    24
    > (random-integer 100)
    2
    > (random-integer 10000000000000000000000000000000000000000)
    6143360270902284438072426748425263488507
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**random-real** [¶](#index-random_002dreal){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns a pseudo random inexact real between, but not
    including, 0 and 1. The random source object in the global variable
    `default-random-source`{.code} is used to generate this number.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (random-real)
    .24230672079133753
    > (random-real)
    .02317001922506932
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**random-u8vector** `n`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-random_002du8vector){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns a u8vector of length `n`{.variable .var}
    containing pseudo random exact integers in the range 0 to 255. The
    random source object in the global variable
    `default-random-source`{.code} is used to generate these numbers.
    The parameter `n`{.variable .var} must be a nonnegative exact
    integer.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (random-u8vector 10)
    #u8(200 53 29 202 3 85 208 187 73 219)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**random-f64vector** `n`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-random_002df64vector){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns a f64vector of length `n`{.variable .var}
    containing pseudo random inexact reals between, but not including, 0
    and 1. The random source object in the global variable
    `default-random-source`{.code} is used to generate these numbers.
    The parameter `n`{.variable .var} must be a nonnegative exact
    integer.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (random-f64vector 3)
    #f64(.7145854494613069 .47089632669147946 .5400124875182746)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**make-random-source** [¶](#index-make_002drandom_002dsource){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns a new random source object initialized to a
    predetermined state (to initialize to a pseudo random state the
    procedure `random-source-randomize!`{.code} should be called).

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define rs (make-random-source))
    > ((random-source-make-integers rs) 10000000)
    8583952
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**random-source?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-random_002dsource_003f){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is a
    random source object and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (random-source? default-random-source)
    #t
    > (random-source? 123)
    #f
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**random-source-state-ref** `random-source`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-random_002dsource_002dstate_002dref){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**random-source-state-set!** `random-source`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`state`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-random_002dsource_002dstate_002dset_0021){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `random-source-state-ref`{.code} extracts the state of
    the random source object `random-source`{.variable .var} and returns
    a vector containing the state.

    The procedure `random-source-state-set!`{.code} restores the state
    of the random source object `random-source`{.variable .var} to
    `state`{.variable .var} which must be a vector returned from a call
    to the procedure `random-source-state-ref`{.code}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define s (random-source-state-ref default-random-source))
    > (random-integer 10000000000000000000000000000000000000000)
    7583880188903074396261960585615270693321
    > (random-source-state-set! default-random-source s)
    > (random-integer 10000000000000000000000000000000000000000)
    7583880188903074396261960585615270693321
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**random-source-randomize!** `random-source`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-random_002dsource_002drandomize_0021){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**random-source-pseudo-randomize!** `random-source`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`i`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`j`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-random_002dsource_002dpseudo_002drandomize_0021){.copiable-link}

:   These procedures change the state of the random source object
    `random-source`{.variable .var}. The procedure
    `random-source-randomize!`{.code} sets the random source object to a
    state that depends on the current time (which for typical uses can
    be considered to randomly initialize the state). The procedure
    `random-source-pseudo-randomize!`{.code} sets the random source
    object to a state that is determined only by the current state and
    the nonnegative exact integers `i`{.variable .var} and `j`{.variable
    .var}. For both procedures the value returned is unspecified.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define s (random-source-state-ref default-random-source))
    > (random-source-pseudo-randomize! default-random-source 5 99)
    > (random-integer 10000000000000000000000000000000000000000)
    9816755163910623041601722050112674079767
    > (random-source-state-set! default-random-source s)
    > (random-source-pseudo-randomize! default-random-source 5 99)
    > (random-integer 10000000000000000000000000000000000000000)
    9816755163910623041601722050112674079767
    > (random-source-pseudo-randomize! default-random-source 5 99)
    > (random-integer 10000000000000000000000000000000000000000)
    9816755163910623041601722050112674079767
    > (random-source-state-set! default-random-source s)
    > (random-source-randomize! default-random-source)
    > (random-integer 10000000000000000000000000000000000000000)
    2271441220851914333384493143687768110622
    > (random-source-state-set! default-random-source s)
    > (random-source-randomize! default-random-source)
    > (random-integer 10000000000000000000000000000000000000000)
    6247966138948323029033944059178072366895
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**random-source-make-integers** `random-source`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-random_002dsource_002dmake_002dintegers){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns a procedure for generating pseudo random
    exact integers using the random source object
    `random-source`{.variable .var}. The returned procedure accepts a
    single parameter `n`{.variable .var}, a positive exact integer, and
    returns a pseudo random exact integer in the range 0 to
    `n`{.variable .var}-1.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define rs (make-random-source))
    > (define ri (random-source-make-integers rs))
    > (ri 10000000)
    8583952
    > (ri 10000000)
    2879793
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**random-source-make-reals** `random-source`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`precision`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-random_002dsource_002dmake_002dreals){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns a procedure for generating pseudo random
    inexact reals using the random source object
    `random-source`{.variable .var}. The returned procedure accepts no
    parameters and returns a pseudo random inexact real between, but not
    including, 0 and 1. The optional parameter `precision`{.variable
    .var} specifies an upper bound on the minimum amount by which two
    generated pseudo-random numbers can be separated.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define rs (make-random-source))
    > (define rr (random-source-make-reals rs))
    > (rr)
    .857402537562821
    > (rr)
    .2876463473845367
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**random-source-make-u8vectors** `random-source`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-random_002dsource_002dmake_002du8vectors){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns a procedure for generating pseudo random
    u8vectors using the random source object `random-source`{.variable
    .var}. The returned procedure accepts a single parameter
    `n`{.variable .var}, a nonnegative exact integer, and returns a
    u8vector of length `n`{.variable .var} containing pseudo random
    exact integers in the range 0 to 255.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define rs (make-random-source))
    > (define rv (random-source-make-u8vectors rs))
    > (rv 10)
    #u8(200 53 29 202 3 85 208 187 73 219)
    > (rv 10)
    #u8(113 8 182 120 138 103 53 192 40 176)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**random-source-make-f64vectors** `random-source`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`precision`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-random_002dsource_002dmake_002df64vectors){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns a procedure for generating pseudo random
    f64vectors using the random source object `random-source`{.variable
    .var}. The returned procedure accepts a single parameter
    `n`{.variable .var}, a nonnegative exact integer, and returns an
    f64vector of length `n`{.variable .var} containing pseudo random
    inexact reals between, but not including, 0 and 1. The optional
    parameter `precision`{.variable .var} specifies an upper bound on
    the minimum amount by which two generated pseudo-random numbers can
    be separated.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define rs (make-random-source))
    > (define rv (random-source-make-f64vectors rs))
    > (rv 3)
    #f64(.7342236104231586 .2876463473845367 .8574025375628211)
    > (rv 3)
    #f64(.013863292728449427 .33449296573515447 .8162050798467028)
    ```
    :::

### 8.5 Characters and strings {#Characters-and-strings-1 .section}

Gambit supports the Unicode character encoding standard. Scheme
characters can be any of the characters whose Unicode encoding is in the
range 0 to #x10ffff (inclusive) but not in the range #xd800 to #xdfff.
Source code can also contain any Unicode character, however to read such
source code properly `gsi`{.code} and `gsc`{.code} must be told which
character encoding to use for reading the source code (i.e. ISO-8859-1,
UTF-8, UTF-16, etc). This can be done by specifying the runtime option
'`-:file-settings=...`{.sample .samp}' or '`-:io-settings=...`{.sample
.samp}' when `gsi`{.code} and `gsc`{.code} are started.

------------------------------------------------------------------------

### 8.6 Extensions to character procedures {#Extensions-to-character-procedures-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**char-\>integer** `char`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-char_002d_003einteger){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**integer-\>char** `n`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-integer_002d_003echar){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `char->integer`{.code} returns the Unicode encoding of
    the character `char`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `integer->char`{.code} returns the character whose
    Unicode encoding is the exact integer `n`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (char->integer #\!)
    33
    > (integer->char 65)
    #\A
    > (integer->char (char->integer #\u1234))
    #\u1234
    > (integer->char #xd800)
    *** ERROR IN (console)@4.1 -- (Argument 1) Out of range
    (integer->char 55296)
    ```
    :::


### 8.9 Homogeneous numeric vectors {#Homogeneous-numeric-vectors-1 .section}

[]{#index-Homogeneous-numeric-vectors .index-entry-id}

Homogeneous vectors are vectors containing raw numbers of the same type
(signed or unsigned exact integers or inexact reals). There are 10 types
of homogeneous vectors: '`s8vector`{.sample .samp}' (vector of exact
integers in the range -2\^7 to 2\^7-1), '`u8vector`{.sample .samp}'
(vector of exact integers in the range 0 to 2\^8-1),
'`s16vector`{.sample .samp}' (vector of exact integers in the range
-2\^15 to 2\^15-1), '`u16vector`{.sample .samp}' (vector of exact
integers in the range 0 to 2\^16-1), '`s32vector`{.sample .samp}'
(vector of exact integers in the range -2\^31 to 2\^31-1),
'`u32vector`{.sample .samp}' (vector of exact integers in the range 0 to
2\^32-1), '`s64vector`{.sample .samp}' (vector of exact integers in the
range -2\^63 to 2\^63-1), '`u64vector`{.sample .samp}' (vector of exact
integers in the range 0 to 2\^64-1), '`f32vector`{.sample .samp}'
(vector of 32 bit floating point numbers), and '`f64vector`{.sample
.samp}' (vector of 64 bit floating point numbers).

The lexical syntax of homogeneous vectors is specified in [Homogeneous
vector syntax](#Homogeneous-vector-syntax){.ref}.

The procedures available for homogeneous vectors, listed below, are the
analog of the normal vector/string procedures for each of the
homogeneous vector types.

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**object-\>u8vector** `obj`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`encoder`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-object_002d_003eu8vector){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**u8vector-\>object** `u8vector`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`decoder`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-u8vector_002d_003eobject){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-serialization .index-entry-id} []{#index-deserialization
    .index-entry-id}

    The procedure `object->u8vector`{.code} returns a u8vector that
    contains the sequence of bytes that encodes the object
    `obj`{.variable .var}. The procedure `u8vector->object`{.code}
    decodes the sequence of bytes contained in the u8vector
    `u8vector`{.variable .var}, which was produced by the procedure
    `object->u8vector`{.code}, and reconstructs an object structurally
    equal to the original object. In other words the procedures
    `object->u8vector`{.code} and `u8vector->object`{.code} respectively
    perform serialization and deserialization of Scheme objects. Note
    that some objects are non-serializable (e.g. threads, wills, some
    types of ports, and any object containing a non-serializable
    object).

    The optional `encoder`{.variable .var} and `decoder`{.variable .var}
    parameters are single parameter procedures which default to the
    identity function. The `encoder`{.variable .var} procedure is called
    during serialization. As the serializer walks through
    `obj`{.variable .var}, it calls the `encoder`{.variable .var}
    procedure on each sub-object `X`{.variable .var} that is
    encountered. The `encoder`{.variable .var} transforms the object
    `X`{.variable .var} into an object `Y`{.variable .var} that will be
    serialized instead of `X`{.variable .var}. Similarly the
    `decoder`{.variable .var} procedure is called during
    deserialization. When an object `Y`{.variable .var} is encountered,
    the `decoder`{.variable .var} procedure is called to transform it
    into the object `X`{.variable .var} that is the result of
    deserialization.

    The `encoder`{.variable .var} and `decoder`{.variable .var}
    procedures are useful to customize the serialized representation of
    objects. In particular, it can be used to define the semantics of
    serializing objects, such as threads and ports, that would otherwise
    not be serializable. The `decoder`{.variable .var} procedure is
    typically the inverse of the `encoder`{.variable .var} procedure,
    i.e. `(`{.code}`decoder`{.variable
    .var}` (`{.code}`encoder`{.variable .var}` `{.code}`X`{.variable
    .var}`))`{.code} = `X`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (make-adder x) (lambda (y) (+ x y)))
    > (define f (make-adder 10))
    > (define a (object->u8vector f))
    > (define b (u8vector->object a))
    > (u8vector-length a)
    1639
    > (f 5)
    15
    > (b 5)
    15
    > (pp b)
    (lambda (y) (+ x y))
    ```
    :::

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**object-\>serial-number** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-object_002d_003eserial_002dnumber){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**serial-number-\>object** `n`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`default`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-serial_002dnumber_002d_003eobject){.copiable-link}

:   All Scheme objects are uniquely identified with a serial number
    which is a nonnegative exact integer. The
    `object->serial-number`{.code} procedure returns the serial number
    of object `obj`{.variable .var}. This serial number is only
    allocated the first time the `object->serial-number`{.code}
    procedure is called on that object. Objects which do not have an
    external textual representation that can be read by the
    `read`{.code} procedure, use an external textual representation that
    includes a serial number of the form `#`{.code}`n`{.variable .var}.
    Consequently, the procedures `write`{.code}, `pretty-print`{.code},
    etc will call the `object->serial-number`{.code} procedure to get
    the serial number, and this may cause the serial number to be
    allocated.

    The `serial-number->object`{.code} procedure takes an exact integer
    parameter `n`{.variable .var} and returns the object whose serial
    number is `n`{.variable .var}. If no object currently exists with
    that serial number, `default`{.variable .var} is returned if it is
    specified, otherwise an unbound-serial-number-exception object is
    raised. The reader defines the following abbreviation for calling
    `serial-number->object`{.code}: the syntax `#`{.code}`n`{.variable
    .var}, where `n`{.variable .var} is a sequence of decimal digits and
    it is not followed by '`=`{.code}' or '`#`{.code}', is equivalent to
    the list `(serial-number->object `{.code}`n`{.variable
    .var}`)`{.code}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define z (list (lambda (x) (* x x)) (lambda (y) (/ 1 y))))
    > z
    (#<procedure #2> #<procedure #3>)
    > (#3 10)
    1/10
    > '(#3 10)
    ((serial-number->object 3) 10)
    > car
    #<procedure #4 car>
    > (#4 z)
    #<procedure #2>
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**unbound-serial-number-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-unbound_002dserial_002dnumber_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**unbound-serial-number-exception-procedure** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-unbound_002dserial_002dnumber_002dexception_002dprocedure){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**unbound-serial-number-exception-arguments** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-unbound_002dserial_002dnumber_002dexception_002darguments){.copiable-link}

:   Unbound-serial-number-exception objects are raised by the procedure
    `serial-number->object`{.code} when no object currently exists with
    that serial number. The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be an
    unbound-serial-number-exception object.

    The procedure `unbound-serial-number-exception?`{.code} returns
    `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is a
    unbound-serial-number-exception object and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `unbound-serial-number-exception-procedure`{.code}
    returns the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `unbound-serial-number-exception-arguments`{.code}
    returns the list of arguments of the procedure that raised
    `exc`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (unbound-serial-number-exception? exc)
            (list (unbound-serial-number-exception-procedure exc)
                  (unbound-serial-number-exception-arguments exc))
            'not-unbound-serial-number-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (serial-number->object 1000)))
    (#<procedure #2 serial-number->object> (1000))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**symbol-hash** `symbol`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-symbol_002dhash){.copiable-link}

:   The `symbol-hash`{.code} procedure returns the hash number of the
    symbol `symbol`{.variable .var}. The hash number is a small exact
    integer (fixnum). When `symbol`{.variable .var} is an interned
    symbol the value returned is the same as
    `(string=?-hash (symbol->string `{.code}`symbol`{.variable
    .var}`))`{.code}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (symbol-hash 'car)
    444471047
    ```
    :::

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**string=?-hash** `string`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-string_003d_003f_002dhash){.copiable-link}

:   The `string=?-hash`{.code} procedure returns the hash number of the
    string `string`{.variable .var}. The hash number is a small exact
    integer (fixnum). For any two strings `s1`{.variable .var} and
    `s2`{.variable .var}, `(string=? `{.code}`s1`{.variable
    .var}` `{.code}`s2`{.variable .var}`)`{.code} implies
    `(= (string=?-hash `{.code}`s1`{.variable
    .var}`) (string=?-hash `{.code}`s2`{.variable .var}`))`{.code}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**eqv?-hash** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-eqv_003f_002dhash){.copiable-link}

:   The `eqv?-hash`{.code} procedure returns the hash number of the
    object `obj`{.variable .var}. The hash number is a small exact
    integer (fixnum). For any two objects `o1`{.variable .var} and
    `o2`{.variable .var}, `(eqv? `{.code}`o1`{.variable
    .var}` `{.code}`o2`{.variable .var}`)`{.code} implies


```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**equal?-hash** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-equal_003f_002dhash){.copiable-link}

:   The `equal?-hash`{.code} procedure returns the hash number of the
    object `obj`{.variable .var}. The hash number is a small exact
    integer (fixnum). For any two objects `o1`{.variable .var} and
    `o2`{.variable .var}, `(equal? `{.code}`o1`{.variable
    .var}` `{.code}`o2`{.variable .var}`)`{.code} implies
    `(= (equal?-hash `{.code}`o1`{.variable
    .var}`) (equal?-hash `{.code}`o2`{.variable .var}`))`{.code}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
