#### 8.10.2 Weak references {#Weak-references-1 .subsection}

The garbage collector is responsible for reclaiming objects that are no
longer needed by the program. This is done by analyzing the reachability
graph of all objects from the roots (i.e. the global variables, the
runnable threads, permanently allocated objects such as procedures
defined in a compiled file, nonexecutable wills, etc). If a root or a
reachable object `X`{.variable .var} contains a reference to an object
`Y`{.variable .var} then `Y`{.variable .var} is reachable. As a general
rule, unreachable objects are reclaimed by the garbage collector.

There are two types of references: strong references and weak
references. Most objects, including pairs, vectors, records and
closures, contain strong references. An object `X`{.variable .var} is
*strongly reachable* if there is a path from the roots to `X`{.variable
.var} that traverses only strong references. Weak references only occur
in wills and tables. There are two types of weak references: will-weak
references and table-weak references. If all paths from the roots to an
object `Y`{.variable .var} traverse at least one table-weak reference,
then `Y`{.variable .var} will be reclaimed by the garbage collector. The
will-weak references are used for finalization and are explained in the
next section.

-   [Wills](#Wills){accesskey="1"}

#### 8.10.2.1 Wills {#Wills-1 .subsubsection}

The following procedures implement the *will* data type. Will objects
provide support for finalization. A will is an object that contains a
will-weak reference to a `testator`{.variable .var} object (the object
attached to the will), and a strong reference to an `action`{.variable
.var} procedure which is a one parameter procedure which is called when
the will is executed.

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**make-will** `testator`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`action`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-make_002dwill){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**will?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-will_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**will-testator** `will`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-will_002dtestator){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**will-execute!** `will`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-will_002dexecute_0021){.copiable-link}

:   The `make-will`{.code} procedure creates a will object with the
    given `testator`{.variable .var} object and `action`{.variable .var}
    procedure. The `will?`{.code} procedure tests if `obj`{.variable
    .var} is a will object. The `will-testator`{.code} procedure gets
    the testator object attached to the `will`{.variable .var}. The
    `will-execute!`{.code} procedure executes `will`{.variable .var}.

    A will becomes *executable* when its `testator`{.variable .var}
    object is not strongly reachable (i.e. the `testator`{.variable
    .var} object is either unreachable or only reachable using paths
    from the roots that traverse at least one weak reference). Some
    objects, including symbols, small exact integers (fixnums), booleans
    and characters, are considered to be always strongly reachable.

    When the runtime system detects that a will has become executable
    the current computation is interrupted, the will's testator is set
    to `#f`{.code} and the will's action procedure is called with the
    will's testator as the sole argument. Currently only the garbage
    collector detects when wills become executable but this may change
    in future versions of Gambit (for example the compiler could perform
    an analysis to infer will executability at compile time). The
    garbage collector builds a list of all executable wills. Shortly
    after a garbage collection, the action procedures of these wills
    will be called. The link from the will to the action procedure is
    severed when the action procedure is called.

    Note that the testator object will not be reclaimed during the
    garbage collection that determined executability of the will. It is
    only when an object is not reachable from the roots that it is
    reclaimed by the garbage collector.

    A remarkable feature of wills is that an action procedure can
    "resurrect" an object. An action procedure could for example assign
    the testator object to a global variable or create a new will with
    the same testator object.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define a (list 123))
    > (set-cdr! a a) ; create a circular list
    > (define b (vector a))
    > (define c #f)
    > (define w
        (let ((obj a))
          (make-will obj
                     (lambda (x) ; x will be eq? to obj
                       (display "executing action procedure")
                       (newline)
                       (set! c x)))))
    > (will? w)
    #t
    > (car (will-testator w))
    123
    > (##gc)
    > (set! a #f)
    > (##gc)
    > (set! b #f)
    > (##gc)
    executing action procedure
    > (will-testator w)
    #f
    > (car c)
    123
    ```
    :::

#### 8.10.3 Tables {#Tables-1 .subsection}

The following procedures implement the *table* data type. Tables are
heterogenous structures whose elements are indexed by keys which are
arbitrary objects. Tables are similar to association lists but are
abstract and the access time for large tables is typically smaller. Each
key contained in the table is bound to a value. The length of the table
is the number of key/value bindings it contains. New key/value bindings
can be added to a table, the value bound to a key can be changed, and
existing key/value bindings can be removed.

The references to the keys can either be all strong or all table-weak
and the references to the values can either be all strong or all
table-weak. The garbage collector removes key/value bindings from a
table when 1) the key is a table-weak reference and the key is
unreachable or only reachable using paths from the roots that traverse
at least one table-weak reference, or 2) the value is a table-weak
reference and the value is unreachable or only reachable using paths
from the roots that traverse at least one table-weak reference.
Key/value bindings that are removed by the garbage collector are
reclaimed immediately.

Although there are several possible ways of implementing tables, the
current implementation uses hashing with open-addressing. This is space
efficient and provides constant-time access. Hash tables are
automatically resized to maintain the load within specified bounds. The
load is the number of active entries (the length of the table) divided
by the total number of entries in the hash table.

Tables are parameterized with a key comparison procedure. By default the
`equal?`{.code} procedure is used, but `eq?`{.code}, `eqv?`{.code},
`string=?`{.code}, `string-ci=?`{.code}, or a user defined procedure can
also be used. To support arbitrary key comparison procedures, tables are
also parameterized with a hashing procedure accepting a key as its
single parameter and returning a fixnum result. The hashing procedure
`hash`{.variable .var} must be consistent with the key comparison
procedure `test`{.variable .var}, that is, for any two keys
`k1`{.variable .var} and `k2`{.variable .var} in the table,
`(`{.code}`test`{.variable .var}` `{.code}`k1`{.variable
.var}` `{.code}`k2`{.variable .var}`)`{.code} implies
`(= (`{.code}`hash`{.variable .var}` `{.code}`k1`{.variable
.var}`) (`{.code}`hash`{.variable .var}` `{.code}`k2`{.variable
.var}`))`{.code}. A default hashing procedure consistent with the key
comparison procedure is provided by the system. The default hashing
procedure generally gives good performance when the key comparison
procedure is `eq?`{.code}, `eqv?`{.code}, `equal?`{.code},
`string=?`{.code}, and `string-ci=?`{.code}. However, for user defined
key comparison procedures, the default hashing procedure always returns
0. This degrades the performance of the table to a linear search.

Tables can be compared for equality using the `equal?`{.code} procedure.
Two tables `X`{.variable .var} and `Y`{.variable .var} are considered
equal by `equal?`{.code} when they have the same weakness attributes,
the same key comparison procedure, the same hashing procedure, the same
length, and for all the keys `k`{.variable .var} in `X`{.variable .var},
`(equal? (table-ref `{.code}`X`{.variable .var}` `{.code}`k`{.variable
.var}`) (table-ref `{.code}`Y`{.variable .var}` `{.code}`k`{.variable
.var}`))`{.code}.

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**make-table** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`size:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`size`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`init:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`init`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`weak-keys:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`weak-keys`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`weak-values:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`weak-values`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`test:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`test`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`hash:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`hash`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`min-load:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`min-load`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`max-load:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`max-load`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-make_002dtable){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `make-table`{.code} returns a new table. The optional
    keyword parameters specify various parameters of the table.

    The `size`{.variable .var} parameter is a nonnegative exact integer
    indicating the expected length of the table. The system uses
    `size`{.variable .var} to choose an appropriate initial size of the
    hash table so that it does not need to be resized too often.

    The `init`{.variable .var} parameter indicates a value that is
    associated to keys that are not in the table. When `init`{.variable
    .var} is not specified, no value is associated to keys that are not
    in the table.

    The `weak-keys`{.variable .var} and `weak-values`{.variable .var}
    parameters are extended booleans indicating respectively whether the
    keys and values are table-weak references (true) or strong
    references (false). By default the keys and values are strong
    references.

    The `test`{.variable .var} parameter indicates the key comparison
    procedure. The default key comparison procedure is `equal?`{.code}.
    The key comparison procedures `eq?`{.code}, `eqv?`{.code},
    `equal?`{.code}, `string=?`{.code}, and `string-ci=?`{.code} are
    special because the system will use a reasonably good hash procedure
    when none is specified.

    The `hash`{.variable .var} parameter indicates the hash procedure.
    This procedure must accept a single key parameter, return a fixnum,
    and be consistent with the key comparison procedure. When
    `hash`{.variable .var} is not specified, a default hash procedure is
    used. The default hash procedure is reasonably good when the key
    comparison procedure is `eq?`{.code}, `eqv?`{.code},
    `equal?`{.code}, `string=?`{.code}, or `string-ci=?`{.code}.

    The `min-load`{.variable .var} and `max-load`{.variable .var}
    parameters are real numbers that indicate the minimum and maximum
    load of the table respectively. The table is resized when adding or
    deleting a key/value binding would bring the table's load outside of
    this range. The `min-load`{.variable .var} parameter must be no less
    than 0.05 and the `max-load`{.variable .var} parameter must be no
    greater than 0.95. Moreover the difference between
    `min-load`{.variable .var} and `max-load`{.variable .var} must be at
    least 0.20. When `min-load`{.variable .var} is not specified, the
    value 0.45 is used. When `max-load`{.variable .var} is not
    specified, the value 0.90 is used.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define t (make-table))
    > (table? t)
    #t
    > (table-length t)
    0
    > (table-set! t (list 1 2) 3)
    > (table-set! t (list 4 5) 6)
    > (table-ref t (list 1 2))
    3
    > (table-length t)
    2
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**table?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-table_003f){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `table?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code} when
    `obj`{.variable .var} is a table and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (table? (make-table))
    #t
    > (table? 123)
    #f
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**table-length** `table`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-table_002dlength){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `table-length`{.code} returns the number of key/value
    bindings contained in the table `table`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define t (make-table weak-keys: #t))
    > (define x (list 1 2))
    > (define y (list 3 4))
    > (table-set! t x 111)
    > (table-set! t y 222)
    > (table-length t)
    2
    > (table-set! t x)
    > (table-length t)
    1
    > (##gc)
    > (table-length t)
    1
    > (set! y #f)
    > (##gc)
    > (table-length t)
    0
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**table-ref** `table`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`key`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`default`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-table_002dref){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `table-ref`{.code} returns the value bound to the
    object `key`{.variable .var} in the table `table`{.variable .var}.
    When `key`{.variable .var} is not bound and `default`{.variable
    .var} is specified, `default`{.variable .var} is returned. When
    `default`{.variable .var} is not specified but an `init`{.variable
    .var} parameter was specified when `table`{.variable .var} was
    created, `init`{.variable .var} is returned. Otherwise an
    unbound-key-exception object is raised.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define t1 (make-table init: 999))
    > (table-set! t1 (list 1 2) 3)
    > (table-ref t1 (list 1 2))
    3
    > (table-ref t1 (list 4 5))
    999
    > (table-ref t1 (list 4 5) #f)
    #f
    > (define t2 (make-table))
    > (table-ref t2 (list 4 5))
    *** ERROR IN (console)@7.1 -- Unbound key
    (table-ref '#<table #2> '(4 5))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**table-set!** `table`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`key`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`value`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-table_002dset_0021){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `table-set!`{.code} binds the object `key`{.variable
    .var} to `value`{.variable .var} in the table `table`{.variable
    .var}. When `value`{.variable .var} is not specified, if
    `table`{.variable .var} contains a binding for `key`{.variable .var}
    then the binding is removed from `table`{.variable .var}. The
    procedure `table-set!`{.code} returns an unspecified value.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define t (make-table))
    > (table-set! t (list 1 2) 3)
    > (table-set! t (list 4 5) 6)
    > (table-set! t (list 4 5))
    > (table-set! t (list 7 8))
    > (table-ref t (list 1 2))
    3
    > (table-ref t (list 4 5))
    *** ERROR IN (console)@7.1 -- Unbound key
    (table-ref '#<table #2> '(4 5))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**table-search** `proc`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`table`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-table_002dsearch){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `table-search`{.code} searches the table
    `table`{.variable .var} for a key/value binding for which the two
    parameter procedure `proc`{.variable .var} returns a non false
    result. For each key/value binding visited by `table-search`{.code}
    the procedure `proc`{.variable .var} is called with the key as the
    first parameter and the value as the second parameter. The procedure
    `table-search`{.code} returns the first non false value returned by
    `proc`{.variable .var}, or `#f`{.code} if `proc`{.variable .var}
    returned `#f`{.code} for all key/value bindings in `table`{.variable
    .var}.

    The order in which the key/value bindings are visited is unspecified
    and may vary from one call of `table-search`{.code} to the next.
    While a call to `table-search`{.code} is being performed on
    `table`{.variable .var}, it is an error to call any of the following
    procedures on `table`{.variable .var}: `table-ref`{.code},
    `table-set!`{.code}, `table-search`{.code}, `table-for-each`{.code},
    `table-copy`{.code}, `table-merge`{.code}, `table-merge!`{.code},
    and `table->list`{.code}. It is also an error to compare with
    `equal?`{.code} (directly or indirectly with `member`{.code},
    `assoc`{.code}, `table-ref`{.code}, etc.) an object that contains
    `table`{.variable .var}. All these procedures may cause
    `table`{.variable .var} to be reordered and resized. This
    restriction allows a more efficient iteration over the key/value
    bindings.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define square (make-table))
    > (table-set! square 2 4)
    > (table-set! square 3 9)
    > (table-search (lambda (k v) (and (odd? k) v)) square)
    9
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**table-for-each** `proc`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`table`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-table_002dfor_002deach){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `table-for-each`{.code} calls the two parameter
    procedure `proc`{.variable .var} for each key/value binding in the
    table `table`{.variable .var}. The procedure `proc`{.variable .var}
    is called with the key as the first parameter and the value as the
    second parameter. The procedure `table-for-each`{.code} returns an
    unspecified value.

    The order in which the key/value bindings are visited is unspecified
    and may vary from one call of `table-for-each`{.code} to the next.
    While a call to `table-for-each`{.code} is being performed on
    `table`{.variable .var}, it is an error to call any of the following
    procedures on `table`{.variable .var}: `table-ref`{.code},
    `table-set!`{.code}, `table-search`{.code}, `table-for-each`{.code},
    and `table->list`{.code}. It is also an error to compare with
    `equal?`{.code} (directly or indirectly with `member`{.code},
    `assoc`{.code}, `table-ref`{.code}, etc.) an object that contains
    `table`{.variable .var}. All these procedures may cause
    `table`{.variable .var} to be reordered and resized. This
    restriction allows a more efficient iteration over the key/value
    bindings.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define square (make-table))
    > (table-set! square 2 4)
    > (table-set! square 3 9)
    > (table-for-each (lambda (k v) (write (list k v)) (newline)) square)
    (2 4)
    (3 9)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**table-\>list** `table`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-table_002d_003elist){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `table->list`{.code} returns an association list
    containing the key/value bindings in the table `table`{.variable
    .var}. Each key/value binding yields a pair whose car field is the
    key and whose cdr field is the value bound to that key. The order of
    the bindings in the list is unspecified.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define square (make-table))
    > (table-set! square 2 4)
    > (table-set! square 3 9)
    > (table->list square)
    ((3 . 9) (2 . 4))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**list-\>table** `list`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`size:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`size`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`init:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`init`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`weak-keys:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`weak-keys`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`weak-values:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`weak-values`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`test:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`test`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`hash:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`hash`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`min-load:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`min-load`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`max-load:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`max-load`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-list_002d_003etable){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `list->table`{.code} returns a new table containing
    the key/value bindings in the association list `list`{.variable
    .var}. The optional keyword parameters specify various parameters of
    the table and have the same meaning as for the `make-table`{.code}
    procedure.

    Each element of `list`{.variable .var} is a pair whose car field is
    a key and whose cdr field is the value bound to that key. If a key
    appears more than once in `list`{.variable .var} (tested using the
    table's key comparison procedure) it is the first key/value binding
    in `list`{.variable .var} that has precedence.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define t (list->table '((b . 2) (a . 1) (c . 3) (a . 4))))
    > (table->list t)
    ((a . 1) (b . 2) (c . 3))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**unbound-key-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-unbound_002dkey_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**unbound-key-exception-procedure** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-unbound_002dkey_002dexception_002dprocedure){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**unbound-key-exception-arguments** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-unbound_002dkey_002dexception_002darguments){.copiable-link}

:   Unbound-key-exception objects are raised by the procedure
    `table-ref`{.code} when the key does not have a binding in the
    table. The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be an
    unbound-key-exception object.

    The procedure `unbound-key-exception?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code}
    when `obj`{.variable .var} is a unbound-key-exception object and
    `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `unbound-key-exception-procedure`{.code} returns the
    procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `unbound-key-exception-arguments`{.code} returns the
    list of arguments of the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable
    .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define t (make-table))
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (unbound-key-exception? exc)
            (list (unbound-key-exception-procedure exc)
                  (unbound-key-exception-arguments exc))
            'not-unbound-key-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (table-ref t '(1 2))))
    (#<procedure #2 table-ref> (#<table #3> (1 2)))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**table-copy** `table`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-table_002dcopy){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `table-copy`{.code} returns a new table containing the
    same key/value bindings as `table`{.variable .var} and the same
    table parameters (i.e. hash procedure, key comparison procedure, key
    and value weakness, etc).

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define t (list->table '((b . 2) (a . 1) (c . 3))))
    > (define x (table-copy t))
    > (table-set! t 'b 99)
    > (table->list t)
    ((a . 1) (b . 99) (c . 3))
    > (table->list x)
    ((a . 1) (b . 2) (c . 3))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**table-merge!** `table1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`table2`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`table2-takes-precedence?`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-table_002dmerge_0021){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `table-merge!`{.code} returns `table1`{.variable .var}
    after the key/value bindings contained in `table2`{.variable .var}
    have been added to it. When a key exists both in `table1`{.variable
    .var} and `table2`{.variable .var}, then the parameter
    `table2-takes-precedence?`{.variable .var} indicates which binding
    will be kept (the one in `table1`{.variable .var} if
    `table2-takes-precedence?`{.variable .var} is false, and the one in
    `table2`{.variable .var} otherwise). If
    `table2-takes-precedence?`{.variable .var} is not specified the
    binding in `table1`{.variable .var} is kept.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define t1 (list->table '((a . 1) (b . 2) (c . 3))))
    > (define t2 (list->table '((a . 4) (b . 5) (z . 6))))
    > (table->list (table-merge! t1 t2))
    ((a . 1) (b . 2) (c . 3) (z . 6))
    > (define t1 (list->table '((a . 1) (b . 2) (c . 3))))
    > (define t2 (list->table '((a . 4) (b . 5) (z . 6))))
    > (table->list (table-merge! t1 t2 #t))
    ((a . 4) (b . 5) (c . 3) (z . 6))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**table-merge** `table1`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`table2`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`table2-takes-precedence?`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-table_002dmerge){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `table-merge`{.code} returns a copy of
    `table1`{.variable .var} (created with `table-copy`{.code}) to which
    the key/value bindings contained in `table2`{.variable .var} have
    been added using `table-merge!`{.code}. When a key exists both in
    `table1`{.variable .var} and `table2`{.variable .var}, then the
    parameter `table2-takes-precedence?`{.variable .var} indicates which
    binding will be kept (the one in `table1`{.variable .var} if
    `table2-takes-precedence?`{.variable .var} is false, and the one in
    `table2`{.variable .var} otherwise). If
    `table2-takes-precedence?`{.variable .var} is not specified the
    binding in `table1`{.variable .var} is kept.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define t1 (list->table '((a . 1) (b . 2) (c . 3))))
    > (define t2 (list->table '((a . 4) (b . 5) (z . 6))))
    > (table->list (table-merge t1 t2))
    ((a . 1) (b . 2) (c . 3) (z . 6))
    > (table->list (table-merge t1 t2 #t))
    ((a . 4) (b . 5) (c . 3) (z . 6))
    ```

## 9 Records {#Records-1 .chapter}

[special form: ]{.category-def}**define-structure** [*`name`{.variable .def-var-arguments}*]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[*`field`{.variable .def-var-arguments}*]{.r}`…`{.variable .def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-define_002dstructure){.copiable-link}

:   Record data types similar to Pascal records and C `struct`{.code}
    types can be defined using the `define-structure`{.code} special
    form. The identifier *name* specifies the name of the new data type.
    The structure name is followed by `k`{.variable .var} identifiers
    naming each field of the record. The `define-structure`{.code}
    expands into a set of definitions of the following procedures:

    -   '`make-`{.t}*name*' -- A `k`{.variable .var} argument procedure
        which constructs a new record from the value of its
        `k`{.variable .var} fields.
    -   '*name*`?`{.t}' -- A procedure which tests if its single
        argument is of the given record type.
    -   '*name*`-`{.t}*field*' -- For each field, a procedure taking as
        its single argument a value of the given record type and
        returning the content of the corresponding field of the record.
    -   '*name*`-`{.t}*field*`-set!`{.t}' -- For each field, a two
        argument procedure taking as its first argument a value of the
        given record type. The second argument gets assigned to the
        corresponding field of the record and the void object is
        returned.

    Record data types have a printed representation that includes the
    name of the type and the name and value of each field. Record data
    types can not be read by the `read`{.code} procedure.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define-structure point x y color)
    > (define p (make-point 3 5 'red))
    > p
    #<point #2 x: 3 y: 5 color: red>
    > (point-x p)
    3
    > (point-color p)
    red
    > (point-color-set! p 'black)
    > p
    #<point #2 x: 3 y: 5 color: black>
    ```
    :::

## 10 Threads {#Threads-1 .chapter}

[]{#index-threads .index-entry-id}

Gambit supports the execution of multiple Scheme threads. These threads
are managed entirely by Gambit's runtime and are not related to the host
operating system's threads. Gambit's runtime does not currently take
advantage of multiprocessors (i.e. at most one thread is running).

### 10.1 Introduction {#Introduction-1 .section}

Multithreading is a paradigm that is well suited for building complex
systems such as: servers, GUIs, and high-level operating systems.
Gambit's thread system offers mechanisms for creating threads of
execution and for synchronizing them. The thread system also supports
features which are useful in a real-time context, such as priorities,
priority inheritance and timeouts.

The thread system provides the following data types:

-   Thread (a virtual processor which shares object space with all other
    threads)
-   Mutex (a mutual exclusion device, also known as a lock and binary
    semaphore)
-   Condition variable (a set of blocked threads)

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

::: {#Thread-objects .section-level-extent}
::: nav-panel

### 10.2 Thread objects {#Thread-objects-1 .section}

A *running thread* is a thread that is currently executing. A *runnable
thread* is a thread that is ready to execute or running. A thread is
*blocked* if it is waiting for a mutex to become unlocked, an I/O
operation to become possible, the end of a "sleep" period, etc. A *new
thread* is a thread that has been allocated but has not yet been
initialized. An *initialized thread* is a thread that can be made
runnable. A new thread becomes runnable when it is started by calling
`thread-start!`{.code}. A *terminated thread* is a thread that can no
longer become runnable (but *deadlocked threads* are not considered
terminated). The only valid transitions between the thread states are
from new to initialized, from initialized to runnable, between runnable
and blocked, and from any state except new to terminated as indicated in
the following diagram:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
                                            unblock
                          start            <-------
NEW -------> INITIALIZED -------> RUNNABLE -------> BLOCKED
                       \             |      block  /
                        \            v            /
                         +-----> TERMINATED <----+
```
:::

Each thread has a *base priority*, which is a real number (where a
higher numerical value means a higher priority), a *priority boost*,
which is a nonnegative real number representing the priority increase
applied to a thread when it blocks, and a *quantum*, which is a
nonnegative real number representing a duration in seconds.

Each thread has a *specific field* which can be used in an application
specific way to associate data with the thread (some thread systems call
this "thread local storage").

Each thread has a *mailbox* which is used for inter-thread
communication.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

### 10.3 Mutex objects {#Mutex-objects-1 .section}

A mutex can be in one of four states: *locked* (either *owned* or *not
owned*) and *unlocked* (either *abandoned* or *not abandoned*).

An attempt to lock a mutex only succeeds if the mutex is in an unlocked
state, otherwise the current thread will wait. A mutex in the
locked/owned state has an associated *owner thread*, which by convention
is the thread that is responsible for unlocking the mutex (this case is
typical of critical sections implemented as "lock mutex, perform
operation, unlock mutex"). A mutex in the locked/not-owned state is not
linked to a particular thread.

A mutex becomes locked when a thread locks it using the
'`mutex-lock!`{.sample .samp}' primitive. A mutex becomes
unlocked/abandoned when the owner of a locked/owned mutex terminates. A
mutex becomes unlocked/not-abandoned when a thread unlocks it using the
'`mutex-unlock!`{.sample .samp}' primitive.

The mutex primitives do not implement *recursive mutex semantics*. An
attempt to lock a mutex that is locked implies that the current thread
waits even if the mutex is owned by the current thread (this can lead to
a deadlock if no other thread unlocks the mutex).

Each mutex has a *specific field* which can be used in an application
specific way to associate data with the mutex.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

### 10.4 Condition variable objects {#Condition-variable-objects-1 .section}

A condition variable represents a set of blocked threads. These blocked
threads are waiting for a certain condition to become true. When a
thread modifies some program state that might make the condition true,
the thread unblocks some number of threads (one or all depending on the
primitive used) so they can check if the condition is now true. This
allows complex forms of interthread synchronization to be expressed more
conveniently than with mutexes alone.

Each condition variable has a *specific field* which can be used in an
application specific way to associate data with the condition variable.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

### 10.5 Fairness {#Fairness-1 .section}

In various situations the scheduler must select one thread from a set of
threads (e.g. which thread to run when a running thread blocks or
expires its quantum, which thread to unblock when a mutex becomes
unlocked or a condition variable is signaled). The constraints on the
selection process determine the scheduler's *fairness*. The selection
depends on the order in which threads become runnable or blocked and on
the *priority* attached to the threads.

The definition of fairness requires the notion of time ordering, i.e.
"event `A`{.variable .var} occured before event `B`{.variable .var}".
For the purpose of establishing time ordering, the scheduler uses a
clock with a discrete, usually variable, resolution (a "tick"). Events
occuring in a given tick can be considered to be simultaneous (i.e. if
event `A`{.variable .var} occured before event `B`{.variable .var} in
real time, then the scheduler will claim that event `A`{.variable .var}
occured before event `B`{.variable .var} unless both events fall within
the same tick, in which case the scheduler arbitrarily chooses a time
ordering).

Each thread `T`{.variable .var} has three priorities which affect
fairness; the *base priority*, the *boosted priority*, and the
*effective priority*.

-   The *base priority* is the value contained in `T`{.variable .var}'s
    *base priority* field (which is set with the
    '`thread-base-priority-set!`{.sample .samp}' primitive).
-   `T`{.variable .var}'s *boosted flag* field contains a boolean that
    affects `T`{.variable .var}'s *boosted priority*. When the boosted
    flag field is false, the boosted priority is equal to the base
    priority, otherwise the boosted priority is equal to the base
    priority plus the value contained in `T`{.variable .var}'s *priority
    boost* field (which is set with the
    '`thread-priority-boost-set!`{.sample .samp}' primitive). The
    boosted flag field is set to false when a thread is created, when
    its quantum expires, and when *thread-yield!* is called. The boosted
    flag field is set to true when a thread blocks. By carefully
    choosing the base priority and priority boost, relatively to the
    other threads, it is possible to set up an interactive thread so
    that it has good I/O response time without being a CPU hog when it
    performs long computations.
-   The *effective priority* is equal to the maximum of `T`{.variable
    .var}'s boosted priority and the effective priority of all the
    threads that are blocked on a mutex owned by `T`{.variable .var}.
    This *priority inheritance* avoids priority inversion problems that
    would prevent a high priority thread blocked at the entry of a
    critical section to progress because a low priority thread inside
    the critical section is preempted for an arbitrary long time by a
    medium priority thread.

Let `P`{.variable .var}(`T`{.variable .var}) be the effective priority
of thread `T`{.variable .var} and let `R`{.variable .var}(`T`{.variable
.var}) be the most recent time when one of the following events occurred
for thread `T`{.variable .var}, thus making it runnable: `T`{.variable
.var} was started by calling '`thread-start!`{.sample .samp}',
`T`{.variable .var} called '`thread-yield!`{.sample .samp}',
`T`{.variable .var} expired its quantum, or `T`{.variable .var} became
unblocked. Let the relation `NL`{.variable .var}(`T1`{.variable
.var},`T2`{.variable .var}), "`T1`{.variable .var} no later than
`T2`{.variable .var}", be true if `P`{.variable .var}(`T1`{.variable
.var})\<`P`{.variable .var}(`T2`{.variable .var}) or `P`{.variable
.var}(`T1`{.variable .var})=`P`{.variable .var}(`T2`{.variable .var})
and `R`{.variable .var}(`T1`{.variable .var})\>`R`{.variable
.var}(`T2`{.variable .var}), and false otherwise. The scheduler will
schedule the execution of threads in such a way that whenever there is
at least one runnable thread, 1) within a finite time at least one
thread will be running, and 2) there is never a pair of runnable threads
`T1`{.variable .var} and `T2`{.variable .var} for which `NL`{.variable
.var}(`T1`{.variable .var},`T2`{.variable .var}) is true and
`T1`{.variable .var} is not running and `T2`{.variable .var} is running.

A thread `T`{.variable .var} expires its quantum when an amount of time
equal to `T`{.variable .var}'s quantum has elapsed since `T`{.variable
.var} entered the running state and `T`{.variable .var} did not block,
terminate or call '`thread-yield!`{.sample .samp}'. At that point
`T`{.variable .var} exits the running state to allow other threads to
run. A thread's quantum is thus an indication of the rate of progress of
the thread relative to the other threads of the same priority. Moreover,
the resolution of the timer measuring the running time may cause a
certain deviation from the quantum, so a thread's quantum should only be
viewed as an approximation of the time it can run before yielding to
another thread.

Threads blocked on a given mutex or condition variable will unblock in
an order which is consistent with decreasing priority and increasing
blocking time (i.e. the highest priority thread unblocks first, and
among equal priority threads the one that blocked first unblocks first).

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

### 10.6 Memory coherency {#Memory-coherency-1 .section}

Read and write operations on the store (such as reading and writing a
variable, an element of a vector or a string) are not atomic. It is an
error for a thread to write a location in the store while some other
thread reads or writes that same location. It is the responsibility of
the application to avoid write/read and write/write races through
appropriate uses of the synchronization primitives.

Concurrent reads and writes to ports are allowed. It is the
responsibility of the implementation to serialize accesses to a given
port using the appropriate synchronization primitives.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

### 10.7 Timeouts {#Timeouts-1 .section}

All synchronization primitives which take a timeout parameter accept
three types of values as a timeout, with the following meaning:

-   a time object represents an absolute point in time
-   an exact or inexact real number represents a relative time in
    seconds from the moment the primitive was called
-   '`#f`{.sample .samp}' means that there is no timeout

When a timeout denotes the current time or a time in the past, the
synchronization primitive claims that the timeout has been reached only
after the other synchronization conditions have been checked. Moreover
the thread remains running (it does not enter the blocked state). For
example, `(mutex-lock! m 0)`{.code} will lock mutex `m`{.code} and
return '`#t`{.sample .samp}' if `m`{.code} is currently unlocked,
otherwise '`#f`{.sample .samp}' is returned because the timeout is
reached.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

### 10.8 Primordial thread {#Primordial-thread-1 .section}

The execution of a program is initially under the control of a single
thread known as the *primordial thread*. The primordial thread has an
unspecified base priority, priority boost, boosted flag, quantum, name,
specific field, dynamic environment, '`dynamic-wind`{.sample .samp}'
stack, and exception-handler. All threads are terminated when the
primordial thread terminates (normally or not).

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**make-root-thread** `thunk`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`name`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`thread-group`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`input-port`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`output-port`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-make_002droot_002dthread){.copiable-link}

:   The `make-thread`{.code} procedure creates and returns an
    initialized thread. This thread is not automatically made runnable
    (the procedure `thread-start!`{.code} must be used for this). A
    thread has the following fields: base priority, priority boost,
    boosted flag, quantum, name, specific, end-result, end-exception,
    and a list of locked/owned mutexes it owns. The thread's execution
    consists of a call to `thunk`{.variable .var} with the *initial
    continuation*. This continuation causes the (then) current thread to
    store the result in its end-result field, abandon all mutexes it
    owns, and finally terminate. The '`dynamic-wind`{.sample .samp}'
    stack of the initial continuation is empty. The optional
    `name`{.variable .var} is an arbitrary Scheme object which
    identifies the thread (useful for debugging); it defaults to an
    unspecified value. The specific field is set to an unspecified
    value. The optional `thread-group`{.variable .var} indicates which
    thread group this thread belongs to; it defaults to the thread group
    of the current thread. The base priority, priority boost, and
    quantum of the thread are set to the same value as the current
    thread and the boosted flag is set to false. The thread's mailbox is
    initially empty. The thread inherits the dynamic environment from
    the current thread. Moreover, in this dynamic environment the
    exception-handler is bound to the *initial exception-handler* which
    is a unary procedure which causes the (then) current thread to store
    in its end-exception field an uncaught-exception object whose
    "reason" is the argument of the handler, abandon all mutexes it
    owns, and finally terminate.

    The `make-root-thread`{.code} procedure behaves like the
    `make-thread`{.code} procedure except the created thread does not
    inherit the dynamic environment from the current thread and the base
    priority is set to 0, the priority boost is set to 1.0e-6, and the
    quantum is set to 0.02. The dynamic environment of the thread has
    the global bindings of the parameter objects, except
    `current-input-port`{.code} which is bound to `input-port`{.variable
    .var}, `current-output-port`{.code} which is bound to
    `output-port`{.variable .var}, and `current-directory`{.code} which
    is bound to the initial current working directory of the current
    process. If `input-port`{.variable .var} is not specified it
    defaults to a port corresponding to the standard input
    ('`stdin`{.sample .samp}'). If `output-port`{.variable .var} is not
    specified it defaults to a port corresponding to the standard output
    ('`stdout`{.sample .samp}').

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (make-thread (lambda () (write 'hello)))
    #<thread #2>
    > (make-root-thread (lambda () (write 'world)) 'a-name)
    #<thread #3 a-name>
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**thread** `thunk`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-thread){.copiable-link}

:   The `thread`{.code} procedure creates, starts and returns a new
    thread. The call `(thread `{.code}`thunk`{.variable .var}`)`{.code}
    is equivalent to
    `(thread-start! (make-thread `{.code}`thunk`{.variable
    .var}`))`{.code}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define a (thread (lambda () (expt 2 1005))))
    > (define b (thread (lambda () (expt 2 1000))))
    > (/ (thread-join! a) (thread-join! b))
    32
    ```
    :::

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**thread-quantum** `thread`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-thread_002dquantum){.copiable-link}\

:   The procedure `thread-quantum`{.code} returns a real number which
    corresponds to the quantum of the `thread`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `thread-quantum-set!`{.code} changes the quantum of
    the `thread`{.variable .var} to `quantum`{.variable .var} and
    returns an unspecified value. The `quantum`{.variable .var} must be
    a nonnegative real. A value of zero selects the smallest quantum
    supported by the implementation.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (thread-quantum-set! (current-thread) 1.5)
    > (thread-quantum (current-thread))
    1.5
    > (thread-quantum-set! (current-thread) 0)
    > (thread-quantum (current-thread))
    0.
    ```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**thread-start!** `thread`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-thread_002dstart_0021){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure makes `thread`{.variable .var} runnable and returns
    the `thread`{.variable .var}. The `thread`{.variable .var} must be
    an initialized thread.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (let ((t (thread-start! (make-thread (lambda () (write 'a))))))
        (write 'b)
        (thread-join! t))
    ab> or ba>
    ```
    :::

    NOTE: It is useful to separate thread creation and thread activation
    to avoid the race condition that would occur if the created thread
    tries to examine a table in which the current thread stores the
    created thread. See the last example of the
    `thread-terminate!`{.code} procedure which contains mutually
    recursive threads.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**thread-yield!** [¶](#index-thread_002dyield_0021){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure causes the current thread to exit the running state
    as if its quantum had expired and returns an unspecified value.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    ; a busy loop that avoids being too wasteful of the CPU

    (let loop ()
      (if (mutex-lock! m 0) ; try to lock m but don’t block
          (begin
            (display "locked mutex m")
            (mutex-unlock! m))
          (begin
            (do-something-else)
            (thread-yield!) ; relinquish rest of quantum
            (loop))))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**thread-sleep!** `timeout`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-thread_002dsleep_0021){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure causes the current thread to wait until the timeout
    is reached and returns an unspecified value. This blocks the thread
    only if `timeout`{.variable .var} represents a point in the future.
    It is an error for `timeout`{.variable .var} to be '`#f`{.sample
    .samp}'.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    ; a clock with a gradual drift:

    (let loop ((x 1))
      (thread-sleep! 1)
      (write x)
      (loop (+ x 1)))

    ; a clock with no drift:

    (let ((start (time->seconds (current-time)))
      (let loop ((x 1))
        (thread-sleep! (seconds->time (+ x start)))
        (write x)
        (loop (+ x 1))))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**thread-terminate!** `thread`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-thread_002dterminate_0021){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure causes an abnormal termination of the
    `thread`{.variable .var}. If the `thread`{.variable .var} is not
    already terminated, all mutexes owned by the `thread`{.variable
    .var} become unlocked/abandoned and a terminated-thread-exception
    object is stored in the `thread`{.variable .var}'s end-exception
    field. If `thread`{.variable .var} is the current thread,
    `thread-terminate!`{.code} does not return. Otherwise
    `thread-terminate!`{.code} returns an unspecified value; the
    termination of the `thread`{.variable .var} will occur at some point
    between the calling of `thread-terminate!`{.code} and a finite time
    in the future (an explicit thread synchronization is needed to
    detect termination, see `thread-join!`{.code}).

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    (define (amb thunk1 thunk2)
      (let ((result #f)
            (result-mutex (make-mutex))
            (done-mutex (make-mutex)))
        (letrec ((child1
                  (make-thread
                    (lambda ()
                      (let ((x (thunk1)))
                        (mutex-lock! result-mutex #f #f)
                        (set! result x)
                        (thread-terminate! child2)
                        (mutex-unlock! done-mutex)))))
                 (child2
                  (make-thread
                    (lambda ()
                      (let ((x (thunk2)))
                        (mutex-lock! result-mutex #f #f)
                        (set! result x)
                        (thread-terminate! child1)
                        (mutex-unlock! done-mutex))))))
          (mutex-lock! done-mutex #f #f)
          (thread-start! child1)
          (thread-start! child2)
          (mutex-lock! done-mutex #f #f)
          result)))
    ```
    :::

    NOTE: This operation must be used carefully because it terminates a
    thread abruptly and it is impossible for that thread to perform any
    kind of cleanup. This may be a problem if the thread is in the
    middle of a critical section where some structure has been put in an
    inconsistent state. However, another thread attempting to enter this
    critical section will raise an abandoned-mutex-exception object
    because the mutex is unlocked/abandoned. This helps avoid observing
    an inconsistent state. Clean termination can be obtained by polling,
    as shown in the example below.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    (define (spawn thunk)
      (let ((t (make-thread thunk)))
        (thread-specific-set! t #t)
        (thread-start! t)
        t))

    (define (stop! thread)
      (thread-specific-set! thread #f)
      (thread-join! thread))

    (define (keep-going?)
      (thread-specific (current-thread)))

    (define count!
      (let ((m (make-mutex))
            (i 0))
        (lambda ()
          (mutex-lock! m)
          (let ((x (+ i 1)))
            (set! i x)
            (mutex-unlock! m)
            x))))

    (define (increment-forever!)
      (let loop () (count!) (if (keep-going?) (loop))))

    (let ((t1 (spawn increment-forever!))
          (t2 (spawn increment-forever!)))
      (thread-sleep! 1)
      (stop! t1)
      (stop! t2)
      (count!))  ==>  377290
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**thread-join!** `thread `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`timeout`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`timeout-val`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-thread_002djoin_0021){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure causes the current thread to wait until the
    `thread`{.variable .var} terminates (normally or not) or until the
    timeout is reached if `timeout`{.variable .var} is supplied. If the
    timeout is reached, `thread-join!`{.variable .var} returns
    `timeout-val`{.variable .var} if it is supplied, otherwise a
    join-timeout-exception object is raised. If the `thread`{.variable
    .var} terminated normally, the content of the end-result field is
    returned, otherwise the content of the end-exception field is
    raised.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    (let ((t (thread-start! (make-thread (lambda () (expt 2 100))))))
      (do-something-else)
      (thread-join! t))  ==>  1267650600228229401496703205376

    (let ((t (thread-start! (make-thread (lambda () (raise 123))))))
      (do-something-else)
      (with-exception-handler
        (lambda (exc)
          (if (uncaught-exception? exc)
              (* 10 (uncaught-exception-reason exc))
              99999))
        (lambda ()
          (+ 1 (thread-join! t)))))  ==>  1231

    (define thread-alive?
      (let ((unique (list 'unique)))
        (lambda (thread)
          ; Note: this procedure raises an exception if
          ; the thread terminated abnormally.
          (eq? (thread-join! thread 0 unique) unique))))

    (define (wait-for-termination! thread)
      (let ((eh (current-exception-handler)))
        (with-exception-handler
          (lambda (exc)
            (if (not (or (terminated-thread-exception? exc)
                         (uncaught-exception? exc)))
                (eh exc))) ; unexpected exceptions are handled by eh
          (lambda ()
            ; The following call to thread-join! will wait until the
            ; thread terminates.  If the thread terminated normally
            ; thread-join! will return normally.  If the thread
            ; terminated abnormally then one of these two exception
            ; objects is raised by thread-join!:
            ;   - terminated-thread-exception object
            ;   - uncaught-exception object
            (thread-join! thread)
            #f)))) ; ignore result of thread-join!
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**thread-send** `thread`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`msg`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-thread_002dsend){.copiable-link}

:   Each thread has a mailbox which stores messages delivered to the
    thread in the order delivered.

    The procedure `thread-send`{.code} adds the message `msg`{.variable
    .var} at the end of the mailbox of thread `thread`{.variable .var}
    and returns an unspecified value.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (thread-send (current-thread) 111)
    > (thread-send (current-thread) 222)
    > (thread-receive)
    111
    > (thread-receive)
    222
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**thread-receive** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`timeout`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`default`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-thread_002dreceive){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**thread-mailbox-next** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`timeout`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`default`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-thread_002dmailbox_002dnext){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**thread-mailbox-rewind** [¶](#index-thread_002dmailbox_002drewind){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**thread-mailbox-extract-and-rewind** [¶](#index-thread_002dmailbox_002dextract_002dand_002drewind){.copiable-link}

:   To allow a thread to examine the messages in its mailbox without
    removing them from the mailbox, each thread has a *mailbox cursor*
    which normally points to the last message accessed in the mailbox.
    When a mailbox cursor is rewound using the procedure
    `thread-mailbox-rewind`{.code} or
    `thread-mailbox-extract-and-rewind`{.code} or
    `thread-receive`{.code}, the cursor does not point to a message, but
    the next call to `thread-receive`{.code} and
    `thread-mailbox-next`{.code} will set the cursor to the oldest
    message in the mailbox.

    The procedure `thread-receive`{.code} advances the mailbox cursor of
    the current thread to the next message, removes that message from
    the mailbox, rewinds the mailbox cursor, and returns the message.
    When `timeout`{.variable .var} is not specified, the current thread
    will wait until a message is available in the mailbox. When
    `timeout`{.variable .var} is specified and `default`{.variable .var}
    is not specified, a mailbox-receive-timeout-exception object is
    raised if the timeout is reached before a message is available. When
    `timeout`{.variable .var} is specified and `default`{.variable .var}
    is specified, `default`{.variable .var} is returned if the timeout
    is reached before a message is available.

    The procedure `thread-mailbox-next`{.code} behaves like
    `thread-receive`{.code} except that the message remains in the
    mailbox and the mailbox cursor is not rewound.

    The procedures `thread-mailbox-rewind`{.code} or
    `thread-mailbox-extract-and-rewind`{.code} rewind the mailbox cursor
    of the current thread so that the next call to
    `thread-mailbox-next`{.code} and `thread-receive`{.code} will access
    the oldest message in the mailbox. Additionally the procedure
    `thread-mailbox-extract-and-rewind`{.code} will remove from the
    mailbox the message most recently accessed by a call to
    `thread-mailbox-next`{.code}. When `thread-mailbox-next`{.code} has
    not been called since the last call to `thread-receive`{.code} or
    `thread-mailbox-rewind`{.code} or
    `thread-mailbox-extract-and-rewind`{.code}, a call to
    `thread-mailbox-extract-and-rewind`{.code} only resets the mailbox
    cursor (no message is removed).

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (thread-send (current-thread) 111)
    > (thread-receive 1 999)
    111
    > (thread-send (current-thread) 222)
    > (thread-send (current-thread) 333)
    > (thread-mailbox-next 1 999)
    222
    > (thread-mailbox-next 1 999)
    333
    > (thread-mailbox-next 1 999)
    999
    > (thread-mailbox-extract-and-rewind)
    > (thread-receive 1 999)
    222
    > (thread-receive 1 999)
    999
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**mailbox-receive-timeout-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-mailbox_002dreceive_002dtimeout_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**mailbox-receive-timeout-exception-procedure** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-mailbox_002dreceive_002dtimeout_002dexception_002dprocedure){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**mailbox-receive-timeout-exception-arguments** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-mailbox_002dreceive_002dtimeout_002dexception_002darguments){.copiable-link}

:   Mailbox-receive-timeout-exception objects are raised by the
    procedures `thread-receive`{.code} and `thread-mailbox-next`{.code}
    when a timeout expires before a message is available and no default
    value is specified. The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be a
    mailbox-receive-timeout-exception object.

    The procedure `mailbox-receive-timeout-exception?`{.code} returns
    `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is a
    mailbox-receive-timeout-exception object and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `mailbox-receive-timeout-exception-procedure`{.code}
    returns the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `mailbox-receive-timeout-exception-arguments`{.code}
    returns the list of arguments of the procedure that raised
    `exc`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (mailbox-receive-timeout-exception? exc)
            (list (mailbox-receive-timeout-exception-procedure exc)
                  (mailbox-receive-timeout-exception-arguments exc))
            'not-mailbox-receive-timeout-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (thread-receive 1)))
    (#<procedure #2 thread-receive> (1))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**make-mutex** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`name`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-make_002dmutex){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns a new mutex in the unlocked/not-abandoned
    state. The optional `name`{.variable .var} is an arbitrary Scheme
    object which identifies the mutex (useful for debugging); it
    defaults to an unspecified value. The mutex's specific field is set
    to an unspecified value.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (make-mutex)
    ```

:   Returns the name of the `mutex`{.variable .var}. For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**mutex-specific** `mutex`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-mutex_002dspecific){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**mutex-specific-set!** `mutex`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-mutex_002dspecific_002dset_0021){.copiable-link}

:   The `mutex-specific`{.code} procedure returns the content of the
    `mutex`{.variable .var}'s specific field.

    The `mutex-specific-set!`{.code} procedure stores `obj`{.variable
    .var} into the `mutex`{.variable .var}'s specific field and returns
    an unspecified value.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define m (make-mutex))
    > (mutex-specific-set! m "hello")
    > (mutex-specific m)
    "hello"
    > (define (mutex-lock-recursively! mutex)
        (if (eq? (mutex-state mutex) (current-thread))
            (let ((n (mutex-specific mutex)))
              (mutex-specific-set! mutex (+ n 1)))
            (begin
              (mutex-lock! mutex)
              (mutex-specific-set! mutex 0))))
    > (define (mutex-unlock-recursively! mutex)
        (let ((n (mutex-specific mutex)))
          (if (= n 0)
              (mutex-unlock! mutex)
              (mutex-specific-set! mutex (- n 1)))))
    > (mutex-lock-recursively! m)
    > (mutex-lock-recursively! m)
    > (mutex-lock-recursively! m)
    > (mutex-specific m)
    2
    ```
    :::

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**mutex-state** `mutex`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-mutex_002dstate){.copiable-link}

:   Thos procedure returns information about the state of the
    `mutex`{.variable .var}. The possible results are:

    -   thread `T`{.variable .var}: the `mutex`{.variable .var} is in
        the locked/owned state and thread `T`{.variable .var} is the
        owner of the `mutex`{.variable .var}
    -   symbol `not-owned`{.code}: the `mutex`{.variable .var} is in the
        locked/not-owned state
    -   symbol `abandoned`{.code}: the `mutex`{.variable .var} is in the
        unlocked/abandoned state
    -   symbol `not-abandoned`{.code}: the `mutex`{.variable .var} is in
        the unlocked/not-abandoned state

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    (mutex-state (make-mutex))  ==>  not-abandoned

    (define (thread-alive? thread)
      (let ((mutex (make-mutex)))
        (mutex-lock! mutex #f thread)
        (let ((state (mutex-state mutex)))
          (mutex-unlock! mutex) ; avoid space leak
          (eq? state thread))))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**mutex-lock!** `mutex`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`timeout`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`thread`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-mutex_002dlock_0021){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure locks `mutex`{.variable .var}. If the
    `mutex`{.variable .var} is currently locked, the current thread
    waits until the `mutex`{.variable .var} is unlocked, or until the
    timeout is reached if `timeout`{.variable .var} is supplied. If the
    timeout is reached, `mutex-lock!`{.code} returns '`#f`{.sample
    .samp}'. Otherwise, the state of the `mutex`{.variable .var} is
    changed as follows:

    -   if `thread`{.variable .var} is '`#f`{.sample .samp}' the
        `mutex`{.variable .var} becomes locked/not-owned,
    -   otherwise, let `T`{.variable .var} be `thread`{.variable .var}
        (or the current thread if `thread`{.variable .var} is not
        supplied),
        -   if `T`{.variable .var} is terminated the `mutex`{.variable
            .var} becomes unlocked/abandoned,
        -   otherwise `mutex`{.variable .var} becomes locked/owned with
            `T`{.variable .var} as the owner.

    After changing the state of the `mutex`{.variable .var}, an
    abandoned-mutex-exception object is raised if the `mutex`{.variable
    .var} was unlocked/abandoned before the state change, otherwise
    `mutex-lock!`{.code} returns '`#t`{.sample .samp}'. It is not an
    error if the `mutex`{.variable .var} is owned by the current thread
    (but the current thread will have to wait).

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    ; an implementation of a mailbox object of depth one; this
    ; implementation does not behave well in the presence of forced
    ; thread terminations using thread-terminate! (deadlock can occur
    ; if a thread is terminated in the middle of a put! or get! operation)

    (define (make-empty-mailbox)
      (let ((put-mutex (make-mutex)) ; allow put! operation
            (get-mutex (make-mutex))
            (cell #f))

        (define (put! obj)
          (mutex-lock! put-mutex #f #f) ; prevent put! operation
          (set! cell obj)
          (mutex-unlock! get-mutex)) ; allow get! operation

        (define (get!)
          (mutex-lock! get-mutex #f #f) ; wait until object in mailbox
          (let ((result cell))
            (set! cell #f) ; prevent space leaks
            (mutex-unlock! put-mutex) ; allow put! operation
            result))

        (mutex-lock! get-mutex #f #f) ; prevent get! operation

        (lambda (msg)
          (case msg
            ((put!) put!)
            ((get!) get!)
            (else (error "unknown message"))))))

    (define (mailbox-put! m obj) ((m 'put!) obj))
    (define (mailbox-get! m) ((m 'get!)))

    ; an alternate implementation of thread-sleep!

    (define (sleep! timeout)
      (let ((m (make-mutex)))
        (mutex-lock! m #f #f)
        (mutex-lock! m timeout #f)))

    ; a procedure that waits for one of two mutexes to unlock

    (define (lock-one-of! mutex1 mutex2)
      ; this procedure assumes that neither mutex1 or mutex2
      ; are owned by the current thread
      (let ((ct (current-thread))
            (done-mutex (make-mutex)))
        (mutex-lock! done-mutex #f #f)
        (let ((t1 (thread-start!
                   (make-thread
                    (lambda ()
                      (mutex-lock! mutex1 #f ct)
                      (mutex-unlock! done-mutex)))))
              (t2 (thread-start!
                   (make-thread
                    (lambda ()
                      (mutex-lock! mutex2 #f ct)
                      (mutex-unlock! done-mutex))))))
          (mutex-lock! done-mutex #f #f)
          (thread-terminate! t1)
          (thread-terminate! t2)
          (if (eq? (mutex-state mutex1) ct)
              (begin
                (if (eq? (mutex-state mutex2) ct)
                    (mutex-unlock! mutex2)) ; don't lock both
                mutex1)
              mutex2))))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**mutex-unlock!** `mutex`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`condition-variable`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`timeout`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-mutex_002dunlock_0021){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure unlocks the `mutex`{.variable .var} by making it
    unlocked/not-abandoned. It is not an error to unlock an unlocked
    mutex and a mutex that is owned by any thread. If
    `condition-variable`{.variable .var} is supplied, the current thread
    is blocked and added to the `condition-variable`{.variable .var}
    before unlocking `mutex`{.variable .var}; the thread can unblock at
    any time but no later than when an appropriate call to
    `condition-variable-signal!`{.code} or
    `condition-variable-broadcast!`{.code} is performed (see below), and
    no later than the timeout (if `timeout`{.variable .var} is
    supplied). If there are threads waiting to lock this
    `mutex`{.variable .var}, the scheduler selects a thread, the mutex
    becomes locked/owned or locked/not-owned, and the thread is
    unblocked. `mutex-unlock!`{.code} returns '`#f`{.sample .samp}' when
    the timeout is reached, otherwise it returns '`#t`{.sample .samp}'.

    NOTE: The reason the thread can unblock at any time (when
    `condition-variable`{.variable .var} is supplied) is that the
    scheduler, when it detects a serious problem such as a deadlock,
    must interrupt one of the blocked threads (such as the primordial
    thread) so that it can perform some appropriate action. After a
    thread blocked on a condition-variable has handled such an interrupt
    it would be wrong for the scheduler to return the thread to the
    blocked state, because any calls to
    `condition-variable-broadcast!`{.code} during the interrupt will
    have gone unnoticed. It is necessary for the thread to remain
    runnable and return from the call to `mutex-unlock!`{.code} with a
    result of '`#t`{.sample .samp}'.

    NOTE: `mutex-unlock!`{.code} is related to the "wait" operation on
    condition variables available in other thread systems. The main
    difference is that "wait" automatically locks `mutex`{.variable
    .var} just after the thread is unblocked. This operation is not
    performed by `mutex-unlock!`{.code} and so must be done by an
    explicit call to `mutex-lock!`{.code}. This has the advantages that
    a different timeout and exception-handler can be specified on the
    `mutex-lock!`{.code} and `mutex-unlock!`{.code} and the location of
    all the mutex operations is clearly apparent.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    (let loop ()
      (mutex-lock! m)
      (if (condition-is-true?)
          (begin
            (do-something-when-condition-is-true)
            (mutex-unlock! m))
          (begin
            (mutex-unlock! m cv)
            (loop))))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**condition-variable-signal!** `condition-variable`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-condition_002dvariable_002dsignal_0021){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure unblocks a thread blocked on the
    `condition-variable`{.variable .var} (if there is at least one) and
    returns an unspecified value.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    ; an implementation of a mailbox object of depth one; this
    ; implementation behaves gracefully when threads are forcibly
    ; terminated using thread-terminate! (an abandoned-mutex-exception
    ; object will be raised when a put! or get! operation is attempted
    ; after a thread is terminated in the middle of a put! or get!
    ; operation)

    (define (make-empty-mailbox)
      (let ((mutex (make-mutex))
            (put-condvar (make-condition-variable))
            (get-condvar (make-condition-variable))
            (full? #f)
            (cell #f))

        (define (put! obj)
          (mutex-lock! mutex)
          (if full?
              (begin
                (mutex-unlock! mutex put-condvar)
                (put! obj))
              (begin
                (set! cell obj)
                (set! full? #t)
                (condition-variable-signal! get-condvar)
                (mutex-unlock! mutex))))

        (define (get!)
          (mutex-lock! mutex)
          (if (not full?)
              (begin
                (mutex-unlock! mutex get-condvar)
                (get!))
              (let ((result cell))
                (set! cell #f) ; avoid space leaks
                (set! full? #f)
                (condition-variable-signal! put-condvar)
                (mutex-unlock! mutex)
                result)))

        (lambda (msg)
          (case msg
            ((put!) put!)
            ((get!) get!)
            (else (error "unknown message"))))))

    (define (mailbox-put! m obj) ((m 'put!) obj))
    (define (mailbox-get! m) ((m 'get!)))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**condition-variable-broadcast!** `condition-variable`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-condition_002dvariable_002dbroadcast_0021){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure unblocks all the thread blocked on the
    `condition-variable`{.variable .var} and returns an unspecified
    value.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    (define (make-semaphore n)
      (vector n (make-mutex) (make-condition-variable)))

    (define (semaphore-wait! sema)
      (mutex-lock! (vector-ref sema 1))
      (let ((n (vector-ref sema 0)))
        (if (> n 0)
            (begin
              (vector-set! sema 0 (- n 1))
              (mutex-unlock! (vector-ref sema 1)))
            (begin
              (mutex-unlock! (vector-ref sema 1) (vector-ref sema 2))
              (semaphore-wait! sema))))

    (define (semaphore-signal-by! sema increment)
      (mutex-lock! (vector-ref sema 1))
      (let ((n (+ (vector-ref sema 0) increment)))
        (vector-set! sema 0 n)
        (if (> n 0)
            (condition-variable-broadcast! (vector-ref sema 2)))
        (mutex-unlock! (vector-ref sema 1))))
    ```
    :::
