## 11 Dynamic environment {#Dynamic-environment-1 .chapter}

The *dynamic environment* is the structure which allows the system to
find the value returned by the standard procedures
`current-input-port`{.code} and `current-output-port`{.code}. The
standard procedures `with-input-from-file`{.code} and
`with-output-to-file`{.code} extend the dynamic environment to produce a
new dynamic environment which is in effect for the dynamic extent of the
call to the thunk passed as their last argument. These procedures are
essentially special purpose dynamic binding operations on hidden dynamic
variables (one for `current-input-port`{.code} and one for
`current-output-port`{.code}). Gambit generalizes this dynamic binding
mechanism to allow the user to introduce new dynamic variables, called
*parameter objects*, and dynamically bind them. The parameter objects
implemented by Gambit are compatible with the specification of the
"Parameter objects SRFI" (SRFI 39).

One important issue is the relationship between the dynamic environments
of the parent and child threads when a thread is created. Each thread
has its own dynamic environment that is accessed when looking up the
value bound to a parameter object by that thread. When a thread's
dynamic environment is extended it does not affect the dynamic
environment of other threads. When a thread is created it is given a
dynamic environment whose bindings are inherited from the parent thread.
In this inherited dynamic environment the parameter objects are bound to
the same cells as the parent's dynamic environment (in other words an
assignment of a new value to a parameter object is visible in the other
thread).

Another important issue is the interaction between the
`dynamic-wind`{.code} procedure and dynamic environments. When a thread
creates a continuation, the thread's dynamic environment and the
'`dynamic-wind`{.sample .samp}' stack are saved within the continuation
(an alternate but equivalent point of view is that the
'`dynamic-wind`{.sample .samp}' stack is part of the dynamic
environment). When this continuation is invoked the required
'`dynamic-wind`{.sample .samp}' before and after thunks are called and
the saved dynamic environment is reinstated as the dynamic environment
of the current thread. During the call to each required
'`dynamic-wind`{.sample .samp}' before and after thunk, the dynamic
environment and the '`dynamic-wind`{.sample .samp}' stack in effect when
the corresponding '`dynamic-wind`{.sample .samp}' was executed are
reinstated. Note that this specification precisely defines the semantics
of calling '`call-with-current-continuation`{.sample .samp}' or invoking
a continuation within a before or after thunk. The semantics are well
defined even when a continuation created by another thread is invoked.
Below is an example exercising the subtleties of this semantics.

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
(with-output-to-file
 "foo"
 (lambda ()
   (let ((k (call-with-current-continuation
             (lambda (exit)
               (with-output-to-file
                "bar"
                (lambda ()
                  (dynamic-wind
                   (lambda ()
                     (write '(b1))
                     (force-output))
                   (lambda ()
                     (let ((x (call-with-current-continuation
                               (lambda (cont) (exit cont)))))
                       (write '(t1))
                       (force-output)
                       x))
                   (lambda ()
                     (write '(a1))
                     (force-output)))))))))
     (if k
         (dynamic-wind
          (lambda ()
            (write '(b2))
            (force-output))
          (lambda ()
            (with-output-to-file
             "baz"
             (lambda ()
               (write '(t2))
               (force-output)
               ; go back inside (with-output-to-file "bar" ...)
               (k #f))))
          (lambda ()
            (write '(a2))
            (force-output)))))))
```
:::

The following actions will occur when this code is executed:
`(b1)(a1)`{.code} is written to "bar", `(b2)`{.code} is then written to
"foo", `(t2)`{.code} is then written to "baz", `(a2)`{.code} is then
written to "foo", and finally `(b1)(t1)(a1)`{.code} is written to "bar".

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**make-parameter** `obj`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`set-filter`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`get-filter`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-make_002dparameter){.copiable-link}

:   The dynamic environment is composed of two parts: the *local dynamic
    environment* and the *global dynamic environment*. There is a single
    global dynamic environment, and it is used to lookup parameter
    objects that can't be found in the local dynamic environment.

    The `make-parameter`{.code} procedure returns a new *parameter
    object*. The `set-filter`{.variable .var} argument is a one argument
    "set" conversion procedure. The `get-filter`{.variable .var}
    argument is a one argument "get" conversion procedure. If they are
    not specified the conversion procedures default to the identity
    function.

    The global dynamic environment is updated to associate the parameter
    object to a new cell. The initial content of the cell is the result
    of applying the "set" conversion procedure to `obj`{.variable .var}.

    A parameter object is a procedure which accepts zero or one
    argument. The cell bound to a particular parameter object in the
    dynamic environment is accessed by calling the parameter object.
    When no argument is passed, the value returned is the result of
    applying the "get" conversion procedure to the content of the cell.
    When one argument is passed the content of the cell is updated with
    the result of applying the parameter object's "set" conversion
    procedure to the argument. Note that the conversion procedures can
    be used for guaranteeing the type of the parameter object's binding
    and/or to perform some conversion of the value.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define radix (make-parameter 10))
    > (radix)
    10
    > (radix 2)
    > (radix)
    2
    > (define prompt
        (make-parameter
          123
          (lambda (x)
            (if (string? x)
                x
                (object->string x)))))
    > (prompt)
    "123"
    > (prompt "$")
    > (prompt)
    "$"
    > (define p
        (make-parameter
          100
          (lambda (val) ;; set filter
            (pp (list val: val))
            (list 0 val))
          (lambda (state) ;; get filter
            (pp (list state: state))
            (set-car! state (+ 1 (car state)))
            (+ (car state) (cadr state)))))
    (val: 100)
    > (p)
    (state: (0 100))
    101
    > (p)
    (state: (1 100))
    102
    > (p)
    (state: (2 100))
    103
    > (p 555)
    (val: 555)
    > (p)
    (state: (0 555))
    556
    > (p)
    (state: (1 555))
    557
    > (define write-shared
        (make-parameter
          #f
          (lambda (x)
            (if (boolean? x)
                x
                (error "only booleans are accepted by write-shared")))))
    > (write-shared 123)
    *** ERROR IN ##make-parameter -- only booleans are accepted by write-shared
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[special form: ]{.category-def}**parameterize** `((`{.variable .def-var-arguments}[*`procedure`{.variable .def-var-arguments}*]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[*`value`{.variable .def-var-arguments}*]{.r}`)…) `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[*`body`{.variable .def-var-arguments}*]{.r} [¶](#index-parameterize){.copiable-link}

:   The `parameterize`{.code} form, evaluates all *procedure* and
    *value* expressions in an unspecified order. All the *procedure*
    expressions must evaluate to procedures, either parameter objects or
    procedures accepting zero and one argument. Then, for each procedure
    *p* and in an unspecified order:

    -   If *p* is a parameter object a new cell is created, initialized,
        and bound to the parameter object in the local dynamic
        environment. The value contained in the cell is the result of
        applying the parameter object's "set" conversion procedure to
        *value*. The resulting dynamic environment is then used for
        processing the remaining bindings (or the evaluation of *body*
        if there are no other bindings).
    -   Otherwise *p* will be used according to the following protocol:
        we say that the call `(`{.code}[*`p`{.code}*]{.r}`)`{.code}
        "gets *p*'s value" and that the call
        `(`{.code}[*`p`{.code}*]{.r}` `{.code}[*`x`{.code}*]{.r}`)`{.code}
        "sets *p*'s value to *x*". First, the `parameterize`{.code} form
        gets *p*'s value and saves it in a local variable. It then sets
        *p*'s value to *value*. It then processes the remaining bindings
        (or evaluates *body* if there are no other bindings). Then it
        sets *p*'s value to the saved value. These steps are performed
        in a `dynamic-wind`{.code} so that it is possible to use
        continuations to jump into and out of the body (i.e. the
        `dynamic-wind`{.code}'s before thunk sets *p*'s value to *value*
        and the after thunk sets *p*'s value to the saved value).

    The result(s) of the `parameterize`{.code} form are the result(s) of
    the *body*.

    Note that using procedures instead of parameter objects may lead to
    unexpected results in multithreaded programs because the before and
    after thunks of the `dynamic-wind`{.code} are not called when
    control switches between threads.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define radix (make-parameter 2))
    > (define prompt
        (make-parameter
          123
          (lambda (x)
            (if (string? x)
                x
                (object->string x)))))
    > (radix)
    2
    > (parameterize ((radix 16)) (radix))
    16
    > (radix)
    2
    > (define (f n) (number->string n (radix)))
    > (f 10)
    "1010"
    > (parameterize ((radix 8)) (f 10))
    "12"
    > (parameterize ((radix 8) (prompt (f 10))) (prompt))
    "1010"
    > (define p
        (let ((x 1))
          (lambda args
            (if (null? args) x (set! x (car args))))))
    > (let* ((a (p))
             (b (parameterize ((p 2)) (list (p))))
             (c (p)))
        (list a b c))
    (1 (2) 1)
    ```
    :::

### 12.1 Exception-handling {#Exception_002dhandling-1 .section}

Gambit's exception-handling model is inspired from the withdrawn
"Exception Handling SRFI" (SRFI 12), the "Multithreading support SRFI"
(SRFI 18), and the "Exception Handling for Programs SRFI" (SRFI 34). The
two fundamental operations are the dynamic binding of an exception
handler (i.e. the procedure `with-exception-handler`{.code}) and the
invocation of the exception handler (i.e. the procedure `raise`{.code}).

All predefined procedures which check for errors (including type errors,
memory allocation errors, host operating-system errors, etc) report
these errors using the exception-handling system (i.e. they "raise" an
exception that can be handled in a user-defined exception handler). When
an exception is raised and the exception is not handled by a
user-defined exception handler, the predefined exception handler will
display an error message (if the primordial thread raised the exception)
or the thread will silently terminate with no error message (if it is
not the primordial thread that raised the exception). This default
behavior can be changed through the '`-:debug=...`{.sample .samp}'
runtime option (see [Runtime options](#Runtime-options){.pxref}).

Predefined procedures normally raise exceptions by performing a
tail-call to the exception handler (the exceptions are "complex"
procedures such as `eval`{.code}, `compile-file`{.code}, `read`{.code},
`write`{.code}, etc). This means that the continuation of the exception
handler and of the REPL that may be started due to this is normally the
continuation of the predefined procedure that raised the exception. By
exiting the REPL with the `,(c `{.code}`expression`{.variable
.var}`)`{.code} command it is thus possible to resume the program as
though the call to the predefined procedure returned the value of
`expression`{.variable .var}. For example:

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
> (define (f x) (+ (car x) 1))
> (f 2) ; typo... we meant to say (f ’(2))
*** ERROR IN f, (console)@1.18 -- (Argument 1) PAIR expected
(car 2)
1> ,(c 2)
3
```
:::

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**current-exception-handler** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`new-exception-handler`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-current_002dexception_002dhandler){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-current-exception_002dhandler .index-entry-id}

    The parameter object `current-exception-handler`{.code} is bound to
    the current exception-handler. Calling this procedure with no
    argument returns the current exception-handler and calling this
    procedure with one argument sets the current exception-handler to
    `new-exception-handler`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (current-exception-handler)
    #<procedure #2 primordial-exception-handler>
    > (current-exception-handler (lambda (exc) (pp exc) 999))
    > (/ 1 0)
    #<divide-by-zero-exception #3>
    999
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**with-exception-handler** `handler`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`thunk`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-with_002dexception_002dhandler){.copiable-link}

:   Returns the result(s) of calling `thunk`{.variable .var} with no
    arguments. The `handler`{.variable .var}, which must be a procedure,
    is installed as the current exception-handler in the dynamic
    environment in effect during the call to `thunk`{.variable .var}.
    Note that the dynamic environment in effect during the call to
    `handler`{.variable .var} has `handler`{.variable .var} as the
    exception-handler. Consequently, an exception raised during the call
    to `handler`{.variable .var} may lead to an infinite loop.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (with-exception-handler
        (lambda (e) (write e) 5)
        (lambda () (+ 1 (* 2 3) 4)))
    11
    > (with-exception-handler
        (lambda (e) (write e) 5)
        (lambda () (+ 1 (* 'foo 3) 4)))
    #<type-exception #2>10
    > (with-exception-handler
        (lambda (e) (write e 9))
        (lambda () (+ 1 (* 'foo 3) 4)))
    infinite loop
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**with-exception-catcher** `handler`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`thunk`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-with_002dexception_002dcatcher){.copiable-link}

:   Returns the result(s) of calling `thunk`{.variable .var} with no
    arguments. A new exception-handler is installed as the current
    exception-handler in the dynamic environment in effect during the
    call to `thunk`{.variable .var}. This new exception-handler will
    call the `handler`{.variable .var}, which must be a procedure, with
    the exception object as an argument and with the same continuation
    as the call to `with-exception-catcher`{.code}. This implies that
    the dynamic environment in effect during the call to
    `handler`{.variable .var} is the same as the one in effect at the
    call to `with-exception-catcher`{.code}. Consequently, an exception
    raised during the call to `handler`{.variable .var} will not lead to
    an infinite loop.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (with-exception-catcher
        (lambda (e) (write e) 5)
        (lambda () (+ 1 (* 2 3) 4)))
    11
    > (with-exception-catcher
        (lambda (e) (write e) 5)
        (lambda () (+ 1 (* 'foo 3) 4)))
    #<type-exception #2>5
    > (with-exception-catcher
        (lambda (e) (write e 9))
        (lambda () (+ 1 (* 'foo 3) 4)))
    *** ERROR IN (console)@7.1 -- (Argument 2) OUTPUT PORT expected
    (write '#<type-exception #3> 9)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**raise** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-raise){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure tail-calls the current exception-handler with
    `obj`{.variable .var} as the sole argument. If the exception-handler
    returns, the continuation of the call to `raise`{.code} is invoked.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (with-exception-handler
        (lambda (exc)
          (pp exc)
          100)
        (lambda ()
          (+ 1 (raise "hello"))))
    "hello"
    101
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**abort** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-abort){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**noncontinuable-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-noncontinuable_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**noncontinuable-exception-reason** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-noncontinuable_002dexception_002dreason){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `abort`{.code} calls the current exception-handler
    with `obj`{.variable .var} as the sole argument. If the
    exception-handler returns, the procedure `abort`{.code} will be
    tail-called with a noncontinuable-exception object, whose reason
    field is `obj`{.variable .var}, as sole argument.

    Noncontinuable-exception objects are raised by the `abort`{.code}
    procedure when the exception-handler returns. The parameter
    `exc`{.variable .var} must be a noncontinuable-exception object.

    The procedure `noncontinuable-exception?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code}
    when `obj`{.variable .var} is a noncontinuable-exception object and
    `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `noncontinuable-exception-reason`{.code} returns the
    argument of the call to `abort`{.code} that raised `exc`{.variable
    .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (call-with-current-continuation
        (lambda (k)
          (with-exception-handler
            (lambda (exc)
              (pp exc)
              (if (noncontinuable-exception? exc)
                  (k (list (noncontinuable-exception-reason exc)))
                  100))
            (lambda ()
              (+ 1 (abort "hello"))))))
    "hello"
    #<noncontinuable-exception #2>
    ("hello")
    ```
    :::

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

### 12.2 Exception objects related to memory management {#Exception-objects-related-to-memory-management-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**heap-overflow-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-heap_002doverflow_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}

:   Heap-overflow-exception objects are raised when the allocation of an
    object would cause the heap to use more memory space than is
    available.

    The procedure `heap-overflow-exception?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code}
    when `obj`{.variable .var} is a heap-overflow-exception object and
    `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (heap-overflow-exception? exc)
            exc
            'not-heap-overflow-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda ()
          (define (f x) (f (cons 1 x)))
          (f '())))
    #<heap-overflow-exception #2>
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**stack-overflow-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-stack_002doverflow_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}

:   Stack-overflow-exception objects are raised when the allocation of a
    continuation frame would cause the heap to use more memory space
    than is available.

    The procedure `stack-overflow-exception?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code}
    when `obj`{.variable .var} is a stack-overflow-exception object and
    `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (stack-overflow-exception? exc)
            exc
            'not-stack-overflow-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda ()
          (define (f) (+ 1 (f)))
          (f)))
    #<stack-overflow-exception #2>
    ```
    :::

:::

### 12.3 Exception objects related to the host environment {#Exception-objects-related-to-the-host-environment-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**os-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-os_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**os-exception-procedure** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-os_002dexception_002dprocedure){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**os-exception-arguments** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-os_002dexception_002darguments){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**os-exception-code** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-os_002dexception_002dcode){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**os-exception-message** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-os_002dexception_002dmessage){.copiable-link}

:   Os-exception objects are raised by procedures which access the host
    operating-system's services when the requested operation fails. The
    parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be a os-exception object.

    The procedure `os-exception?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code} when
    `obj`{.variable .var} is a os-exception object and `#f`{.code}
    otherwise.

    The procedure `os-exception-procedure`{.code} returns the procedure
    that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `os-exception-arguments`{.code} returns the list of
    arguments of the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `os-exception-code`{.code} returns an exact integer
    error code that can be converted to a string by the
    `err-code->string`{.code} procedure. Note that the error code is
    operating-system dependent.

    The procedure `os-exception-message`{.code} returns `#f`{.code} or a
    string giving details of the exception in a human-readable form.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (os-exception? exc)
            (list (os-exception-procedure exc)
                  (os-exception-arguments exc)
                  (err-code->string (os-exception-code exc))
                  (os-exception-message exc))
            'not-os-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (host-info "x.y.z")))
    (#<procedure #2 host-info> ("x.y.z") "Unknown host" #f)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**no-such-file-or-directory-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-no_002dsuch_002dfile_002dor_002ddirectory_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**no-such-file-or-directory-exception-procedure** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-no_002dsuch_002dfile_002dor_002ddirectory_002dexception_002dprocedure){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**no-such-file-or-directory-exception-arguments** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-no_002dsuch_002dfile_002dor_002ddirectory_002dexception_002darguments){.copiable-link}

:   No-such-file-or-directory-exception objects are raised by procedures
    which access the filesystem (such as `open-input-file`{.code} and
    `directory-files`{.code}) when the path specified can't be found on
    the filesystem. The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be a
    no-such-file-or-directory-exception object.

    The procedure `no-such-file-or-directory-exception?`{.code} returns
    `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is a
    no-such-file-or-directory-exception object and `#f`{.code}
    otherwise.

    The procedure `no-such-file-or-directory-exception-procedure`{.code}
    returns the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `no-such-file-or-directory-exception-arguments`{.code}
    returns the list of arguments of the procedure that raised
    `exc`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (no-such-file-or-directory-exception? exc)
            (list (no-such-file-or-directory-exception-procedure exc)
                  (no-such-file-or-directory-exception-arguments exc))
            'not-no-such-file-or-directory-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (with-input-from-file "nofile" read)))
    (#<procedure #2 with-input-from-file> ("nofile" #<procedure #3 read>))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**file-exists-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-file_002dexists_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**file-exists-exception-procedure** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-file_002dexists_002dexception_002dprocedure){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**file-exists-exception-arguments** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-file_002dexists_002dexception_002darguments){.copiable-link}

:   File-exists-exception objects are raised by procedures which access
    the filesystem (such as `open-output-file`{.code} and
    `create-directory`{.code}) when the path specified is an existing
    file on the filesystem. The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be
    a file-exists-exception object.

    The procedure `file-exists-exception?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code}
    when `obj`{.variable .var} is a file-exists-exception object and
    `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `file-exists-exception-procedure`{.code} returns the
    procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `file-exists-exception-arguments`{.code} returns the
    list of arguments of the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable
    .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (file-exists-exception? exc)
            (list (file-exists-exception-procedure exc)
                  (file-exists-exception-arguments exc))
            'not-file-exists-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (with-output-to-file '(path: "foo" create: #t) newline)))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (with-output-to-file '(path: "foo" create: #t) newline)))
    (#<procedure #2 with-output-to-file>
     ((path: "foo" create: #t) #<procedure #3 newline>))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**permission-denied-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-permission_002ddenied_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**permission-denied-exception-procedure** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-permission_002ddenied_002dexception_002dprocedure){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**permission-denied-exception-arguments** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-permission_002ddenied_002dexception_002darguments){.copiable-link}

:   Permission-denied-exception objects are raised by procedures which
    access the filesystem (such as `open-file`{.code} and
    `open-directory`{.code}) when the access to the specified path is
    not allowed, or search permission is denied for a directory in the
    path prefix, or write access to the parent directory isn't allowed
    for a file that doesn't exist yet on the filesystem. The parameter
    `exc`{.variable .var} must be a permission-denied-exception object.

    The procedure `permission-denied-exception?`{.code} returns
    `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is a
    permission-denied-exception object and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `permission-denied-exception-procedure`{.code} returns
    the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `permission-denied-exception-arguments`{.code} returns
    the list of arguments of the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable
    .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (permission-denied-exception? exc)
            (list (permission-denied-exception-procedure exc)
                  (permission-denied-exception-arguments exc))
            'not-permission-denied-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (with-input-from-file "empty" read)))
    #!eof
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (with-input-from-file "noperm" read)))
    (#<procedure #2 with-input-from-file> ("noperm" #<procedure #3 read>))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**unbound-os-environment-variable-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-unbound_002dos_002denvironment_002dvariable_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**unbound-os-environment-variable-exception-procedure** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-unbound_002dos_002denvironment_002dvariable_002dexception_002dprocedure){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**unbound-os-environment-variable-exception-arguments** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-unbound_002dos_002denvironment_002dvariable_002dexception_002darguments){.copiable-link}

:   Unbound-os-environment-variable-exception objects are raised when an
    unbound operating-system environment variable is accessed by the
    procedures `getenv`{.code} and `setenv`{.code}. The parameter
    `exc`{.variable .var} must be an
    unbound-os-environment-variable-exception object.

    The procedure `unbound-os-environment-variable-exception?`{.code}
    returns `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is an
    unbound-os-environment-variable-exception object and `#f`{.code}
    otherwise.

    The procedure
    `unbound-os-environment-variable-exception-procedure`{.code} returns
    the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure
    `unbound-os-environment-variable-exception-arguments`{.code} returns
    the list of arguments of the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable
    .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (unbound-os-environment-variable-exception? exc)
            (list (unbound-os-environment-variable-exception-procedure exc)
                  (unbound-os-environment-variable-exception-arguments exc))
            'not-unbound-os-environment-variable-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (getenv "DOES_NOT_EXIST")))
    (#<procedure #2 getenv> ("DOES_NOT_EXIST"))
    ```
    :::

### 12.4 Exception objects related to threads {#Exception-objects-related-to-threads-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**scheduler-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-scheduler_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**scheduler-exception-reason** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-scheduler_002dexception_002dreason){.copiable-link}

:   Scheduler-exception objects are raised by the scheduler when some
    operation requested from the host operating system failed (e.g.
    checking the status of the devices in order to wake up threads
    waiting to perform I/O on these devices). The parameter
    `exc`{.variable .var} must be a scheduler-exception object.

    The procedure `scheduler-exception?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code} when
    `obj`{.variable .var} is a scheduler-exception object and
    `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `scheduler-exception-reason`{.code} returns the
    os-exception object that describes the failure detected by the
    scheduler.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**deadlock-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-deadlock_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}

:   Deadlock-exception objects are raised when the scheduler discovers
    that all threads are blocked and can make no further progress. In
    that case the scheduler unblocks the primordial-thread and forces it
    to raise a deadlock-exception object.

    The procedure `deadlock-exception?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code} when
    `obj`{.variable .var} is a deadlock-exception object and `#f`{.code}
    otherwise.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (deadlock-exception? exc)
            exc
            'not-deadlock-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (read (open-vector))))
    #<deadlock-exception #2>
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**abandoned-mutex-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-abandoned_002dmutex_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}

:   Abandoned-mutex-exception objects are raised when the current thread
    locks a mutex that was owned by a thread which terminated (see
    `mutex-lock!`{.code}).

    The procedure `abandoned-mutex-exception?`{.code} returns
    `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is a
    abandoned-mutex-exception object and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (abandoned-mutex-exception? exc)
            exc
            'not-abandoned-mutex-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda ()
          (let ((m (make-mutex)))
            (thread-join!
              (thread-start!
                (make-thread
                  (lambda () (mutex-lock! m)))))
            (mutex-lock! m))))
    #<abandoned-mutex-exception #2>
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**join-timeout-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-join_002dtimeout_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**join-timeout-exception-procedure** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-join_002dtimeout_002dexception_002dprocedure){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**join-timeout-exception-arguments** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-join_002dtimeout_002dexception_002darguments){.copiable-link}

:   Join-timeout-exception objects are raised when a call to the
    `thread-join!`{.code} procedure reaches its timeout before the
    target thread terminates and a timeout-value parameter is not
    specified. The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be a
    join-timeout-exception object.

    The procedure `join-timeout-exception?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code}
    when `obj`{.variable .var} is a join-timeout-exception object and
    `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `join-timeout-exception-procedure`{.code} returns the
    procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `join-timeout-exception-arguments`{.code} returns the
    list of arguments of the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable
    .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (join-timeout-exception? exc)
            (list (join-timeout-exception-procedure exc)
                  (join-timeout-exception-arguments exc))
            'not-join-timeout-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda ()
          (thread-join!
            (thread-start!
              (make-thread
                (lambda () (thread-sleep! 10))))
            5)))
    (#<procedure #2 thread-join!> (#<thread #3> 5))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

    of a call to the procedure `thread-start!`{.code} is already
    started. The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be a
    started-thread-exception object.

    The procedure `started-thread-exception?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code}
    when `obj`{.variable .var} is a started-thread-exception object and
    `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `started-thread-exception-procedure`{.code} returns
    the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `started-thread-exception-arguments`{.code} returns
    the list of arguments of the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable
    .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (started-thread-exception? exc)
            (list (started-thread-exception-procedure exc)
                  (started-thread-exception-arguments exc))
            'not-started-thread-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda ()
          (let ((t (make-thread (lambda () (expt 2 1000)))))
    ```


[procedure: ]{.category-def}**terminated-thread-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-terminated_002dthread_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**terminated-thread-exception-procedure** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-terminated_002dthread_002dexception_002dprocedure){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**terminated-thread-exception-arguments** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-terminated_002dthread_002dexception_002darguments){.copiable-link}

:   Terminated-thread-exception objects are raised when the
    `thread-join!`{.code} procedure is called and the target thread has
    terminated as a result of a call to the `thread-terminate!`{.code}
    procedure. The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be a
    terminated-thread-exception object.

    The procedure `terminated-thread-exception?`{.code} returns
    `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is a
    terminated-thread-exception object and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `terminated-thread-exception-procedure`{.code} returns
    the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `terminated-thread-exception-arguments`{.code} returns
    the list of arguments of the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable
    .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (terminated-thread-exception? exc)
            (list (terminated-thread-exception-procedure exc)
                  (terminated-thread-exception-arguments exc))
            'not-terminated-thread-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda ()
          (thread-join!
            (thread-start!
              (make-thread
                (lambda () (thread-terminate! (current-thread))))))))
    (#<procedure #2 thread-join!> (#<thread #3>))
    ```


[procedure: ]{.category-def}**uncaught-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-uncaught_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**uncaught-exception-procedure** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-uncaught_002dexception_002dprocedure){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**uncaught-exception-arguments** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-uncaught_002dexception_002darguments){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**uncaught-exception-reason** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-uncaught_002dexception_002dreason){.copiable-link}

:   Uncaught-exception objects are raised when an object is raised in a
    thread and that thread does not handle it (i.e. the thread
    terminated because it did not catch an exception it raised). The
    parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be an uncaught-exception
    object.

    The procedure `uncaught-exception?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code} when
    `obj`{.variable .var} is an uncaught-exception object and
    `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `uncaught-exception-procedure`{.code} returns the
    procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `uncaught-exception-arguments`{.code} returns the list
    of arguments of the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `uncaught-exception-reason`{.code} returns the object
    that was raised by the thread and not handled by that thread.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (uncaught-exception? exc)
            (list (uncaught-exception-procedure exc)
                  (uncaught-exception-arguments exc)
                  (uncaught-exception-reason exc))
            'not-uncaught-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda ()
          (thread-join!
            (thread-start!
              (make-thread
                (lambda () (open-input-file "data" 99)))))))
    (#<procedure #2 thread-join!>
     (#<thread #3>)
     #<wrong-number-of-arguments-exception #4>)
    ```
    :::

### 12.5 Exception objects related to C-interface {#Exception-objects-related-to-C_002dinterface-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**cfun-conversion-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-cfun_002dconversion_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**cfun-conversion-exception-procedure** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-cfun_002dconversion_002dexception_002dprocedure){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**cfun-conversion-exception-arguments** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-cfun_002dconversion_002dexception_002darguments){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**cfun-conversion-exception-code** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-cfun_002dconversion_002dexception_002dcode){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**cfun-conversion-exception-message** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-cfun_002dconversion_002dexception_002dmessage){.copiable-link}

:   Cfun-conversion-exception objects are raised by the C-interface when
    converting between the Scheme representation and the C
    representation of a value during a call from Scheme to C. The
    parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be a cfun-conversion-exception
    object.

    The procedure `cfun-conversion-exception?`{.code} returns
    `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is a
    cfun-conversion-exception object and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `cfun-conversion-exception-procedure`{.code} returns
    the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `cfun-conversion-exception-arguments`{.code} returns
    the list of arguments of the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable
    .var}.

    The procedure `cfun-conversion-exception-code`{.code} returns an
    exact integer error code that can be converted to a string by the
    `err-code->string`{.code} procedure.

    The procedure `cfun-conversion-exception-message`{.code} returns
    `#f`{.code} or a string giving details of the exception in a
    human-readable form.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    $ cat test1.scm
    (define weird
      (c-lambda (char-string) nonnull-char-string
        "___return(___arg1);"))
    $ gsc test1.scm
    $ gsi
    Gambit v4.9.5

    > (load "test1")
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/test1.o1"
    > (weird "hello")
    "hello"
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (cfun-conversion-exception? exc)
            (list (cfun-conversion-exception-procedure exc)
                  (cfun-conversion-exception-arguments exc)
                  (err-code->string (cfun-conversion-exception-code exc))
                  (cfun-conversion-exception-message exc))
            'not-cfun-conversion-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (weird 'not-a-string)))
    (#<procedure #2 weird>
     (not-a-string)
     "(Argument 1) Can't convert to C char-string"
     #f)
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (weird #f)))
    (#<procedure #2 weird>
     (#f)
     "Can't convert result from C nonnull-char-string"
     #f)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**sfun-conversion-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-sfun_002dconversion_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**sfun-conversion-exception-procedure** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-sfun_002dconversion_002dexception_002dprocedure){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**sfun-conversion-exception-arguments** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-sfun_002dconversion_002dexception_002darguments){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**sfun-conversion-exception-code** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-sfun_002dconversion_002dexception_002dcode){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**sfun-conversion-exception-message** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-sfun_002dconversion_002dexception_002dmessage){.copiable-link}

:   Sfun-conversion-exception objects are raised by the C-interface when
    converting between the Scheme representation and the C
    representation of a value during a call from C to Scheme. The
    parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be a sfun-conversion-exception
    object.

    The procedure `sfun-conversion-exception?`{.code} returns
    `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is a
    sfun-conversion-exception object and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `sfun-conversion-exception-procedure`{.code} returns
    the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `sfun-conversion-exception-arguments`{.code} returns
    the list of arguments of the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable
    .var}.

    The procedure `sfun-conversion-exception-code`{.code} returns an
    exact integer error code that can be converted to a string by the
    `err-code->string`{.code} procedure.

    The procedure `sfun-conversion-exception-message`{.code} returns
    `#f`{.code} or a string giving details of the exception in a
    human-readable form.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    $ cat test2.scm
    (c-define (f str) (nonnull-char-string) int "f" ""
      (string->number str))
    (define t1 (c-lambda () int "___return(f (\"123\"));"))
    (define t2 (c-lambda () int "___return(f (0));"))
    (define t3 (c-lambda () int "___return(f (\"1.5\"));"))
    $ gsc test2.scm
    $ gsi
    Gambit v4.9.5

    > (load "test2")
    "/u/feeley/test2.o1"
    > (t1)
    123
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (sfun-conversion-exception? exc)
            (list (sfun-conversion-exception-procedure exc)
                  (sfun-conversion-exception-arguments exc)
                  (err-code->string (sfun-conversion-exception-code exc))
                  (sfun-conversion-exception-message exc))
            'not-sfun-conversion-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher handler t2)
    (#<procedure #2 f>
     ()
     "(Argument 1) Can't convert from C nonnull-char-string"
     #f)
    > (with-exception-catcher handler t3)
    (#<procedure #2 f> () "Can't convert result to C int" #f)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**multiple-c-return-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-multiple_002dc_002dreturn_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}

:   Multiple-c-return-exception objects are raised by the C-interface
    when a C to Scheme procedure call returns and that call's stack
    frame is no longer on the C stack because the call has already
    returned, or has been removed from the C stack by a
    `longjump`{.code}.

    The procedure `multiple-c-return-exception?`{.code} returns
    `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is a
    multiple-c-return-exception object and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    $ cat test3.scm
    (c-define (f str) (char-string) scheme-object "f" ""
      (pp (list 'entry 'str= str))
      (let ((k (call-with-current-continuation (lambda (k) k))))
        (pp (list 'exit 'k= k))
        k))
    (define scheme-to-c-to-scheme-and-back
      (c-lambda (char-string) scheme-object
        "___return(f (___arg1));"))
    $ gsc test3.scm
    $ gsi
    Gambit v4.9.5

    > (load "test3")
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/test3.o1"
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (multiple-c-return-exception? exc)
            exc
            'not-multiple-c-return-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda ()
          (let ((c (scheme-to-c-to-scheme-and-back "hello")))
            (pp c)
            (c 999))))
    (entry str= "hello")
    (exit k= #<procedure #2>)
    #<procedure #2>
    (exit k= 999)
    #<multiple-c-return-exception #3>
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**wrong-processor-c-return-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-wrong_002dprocessor_002dc_002dreturn_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}

:   Wrong-processor-c-return-exception objects are raised by the runtime
    system when a C to Scheme procedure call returns and that call's
    stack frame was created by another processor.

    The procedure `wrong-processor-c-return-exception?`{.code} returns
    `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is a
    wrong-processor-c-return-exception object and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

### 12.6 Exception objects related to the reader {#Exception-objects-related-to-the-reader-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**datum-parsing-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-datum_002dparsing_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**datum-parsing-exception-kind** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-datum_002dparsing_002dexception_002dkind){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**datum-parsing-exception-parameters** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-datum_002dparsing_002dexception_002dparameters){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**datum-parsing-exception-readenv** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-datum_002dparsing_002dexception_002dreadenv){.copiable-link}

:   Datum-parsing-exception objects are raised by the reader (i.e. the
    `read`{.code} procedure) when the input does not conform to the
    grammar for datum. The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be a
    datum-parsing-exception object.

    The procedure `datum-parsing-exception?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code}
    when `obj`{.variable .var} is a datum-parsing-exception object and
    `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `datum-parsing-exception-kind`{.code} returns a symbol
    denoting the kind of parsing error that was encountered by the
    reader when it raised `exc`{.variable .var}. Here is a table of the
    possible return values:

      ----------------------------------------- ----------------------------------------
      `datum-or-eof-expected`{.code}            Datum or EOF expected
      `datum-expected`{.code}                   Datum expected
      `improperly-placed-dot`{.code}            Improperly placed dot
      `incomplete-form-eof-reached`{.code}      Incomplete form, EOF reached
      `incomplete-form`{.code}                  Incomplete form
      `character-out-of-range`{.code}           Character out of range
      `invalid-character-name`{.code}           Invalid '#\\' name
      `illegal-character`{.code}                Illegal character
      `s8-expected`{.code}                      Signed 8 bit exact integer expected
      `u8-expected`{.code}                      Unsigned 8 bit exact integer expected
      `s16-expected`{.code}                     Signed 16 bit exact integer expected
      `u16-expected`{.code}                     Unsigned 16 bit exact integer expected
      `s32-expected`{.code}                     Signed 32 bit exact integer expected
      `u32-expected`{.code}                     Unsigned 32 bit exact integer expected
      `s64-expected`{.code}                     Signed 64 bit exact integer expected
      `u64-expected`{.code}                     Unsigned 64 bit exact integer expected
      `inexact-real-expected`{.code}            Inexact real expected
      `invalid-hex-escape`{.code}               Invalid hexadecimal escape
      `invalid-escaped-character`{.code}        Invalid escaped character
      `open-paren-expected`{.code}              '(' expected
      `invalid-token`{.code}                    Invalid token
      `invalid-sharp-bang-name`{.code}          Invalid '#!' name
      `duplicate-label-definition`{.code}       Duplicate definition for label
      `missing-label-definition`{.code}         Missing definition for label
      `illegal-label-definition`{.code}         Illegal definition of label
      `invalid-infix-syntax-character`{.code}   Invalid infix syntax character
      `invalid-infix-syntax-number`{.code}      Invalid infix syntax number
      `invalid-infix-syntax`{.code}             Invalid infix syntax
      ----------------------------------------- ----------------------------------------

    The procedure `datum-parsing-exception-parameters`{.code} returns a
    list of the parameters associated with the parsing error that was
    encountered by the reader when it raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (datum-parsing-exception? exc)
            (list (datum-parsing-exception-kind exc)
                  (datum-parsing-exception-parameters exc))
            'not-datum-parsing-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda ()
          (with-input-from-string "(s #\\pace)" read)))
    (invalid-character-name ("pace"))
    ```
    :::

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

### 12.7 Exception objects related to evaluation and compilation {#Exception-objects-related-to-evaluation-and-compilation-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**expression-parsing-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-expression_002dparsing_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**expression-parsing-exception-kind** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-expression_002dparsing_002dexception_002dkind){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**expression-parsing-exception-parameters** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-expression_002dparsing_002dexception_002dparameters){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**expression-parsing-exception-source** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-expression_002dparsing_002dexception_002dsource){.copiable-link}

:   Expression-parsing-exception objects are raised by the evaluator and
    compiler (i.e. the procedures `eval`{.code}, `compile-file`{.code},
    etc) when the input does not conform to the grammar for expression.
    The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be a
    expression-parsing-exception object.

    The procedure `expression-parsing-exception?`{.code} returns
    `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is a
    expression-parsing-exception object and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `expression-parsing-exception-kind`{.code} returns a
    symbol denoting the kind of parsing error that was encountered by
    the evaluator or compiler when it raised `exc`{.variable .var}. Here
    is a table of the possible return values:

      ------------------------------------------- ----------------------------------------------------
      `id-expected`{.code}                        Identifier expected
      `ill-formed-namespace`{.code}               Ill-formed namespace
      `ill-formed-namespace-prefix`{.code}        Ill-formed namespace prefix
      `namespace-prefix-must-be-string`{.code}    Namespace prefix must be a string
      `macro-used-as-variable`{.code}             Macro name can't be used as a variable
      `variable-is-immutable`{.code}              Variable is immutable
      `ill-formed-macro-transformer`{.code}       Macro transformer must be a lambda expression
      `reserved-used-as-variable`{.code}          Reserved identifier can't be used as a variable
      `ill-formed-special-form`{.code}            Ill-formed special form
      `cannot-open-file`{.code}                   Can't open file
      `filename-expected`{.code}                  Filename expected
      `ill-placed-define`{.code}                  Ill-placed 'define'
      `ill-placed-**include`{.code}               Ill-placed '##include'
      `ill-placed-**define-macro`{.code}          Ill-placed '##define-macro'
      `ill-placed-**declare`{.code}               Ill-placed '##declare'
      `ill-placed-**namespace`{.code}             Ill-placed '##namespace'

      `parameter-must-be-id`{.code}               Parameter must be an identifier
      `parameter-must-be-id-or-default`{.code}    Parameter must be an identifier or default binding
      `duplicate-parameter`{.code}                Duplicate parameter in parameter list
      `ill-placed-dotted-rest-parameter`{.code}   Ill-placed dotted rest parameter
      `parameter-expected-after-rest`{.code}      #!rest must be followed by a parameter
      `ill-formed-default`{.code}                 Ill-formed default binding
      `ill-placed-optional`{.code}                Ill-placed #!optional
      `ill-placed-rest`{.code}                    Ill-placed #!rest
      `ill-placed-key`{.code}                     Ill-placed #!key
      `key-expected-after-rest`{.code}            #!key expected after rest parameter
      `ill-placed-default`{.code}                 Ill-placed default binding
      `duplicate-variable-definition`{.code}      Duplicate definition of a variable
      `empty-body`{.code}                         Body must contain at least one expression
      `variable-must-be-id`{.code}                Defined variable must be an identifier
      `else-clause-not-last`{.code}               Else clause must be last
      `ill-formed-selector-list`{.code}           Ill-formed selector list
      `duplicate-variable-binding`{.code}         Duplicate variable in bindings
      `ill-formed-binding-list`{.code}            Ill-formed binding list
      `ill-formed-call`{.code}                    Ill-formed procedure call
      `ill-formed-cond-expand`{.code}             Ill-formed 'cond-expand'
      `unfulfilled-cond-expand`{.code}            Unfulfilled 'cond-expand'
      ------------------------------------------- ----------------------------------------------------

    The procedure `expression-parsing-exception-parameters`{.code}
    returns a list of the parameters associated with the parsing error
    that was encountered by the evaluator or compiler when it raised
    `exc`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (expression-parsing-exception? exc)
            (list (expression-parsing-exception-kind exc)
                  (expression-parsing-exception-parameters exc))
            'not-expression-parsing-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda ()
          (eval '(+ do 1))))
    (reserved-used-as-variable (do))
    ```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**unbound-global-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-unbound_002dglobal_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\

:   Unbound-global-exception objects are raised when an unbound global
    variable is accessed. The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be an
    unbound-global-exception object.

    The procedure `unbound-global-exception?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code}
    when `obj`{.variable .var} is an unbound-global-exception object and
    `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `unbound-global-exception-variable`{.code} returns a
    symbol identifying the unbound global variable.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (unbound-global-exception? exc)
            (list 'variable= (unbound-global-exception-variable exc))
            'not-unbound-global-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () foo))
    (variable= foo)
    ```
    :::

:   Not-in-compilation-context-exception objects are raised by the
    procedure `compilation-target`{.code} when it is executed outside of
    a compilation context. The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be a
    not-in-compilation-context-exception object.

    The procedure `not-in-compilation-context-exception?`{.code} returns
    `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is a
    not-in-compilation-context-exception object and `#f`{.code}
    otherwise.

    The procedure
    `not-in-compilation-context-exception-procedure`{.code} returns the
    procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure
    `not-in-compilation-context-exception-arguments`{.code} returns the
    list of arguments of the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable
    .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (not-in-compilation-context-exception? exc)
            (list (not-in-compilation-context-exception-procedure exc)
                  (not-in-compilation-context-exception-arguments exc))
            'not-not-in-compilation-context-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (compilation-target)))
    (#<procedure #2 compilation-target> ())
    ```
    :::

### 12.8 Exception objects related to type checking {#Exception-objects-related-to-type-checking-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**type-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-type_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**type-exception-procedure** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-type_002dexception_002dprocedure){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**type-exception-arguments** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-type_002dexception_002darguments){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**type-exception-arg-id** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-type_002dexception_002darg_002did){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**type-exception-type-id** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-type_002dexception_002dtype_002did){.copiable-link}

:   Type-exception objects are raised when a primitive procedure is
    called with an argument of incorrect type (i.e. when a run time
    type-check fails). The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be a
    type-exception object.

    The procedure `type-exception?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code} when
    `obj`{.variable .var} is a type-exception object and `#f`{.code}
    otherwise.

    The procedure `type-exception-procedure`{.code} returns the
    procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `type-exception-arguments`{.code} returns the list of
    arguments of the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `type-exception-arg-id`{.code} returns the identity of
    the argument whose type is incorrect, which can be an exact integer
    position (1 for the first argument) or a pair whose `car`{.code} is
    the position and the `cdr`{.code} is the parameter name as a symbol.

    The procedure `type-exception-type-id`{.code} returns an identifier
    of the type expected. The type-id can be a symbol, such as
    `number`{.code} and `string-or-nonnegative-fixnum`{.code}, or a
    record type descriptor.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (type-exception? exc)
            (list (type-exception-procedure exc)
                  (type-exception-arguments exc)
                  (type-exception-arg-id exc)
                  (type-exception-type-id exc))
            'not-type-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (vector-ref '#(a b c) 'foo)))
    (#<procedure #2 vector-ref> (#(a b c) foo) 2 exact-integer)
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (time->seconds 'foo)))
    (#<procedure #3 time->seconds> (foo) 1 #<type #4 time>)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**range-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-range_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**range-exception-procedure** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-range_002dexception_002dprocedure){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**range-exception-arguments** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-range_002dexception_002darguments){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**range-exception-arg-id** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-range_002dexception_002darg_002did){.copiable-link}

:   Range-exception objects are raised when a numeric parameter is not
    in the allowed range. The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be a
    range-exception object.

    The procedure `range-exception?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code} when
    `obj`{.variable .var} is a range-exception object and `#f`{.code}
    otherwise.

    The procedure `range-exception-procedure`{.code} returns the
    procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `range-exception-arguments`{.code} returns the list of
    arguments of the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `range-exception-arg-id`{.code} returns the identity
    of the argument which is not in the allowed range, which can be an
    exact integer position (1 for the first argument) or a pair whose
    `car`{.code} is the position and the `cdr`{.code} is the parameter
    name as a symbol.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (range-exception? exc)
            (list (range-exception-procedure exc)
                  (range-exception-arguments exc)
                  (range-exception-arg-id exc))
            'not-range-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (string-ref "abcde" 10)))
    (#<procedure #2 string-ref> ("abcde" 10) 2)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**divide-by-zero-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-divide_002dby_002dzero_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**length-mismatch-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-length_002dmismatch_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**length-mismatch-exception-procedure** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-length_002dmismatch_002dexception_002dprocedure){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**length-mismatch-exception-arguments** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-length_002dmismatch_002dexception_002darguments){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**length-mismatch-exception-arg-id** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-length_002dmismatch_002dexception_002darg_002did){.copiable-link}

:   Length-mismatch-exception objects are raised by some procedures when
    they are called with two or more list arguments and the lists are
    not of the same length. The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be
    a length-mismatch-exception object.

    The procedure `length-mismatch-exception?`{.code} returns
    `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is an
    length-mismatch-exception object and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `length-mismatch-exception-procedure`{.code} returns
    the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `length-mismatch-exception-arguments`{.code} returns
    the list of arguments of the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable
    .var}.

    The procedure `length-mismatch-exception-arg-id`{.code} returns the
    identity of the argument whose length is the shortest, which can be
    an exact integer position (1 for the first argument) or a pair whose
    `car`{.code} is the position and the `cdr`{.code} is the parameter

    The procedure `wrong-number-of-arguments-exception?`{.code} returns
    `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is a
    wrong-number-of-arguments-exception object and `#f`{.code}

    returns the list of arguments of the procedure that raised
    `exc`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (wrong-number-of-arguments-exception? exc)
            (list (wrong-number-of-arguments-exception-procedure exc)
                  (wrong-number-of-arguments-exception-arguments exc))
            'not-wrong-number-of-arguments-exception))
    ```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**number-of-arguments-limit-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-number_002dof_002darguments_002dlimit_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**number-of-arguments-limit-exception-procedure** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-number_002dof_002darguments_002dlimit_002dexception_002dprocedure){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**number-of-arguments-limit-exception-arguments** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-number_002dof_002darguments_002dlimit_002dexception_002darguments){.copiable-link}

:   Number-of-arguments-limit-exception objects are raised by the
    `apply`{.code} procedure when the procedure being called is passed
    more than 8192 arguments. The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must
    be a number-of-arguments-limit-exception object.

    The procedure `number-of-arguments-limit-exception?`{.code} returns
    `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is a
    number-of-arguments-limit-exception object and `#f`{.code}
    otherwise.

    The procedure `number-of-arguments-limit-exception-procedure`{.code}
    returns the target procedure of the call to `apply`{.code} that
    raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `number-of-arguments-limit-exception-arguments`{.code}
    returns the list of arguments of the target procedure of the call to
    `apply`{.code} that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (iota n) (if (= n 0) '() (cons n (iota (- n 1)))))
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (number-of-arguments-limit-exception? exc)
            (list (number-of-arguments-limit-exception-procedure exc)
                  (length (number-of-arguments-limit-exception-arguments exc)))
            'not-number-of-arguments-limit-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (apply + 1 2 3 (iota 8190))))
    (#<procedure #2 +> 8193)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

    raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `nonprocedure-operator-exception-arguments`{.code}
    returns the list of arguments of the procedure call that raised
    `exc`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (nonprocedure-operator-exception? exc)
            (list (nonprocedure-operator-exception-operator exc)
                  (nonprocedure-operator-exception-arguments exc))
            'not-nonprocedure-operator-exception))
    ```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**wrong-number-of-values-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-wrong_002dnumber_002dof_002dvalues_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**wrong-number-of-values-exception-vals** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-wrong_002dnumber_002dof_002dvalues_002dexception_002dvals){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**wrong-number-of-values-exception-code** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-wrong_002dnumber_002dof_002dvalues_002dexception_002dcode){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**wrong-number-of-values-exception-rte** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-wrong_002dnumber_002dof_002dvalues_002dexception_002drte){.copiable-link}

:   Wrong-number-of-values-exception objects are raised by the
    `let-values`{.code} and `define-values`{.code} forms when the number
    of values does not conform to the number of variables to be bound.
    The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be an
    wrong-number-of-values-exception object.

    The procedure `wrong-number-of-values-exception?`{.code} returns
    `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is an
    wrong-number-of-values-exception object and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `wrong-number-of-values-exception-vals`{.code} returns
    the values that were to be bound.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (wrong-number-of-values-exception? exc)
            (call-with-values
             (lambda () (wrong-number-of-values-exception-vals exc))
             list)
            'not-wrong-number-of-values-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (let-values (((a b) (values 11 22 33))) (* a b))))
    (11 22 33)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

    .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (keyword-expected-exception? exc)
            (list (keyword-expected-exception-procedure exc)
                  (keyword-expected-exception-arguments exc))
            'not-keyword-expected-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () ((lambda (#!key (foo 5)) foo) 11 22)))
    (#<procedure #2> (11 22))
    ```
    :::

### 12.10 Other exception objects {#Other-exception-objects-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**error-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-error_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**error-exception-message** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-error_002dexception_002dmessage){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**error-exception-parameters** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-error_002dexception_002dparameters){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**error** `message`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`obj`{.variable .var}`…`{.variable .def-var-arguments} [¶](#index-error){.copiable-link}

:   Error-exception objects are raised when the `error`{.code} procedure
    is called. The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be an
    error-exception object.

    The procedure `error-exception?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code} when
    `obj`{.variable .var} is an error-exception object and `#f`{.code}
    otherwise.

    The procedure `error-exception-message`{.code} returns the first
    argument of the call to `error`{.code} that raised `exc`{.variable
    .var}.

    The procedure `error-exception-parameters`{.code} returns the list
    of arguments, starting with the second argument, of the call to
    `error`{.code} that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The `error`{.code} procedure raises an error-exception object whose
    message field is `message`{.variable .var} and parameters field is
    the list of values `obj`{.variable .var}....

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (error-exception? exc)
            (list (error-exception-message exc)
                  (error-exception-parameters exc))
            'not-error-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda () (error "unexpected object:" 123)))
    ("unexpected object:" (123))
    ```
    :::

:::

## 13 Host environment {#Host-environment-1 .chapter}

The host environment is the set of resources, such as the filesystem,
network and processes, that are managed by the operating system within
which the Scheme program is executing. This chapter specifies how the
host environment can be accessed from within the Scheme program.

In this chapter we say that the Scheme program being executed is a
process, even though the concept of process does not exist in some
operating systems supported by Gambit (e.g. MSDOS).
