### 13.1 Handling of file names {#Handling-of-file-names-1 .section}

[]{#index-file-names .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-current-working-directory .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-absolute-path .index-entry-id} []{#index-relative-path
.index-entry-id} []{#index-home-directory .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-central-installation-directory .index-entry-id}
[]{#index-installation-directories .index-entry-id}

Gambit uses a naming convention for files that is compatible with the
one used by the host environment but extended to allow referring to the
*home directory* of the current user or some specific user and the
*installation directories*.

A *path* is a string that denotes a file, for example
`"src/readme.txt"`{.code}. Each component of a path is separated by a
'`/`{.sample .samp}' under UNIX and macOS and by a '`/`{.sample .samp}'
or '`\`{.sample .samp}' under MSDOS and Microsoft Windows. A leading
separator indicates an absolute path under UNIX, macOS, MSDOS and
Microsoft Windows. A path which does not contain a path separator is
relative to the *current working directory* on all operating systems. A
volume specifier such as '`C:`{.sample .samp}' may prefix a file name
under MSDOS and Microsoft Windows.

[]{#index-_007e_007e .index-entry-id}

A path which starts with the characters '`~~`{.sample .samp}' denotes a
file in an installation directory. If nothing follows the '`~~`{.sample
.samp}' then the directory denoted is the central installation
directory. Otherwise what follows the '`~~`{.sample .samp}' is the name
of the installation directory, for example '`~~lib`{.sample .samp}'
denotes the '`lib`{.sample .samp}' installation directory. Note that the
location of the installation directories may be overridden by using the
'`-:~~`{.sample .samp}`NAME`{.variable .var}`=`{.sample
.samp}`DIRECTORY`{.variable .var}' runtime option or by defining the
'`GAMBOPT`{.sample .samp}' environment variable. Unless explicitly
overridden, '`~~execdir`{.sample .samp}' denotes the directory
containing the current executable program.

[]{#index-_007e .index-entry-id}

A path which starts with the character '`~`{.sample .samp}' not followed
by '`~`{.sample .samp}' denotes a file in the user's home directory. The
user's home directory is contained in the '`HOME`{.sample .samp}'
environment variable under UNIX, macOS, MSDOS and Microsoft Windows.
Under MSDOS and Microsoft Windows, if the '`HOME`{.sample .samp}'
environment variable is not defined, the environment variables
'`HOMEDRIVE`{.sample .samp}' and '`HOMEPATH`{.sample .samp}' are
concatenated if they are defined. If this fails to yield a home
directory, the central installation directory is used instead.

[]{#index-_007eusername .index-entry-id}

A path which starts with the characters '`~`{.sample
.samp}`username`{.variable .var}' denotes a file in the home directory
of the given user. Under UNIX and macOS this is found using the password
file. There is no equivalent under MSDOS and Microsoft Windows.

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**initial-current-directory** [¶](#index-initial_002dcurrent_002ddirectory){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**current-directory** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`new-current-directory`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-current_002ddirectory){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-initial-current-working-directory .index-entry-id}

    The procedure `initial-current-directory`{.code} returns the
    absolute *normalized path* of the current working directory of the
    current process when it was started.

    []{#index-current-working-directory-1 .index-entry-id}

    The parameter object `current-directory`{.code} is bound to the
    current working directory. Calling this procedure with no argument
    returns the absolute *normalized path* of the directory and calling
    this procedure with one argument sets the directory to
    `new-current-directory`{.variable .var}. The initial binding of this
    parameter object is the path returned by
    `initial-current-directory`{.code}. The path returned by
    `current-directory`{.code} always contains a trailing directory
    separator. Modifications of the parameter object do not change the
    current working directory of the current process (i.e. that is
    accessible with the UNIX `getcwd()`{.code} function and the
    Microsoft Windows `GetCurrentDirectory`{.code} function). It is an
    error to mutate the string returned by `current-directory`{.code}.

    For example under UNIX:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (current-directory)
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/"
    > (current-directory "..")
    > (current-directory)
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/"
    > (initial-current-directory)
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/"
    > (path-expand "foo" "~~")
    "/usr/local/Gambit/foo"
    > (parameterize ((current-directory "~~")) (path-expand "foo"))
    "/usr/local/Gambit/foo"
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**path-expand** `path`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`origin-directory`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-path_002dexpand){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-absolute-path-1 .index-entry-id} []{#index-relative-path-1
    .index-entry-id}

    The procedure `path-expand`{.code} takes the path of a file or
    directory and returns an expanded path, which is an absolute path
    when `path`{.variable .var} or `origin-directory`{.variable .var}
    are absolute paths. The optional `origin-directory`{.variable .var}
    parameter, which defaults to the current working directory, is the
    directory used to resolve relative paths. Components of the paths
    `path`{.variable .var} and `origin-directory`{.variable .var} need
    not exist.

    For example under UNIX:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (path-expand "foo")
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/foo"
    > (path-expand "~/foo")
    "/Users/feeley/foo"
    > (path-expand "~~lib/foo")
    "/usr/local/Gambit/lib/foo"
    > (path-expand "../foo")
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/../foo"
    > (path-expand "foo" "")
    "foo"
    > (path-expand "foo" "/tmp")
    "/tmp/foo"
    > (path-expand "this/file/does/not/exist")
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/this/file/does/not/exist"
    > (path-expand "")
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/"
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**path-normalize** `path`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`allow-relative?`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`origin-directory`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-path_002dnormalize){.copiable-link}

:   []{#index-normalized-path .index-entry-id}

    The procedure `path-normalize`{.code} takes a path of a file or
    directory and returns its normalized path. The optional
    `origin-directory`{.variable .var} parameter, which defaults to the
    current working directory, is the directory used to resolve relative
    paths. All components of the paths `path`{.variable .var} and
    `origin-directory`{.variable .var} must exist, except possibly the
    last component of `path`{.variable .var}. A normalized path is a
    path containing no redundant parts and which is consistent with the
    current structure of the filesystem. A normalized path of a
    directory will always end with a path separator (i.e. '`/`{.sample
    .samp}', '`\`{.sample .samp}', or '`:`{.sample .samp}' depending on
    the operating system). The optional `allow-relative?`{.variable
    .var} parameter, which defaults to `#f`{.code}, indicates if the
    path returned can be expressed relatively to
    `origin-directory`{.variable .var}: a `#f`{.code} requests an
    absolute path, the symbol `shortest`{.code} requests the shortest of
    the absolute and relative paths, and any other value requests the
    relative path. The shortest path is useful for interaction with the
    user because short relative paths are typically easier to read than
    long absolute paths.

    For example under UNIX:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (path-expand "../foo")
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/doc/../foo"
    > (path-normalize "../foo")
    "/Users/feeley/gambit/foo"
    > (path-normalize "this/file/does/not/exist")
    *** ERROR IN (console)@3.1 -- No such file or directory
    (path-normalize "this/file/does/not/exist")
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**path-extension** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-path_002dextension){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**path-strip-extension** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-path_002dstrip_002dextension){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**path-directory** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-path_002ddirectory){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**path-strip-directory** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-path_002dstrip_002ddirectory){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**path-strip-trailing-directory-separator** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-path_002dstrip_002dtrailing_002ddirectory_002dseparator){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**path-volume** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-path_002dvolume){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**path-strip-volume** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-path_002dstrip_002dvolume){.copiable-link}

:   These procedures extract various parts of a path, which need not be
    a normalized path. The procedure `path-extension`{.code} returns the
    file extension (including the period) or the empty string if there
    is no extension. The procedure `path-strip-extension`{.code} returns
    the path with the extension stripped off. The procedure
    `path-directory`{.code} returns the file's directory (including the
    last path separator) or the empty string if no directory is
    specified in the path. The procedure `path-strip-directory`{.code}
    returns the path with the directory stripped off. The procedure
    `path-strip-trailing-directory-separator`{.code} returns the path
    with the directory separator stripped off if one is at the end of
    the path. The procedure `path-volume`{.code} returns the file's
    volume (including the last path separator) or the empty string if no
    volume is specified in the path. The procedure
    `path-strip-volume`{.code} returns the path with the volume stripped
    off.

    For example under UNIX:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (path-extension "/tmp/foo")
    ""
    > (path-extension "/tmp/foo.txt")
    ".txt"
    > (path-strip-extension "/tmp/foo.txt")
    "/tmp/foo"
    > (path-directory "/tmp/foo.txt")
    "/tmp/"
    > (path-strip-directory "/tmp/foo.txt")
    "foo.txt"
    > (path-strip-trailing-directory-separator "/usr/local/bin/")
    "/usr/local/bin"
    > (path-strip-trailing-directory-separator "/usr/local/bin")
    "/usr/local/bin"
    > (path-volume "/tmp/foo.txt")
    ""
    > (path-volume "C:/tmp/foo.txt")
    "" ; result is "C:" under Microsoft Windows
    > (path-strip-volume "C:/tmp/foo.txt")
    "C:/tmp/foo.txt" ; result is "/tmp/foo.txt" under Microsoft Windows
    ```
    :::

### 13.2 Filesystem operations {#Filesystem-operations-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**create-directory** `path-or-settings`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-create_002ddirectory){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**create-temporary-directory** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`path-or-settings`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-create_002dtemporary_002ddirectory){.copiable-link}

:   These procedures create directories. The argument
    `path-or-settings`{.variable .var} is either a string denoting a
    filesystem path or a list of port settings which must contain a
    `path:`{.code} setting in the case the procedure
    `create-directory`{.code}. The procedure `create-directory`{.code}
    returns an unspecified value. In the case of
    `create-temporary-directory`{.code} the path is used as a prefix to
    generate new directory paths until the path of a directory not
    currently existing is generated and that path is returned. When a
    path is not specified it defaults to a unique name in the operating
    system's temporary directory. Here are the settings allowed:

    -   `path:`{.code} `string`{.variable .var}

        This setting indicates the location of the directory to create
        in the filesystem. There is no default value for this setting.

    -   `permissions:`{.code} `12-bit-exact-integer`{.variable .var}

        This setting controls the UNIX permissions that will be attached
        to the file if it is created. The default value of this setting
        is `#o777`{.code}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (create-directory "newdir")
    > (create-temporary-directory "~/foo")
    "/Users/feeley/foo91992"
    > (create-temporary-directory)
    "/tmp/gsi-temp91992"
    > (create-directory "newdir")
    *** ERROR IN (console)@2.1 -- File exists
    (create-directory "newdir")
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**create-fifo** `path-or-settings`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-create_002dfifo){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure creates a FIFO. The argument
    `path-or-settings`{.variable .var} is either a string denoting a
    filesystem path or a list of port settings which must contain a
    `path:`{.code} setting. Here are the settings allowed:

    -   `path:`{.code} `string`{.variable .var}

        This setting indicates the location of the FIFO to create in the
        filesystem. There is no default value for this setting.

    -   `permissions:`{.code} `12-bit-exact-integer`{.variable .var}

        This setting controls the UNIX permissions that will be attached
        to the file if it is created. The default value of this setting
        is `#o666`{.code}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (create-fifo "fifo")
    > (define a (open-input-file "fifo"))
    > (define b (open-output-file "fifo"))
    > (display "1 22 333" b)
    > (force-output b)
    > (read a)
    1
    > (read a)
    22
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**create-link** `source-path`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`destination-path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-create_002dlink){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure creates a hard link between `source-path`{.variable
    .var} and `destination-path`{.variable .var}. The argument
    `source-path`{.variable .var} must be a string denoting the path of
    an existing file. The argument `destination-path`{.variable .var}
    must be a string denoting the path of the link to create.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**create-symbolic-link** `source-path`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`destination-path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-create_002dsymbolic_002dlink){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure creates a symbolic link between
    `source-path`{.variable .var} and `destination-path`{.variable
    .var}. The argument `source-path`{.variable .var} must be a string
    denoting the path of an existing file. The argument
    `destination-path`{.variable .var} must be a string denoting the
    path of the symbolic link to create.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**rename-file** `source-path`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`destination-path`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`replace?`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-rename_002dfile){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure renames the file `source-path`{.variable .var} to
    `destination-path`{.variable .var}. The argument
    `source-path`{.variable .var} must be a string denoting the path of
    an existing file. The argument `destination-path`{.variable .var}
    must be a string denoting the new path of the file. If
    `replace?`{.variable .var} is absent or true, an existing
    `destination-path`{.variable .var} will be replaced by
    `source-path`{.variable .var}. Otherwise, the rename operation will
    fail if `destination-path`{.variable .var} exists. Not all
    filesystems support atomic renaming and existence testing.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**copy-file** `source-path`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`destination-path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-copy_002dfile){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure copies the file `source-path`{.variable .var} to
    `destination-path`{.variable .var}. The argument
    `source-path`{.variable .var} must be a string denoting the path of
    an existing file. The argument `destination-path`{.variable .var}
    must be a string denoting the path of the file to create.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**delete-file** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-delete_002dfile){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure deletes the file `path`{.variable .var}. The argument
    `path`{.variable .var} must be a string denoting the path of an
    existing file.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**delete-directory** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-delete_002ddirectory){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure deletes the directory `path`{.variable .var}. The
    argument `path`{.variable .var} must be a string denoting the path
    of an existing empty directory.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**delete-file-or-directory** `path`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`recursive?`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-delete_002dfile_002dor_002ddirectory){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure deletes the file or directory `path`{.variable .var}.
    The argument `path`{.variable .var} must be a string denoting the
    path of an existing file or directory. If `recursive?`{.variable
    .var} is specified and is true, directories are recursively deleted.
    Otherwise only empty directories can be deleted.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**directory-files** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`path-or-settings`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-directory_002dfiles){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the list of the files in a directory. The
    argument `path-or-settings`{.variable .var} is either a string
    denoting a filesystem path to a directory or a list of settings
    which must contain a `path:`{.code} setting. If it is not specified,
    `path-or-settings`{.variable .var} defaults to the current directory
    (the value bound to the `current-directory`{.code} parameter
    object). Here are the settings allowed:

    -   `path:`{.code} `string`{.variable .var}

        This setting indicates the location of the directory in the
        filesystem. There is no default value for this setting.

    -   `ignore-hidden:`{.code} ( `#f`{.code} \| `#t`{.code} \|
        `dot-and-dot-dot`{.code} )

        This setting controls whether hidden-files will be returned.
        Under UNIX and macOS hidden-files are those that start with a
        period (such as '`.`{.sample .samp}', '`..`{.sample .samp}', and
        '`.profile`{.sample .samp}'). Under Microsoft Windows hidden
        files are the '`.`{.sample .samp}' and '`..`{.sample .samp}'
        entries and the files whose "hidden file" attribute is set. A
        setting of `#f`{.code} will enumerate all the files. A setting
        of `#t`{.code} will only enumerate the files that are not
        hidden. A setting of `dot-and-dot-dot`{.code} will enumerate all
        the files except for the '`.`{.sample .samp}' and '`..`{.sample
        .samp}' hidden files. The default value of this setting is
        `#t`{.code}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (directory-files)
    ("complex" "README" "simple")
    > (directory-files "../include")
    ("config.h" "config.h.in" "gambit.h" "makefile" "makefile.in")
    > (directory-files (list path: "../include" ignore-hidden: #f))
    ("." ".." "config.h" "config.h.in" "gambit.h" "makefile" "makefile.in")
    ```
    :::

### 13.3 Shell command execution {#Shell-command-execution-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**shell-command** `command`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`capture?`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-shell_002dcommand){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `shell-command`{.code} calls up the shell to execute
    `command`{.variable .var} which must be a string. The argument
    `capture?`{.variable .var}, which defaults to `#f`{.code}, indicates
    if the output of the command is captured as a string. If
    `capture?`{.variable .var} is `#f`{.code}, this procedure returns
    the exit status of the shell in the form that the C library's
    `system`{.code} routine returns. If `capture?`{.variable .var} is
    not `#f`{.code}, this procedure returns a pair consisting of the
    exit status of the shell in the `car`{.code} field, and the captured
    output in the `cdr`{.code} field. Be advised that the shell that is
    used, and consequently the syntax of `command`{.variable .var},
    depends on the operating system. On Unix, the shell `/bin/sh`{.code}
    is usually invoked. On Windows, the shell `cmd.exe`{.code} is
    usually invoked.

    For example under UNIX:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (shell-command "ls -sk f*.scm")
    4 fact.scm   4 fib.scm
    0
    > (shell-command "ls -sk f*.scm" #t)
    (0 . "4 fact.scm   4 fib.scm\n")
    > (shell-command "echo x\\\\\\\\y $HOME" #t)
    (0 . "x\\y /Users/feeley\n")
    ```
    :::

    For example under Windows:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (shell-command "echo x\\\\\\\\y %HOME%" #t)
    (0 . "x\\\\\\\\y C:\\Users\\feeley\r\n")
    ```
    :::

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

### 13.4 Process termination {#Process-termination-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**exit** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`status`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-exit){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `exit`{.code} causes the process to terminate with the
    status `status`{.variable .var} which must be an exact integer in
    the range 0 to 255 or `#f`{.code}. If it is not specified,
    `status`{.variable .var} defaults to 0. When `status`{.variable
    .var} is `#f`{.code} the process terminates with an error status.

    For example under UNIX:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    $ gsi
    Gambit v4.9.5

    > (exit #f)
    $ echo $?
    70
    ```
    :::

### 13.5 Command line arguments {#Command-line-arguments-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**command-line** [¶](#index-command_002dline-1){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns a list of strings corresponding to the
    command line arguments, including the program file name as the first
    element of the list. When the interpreter executes a Scheme script,
    the list returned by `command-line`{.code} contains the script's
    absolute path followed by the remaining command line arguments.

    For example under UNIX:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    $ gsi -:debug -e "(pretty-print (command-line))"
    ("gsi" "-e" "(pretty-print (command-line))")
    $ cat foo
    #!/usr/local/Gambit/bin/gsi-script
    (pretty-print (command-line))
    $ ./foo 1 2 "3 4"
    ("/u/feeley/./foo" "1" "2" "3 4")
    ```
    :::

### 13.6 Environment variables {#Environment-variables-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**getenv** `name`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`default`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-getenv){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**setenv** `name`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`new-value`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-setenv){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `getenv`{.code} returns the value of the environment
    variable `name`{.variable .var} of the current process. Variable
    names are denoted with strings. A string is returned if the
    environment variable is bound, otherwise `default`{.variable .var}
    is returned if it is specified, otherwise an exception is raised.

    The procedure `setenv`{.code} changes the binding of the environment
    variable `name`{.variable .var} to `new-value`{.variable .var} which
    must be a string. If `new-value`{.variable .var} is not specified
    the binding is removed.

    For example under UNIX:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (getenv "HOME")
    "/Users/feeley"
    > (getenv "DOES_NOT_EXIST" #f)
    #f
    > (setenv "DOES_NOT_EXIST" "it does now")
    > (getenv "DOES_NOT_EXIST" #f)
    "it does now"
    > (setenv "DOES_NOT_EXIST")
    > (getenv "DOES_NOT_EXIST" #f)
    #f
    > (getenv "DOES_NOT_EXIST")
    *** ERROR IN (console)@7.1 -- Unbound OS environment variable
    (getenv "DOES_NOT_EXIST")
    ```
    :::

:::

### 13.7 Measuring time {#Measuring-time-1 .section}

Procedures are available for measuring real time (aka "wall" time) and
cpu time (the amount of time the cpu has been executing the process).
The resolution of the real time and cpu time clock is operating system
dependent. Typically the resolution of the cpu time clock is rather
coarse (measured in "ticks" of 1/60th or 1/100th of a second). Real time
is internally computed relative to some arbitrary point in time using
floating point numbers, which means that there is a gradual loss of
resolution as time elapses. Moreover, some operating systems report time
in number of ticks using a 32 bit integer so the value returned by the
time related procedures may wraparound much before any significant loss
of resolution occurs (for example 2.7 years if ticks are 1/50th of a
second).

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**current-time** [¶](#index-current_002dtime){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**time?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-time_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**time-\>seconds** `time`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-time_002d_003eseconds){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**seconds-\>time** `x`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-seconds_002d_003etime){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `current-time`{.code} returns a *time object*
    representing the current point in real time.

    The procedure `time?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code} when
    `obj`{.variable .var} is a time object and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `time->seconds`{.code} converts the time object
    `time`{.variable .var} into an inexact real number representing the
    number of seconds elapsed since the "epoch" (which is 00:00:00
    Coordinated Universal Time 01-01-1970).

    The procedure `seconds->time`{.code} converts the real number
    `x`{.variable .var} representing the number of seconds elapsed since
    the "epoch" into a time object.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (current-time)
    #<time #2>
    > (time? (current-time))
    #t
    > (time? 123)
    #f
    > (time->seconds (current-time))
    1083118758.63973
    > (time->seconds (current-time))
    1083118759.909163
    > (seconds->time (+ 10 (time->seconds (current-time))
    #<time #3>  ; a time object representing 10 seconds in the future
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**process-times** [¶](#index-process_002dtimes){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**cpu-time** [¶](#index-cpu_002dtime){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**real-time** [¶](#index-real_002dtime){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `process-times`{.code} returns a three element
    f64vector containing the cpu time that has been used by the program
    and the real time that has elapsed since it was started. The first
    element corresponds to "user" time in seconds, the second element
    corresponds to "system" time in seconds and the third element is the
    elapsed real time in seconds. On operating systems that can't
    differentiate user and system time, the system time is zero. On
    operating systems that can't measure cpu time, the user time is
    equal to the elapsed real time and the system time is zero.

    The procedure `cpu-time`{.code} returns the cpu time in seconds that
    has been used by the program (user time plus system time).

    The procedure `real-time`{.code} returns the real time that has
    elapsed since the program was started.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (process-times)
    #f64(.02794 .021754 .159926176071167)
    > (cpu-time)
    .051223
    > (real-time)
    .40660619735717773
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[special form: ]{.category-def}**time** [*`expr`{.variable .def-var-arguments}*]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`port`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-time){.copiable-link}

:   The `time`{.code} special form evaluates *expr* and returns the
    result. As a side effect it displays a message on the port
    `port`{.variable .var} which indicates various statistics about the
    evaluation of *expr* including how long the evaluation took (in real
    time and cpu time), how much time was spent in the garbage
    collector, how much memory was allocated during the evaluation and
    how many minor and major page faults occured (0 is reported if not
    running under UNIX). If it is not specified, `port`{.variable .var}
    defaults to the interaction channel (i.e. the output will appear at
    the REPL).

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (f x)
        (let loop ((x x) (lst '()))
          (if (= x 0)
              lst
              (loop (- x 1) (cons x lst)))))
    > (length (time (f 100000)))
    (time (f 100000))
        683 ms real time
        558 ms cpu time (535 user, 23 system)
        8 collections accounting for 102 ms real time (70 user, 5 system)
        6400160 bytes allocated
        no minor faults
        no major faults
    100000
    ```
    :::

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

### 13.8 File information {#File-information-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**file-exists?** `path`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`chase?`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-file_002dexists_003f){.copiable-link}

:   The `path`{.variable .var} argument must be a string. This procedure
    returns `#t`{.code} when a file by that name exists, and returns
    `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    When `chase?`{.variable .var} is present and `#f`{.code}, symbolic
    links will not be chased, in other words if `path`{.variable .var}
    refers to a symbolic link, `file-exists?`{.code} will return
    `#t`{.code} whether or not it points to an existing file.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (file-exists? "nofile")
    #f
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**file-info** `path`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`chase?`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-file_002dinfo){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure accesses the filesystem to get information about the
    file whose location is given by the string `path`{.variable .var}. A
    file-information record is returned that contains the file's type,
    the device number, the inode number, the mode (permission bits), the
    number of links, the file's user id, the file's group id, the file's
    size in bytes, the times of last-access, last-modification and
    last-change, the attributes, and the creation time.

    When `chase?`{.variable .var} is present and `#f`{.code}, symbolic
    links will not be chased, in other words if `path`{.variable .var}
    refers to a symbolic link the `file-info`{.code} procedure will
    return information about the link rather than the file it links to.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (file-info "/dev/tty")
    #<file-info #2
       type: character-special
       device: 19513156
       inode: 20728196
       mode: 438
       number-of-links: 1
       owner: 0
       group: 0
       size: 0
       last-access-time: #<time #3>
       last-modification-time: #<time #4>
       last-change-time: #<time #5>
       attributes: 128
       creation-time: #<time #6>>
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**file-info?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-file_002dinfo_003f){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is a
    file-information record and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (file-info? (file-info "/dev/tty"))
    #t
    > (file-info? 123)
    #f
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**file-info-type** `file-info`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-file_002dinfo_002dtype){.copiable-link}

:   Returns the type field of the file-information record
    `file-info`{.variable .var}. The type is denoted by a symbol. The
    following types are possible:

    `regular`{.code}

    :   Regular file

    `directory`{.code}

    :   Directory

    `character-special`{.code}

    :   Character special device

    `block-special`{.code}

    :   Block special device

    `fifo`{.code}

    :   FIFO

    `symbolic-link`{.code}

    :   Symbolic link

    `socket`{.code}

    :   Socket

    `unknown`{.code}

    :   File is of an unknown type

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (file-info-type (file-info "/dev/tty"))

    > (file-info-type (file-info "/dev"))
    ```

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**file-type** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-file_002dtype){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**file-device** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-file_002ddevice){.copiable-link}\

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**file-owner** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-file_002downer){.copiable-link}\

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**file-last-access-time** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-file_002dlast_002daccess_002dtime){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**file-last-modification-time** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-file_002dlast_002dmodification_002dtime){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**file-last-change-time** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-file_002dlast_002dchange_002dtime){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**file-attributes** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-file_002dattributes){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**file-creation-time** `path`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-file_002dcreation_002dtime){.copiable-link}

:   These procedures combine a call to the `file-info`{.code} procedure
    and a call to a file-information record field accessor. For instance
    `(file-type `{.code}`path`{.variable .var}`)`{.code} is equivalent
    to `(file-info-type (file-info `{.code}`path`{.variable
    .var}`))`{.code}.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**file-last-access-and-modification-times-set!** `path`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`atime`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`mtime`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-file_002dlast_002daccess_002dand_002dmodification_002dtimes_002dset_0021){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure changes the last-access and last-modification times
    of the file whose location is given by the string `path`{.variable
    .var}. Time is specified either with a time object indicating an
    absolute point in time or a real number indicating the number of
    seconds relative to the moment the procedure is called. When
    `atime`{.variable .var} and `mtime`{.variable .var} are not
    specified, the last-access and last-modification times are set to
    the current time. When `mtime`{.variable .var} is not specified, the
    last-access and last-modification times are set to `atime`{.variable
    .var}. Otherwise the last-access time is set to `atime`{.variable
    .var} and the last-modification time is set to `mtime`{.variable
    .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (t path)
        (list (time->seconds (file-last-access-time path))
              (time->seconds (file-last-modification-time path))))
    > (with-output-to-file "nl.txt" newline)
    > (t "nl.txt")
    (1429547027. 1429547027.)
    > (t "nl.txt")
    (1429547027. 1429547027.)
    > (file-last-access-and-modification-times-set! "nl.txt")
    > (t "nl.txt")
    (1429547039. 1429547039.)
    > (file-last-access-and-modification-times-set! "nl.txt" -60)
    > (t "nl.txt")
    (1429547006. 1429547006.)
    > (file-last-access-and-modification-times-set! "nl.txt" -60 0)
    > (t "nl.txt")
    (1429547049. 1429547109.)
    ```
    :::

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

### 13.9 Group information {#Group-information-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**group-info** `group-name-or-id`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-group_002dinfo){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure accesses the group database to get information about
    the group identified by `group-name-or-id`{.variable .var}, which is
    the group's symbolic name (string) or the group's GID (exact
    integer). A group-information record is returned that contains the
    group's symbolic name, the group's id (GID), and the group's members
    (list of symbolic user names).

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (group-info "staff")
    #<group-info #2 name: "staff" gid: 20 members: ("root")>
    > (group-info 29)
    #<group-info #3
       name: "certusers"
       gid: 29
       members: ("root" "jabber" "postfix" "cyrusimap")>
    > (group-info 5000)
    *** ERROR IN (console)@3.1 -- Resource temporarily unavailable
    (group-info 5000)
    ```

    the user identified by `user-name-or-id`{.variable .var}, which is
    the user's symbolic name (string) or the user's UID (exact integer).

    ``` example-preformatted
    #<user-info #3 name: "root" uid: 0 gid: 0 home: "/var/root" shell: "/bin/sh">

    *** ERROR IN (console)@3.1 -- Resource temporarily unavailable
    (user-info 5000)
    ```

### 13.11 Host information {#Host-information-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**host-name** [¶](#index-host_002dname){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the machine's host name as a string.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (host-name)
    "mega.iro.umontreal.ca"
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**host-info** `host-name`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-host_002dinfo){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure accesses the internet host database to get
    information about the machine whose name is denoted by the string
    `host-name`{.variable .var}. A host-information record is returned
    that contains the official name of the machine, a list of aliases
    (alternative names), and a non-empty list of IP addresses for this
    machine. An exception is raised when `host-name`{.variable .var}
    does not appear in the database.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (host-info "www.google.com")
    #<host-info #2
       name: "www.l.google.com"
       aliases: ("www.google.com")
       addresses: (#u8(66 249 85 99) #u8(66 249 85 104))>
    > (host-info "unknown.domain")
    *** ERROR IN (console)@2.1 -- Unknown host
    (host-info "unknown.domain")
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**host-info?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-host_002dinfo_003f){.copiable-link}

    ``` example-preformatted
    #t
    ```

    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**host-info-name** `host-info`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-host_002dinfo_002dname){.copiable-link}

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**address-infos** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`host:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`host`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`service:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`service`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`family:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`family`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`socket-type:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`socket-type`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`protocol:`{.code}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`protocol`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-address_002dinfos){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure is an interface to the `getaddrinfo`{.code} system
    call. It accesses the internet host database to get information
    about the machine whose name is denoted by the string
    `host`{.variable .var} and service is denoted by the string
    `service`{.variable .var} and network address family is
    `family`{.variable .var} (`INET`{.code} or `INET6`{.code}) and
    network socket-type is `socket-type`{.variable .var}
    (`STREAM`{.code} or `DGRAM`{.code} or `RAW`{.code}) and network
    protocol is `socket-type`{.variable .var} (`TCP`{.code} or
    `UDP`{.code}). A list of address-information records is returned.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (address-infos host: "ftp.at.debian.org")
    (#<address-info #2
        family: INET6
        socket-type: DGRAM
        protocol: UDP
        socket-info:
         #<socket-info #3
            family: INET6
            port-number: 0
            address: #u16(8193 2136 2 1 0 0 0 16)>>
     #<address-info #4
        family: INET6
        socket-type: STREAM
        protocol: TCP
        socket-info:
         #<socket-info #5
            family: INET6
            port-number: 0
            address: #u16(8193 2136 2 1 0 0 0 16)>>
     #<address-info #6
        family: INET
        socket-type: DGRAM
        protocol: UDP
        socket-info:
         #<socket-info #7
            family: INET
            port-number: 0
            address: #u8(213 129 232 18)>>
     #<address-info #8
        family: INET
        socket-type: STREAM
        protocol: TCP
        socket-info:
         #<socket-info #9
            family: INET
            port-number: 0
            address: #u8(213 129 232 18)>>)
    > (address-infos host: "ftp.at.debian.org"
                     family: 'INET
                     protocol: 'TCP)
    (#<address-info #10
        family: INET
        socket-type: STREAM
        protocol: TCP
        socket-info:
         #<socket-info #11
            family: INET
            port-number: 0
            address: #u8(213 129 232 18)>>)
    > (address-infos host: "unknown.domain")
    *** ERROR IN (console)@5.1 -- nodename nor servname provided, or not known
    (address-infos host: "unknown.domain")
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**address-info?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-address_002dinfo_003f){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is an

### 13.12 Service information {#Service-information-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**service-info** `service-name-or-id`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-service_002dinfo){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure accesses the service database to get information
    about the service identified by `service-name-or-id`{.variable
    .var}, which is the service's symbolic name (string) or the
    service's port number (exact integer). A service-information record
    is returned that contains the service's symbolic name, a list of
    aliases (alternative names), the port number (exact integer), and
    the protocol name (string). An exception is raised when
    `service-name-or-id`{.variable .var} does not appear in the
    database.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (service-info "http")
    #<service-info #2
       name: "http"
       aliases: ("www" "www-http")
       port-number: 80
       protocol: "udp">
    > (service-info 80)
    #<service-info #3
       name: "http"
       aliases: ("www" "www-http")
       port-number: 80
       protocol: "udp">
    ```
    :::

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (service-info-protocol (service-info "http"))
    "udp"
    ```
    :::

### 13.13 Protocol information {#Protocol-information-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**protocol-info** `protocol-name-or-id`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-protocol_002dinfo){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure accesses the protocol database to get information
    about the protocol identified by `protocol-name-or-id`{.variable
    .var}, which is the protocol's symbolic name (string) or the
    protocol's number (exact integer). A protocol-information record is
    returned that contains the protocol's symbolic name, a list of
    aliases (alternative names), and the protocol number (32 bit
    unsigned exact integer). An exception is raised when
    `protocol-name-or-id`{.variable .var} does not appear in the
    database.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (protocol-info "tcp")
    #<protocol-info #2 name: "tcp" aliases: ("TCP") number: 6>
    > (protocol-info 6)
    #<protocol-info #2 name: "tcp" aliases: ("TCP") number: 6>
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**protocol-info?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-protocol_002dinfo_003f){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is a
    protocol-information record and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (protocol-info? (protocol-info "tcp"))
    #t
    > (protocol-info? 123)
    #f
    ```

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

### 14.1 Unidirectional and bidirectional ports {#Unidirectional-and-bidirectional-ports-1 .section}

Unidirectional ports allow communication between a producer of
information and a consumer. An input-port's producer is typically a
resource managed by the operating system (such as a file, a process or a
network connection) and the consumer is the Scheme program. The roles
are reversed for an output-port.

Associated with each port are settings that affect I/O operations on
that port (encoding of characters to bytes, end-of-line encoding, type
of buffering, etc). Port settings are specified when the port is
created. Some port settings can be changed after a port is created.

Bidirectional ports, also called input-output-ports, allow communication
in both directions. They are best viewed as an object that groups two
separate unidirectional ports (one in each direction). Each direction
has its own port settings and can be closed independently from the other
direction.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

### 14.2 Port classes {#Port-classes-1 .section}

The four classes of ports listed below form an inheritance hierarchy.
Operations possible for a certain class of port are also possible for
the subclasses. Only device-ports are connected to a device managed by
the operating system. For instance it is possible to create ports that
behave as a FIFO where the Scheme program is both the producer and
consumer of information (possibly one thread is the producer and another
thread is the consumer).

1.  An *object-port* (or simply a port) provides operations to read and
    write Scheme data (i.e. any Scheme object) to/from the port. It also
    provides operations to force output to occur, to change the way
    threads block on the port, and to close the port. Note that the
    class of objects for which write/read invariance is guaranteed
    depends on the particular class of port.
2.  A *character-port* provides all the operations of an object-port,
    and also operations to read and write individual characters to/from
    the port. When a Scheme object is written to a character-port, it is
    converted into the sequence of characters that corresponds to its
    external-representation. When reading a Scheme object, an inverse
    conversion occurs. Note that some Scheme objects do not have an
    external textual representation that can be read back.
3.  A *byte-port* provides all the operations of a character-port, and
    also operations to read and write individual bytes to/from the port.
    When a character is written to a byte-port, some encoding of that
    character into a sequence of bytes will occur (for example,
    `#\newline`{.code} will be encoded as the 2 bytes CR-LF when using
    ISO-8859-1 character encoding and `cr-lf`{.code} end-of-line
    encoding, and a non-ASCII character will generate more than 1 byte
    when using UTF-8 character encoding). When reading a character, a
    similar decoding occurs.
4.  A *device-port* provides all the operations of a byte-port, and also
    operations to control the operating system managed device (file,
    network connection, terminal, etc) that is connected to the port.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

### 14.3 Port settings {#Port-settings-1 .section}

Some port settings are only valid for specific port classes whereas some
others are valid for all ports. Port settings are specified when a port
is created. The settings that are not specified will default to some
reasonable values. Keyword objects are used to name the settings to be
set. As a simple example, a device-port connected to the file
`"foo"`{.code} can be created using the call

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
(open-input-file "foo")
```
:::

This will use default settings for the character encoding, buffering,
etc. When a specific character encoding is desired, such as UTF-16BE,
the port can be opened using the call

::: {.example .smallexample}
``` example-preformatted
(open-input-file (list path: "foo" char-encoding: 'UTF-16BE))
```
:::

Here the argument of the procedure `open-input-file`{.code} has been
replaced by a *port settings list* which specifies the value of each
port setting that should not be set to the default value. Note that some
port settings have no useful default and it is therefore required to
specify a value for them, such as the `path:`{.code} in the case of the
file opening procedures. All port creation procedures (i.e. named
`open-...`{.code}) take a single argument that can either be a port
settings list or a value of a type that depends on the kind of port
being created (a path string for files, an IP port number for socket
servers, etc).

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

#### 14.4.1 Object-port settings {#Object_002dport-settings-1 .subsection}

The following is a list of port settings that are valid for all types of
ports.

-   `direction:`{.code} ( `input`{.code} \| `output`{.code} \|
    `input-output`{.code} )

    This setting controls the direction of the port. The symbol
    `input`{.code} indicates a unidirectional input-port, the symbol
    `output`{.code} indicates a unidirectional output-port, and the
    symbol `input-output`{.code} indicates a bidirectional port. The
    default value of this setting depends on the port creation
    procedure.

-   `buffering:`{.code} ( `#f`{.code} \| `#t`{.code} \| `line`{.code} )

    This setting controls the buffering of the port. To set each
    direction separately the keywords `input-buffering:`{.code} and
    `output-buffering:`{.code} must be used instead of
    `buffering:`{.code}. The value `#f`{.code} selects unbuffered I/O,
    the value `#t`{.code} selects fully buffered I/O, and the symbol
    `line`{.code} selects line buffered I/O (the output buffer is
    drained when a `#\newline`{.code} character is written). Line
    buffered I/O only applies to character-ports. The default value of
    this setting is operating system dependent except consoles which are
    unbuffered.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

#### 14.4.2 Object-port operations {#Object_002dport-operations-1 .subsection}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**input-port?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-input_002dport_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**output-port?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-output_002dport_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**port?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-port_003f){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `input-port?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code} when
    `obj`{.variable .var} is a unidirectional input-port or a
    bidirectional port and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `output-port?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code} when
    `obj`{.variable .var} is a unidirectional output-port or a
    bidirectional port and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `port?`{.code} returns `#t`{.code} when
    `obj`{.variable .var} is a port (either unidirectional or
    bidirectional) and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (input-port? (current-input-port))
    #t
    > (call-with-input-string "some text" output-port?)
    #f
    > (port? (current-output-port))
    #t
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**read** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`port`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-read){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure reads and returns the next Scheme datum from the
    input-port `port`{.variable .var}. The end-of-file object is
    returned when the end of the stream is reached. If it is not
    specified, `port`{.variable .var} defaults to the current
    input-port.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (call-with-input-string "some text" read)
    some
    > (call-with-input-string "" read)
    #!eof
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**read-all** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`port`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`reader`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-read_002dall){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure repeatedly calls the procedure `reader`{.variable
    .var} with `port`{.variable .var} as the sole argument and
    accumulates a list of each value returned up to the end-of-file
    object. The procedure `read-all`{.code} returns the accumulated list
    without the end-of-file object. If it is not specified,
    `port`{.variable .var} defaults to the current input-port. If it is
    not specified, `reader`{.variable .var} defaults to the procedure
    `read`{.code}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (call-with-input-string "3,2,1\ngo!" read-all)
    (3 ,2 ,1 go!)
    > (call-with-input-string "3,2,1\ngo!"
                              (lambda (p) (read-all p read-char)))
    (#\3 #\, #\2 #\, #\1 #\newline #\g #\o #\!)
    > (call-with-input-string "3,2,1\ngo!"
                              (lambda (p) (read-all p read-line)))
    ("3,2,1" "go!")
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**write** `obj`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`port`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-write){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure writes the Scheme datum `obj`{.variable .var} to the
    output-port `port`{.variable .var} and the value returned is
    unspecified. If it is not specified, `port`{.variable .var} defaults
    to the current output-port.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (write (list 'compare (list 'quote '@x) 'and (list 'unquote '@x))) 
    (compare '@x and , @x)>
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**newline** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`port`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-newline){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure writes an "object separator" to the output-port
    `port`{.variable .var} and the value returned is unspecified. The
    separator ensures that the next Scheme datum written with the
    `write`{.code} procedure will not be confused with the latest datum
    that was written. On character-ports this is done by writing the
    character `#\newline`{.code}. On ports where successive objects are
    implicitly distinct (such as "vector ports") this procedure does
    nothing.

    Regardless of the class of a port `p`{.variable .var} and assuming
    that the external textual representation of the object `x`{.variable
    .var} is readable, the expression
    `(begin (write `{.code}`x`{.variable .var}` `{.code}`p`{.variable
    .var}`) (newline `{.code}`p`{.variable .var}`))`{.code} will write
    to `p`{.variable .var} a representation of `x`{.variable .var} that
    can be read back with the procedure `read`{.code}. If it is not
    specified, `port`{.variable .var} defaults to the current
    output-port.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (begin (write 123) (newline) (write 456) (newline))
    123
    456
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**force-output** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`port`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`level`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-force_002doutput){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `force-output`{.code} causes the data that was written
    to the output-port `port`{.variable .var} to be moved closer to its
    destination according to `level`{.variable .var}, an exact integer
    in the range 0 to 2. If `port`{.variable .var} is not specified, the
    current output-port is used. If `level`{.variable .var} is not
    specified, it defaults to 0. Values of `level`{.variable .var} above
    0 are equivalent to `level`{.variable .var} = 0 except for device
    ports as explained below.

    When `level`{.variable .var} is 0, the output buffers of
    `port`{.variable .var} which are managed in the Scheme process are
    drained (i.e. the output operation that was delayed due to buffering
    is actually performed). In the case of a device port the data is
    passed to the operating system and it becomes its responsibility to
    transmit the data to the device. The operating system may implement
    its own buffering approach which delays the transmission of the data
    to the device.

    When `level`{.variable .var} is 1, in addition to the operations for
    `level`{.variable .var} = 0 and if the operating system supports the
    functionality, the operating system is requested to transmit the
    data to the device. On UNIX this corresponds to a `fsync`{.code}
    system call.

    When `level`{.variable .var} is 2, in addition to the operations for
    `level`{.variable .var} = 1 and if the operating system supports the
    functionality, the operating system is requested to wait until the
    device reports that the data was saved by the device (e.g. actually
    written to disk in the case of a file). This operation can take a
    long time on some operating systems. On macOS this corresponds to a
    `fcntl`{.code} system call with operation `F_FULLFSYNC`{.code}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define p (open-tcp-client "www.iro.umontreal.ca:80"))
    > (display "GET /\n" p)
    > (force-output p)
    > (read-line p)
    "<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC \"-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN\""
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**close-input-port** `port`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-close_002dinput_002dport){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**close-output-port** `port`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-close_002doutput_002dport){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**close-port** `port`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-close_002dport){.copiable-link}

:   The `port`{.variable .var} argument of these procedures must be a
    unidirectional or a bidirectional port. For all three procedures the
    value returned is unspecified.

    The procedure `close-input-port`{.code} closes the input-port side
    of `port`{.variable .var}, which must not be a unidirectional
    output-port.

    The procedure `close-output-port`{.code} closes the output-port side
    of `port`{.variable .var}, which must not be a unidirectional
    input-port. The ouput buffers are drained before `port`{.variable
    .var} is closed.

    The procedure `close-port`{.code} closes all sides of the
    `port`{.variable .var}. Unless `port`{.variable .var} is a
    unidirectional input-port, the output buffers are drained before
    `port`{.variable .var} is closed.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define p (open-tcp-client "www.iro.umontreal.ca:80"))
    > (display "GET /\n" p)
    > (close-output-port p)
    > (read-line p)
    "<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC \"-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN\""
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**input-port-timeout-set!** `port`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`timeout`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`thunk`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-input_002dport_002dtimeout_002dset_0021){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**output-port-timeout-set!** `port`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`timeout`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`thunk`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-output_002dport_002dtimeout_002dset_0021){.copiable-link}

:   When a thread tries to perform an I/O operation on a port, the
    requested operation may not be immediately possible and the thread
    must wait. For example, the thread may be trying to read a line of
    text from the console and the user has not typed anything yet, or
    the thread may be trying to write to a network connection faster
    than the network can handle. In such situations the thread normally
    blocks until the operation becomes possible.

    It is sometimes necessary to guarantee that the thread will not
    block too long. For this purpose, to each input-port and output-port
    is attached a *timeout* and *timeout-thunk*. The timeout indicates
    the point in time beyond which the thread should stop waiting on an
    input and output operation respectively. When the timeout is
    reached, the thread calls the port's timeout-thunk. If the
    timeout-thunk returns `#f`{.code} the thread abandons trying to
    perform the operation (in the case of an input operation an
    end-of-file is read and in the case of an output operation an
    exception is raised). Otherwise, the thread will block again waiting
    for the operation to become possible (note that if the port's
    timeout has not changed the thread will immediately call the
    timeout-thunk again).

    The procedure `input-port-timeout-set!`{.code} sets the timeout of
    the input-port `port`{.variable .var} to `timeout`{.variable .var}
    and the timeout-thunk to `thunk`{.variable .var}. The procedure
    `output-port-timeout-set!`{.code} sets the timeout of the
    output-port `port`{.variable .var} to `timeout`{.variable .var} and
    the timeout-thunk to `thunk`{.variable .var}. If it is not
    specified, the `thunk`{.variable .var} defaults to a thunk that
    returns `#f`{.code}. The `timeout`{.variable .var} is either a time
    object indicating an absolute point in time, or it is a real number
    which indicates the number of seconds relative to the moment the
    procedure is called. For both procedures the value returned is
    unspecified.

    When a port is created the timeout is set to infinity
    (`+inf.0`{.code}). This causes the thread to wait as long as needed
    for the operation to become possible. Setting the timeout to a point
    in the past (`-inf.0`{.code}) will cause the thread to attempt the
    I/O operation and never block (i.e. the timeout-thunk is called if
    the operation is not immediately possible).

    The following example shows how to cause the REPL to terminate when
    the user does not enter an expression within the next 60 seconds.

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (input-port-timeout-set! (repl-input-port) 60)
    >
    *** EOF again to exit
    ```
    :::

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::
:::

#### 14.5.1 Character-port settings {#Character_002dport-settings-1 .subsection}

The following is a list of port settings that are valid for
character-ports.

-   `readtable:`{.code} `readtable`{.variable .var}

    This setting determines the readtable attached to the
    character-port. To set each direction separately the keywords
    `input-readtable:`{.code} and `output-readtable:`{.code} must be
    used instead of `readtable:`{.code}. Readtables control the external
    textual representation of Scheme objects, that is the encoding of
    Scheme objects using characters. The behavior of the `read`{.code}
    procedure depends on the port's input-readtable and the behavior of
    the procedures `write`{.code}, `pretty-print`{.code}, and related
    procedures is affected by the port's output-readtable. The default
    value of this setting is the value bound to the parameter object
    `current-readtable`{.code}.

-   `output-width:`{.code} `positive-integer`{.variable .var}

    This setting indicates the width of the character output-port in
    number of characters. This information is used by the
    pretty-printer. The default value of this setting is 80.

#### 14.5.2 Character-port operations {#Character_002dport-operations-1 .subsection}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**input-port-line** `port`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-input_002dport_002dline){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**input-port-column** `port`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-input_002dport_002dcolumn){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**output-port-line** `port`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-output_002dport_002dline){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**output-port-column** `port`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-output_002dport_002dcolumn){.copiable-link}

:   The current character location of a character input-port is the
    location of the next character to read. The current character
    location of a character output-port is the location of the next
    character to write. Location is denoted by a line number (the first
    line is line 1) and a column number, that is the location on the
    current line (the first column is column 1). The procedures
    `input-port-line`{.code} and `input-port-column`{.code} return the
    line location and the column location respectively of the character
    input-port `port`{.variable .var}. The procedures
    `output-port-line`{.code} and `output-port-column`{.code} return the
    line location and the column location respectively of the character
    output-port `port`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (call-with-output-string
        (lambda (p)
          (display "abc\n123def" p)
          (write (list (output-port-line p) (output-port-column p))
                 p)))
    "abc\n123def(2 7)"
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**output-port-width** `port`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-output_002dport_002dwidth){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the width, in characters, of the character
    output-port `port`{.variable .var}. The value returned is the port's
    output-width setting.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (output-port-width (repl-output-port))
    80
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**read-char** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`port`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-read_002dchar){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure reads the character input-port `port`{.variable .var}
    and returns the character at the current character location and
    advances the current character location to the next character,
    unless the `port`{.variable .var} is already at end-of-file in which
    case `read-char`{.code} returns the end-of-file object. If it is not
    specified, `port`{.variable .var} defaults to the current
    input-port.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (call-with-input-string
        "some text"
        (lambda (p)
          (let ((a (read-char p))) (list a (read-char p)))))
    (#\s #\o)
    > (call-with-input-string "" read-char)
    #!eof
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**peek-char** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`port`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-peek_002dchar){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the same result as `read-char`{.code} but it
    does not advance the current character location of the input-port
    `port`{.variable .var}. If it is not specified, `port`{.variable
    .var} defaults to the current input-port.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (call-with-input-string
        "some text"
        (lambda (p)
          (let ((a (peek-char p))) (list a (read-char p)))))
    (#\s #\s)
    > (call-with-input-string "" peek-char)
    #!eof
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**write-char** `char`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`port`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-write_002dchar){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure writes the character `char`{.variable .var} to the
    character output-port `port`{.variable .var} and advances the
    current character location of that output-port. The value returned
    is unspecified. If it is not specified, `port`{.variable .var}
    defaults to the current output-port.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (write-char #\=)
    =>
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**read-line** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`port`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`separator`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`include-separator?`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`max-length`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-read_002dline){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure reads characters from the character input-port
    `port`{.variable .var} until a specific `separator`{.variable .var}
    or the end-of-file is encountered and returns a string containing
    the sequence of characters read. If it is specified,
    `max-length`{.variable .var} must be a nonnegative exact integer and
    it places an upper limit on the number of characters that are read.

    The `separator`{.variable .var} is included at the end of the string
    only if it was the last character read and
    `include-separator?`{.variable .var} is not `#f`{.code}. The
    `separator`{.variable .var} must be a character or `#f`{.code} (in
    which case all the characters until the end-of-file are read). If it
    is not specified, `port`{.variable .var} defaults to the current
    input-port. If it is not specified, `separator`{.variable .var}
    defaults to `#\newline`{.code}. If it is not specified,
    `include-separator?`{.variable .var} defaults to `#f`{.code}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (split sep)
        (lambda (str)
          (call-with-input-string
            str
            (lambda (p)
              (read-all p (lambda (p) (read-line p sep)))))))
    > ((split #\,) "a,b,c")
    ("a" "b" "c")
    > (map (split #\,)
           (call-with-input-string "1,2,3\n4,5"
                                   (lambda (p) (read-all p read-line))))
    (("1" "2" "3") ("4" "5"))
    > (read-line (current-input-port) #\newline #f 2)1234
    "12"
    > 34
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**read-substring** `string`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`start`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`end`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`port`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`need`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-read_002dsubstring){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**write-substring** `string`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`start`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`end`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`port`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-write_002dsubstring){.copiable-link}

:   These procedures support bulk character I/O. The part of the string
    `string`{.variable .var} starting at index `start`{.variable .var}
    and ending just before index `end`{.variable .var} is used as a
    character buffer that will be the target of `read-substring`{.code}
    or the source of the `write-substring`{.code}. The
    `read-substring`{.code} also accepts a `need`{.variable .var}
    parameter which must be a nonnegative fixnum. Up to `end`{.variable
    .var}-`start`{.variable .var} characters will be transferred. The
    number of characters transferred, possibly zero, is returned by
    these procedures. Fewer characters will be read by
    `read-substring`{.code} if an end-of-file is read, or a timeout
    occurs before all the requested characters are transferred and the
    timeout thunk returns `#f`{.code} (see the procedure
    `input-port-timeout-set!`{.code}), or `need`{.variable .var} is
    specified and at least that many characters have been read (in other
    words the procedure does not block for more characters but may
    transfer more characters if they are immediately available). Fewer
    characters will be written by `write-substring`{.code} if a timeout
    occurs before all the requested characters are transferred and the
    timeout thunk returns `#f`{.code} (see the procedure
    `output-port-timeout-set!`{.code}). If it is not specified,
    `port`{.variable .var} defaults to the current input-port and
    current output-port respectively.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define s (make-string 10 #\x))
    > (read-substring s 2 5)123456789
    3
    > 456789
    > s
    "xx123xxxxx"
    > (read-substring s 2 10 (current-input-port) 3)abcd
    5
    > s
    "xxabcd\nxxx"
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**input-port-readtable** `port`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-input_002dport_002dreadtable){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**output-port-readtable** `port`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-output_002dport_002dreadtable){.copiable-link}

:   These procedures return the readtable attached to the character-port
    `port`{.variable .var}. The `port`{.variable .var} parameter of
    `input-port-readtable`{.code} must be an input-port. The
    `port`{.variable .var} parameter of `output-port-readtable`{.code}
    must be an output-port.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**input-port-readtable-set!** `port`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`readtable`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-input_002dport_002dreadtable_002dset_0021){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**output-port-readtable-set!** `port`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`readtable`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-output_002dport_002dreadtable_002dset_0021){.copiable-link}

:   These procedures change the readtable attached to the character-port
    `port`{.variable .var} to the readtable `readtable`{.variable .var}.
    The `port`{.variable .var} parameter of
    `input-port-readtable-set!`{.code} must be an input-port. The
    `port`{.variable .var} parameter of
    `output-port-readtable-set!`{.code} must be an output-port. The
    value returned is unspecified.
