#### 14.6.1 Byte-port settings {#Byte_002dport-settings-1 .subsection}

The following is a list of port settings that are valid for byte-ports.

-   `char-encoding:`{.code} `encoding`{.variable .var}

    This setting controls the character encoding of the byte-port. For
    bidirectional byte-ports, the character encoding for input and
    output is set. To set each direction separately the keywords
    `input-char-encoding:`{.code} and `output-char-encoding:`{.code}
    must be used instead of `char-encoding:`{.code}. The default value
    of this setting depends on how the runtime system was configured but
    typically UTF-8 is used. The default can be overridden through
    various runtime options (see [Runtime
    options](#Runtime-options){.pxref}), such as
    '`-:file-settings=...`{.sample .samp}' and
    '`-:io-settings=...`{.sample .samp}'. The following encodings are
    supported:

    `ISO-8859-1`{.code}

    :   ISO-8859-1 character encoding. Each character is encoded by a
        single byte. Only Unicode characters with a code in the range 0
        to 255 are allowed.

    `ASCII`{.code}

    :   ASCII character encoding. Each character is encoded by a single
        byte. In principle only Unicode characters with a code in the
        range 0 to 127 are allowed but most types of ports treat this
        exactly like `ISO-8859-1`{.code}.

    `UTF-8`{.code}

    :   UTF-8 character encoding. Each character is encoded by a
        sequence of one to four bytes. The minimum length UTF-8 encoding
        is used. If a BOM is needed at the beginning of the stream then
        it must be explicitly written.

    `UTF-16`{.code}

    :   UTF-16 character encoding. Each character is encoded by one or
        two 16 bit integers (2 or 4 bytes). The 16 bit integers may be
        encoded using little-endian encoding or big-endian encoding. If
        the port is an input-port and the first two bytes read are a BOM
        ("Byte Order Mark" character with hexadecimal code FEFF) then
        the BOM will be discarded and the endianness will be set
        accordingly, otherwise the endianness depends on the operating
        system and how the Gambit runtime was compiled. If the port is
        an output-port then a BOM will be output at the beginning of the
        stream and the endianness depends on the operating system and
        how the Gambit runtime was compiled.

    `UTF-16LE`{.code}

    :   UTF-16 character encoding with little-endian endianness. It is
        like `UTF-16`{.code} except the endianness is set to
        little-endian and there is no BOM processing. If a BOM is needed
        at the beginning of the stream then it must be explicitly
        written.

    `UTF-16BE`{.code}

    :   UTF-16 character encoding with big-endian endianness. It is like
        `UTF-16LE`{.code} except the endianness is set to big-endian.

    `UTF / UTF-fallback-ASCII / UTF-fallback-ISO-8859-1 / UTF-fallback-UTF-16 / UTF-fallback-UTF-16LE / UTF-fallback-UTF-16BE`{.code}

    :   These encodings combine the UTF-8 and UTF-16 encodings. When one
        of these character encodings is used for an output port,
        characters will be encoded using the UTF-8 encoding. The first
        character, if there is one, is prefixed with a UTF-8 BOM (the
        three byte sequence EF BB BF in hexadecimal). When one of these
        character encodings is used for an input port, the character
        encoding depends on the first few bytes. If the first bytes of
        the stream are a UTF-16LE BOM (FF FE in hexadecimal), or a
        UTF-16BE BOM (FE FF in hexadecimal), or a UTF-8 BOM (EF BB BF in
        hexadecimal), then the BOM is discarded and the remaining bytes
        of the stream are decoded using the corresponding character
        encoding. If a BOM is not present, then the stream is decoded
        using the fallback encoding specified. The encoding `UTF`{.code}
        is a synonym for `UTF-fallback-UTF-8`{.code}. Note that the
        `UTF`{.code} character encoding for input will correctly handle
        streams produced using the encodings `UTF`{.code},
        `UTF-8`{.code}, `UTF-16`{.code}, `ASCII`{.code}, and if an
        explicit BOM is output, the encodings `UTF-16LE`{.code}, and
        `UTF-16BE`{.code}.

    `UCS-2`{.code}

    :   UCS-2 character encoding. Each character is encoded by a 16 bit
        integer (2 bytes). The 16 bit integers may be encoded using
        little-endian encoding or big-endian encoding. If the port is an
        input-port and the first two bytes read are a BOM ("Byte Order
        Mark" character with hexadecimal code FEFF) then the BOM will be
        discarded and the endianness will be set accordingly, otherwise
        the endianness depends on the operating system and how the
        Gambit runtime was compiled. If the port is an output-port then
        a BOM will be output at the beginning of the stream and the
        endianness depends on the operating system and how the Gambit
        runtime was compiled.

    `UCS-2LE`{.code}

    :   UCS-2 character encoding with little-endian endianness. It is
        like `UCS-2`{.code} except the endianness is set to
        little-endian and there is no BOM processing. If a BOM is needed
        at the beginning of the stream then it must be explicitly
        written.

    `UCS-2BE`{.code}

    :   UCS-2 character encoding with big-endian endianness. It is like
        `UCS-2LE`{.code} except the endianness is set to big-endian.

    `UCS-4`{.code}

    :   UCS-4 character encoding. Each character is encoded by a 32
        integer (4 bytes). The 32 bit integers may be encoded using
        little-endian encoding or big-endian encoding. If the port is an
        input-port and the first four bytes read are a BOM ("Byte Order
        Mark" character with hexadecimal code 0000FEFF) then the BOM
        will be discarded and the endianness will be set accordingly,
        otherwise the endianness depends on the operating system and how
        the Gambit runtime was compiled. If the port is an output-port
        then a BOM will be output at the beginning of the stream and the
        endianness depends on the operating system and how the Gambit
        runtime was compiled.

    `UCS-4LE`{.code}

    :   UCS-4 character encoding with little-endian endianness. It is
        like `UCS-4`{.code} except the endianness is set to
        little-endian and there is no BOM processing. If a BOM is needed
        at the beginning of the stream then it must be explicitly
        written.

    `UCS-4BE`{.code}

    :   UCS-4 character encoding with big-endian endianness. It is like
        `UCS-4LE`{.code} except the endianness is set to big-endian.

-   `char-encoding-errors:`{.code} ( `#f`{.code} \| `#t`{.code} )

    This setting controls whether illegal character encodings are
    silently replaced with the Unicode character #xfffd (replacement
    character) or raise an error. To set each direction separately the
    keywords `input-char-encoding-errors:`{.code} and
    `output-char-encoding-errors:`{.code} must be used instead of
    `char-encoding-errors:`{.code}. The default value of this setting is
    `#t`{.code}.

-   `eol-encoding:`{.code} `encoding`{.variable .var}

    This setting controls the end-of-line encoding of the byte-port. To
    set each direction separately the keywords
    `input-eol-encoding:`{.code} and `output-eol-encoding:`{.code} must
    be used instead of `eol-encoding:`{.code}. The default value of this
    setting is operating system dependent, but this can be overridden
    through the runtime options (see [Runtime
    options](#Runtime-options){.pxref}). Note that for output-ports the
    end-of-line encoding is applied before the character encoding, and
    for input-ports it is applied after. The following encodings are
    supported:

    `lf`{.code}

    :   For an output-port, writing a `#\newline`{.code} character
        outputs a `#\linefeed`{.code} character to the stream (Unicode
        character code 10). For an input-port, a `#\newline`{.code}
        character is read when a `#\linefeed`{.code} character is
        encountered on the stream. Note that `#\linefeed`{.code} and
        `#\newline`{.code} are two names for the same character, so this
        end-of-line encoding is actually the identity function. Text
        files created by UNIX applications typically use this
        end-of-line encoding.

    `cr`{.code}

    :   For an output-port, writing a `#\newline`{.code} character
        outputs a `#\return`{.code} character to the stream (Unicode
        character code 13). For an input-port, a `#\newline`{.code}
        character is read when a `#\linefeed`{.code} character or a
        `#\return`{.code} character is encountered on the stream. Text
        files created by Classic Mac OS applications typically use this
        end-of-line encoding.

    `cr-lf`{.code}

    :   For an output-port, writing a `#\newline`{.code} character
        outputs to the stream a `#\return`{.code} character followed by
        a `#\linefeed`{.code} character. For an input-port, a
        `#\newline`{.code} character is read when a `#\linefeed`{.code}
        character or a `#\return`{.code} character is encountered on the
        stream. Moreover, if this character is immediately followed by
        the opposite character (`#\linefeed`{.code} followed by
        `#\return`{.code} or `#\return`{.code} followed by
        `#\linefeed`{.code}) then the second character is ignored. In
        other words, all four possible end-of-line encodings are read as
        a single `#\newline`{.code} character. Text files created by DOS
        and Microsoft Windows applications typically use this
        end-of-line encoding.

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

#### 14.6.2 Byte-port operations {#Byte_002dport-operations-1 .subsection}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**read-u8** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`port`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-read_002du8){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**peek-u8** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`port`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-peek_002du8){.copiable-link}

:   These procedures read the byte input-port `port`{.variable .var} and
    return the byte at the current byte location unless the
    `port`{.variable .var} is already at end-of-file in which case the
    end-of-file object is returned. If the end-of-file is not reached
    then the procedure `read-u8`{.code} advances the current byte
    location to the next byte. The procedure `peek-u8`{.code} does not
    advance the port's current byte location. If it is not specified,
    `port`{.variable .var} defaults to the current input-port.

    One way to ensure that the port's input character buffer is empty is
    to call `peek-u8`{.code} strictly before any use of the port in a
    character input operation (i.e. a call to the procedures
    `read`{.code}, `read-char`{.code}, `peek-char`{.code}, etc).
    Alternatively `input-port-characters-buffered`{.code} can be used to
    get the number of characters in the port's input character buffer,
    and to empty the buffer with calls to `read-char`{.code} or
    `read-substring`{.code}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (call-with-input-u8vector
        '#u8(11 22 33 44)
        (lambda (p)
          (let ((a (read-u8 p))) (list a (read-u8 p)))))
    (11 22)
    > (call-with-input-u8vector '#u8() read-u8)
    #!eof
    > (with-input-from-u8vector '#u8(1 5) (lambda () (+ (peek-u8) (peek-u8))))
    2
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**write-u8** `n`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`port`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-write_002du8){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure writes the byte `n`{.variable .var} to the byte
    output-port `port`{.variable .var} and advances the current byte
    location of that output-port. The value returned is unspecified. If
    it is not specified, `port`{.variable .var} defaults to the current
    output-port.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (call-with-output-u8vector (lambda (p) (write-u8 33 p)))
    #u8(33)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**read-subu8vector** `u8vector`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`start`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`end`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`port`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`need`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-read_002dsubu8vector){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**write-subu8vector** `u8vector`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`start`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`end`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`port`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-write_002dsubu8vector){.copiable-link}

:   These procedures support bulk byte I/O. The part of the u8vector
    `u8vector`{.variable .var} starting at index `start`{.variable .var}
    and ending just before index `end`{.variable .var} is used as a byte
    buffer that will be the target of `read-subu8vector`{.code} or the
    source of the `write-subu8vector`{.code}. The
    `read-subu8vector`{.code} also accepts a `need`{.variable .var}
    parameter which must be a nonnegative fixnum. Up to `end`{.variable
    .var}-`start`{.variable .var} bytes will be transferred. The number
    of bytes transferred, possibly zero, is returned by these
    procedures. Fewer bytes will be read by `read-subu8vector`{.code} if
    an end-of-file is read, or a timeout occurs before all the requested
    bytes are transferred and the timeout thunk returns `#f`{.code} (see
    the procedure `input-port-timeout-set!`{.code}), or `need`{.variable
    .var} is specified and at least that many bytes have been read (in
    other words the procedure does not block for more bytes but may
    transfer more bytes if they are immediately available). Fewer bytes
    will be written by `write-subu8vector`{.code} if a timeout occurs
    before all the requested bytes are transferred and the timeout thunk
    returns `#f`{.code} (see the procedure
    `output-port-timeout-set!`{.code}). If it is not specified,
    `port`{.variable .var} defaults to the current input-port and
    current output-port respectively.

    The procedure `read-subu8vector`{.code} must be called before any
    use of the port in a character input operation (i.e. a call to the
    procedures `read`{.code}, `read-char`{.code}, `peek-char`{.code},
    etc) because otherwise the character-stream and byte-stream may be
    out of sync due to the port buffering.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define v (make-u8vector 10))
    > (read-subu8vector v 2 5)123456789
    3
    > 456789
    > v
    #u8(0 0 49 50 51 0 0 0 0 0)
    > (read-subu8vector v 2 10 (current-input-port) 3)abcd
    5
    > v
    #u8(0 0 97 98 99 100 10 0 0 0)
    ```
    :::

------------------------------------------------------------------------
:::

#### 14.7.1 Filesystem devices {#Filesystem-devices-1 .subsection}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**open-file** `path-or-settings`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-open_002dfile){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**open-input-file** `path-or-settings`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-open_002dinput_002dfile){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**open-output-file** `path-or-settings`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-open_002doutput_002dfile){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**call-with-input-file** `path-or-settings`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`proc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-call_002dwith_002dinput_002dfile){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**call-with-output-file** `path-or-settings`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`proc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-call_002dwith_002doutput_002dfile){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**with-input-from-file** `path-or-settings`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`thunk`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-with_002dinput_002dfrom_002dfile){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**with-output-to-file** `path-or-settings`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`thunk`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-with_002doutput_002dto_002dfile){.copiable-link}

:   All of these procedures create a port to interface to a byte-stream
    device (such as a file, console, serial port, named pipe, etc) whose
    name is given by a path of the filesystem. The `direction:`{.code}
    setting will default to the value `input`{.code} for the procedures
    `open-input-file`{.code}, `call-with-input-file`{.code} and
    `with-input-from-file`{.code}, to the value `output`{.code} for the
    procedures `open-output-file`{.code}, `call-with-output-file`{.code}
    and `with-output-to-file`{.code}, and to the value
    `input-output`{.code} for the procedure `open-file`{.code}.

    The procedures `open-file`{.code}, `open-input-file`{.code} and
    `open-output-file`{.code} return the port that is created. The
    procedures `call-with-input-file`{.code} and
    `call-with-output-file`{.code} call the procedure `proc`{.variable
    .var} with the port as single argument, and then return the value(s)
    of this call after closing the port. The procedures
    `with-input-from-file`{.code} and `with-output-to-file`{.code}
    dynamically bind the current input-port and current output-port
    respectively to the port created for the duration of a call to the
    procedure `thunk`{.variable .var} with no argument. The value(s) of
    the call to `thunk`{.variable .var} are returned after closing the
    port.

    The first argument of these procedures is either a string denoting a
    filesystem path or a list of port settings which must contain a
    `path:`{.code} setting. Here are the settings allowed in addition to
    the generic settings of byte-ports:

    -   `path:`{.code} `string`{.variable .var}

        This setting indicates the location of the file in the
        filesystem. There is no default value for this setting.

    -   `append:`{.code} ( `#f`{.code} \| `#t`{.code} )

        This setting controls whether output will be added to the end of
        the file. This is useful for writing to log files that might be
        open by more than one process. The default value of this setting
        is `#f`{.code}.

    -   `create:`{.code} ( `#f`{.code} \| `#t`{.code} \| `maybe`{.code}
        )

        This setting controls whether the file will be created when it
        is opened. A setting of `#f`{.code} requires that the file exist
        (otherwise an exception is raised). A setting of `#t`{.code}
        requires that the file does not exist (otherwise an exception is
        raised). A setting of `maybe`{.code} will create the file if it
        does not exist. The default value of this setting is
        `maybe`{.code} for output-ports and `#f`{.code} for input-ports
        and bidirectional ports.

    -   `permissions:`{.code} `12-bit-exact-integer`{.variable .var}

        This setting controls the UNIX permissions that will be attached
        to the file if it is created. The default value of this setting
        is `#o666`{.code}.

    -   `truncate:`{.code} ( `#f`{.code} \| `#t`{.code} )

        This setting controls whether the file will be truncated when it
        is opened. For input-ports and bidirectional ports, the default
        value of this setting is `#f`{.code}. For output-ports, the
        default value of this setting is `#t`{.code} when the
        `append:`{.code} setting is `#f`{.code}, and `#f`{.code}
        otherwise.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (with-output-to-file
        (list path: "nofile"
              create: #f)
        (lambda ()
          (display "hello world!\n")))
    *** ERROR IN (console)@1.1 -- No such file or directory
    (with-output-to-file '(path: "nofile" create: #f) '#<procedure #2>)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**input-port-byte-position** `port`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`position`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`whence`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-input_002dport_002dbyte_002dposition){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**output-port-byte-position** `port`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`position`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`whence`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-output_002dport_002dbyte_002dposition){.copiable-link}

:   When called with a single argument these procedures return the byte
    position where the next I/O operation would take place in the file
    attached to the given `port`{.variable .var} (relative to the
    beginning of the file). When called with two or three arguments, the
    byte position for subsequent I/O operations on the given
    `port`{.variable .var} is changed to `position`{.variable .var},
    which must be an exact integer. When `whence`{.variable .var} is
    omitted or is 0, the `position`{.variable .var} is relative to the
    beginning of the file. When `whence`{.variable .var} is 1, the
    `position`{.variable .var} is relative to the current byte position
    of the file. When `whence`{.variable .var} is 2, the
    `position`{.variable .var} is relative to the end of the file. The
    return value is the new byte position. On most operating systems the
    byte position for reading and writing of a given bidirectional port
    are the same.

    When `input-port-byte-position`{.code} is called to change the byte
    position of an input-port, all input buffers will be flushed so that
    the next byte read will be the one at the given position.

    When `output-port-byte-position`{.code} is called to change the byte
    position of an output-port, there is an implicit call to
    `force-output`{.code} before the position is changed.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define p  ; p is an input-output-port
        (open-file '(path: "test" char-encoding: ISO-8859-1 create: maybe)))
    > (list (input-port-byte-position p) (output-port-byte-position p))
    (0 0)
    > (display "abcdefghij\n" p)
    > (list (input-port-byte-position p) (output-port-byte-position p))
    (0 0)
    > (force-output p)
    > (list (input-port-byte-position p) (output-port-byte-position p))
    (11 11)
    > (input-port-byte-position p 2)
    2
    > (list (input-port-byte-position p) (output-port-byte-position p))
    (2 2)
    > (peek-char p)
    #\c
    > (list (input-port-byte-position p) (output-port-byte-position p))
    (11 11)
    > (output-port-byte-position p -7 2)
    4
    > (list (input-port-byte-position p) (output-port-byte-position p))
    (4 4)
    > (write-char #\! p)
    > (list (input-port-byte-position p) (output-port-byte-position p))
    (4 4)
    > (force-output p)
    > (list (input-port-byte-position p) (output-port-byte-position p))
    (5 5)
    > (input-port-byte-position p 1)
    1
    > (read p)
    bcd!fghij
    ```
    :::

:::

#### 14.7.2 Process devices {#Process-devices-1 .subsection}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**open-process** `path-or-settings`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-open_002dprocess){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**open-input-process** `path-or-settings`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-open_002dinput_002dprocess){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**open-output-process** `path-or-settings`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-open_002doutput_002dprocess){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**call-with-input-process** `path-or-settings`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`proc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-call_002dwith_002dinput_002dprocess){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**call-with-output-process** `path-or-settings`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`proc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-call_002dwith_002doutput_002dprocess){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**with-input-from-process** `path-or-settings`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`thunk`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-with_002dinput_002dfrom_002dprocess){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**with-output-to-process** `path-or-settings`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`thunk`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-with_002doutput_002dto_002dprocess){.copiable-link}

:   All of these procedures start a new operating system process and
    create a bidirectional port which allows communication with that
    process on its standard input and standard output. The
    `direction:`{.code} setting will default to the value `input`{.code}
    for the procedures `open-input-process`{.code},
    `call-with-input-process`{.code} and
    `with-input-from-process`{.code}, to the value `output`{.code} for
    the procedures `open-output-process`{.code},
    `call-with-output-process`{.code} and
    `with-output-to-process`{.code}, and to the value
    `input-output`{.code} for the procedure `open-process`{.code}. If
    the `direction:`{.code} setting is `input`{.code}, the output-port
    side is closed. If the `direction:`{.code} setting is
    `output`{.code}, the input-port side is closed.

    The procedures `open-process`{.code}, `open-input-process`{.code}
    and `open-output-process`{.code} return the port that is created.
    The procedures `call-with-input-process`{.code} and
    `call-with-output-process`{.code} call the procedure
    `proc`{.variable .var} with the port as single argument, and then
    return the value(s) of this call after closing the port and waiting
    for the process to terminate. The procedures
    `with-input-from-process`{.code} and `with-output-to-process`{.code}
    dynamically bind the current input-port and current output-port
    respectively to the port created for the duration of a call to the
    procedure `thunk`{.variable .var} with no argument. The value(s) of
    the call to `thunk`{.variable .var} are returned after closing the
    port and waiting for the process to terminate.

    The first argument of this procedure is either a string denoting a
    filesystem path of an executable program or a list of port settings
    which must contain a `path:`{.code} setting. Here are the settings
    allowed in addition to the generic settings of byte-ports:

    -   `path:`{.code} `string`{.variable .var}

        This setting indicates the location of the executable program in
        the filesystem. There is no default value for this setting.

    -   `arguments:`{.code} `list-of-strings`{.variable .var}

        This setting indicates the string arguments that are passed to
        the program. The default value of this setting is the empty list
        (i.e. no arguments).

    -   `environment:`{.code} `list-of-strings`{.variable .var}

        This setting indicates the set of environment variable bindings
        that the process receives. Each element of the list is a string
        of the form "`VAR`{.variable .var}`=`{.code}`VALUE`{.variable
        .var}", where `VAR`{.variable .var} is the name of the variable
        and `VALUE`{.variable .var} is its binding. When
        `list-of-strings`{.variable .var} is `#f`{.code}, the process
        inherits the environment variable bindings of the Scheme
        program. The default value of this setting is `#f`{.code}.

    -   `directory:`{.code} `dir`{.variable .var}

        This setting indicates the current working directory of the
        process. When `dir`{.variable .var} is `#f`{.code}, the process
        uses the value of `(current-directory)`{.code}. The default
        value of this setting is `#f`{.code}.

    -   `stdin-redirection:`{.code} ( `#f`{.code} \| `#t`{.code} )

        This setting indicates how the standard input of the process is
        redirected. A setting of `#t`{.code} will redirect the standard
        input from the process-port (i.e. what is written to the
        process-port will be available on the standard input). A setting
        of `#f`{.code} will leave the standard input as-is, which
        typically results in input coming from the console. The default
        value of this setting is `#t`{.code}.

    -   `stdout-redirection:`{.code} ( `#f`{.code} \| `#t`{.code} )

        This setting indicates how the standard output of the process is
        redirected. A setting of `#t`{.code} will redirect the standard
        output to the process-port (i.e. all output to standard output
        can be read from the process-port). A setting of `#f`{.code}
        will leave the standard output as-is, which typically results in
        the output going to the console. The default value of this
        setting is `#t`{.code}.

    -   `stderr-redirection:`{.code} ( `#f`{.code} \| `#t`{.code} )

        This setting indicates how the standard error of the process is
        redirected. A setting of `#t`{.code} will redirect the standard
        error to the process-port (i.e. all output to standard error can
        be read from the process-port). A setting of `#f`{.code} will
        leave the standard error as-is, which typically results in error
        messages being output to the console. The default value of this
        setting is `#f`{.code}.

    -   `pseudo-terminal:`{.code} ( `#f`{.code} \| `#t`{.code} )

        This setting applies to UNIX. It indicates what type of device
        will be bound to the process' standard input and standard
        output. A setting of `#t`{.code} will use a pseudo-terminal
        device (this is a device that behaves like a tty device even
        though there is no real terminal or user directly involved). A
        setting of `#f`{.code} will use a pair of pipes. The difference
        is important for programs which behave differently when they are
        used interactively, for example shells. The default value of
        this setting is `#f`{.code}.

    -   `show-console:`{.code} ( `#f`{.code} \| `#t`{.code} )

        This setting applies to Microsoft Windows. It controls whether
        the process' console window will be hidden or visible. The
        default value of this setting is `#t`{.code} (i.e. show the
        console window).

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (with-input-from-process "date" read-line)
    "Sun Jun 14 15:06:41 EDT 2009"
    > (define p (open-process (list path: "ls"
                                    arguments: '("../examples"))))
    > (read-line p)
    "README"
    > (read-line p)
    "Xlib-simple"
    > (close-port p)
    > (define p (open-process "/usr/bin/dc"))
    > (display "2 100 ^ p\n" p)
    > (force-output p)
    > (read-line p)
    "1267650600228229401496703205376"
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**process-pid** `process-port`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-process_002dpid){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure returns the PID (Process Identifier) of the process
    of `process-port`{.variable .var}. The PID is a small exact integer.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (let ((p (open-process "sort")))
        (process-pid p))
    318
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**process-status** `process-port`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`timeout`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`timeout-val`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-process_002dstatus){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure causes the current thread to wait until the process
    of `process-port`{.variable .var} terminates (normally or not) or
    until the timeout is reached if `timeout`{.variable .var} is
    supplied. If the timeout is reached, `process-status`{.variable
    .var} returns `timeout-val`{.variable .var} if it is supplied,
    otherwise an unterminated-process-exception object is raised. The
    procedure returns the process exit status as encoded by the
    operating system. Typically, if the process exited normally the
    return value is the process exit status multiplied by 256.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (let ((p (open-process "sort")))
        (for-each (lambda (x) (pretty-print x p))
                  '(22 11 33))
        (close-output-port p)
        (let ((r (read-all p)))
          (close-input-port p)
          (list (process-status p) r)))
    (0 (11 22 33))
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**unterminated-process-exception?** `obj`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-unterminated_002dprocess_002dexception_003f){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**unterminated-process-exception-procedure** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-unterminated_002dprocess_002dexception_002dprocedure){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**unterminated-process-exception-arguments** `exc`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-unterminated_002dprocess_002dexception_002darguments){.copiable-link}

:   Unterminated-process-exception objects are raised when a call to the
    `process-status`{.code} procedure reaches its timeout before the
    target process terminates and a timeout-value parameter is not
    specified. The parameter `exc`{.variable .var} must be an
    unterminated-process-exception object.

    The procedure `unterminated-process-exception?`{.code} returns
    `#t`{.code} when `obj`{.variable .var} is an
    unterminated-process-exception object and `#f`{.code} otherwise.

    The procedure `unterminated-process-exception-procedure`{.code}
    returns the procedure that raised `exc`{.variable .var}.

    The procedure `unterminated-process-exception-arguments`{.code}
    returns the list of arguments of the procedure that raised
    `exc`{.variable .var}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define (handler exc)
        (if (unterminated-process-exception? exc)
            (list (unterminated-process-exception-procedure exc)
                  (unterminated-process-exception-arguments exc))
            'not-unterminated-process-exception))
    > (with-exception-catcher
        handler
        (lambda ()
          (let ((p (open-process "sort")))
            (process-status p 1))))
    (#<procedure #2 process-status> (#<input-output-port #3 (process "sort")>))
    ```
    :::

#### 14.7.3 Network devices {#Network-devices-1 .subsection}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**open-tcp-client** `port-number-or-address-or-settings`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-open_002dtcp_002dclient){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure opens a network connection to a socket server and
    returns a tcp-client-port (a subtype of device-port) that represents
    this connection and allows communication with that server. The
    default value of the `direction:`{.code} setting is
    `input-output`{.code}, i.e. the Scheme program can send information
    to the server and receive information from the server. The sending
    direction can be "shutdown" using the `close-output-port`{.code}
    procedure and the receiving direction can be "shutdown" using the
    `close-input-port`{.code} procedure. The `close-port`{.code}
    procedure closes both directions of the connection.

    The parameter of this procedure is an IP port number (16-bit
    nonnegative exact integer), a string of the form
    `"`{.code}`HOST`{.variable .var}`:`{.code}`PORT`{.variable
    .var}`"`{.code} or a list of port settings. When the parameter is
    the number `PORT`{.variable .var} it is handled as if it was the
    setting `port-number:`{.code} `PORT`{.variable .var}. When the
    parameter is the string `"`{.code}`HOST`{.variable
    .var}`:`{.code}`PORT`{.variable .var}`"`{.code} it is handled as if
    it was the setting `address:`{.code} `"`{.code}`HOST`{.variable
    .var}`:`{.code}`PORT`{.variable .var}`"`{.code}.

    Here are the settings allowed in addition to the generic settings of
    byte-ports:

    -   `address:`{.code} `string-or-ip-address`{.variable .var}

        This setting indicates the internet address of the server, and
        possibly the IP port number. When this parameter is not
        specified or is `""`{.code}, the connection requests are sent to
        the loopback interface (with IP address 127.0.0.1). The
        parameter can be a string denoting a host name, which will be
        translated to an IP address by the `host-info`{.code} procedure,
        or a 4 element u8vector which contains the 32-bit IPv4 address
        or an 8 element u16vector which contains the 128-bit IPv6
        address. A string of the form `"`{.code}`HOST`{.variable
        .var}`:`{.code}`PORT`{.variable .var}`"`{.code} is handled as if
        it was the combination of settings `address:`{.code}
        `"`{.code}`HOST`{.variable .var}`"`{.code} `port-number:`{.code}
        `PORT`{.variable .var}.

    -   `port-number:`{.code} `16-bit-exact-integer`{.variable .var}

        This setting indicates the IP port number of the server to
        connect to (e.g. 80 for the standard HTTP server, 23 for the
        standard telnet server). There is no default value for this
        setting.

    -   `local-address:`{.code} `string-or-ip-address`{.variable .var}

        This setting indicates the internet address of the local network
        interface on which connections requests are initiated, and
        possibly the IP port number. When this parameter is not
        specified or is `"*"`{.code}, the connection requests are
        initiated on any network interface (i.e. address INADDR_ANY).
        When this parameter is `""`{.code}, the connection requests are
        initiated only on the loopback interface (with IP address
        127.0.0.1). The parameter can be a string denoting a host name,
        which will be translated to an IP address by the
        `host-info`{.code} procedure, or a 4 element u8vector which
        contains the 32-bit IPv4 address or an 8 element u16vector which
        contains the 128-bit IPv6 address. A string of the form
        `"`{.code}`INTF`{.variable .var}`:`{.code}`PORT`{.variable
        .var}`"`{.code} is handled as if it was the combination of
        settings `local-address:`{.code} `"`{.code}`INTF`{.variable
        .var}`"`{.code} `local-port-number:`{.code} `PORT`{.variable
        .var}.

    -   `local-port-number:`{.code} `16-bit-exact-integer`{.variable
        .var}

        This setting indicates the IP port number assigned to the socket
        which initiates connection requests. The special value 0
        requests that a currently unused port number be assigned to the
        socket. This is the default value for this setting.

    -   `keep-alive:`{.code} ( `#f`{.code} \| `#t`{.code} )

        This setting controls the use of the "keep alive" option on the
        connection. The "keep alive" option will periodically send
        control packets on otherwise idle network connections to ensure
        that the server host is active and reachable. The default value
        of this setting is `#f`{.code}.

    -   `coalesce:`{.code} ( `#f`{.code} \| `#t`{.code} )

        This setting controls the use of TCP's "Nagle algorithm" which
        reduces the number of small packets by delaying their
        transmission and coalescing them into larger packets. A setting
        of `#t`{.code} will coalesce small packets into larger ones. A
        setting of `#f`{.code} will transmit packets as soon as
        possible. The default value of this setting is `#t`{.code}. Note
        that this setting does not affect the buffering of the port.

    -   `tls-context:`{.code} ( `#f`{.code} \| `tls-context`{.variable
        .var} )

        This setting controls the use of TLS encryption. If provided,
        the client will use this configuration for setting up a TCP
        connection with TLS encryption, otherwise it will use a plain
        TCP connection as usual. Please note that Gambit must be
        compiled with TLS support for this option to be implemented. See
        `make-tls-context`{.code} for futher information. The default
        value of this setting is `#f`{.code}.

    Below is an example of the client-side code that opens a connection
    to an HTTP server on port 8080 of the loopback interface (with IP
    address 127.0.0.1). For the server-side code see the example for the
    procedure `open-tcp-server`{.code}.

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define p (open-tcp-client (list port-number: 8080
                                       eol-encoding: 'cr-lf)))
    > p
    #<input-output-port #2 (tcp-client #u8(127 0 0 1) 8080)>
    > (display "GET /\n" p)
    > (force-output p)
    > (read-line p)
    "<HTML>"
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**open-tcp-server** `port-number-or-address-or-settings`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-open_002dtcp_002dserver){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure sets up a socket to accept network connection
    requests from clients and returns a tcp-server-port from which
    network connections to clients are obtained. Tcp-server-ports are a
    direct subtype of object-ports (i.e. they are not character-ports)
    and are input-ports. Reading from a tcp-server-port with the
    `read`{.code} procedure will block until a network connection
    request is received from a client. The `read`{.code} procedure will
    then return a tcp-client-port (a subtype of device-port) that
    represents this connection and allows communication with that
    client. Closing a tcp-server-port with either the
    `close-input-port`{.code} or `close-port`{.code} procedures will
    cause the network subsystem to stop accepting connections on that
    socket.

    The parameter of this procedure is an IP port number (16-bit
    nonnegative exact integer), a string of the form
    `"`{.code}`INTF`{.variable .var}`:`{.code}`PORT`{.variable
    .var}`"`{.code} or a list of port settings which must contain a
    `local-port-number:`{.code} setting. When the parameter is the
    number `PORT`{.variable .var} it is handled as if it was the setting
    `local-port-number:`{.code} `PORT`{.variable .var}. When the
    parameter is the string `"`{.code}`INTF`{.variable
    .var}`:`{.code}`PORT`{.variable .var}`"`{.code} it is handled as if
    it was the setting `local-address:`{.code}
    `"`{.code}`INTF`{.variable .var}`:`{.code}`PORT`{.variable
    .var}`"`{.code}.

    Below is a list of the settings allowed in addition to the settings
    `keep-alive:`{.code} and `coalesce:`{.code} allowed by the
    `open-tcp-client`{.code} procedure and the generic settings of
    byte-ports. The settings which are not listed below apply to the
    tcp-client-port that is returned by `read`{.code} when a connection
    is accepted and have the same meaning as if they were used in a call
    to the `open-tcp-client`{.code} procedure.

    -   `local-address:`{.code} `string-or-ip-address`{.variable .var}

        This setting indicates the internet address of the local network
        interface on which connections requests are accepted, and
        possibly the IP port number. When this parameter is not
        specified or is `""`{.code}, the connection requests are
        accepted only on the loopback interface (with IP address
        127.0.0.1). When this parameter is `"*"`{.code}, the connection
        requests are accepted on all network interfaces (i.e. address
        INADDR_ANY). The parameter can be a string denoting a host name,
        which will be translated to an IP address by the
        `host-info`{.code} procedure, or a 4 element u8vector which
        contains the 32-bit IPv4 address or an 8 element u16vector which
        contains the 128-bit IPv6 address. A string of the form
        `"`{.code}`INTF`{.variable .var}`:`{.code}`PORT`{.variable
        .var}`"`{.code} is handled as if it was the combination of
        settings `local-address:`{.code} `"`{.code}`INTF`{.variable
        .var}`"`{.code} `local-port-number:`{.code} `PORT`{.variable
        .var}.

    -   `local-port-number:`{.code} `16-bit-exact-integer`{.variable
        .var}

        This setting indicates the IP port number assigned to the socket
        which accepts connection requests from clients. So called
        "well-known ports", which are reserved for standard services,
        have a port number below 1024 and can only be assigned to a
        socket by a process with superuser priviledges (e.g. 80 for the
        HTTP service, 23 for the telnet service). No special priviledges
        are needed to assign higher port numbers to a socket. The
        special value 0 requests that a currently unused port number be
        assigned to the socket (the port number assigned can be
        retrieved using the procedure `tcp-server-socket-info`{.code}).
        There is no default value for this setting.

    -   `backlog:`{.code} `positive-exact-integer`{.variable .var}

        This setting indicates the maximum number of connection requests
        that can be waiting to be accepted by a call to `read`{.code}
        (technically it is the value passed as the second argument of
        the UNIX `listen()`{.code} function). The default value of this
        setting is 128.

    -   `reuse-address:`{.code} ( `#f`{.code} \| `#t`{.code} )

        This setting controls whether it is possible to assign a port
        number that is currently active. Note that when a server process
        terminates, the socket it was using to accept connection
        requests does not become inactive immediately. Instead it
        remains active for a few minutes to ensure clean termination of
        the connections. A setting of `#f`{.code} will cause an
        exception to be raised in that case. A setting of `#t`{.code}
        will allow a port number to be used even if it is active. The
        default value of this setting is `#t`{.code}.

    -   `tls-context:`{.code} ( `#f`{.code} \| `tls-context`{.variable
        .var} )

        This setting controls the use of TLS encryption. If provided,
        the server will use this configuration for accepting TCP
        connections with TLS encryption, otherwise it will accept plain
        TCP connections as usual. Please note that Gambit must be
        compiled with TLS support for this option to be implemented. See
        `make-tls-context`{.code} for futher information. The default
        value of this setting is `#f`{.code}.

    Below is an example of the server-side code that accepts connections
    on port 8080 of any network interface. For the client-side code see
    the example for the procedure `open-tcp-client`{.code}.

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define s (open-tcp-server (list local-address: "*"
                                       local-port-number: 8080
                                       eol-encoding: 'cr-lf)))
    > (define p (read s))  ; blocks until client connects
    > p
    #<input-output-port #2 (tcp-client 8080)>
    > (read-line p)
    "GET /"
    > (display "<HTML>\n" p)
    > (force-output p)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**tcp-service-register!** `port-number-or-address-or-settings`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`thunk`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`thread-group`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-tcp_002dservice_002dregister_0021){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**tcp-service-unregister!** `port-number-or-address-or-settings`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-tcp_002dservice_002dunregister_0021){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `tcp-service-register!`{.code} sets up a socket to
    accept network connection requests from clients and creates a
    "service" thread which processes the incoming connections and
    returns this thread. The parameter
    `port-number-or-address-or-settings`{.variable .var} has the same
    meaning as for the procedure `open-tcp-server`{.code}.

    For each connection established the service thread creates a
    "handler" thread which executes a call to the procedure
    `thunk`{.variable .var} with no argument. The handler thread's
    current input-port and current output-port are both set to the
    tcp-client-port created for the connection. There is no need for the
    `thunk`{.variable .var} to close the tcp-client-port, as this is
    done by the handler thread when the `thunk`{.variable .var} returns
    normally.

    The procedure `tcp-service-unregister!`{.code} terminates the
    service thread which was registered by
    `tcp-service-register!`{.code} with the same network interface and
    port number (if a service thread is still registered). The procedure
    `tcp-service-register!`{.code} implicitly calls
    `tcp-service-unregister!`{.code} before registering the new service
    thread.

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (tcp-service-register!
       8000
       (lambda () (display "hello\n")))
    > (define p (open-tcp-client 8000))
    > (read-line p)
    "hello"
    > (tcp-service-unregister! 8000)
    ```
    :::

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**make-tls-context** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`options`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-make_002dtls_002dcontext){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure requires Gambit to be compiled with TLS support,
    which is currently provided by OpenSSL. The
    `--enable-openssl`{.code} flag of the configure script will activate
    it, provided that you have the OpenSSL library and headers
    installed. It is strongly recommended that versions above 1.x are
    used. On OSX, this means updating the OpenSSL bundled by default.
    This can be achieved using Homebrew, but manual installation or any
    other package manager will do. Some notes on Windows with MinGW are
    also relevant here. Once you have a sane MinGW environment, remember
    to decompress the OpenSSL tarball with the tar utility, otherwise
    links to files won't work during the compilation process. The
    recommended build procedure for MinGW is as follows.

    Configure OpenSSL on MinGW 32 bits:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    perl Configure mingw no-asm --prefix=/usr/local --openssldir=/usr/local/openssl
    ```
    :::

    Configure OpenSSL on MinGW 64 bits:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    perl Configure mingw64 no-asm --prefix=/usr/local --openssldir=/usr/local/openssl
    ```
    :::

    Build and install with the following commands:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    make depend
    make
    make install
    ```
    :::

    A TLS context describes the options that will be used for setting up
    a TLS connection. If no TLS context is provided to
    `open-tcp-client`{.code} or `open-tcp-server`{.code}, regular TCP
    connections without encryption will be used instead. The result of
    this procedure is a `SSL_CTX`{.code} pointer, which can be further
    manipulated with custom OpenSSL bindings. The configuration options
    are:

    -   `min-version:`{.code} `symbol`{.variable .var}

        Establish a minimum TLS version for the connection. If the other
        peer doesn't support or agree with it, the connection will fail.
        Possible options (support depends on linked OpenSSL version):
        `ssl-v2`{.code}, `ssl-v3`{.code}, `tls-v1`{.code},
        `tls-v1.1`{.code}, `tls-v1.2`{.code}.

    -   `options:`{.code} `list-of-symbols`{.variable .var}

        A list of flags enabling/disabling TLS options.
        `server-mode`{.code} is required for using the TLS context with
        `open-tcp-server`{.code}. `use-diffie-hellman`{.code} enables
        the Diffie-Hellman key exchange. `use-elliptic-curves`{.code}
        enables Elliptic Curves. If no curve name is provided (with
        `elliptic-curve:`{.code}), `prime256v1`{.code} will be used.
        `request-client-authentication`{.code} is used by a server to
        enable request of authentication to clients.
        `insert-empty-fragments`{.code} enables a countermeasure against
        a SSL 3.0/TLS 1.0 protocol vulnerability affecting CBC ciphers.
        If used, the resulting connection may not be handled by some
        broken SSL implementations. This option has no effect for
        connections using other ciphers.

    -   `certificate:`{.code} `path`{.variable .var}

        Path to PEM Certificate file. This is a recommended option. If
        not provided OpenSSL will try to use anonymous cipher suites.

    -   `private-key:`{.code} `path`{.variable .var}

        Path to PEM Private Key file. If not provided, the Certificate
        path will be used instead.

    -   `client-ca:`{.code} `path`{.variable .var}

        Path to PEM file containing Certificate Authorities allowed for
        client authentication. Used only if
        `request-client-authentication`{.code} option is enabled.

    -   `elliptic-curve:`{.code} `string`{.variable .var}

        Name of the Elliptic Curve to use, according to RFC 4492. Used
        only if `use-elliptic-curves`{.code} option is enabled.

    TCP Client example with TLS encryption.

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    (define (https-get host document)
      (let* ((ctx (make-tls-context))
             (conn (open-tcp-client (list address: host
                                          port-number: 443
                                          tls-context: ctx))))
        (print port: conn
               "GET " document " HTTP/1.1\n"
               "Host: " host "\n"
               "Connection: close\n"
               "\n")
        (force-output conn)
        (let ((string (read-line conn #f)))
          (close-port conn)
          string)))

    (display (https-get "example.com" "/"))
    ```
    :::

    TCP Server example with several options. These are not mandatory,
    except for `server-mode`{.code}.

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    (define ctx (make-tls-context options: '(server-mode
                                             use-diffie-hellman
                                             use-elliptic-curves)
                                  certificate: "server.pem"
                                  diffie-hellman-parameters: "dh_param_1024.pem"
                                  elliptic-curve: "prime256v1"))

    (define s (open-tcp-server (list local-address: "localhost"
                                     local-port-number: 1443
                                     tls-context: ctx)))
    (define p (read s))
    (display "<HTML></HTML>\n" p)
    (force-output p)
    ```
    :::

    A practical way of testing TLS options are the `s_server`{.code} and
    `s_client`{.code} commands of the `openssl`{.code} tool.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**open-udp** `port-number-or-address-or-settings`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-open_002dudp){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure opens a socket for doing network communication with
    the UDP protocol. The default value of the `direction:`{.code}
    setting is `input-output`{.code}, i.e. the Scheme program can send
    information and receive information on the socket. The sending
    direction can be closed using the `close-output-port`{.code}
    procedure and the receiving direction can be closed using the
    `close-input-port`{.code} procedure. The `close-port`{.code}
    procedure closes both directions.

    The resulting port designates a UDP socket. Each call to
    `read`{.code} and `udp-read-subu8vector`{.code} causes the reception
    of a single datagram on the designated UDP socket, and each call to
    `write`{.code} and `udp-write-subu8vector`{.code} sends a single
    datagram. UDP ports are a direct subtype of object-ports (i.e. they
    are not character-ports) and `read`{.code} and `write`{.code}
    transfer u8vectors. If `read`{.code} is called and a timeout occurs
    before a datagram is transferred and the timeout thunk returns
    `#f`{.code} (see the procedure `input-port-timeout-set!`{.code})
    then the end-of-file object is returned.

    The parameter of this procedure is an IP port number (16-bit
    nonnegative exact integer), a string of the form
    `"`{.code}`HOST`{.variable .var}`:`{.code}`PORT`{.variable
    .var}`"`{.code} or a list of port settings. When the parameter is
    the number `PORT`{.variable .var} it is handled as if it was the
    setting `local-port-number:`{.code} `PORT`{.variable .var}. When the
    parameter is the string `"`{.code}`HOST`{.variable
    .var}`:`{.code}`PORT`{.variable .var}`"`{.code} it is handled as if
    it was the setting `local-address:`{.code}
    `"`{.code}`HOST`{.variable .var}`:`{.code}`PORT`{.variable
    .var}`"`{.code}.

    Here are the settings allowed:

    -   `direction:`{.code} ( `input`{.code} \| `output`{.code} \|
        `input-output`{.code} )

        This setting controls the direction of the port. The symbol
        `input`{.code} indicates a unidirectional input-port, the symbol
        `output`{.code} indicates a unidirectional output-port, and the
        symbol `input-output`{.code} indicates a bidirectional port. The
        default value of this setting is `input-output`{.code}.

    -   `local-address:`{.code} `string-or-ip-address`{.variable .var}

        This setting indicates the internet address of the local network
        interface on which the socket is open and possibly the IP port
        number. When this parameter is not specified or is `""`{.code},
        the socket is open on the loopback interface (with IP address
        127.0.0.1). When this parameter is `"*"`{.code} the socket is
        open on all network interfaces (i.e. address INADDR_ANY). The
        parameter can be a string denoting a host name, which will be
        translated to an IP address by the `host-info`{.code} procedure,
        or a 4 element u8vector which contains the 32-bit IPv4 address
        or an 8 element u16vector which contains the 128-bit IPv6
        address. A string of the form `"`{.code}`INTF`{.variable
        .var}`:`{.code}`PORT`{.variable .var}`"`{.code} is handled as if
        it was the combination of settings `local-address:`{.code}
        `"`{.code}`INTF`{.variable .var}`"`{.code}
        `local-port-number:`{.code} `PORT`{.variable .var}.

    -   `local-port-number:`{.code} `16-bit-exact-integer`{.variable
        .var}

        This setting indicates the IP port number assigned to the
        socket. The special value 0 requests that a currently unused
        port number be assigned to the socket. This is the default value
        for this setting.

    -   `address:`{.code} `string-or-ip-address`{.variable .var}

        This setting indicates the initial destination internet address
        of the datagrams, and possibly the IP port number. When this
        parameter is not specified the destination is set to the local
        address if it is not all network interfaces (i.e. `"*"`{.code} =
        address INADDR_ANY). When this parameter is `""`{.code} or this
        parameter is not specified and the local address is all network
        interfaces, the destination is set to the loopback interface
        (with IP address 127.0.0.1). The parameter can be a string
        denoting a host name, which will be translated to an IP address
        by the `host-info`{.code} procedure, or a 4 element u8vector
        which contains the 32-bit IPv4 address or an 8 element u16vector
        which contains the 128-bit IPv6 address. A string of the form
        `"`{.code}`HOST`{.variable .var}`:`{.code}`PORT`{.variable
        .var}`"`{.code} is handled as if it was the combination of
        settings `address:`{.code} `"`{.code}`HOST`{.variable
        .var}`"`{.code} `port-number:`{.code} `PORT`{.variable .var}.

    -   `port-number:`{.code} `16-bit-exact-integer`{.variable .var}

        This setting indicates the initial destination IP port number of
        the datagrams. It defaults to the local port number.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**udp-destination-set!** `address`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`port-number`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`udp-port`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-udp_002ddestination_002dset_0021){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure sets the destination address and port-number for the
    next datagram sent on the UDP socket designated by
    `udp-port`{.variable .var}, obtained with a call to
    `open-udp`{.code}. If it is not specified, `udp-port`{.variable
    .var} defaults to the current output-port.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**udp-read-u8vector** [`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`udp-port`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-udp_002dread_002du8vector){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**udp-write-u8vector** `u8vector`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`udp-port`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-udp_002dwrite_002du8vector){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**udp-read-subu8vector** `u8vector`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`start`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`end`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`udp-port`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-udp_002dread_002dsubu8vector){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**udp-write-subu8vector** `u8vector`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`start`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}`end`{.variable .var}` `{.variable .def-var-arguments}[`[`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r}`udp-port`{.variable .var}[`]`{.variable .def-var-arguments}]{.r} [¶](#index-udp_002dwrite_002dsubu8vector){.copiable-link}

:   These procedures receive and send datagrams on the UDP socket
    designated by `udp-port`{.variable .var}, obtained with a call to
    `open-udp`{.code}. If it is not specified, `udp-port`{.variable
    .var} defaults to the current input-port for
    `udp-read-u8vector`{.code} and `udp-read-subu8vector`{.code} and to
    the current output-port for `udp-write-u8vector`{.code} and
    `udp-write-subu8vector`{.code}.

    These procedures are similar in function to
    `read-subu8vector`{.code} and `write-subu8vector`{.code}, but
    because they read or write a group of bytes at a time rather than a
    stream of bytes, they are distinct procedures with slightly
    different APIs.

    The procedure `udp-read-u8vector`{.code} receives the next datagram
    and returns it in a fresh u8vector. If a timeout occurs before a
    datagram is transferred and the timeout thunk returns `#f`{.code}
    (see the procedure `input-port-timeout-set!`{.code}) then
    `#f`{.code} is returned.

    The procedure `udp-write-u8vector`{.code} sends as a datagram the
    u8vector `u8vector`{.variable .var}.

    For the procedures `udp-read-subu8vector`{.code} and
    `udp-write-subu8vector`{.code}, the part of the u8vector
    `u8vector`{.variable .var} starting at index `start`{.variable .var}
    and ending just before index `end`{.variable .var} is used as a byte
    buffer that will be the target of `udp-read-subu8vector`{.code} or
    the source of the `udp-write-subu8vector`{.code}. Up to
    `end`{.variable .var}-`start`{.variable .var} bytes will be
    transferred. The number of bytes transferred, possibly zero, is
    returned by these procedures, unless a timeout occurs (see below).
    Fewer bytes will be read by `udp-read-subu8vector`{.code} if the
    received datagram's length is less than `end`{.variable
    .var}-`start`{.variable .var}. `udp-write-subu8vector`{.code} always
    transfers `end`{.variable .var}-`start`{.variable .var} bytes, but
    note that this must be less than 65536 bytes, and some operating
    systems have a lower limit (for example macOS limits the number of
    bytes to 9216 by default). If a timeout occurs before a datagram is
    transferred and the timeout thunk returns `#f`{.code} (see the
    procedure `input-port-timeout-set!`{.code}) then `#f`{.code} is
    returned by these procedures (this is different from the procedures
    `read-subu8vector`{.code} and `write-subu8vector`{.code} which
    return 0).

    For `udp-write-u8vector`{.code} and `udp-write-subu8vector`{.code}
    the datagram's destination is the address initially supplied when
    `open-udp`{.code} was called, or the latest address set when
    `udp-destination-set!`{.code} was called.

    Here is an example of sending a 3 byte datagram to port 5678 of the
    loopback interface (with IP address 127.0.0.1):

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define p (open-udp (list address: '#u8(127 0 0 1) port-number: 5678)))
    > (write '#u8(11 22 33) p)
    ```
    :::

    An alternative approach is to use `udp-destination-set!`{.code}:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define p (open-udp))
    > (udp-destination-set! '#u8(127 0 0 1) 5678 p)
    > (write '#u8(11 22 33) p)
    ```
    :::

    Another approach is to use `udp-write-subu8vector`{.code}:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define p (open-udp))
    > (udp-destination-set! '#u8(127 0 0 1) 5678 p)
    > (define v '#u8(11 22 33))
    > (udp-write-subu8vector v 0 3 p)
    3
    ```
    :::

    Note that by default the internet address of the local network
    interface is the loopback interface, which is not connected to the
    internet. To contact an external socket the address of the local
    network interface must be specified, for example `"*"`{.code} will
    select all interfaces. The following example shows how to connect to
    a Time Protocol server to get the current time:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define p (open-udp (list local-address: "*" address: "time.nist.gov:37")))
    > (write '#u8() p)
    > (read p)
    #u8(222 27 158 226)
    ```
    :::

    Here is an example of receiving a 3 byte datagram on port 5678 of
    the loopback interface:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define p (open-udp 5678))
    > (read p)
    #u8(11 22 33)
    ```
    :::

    An alternative approach is to use `udp-read-subu8vector`{.code}:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define p (open-udp 5678))
    > (define v (make-u8vector 10000))
    > (udp-read-subu8vector v 0 10000 p)
    3
    > (subu8vector v 0 3)
    #u8(11 22 33)
    ```
    :::

    Note that using `udp-read-subu8vector`{.code} and
    `udp-write-subu8vector`{.code} is typically more efficient than
    `read`{.code} and `write`{.code} because it avoids having to
    construct a new u8vector for each datagram transferred.

```{=html}
<!-- -->
```

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**udp-local-socket-info** `udp-port`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-udp_002dlocal_002dsocket_002dinfo){.copiable-link}\
[procedure: ]{.category-def}**udp-source-socket-info** `udp-port`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-udp_002dsource_002dsocket_002dinfo){.copiable-link}

:   The procedure `udp-local-socket-info`{.code} returns the local
    socket-info of the UDP socket designated by `udp-port`{.variable
    .var}.

    The procedure `udp-source-socket-info`{.code} returns the
    socket-info of the source of the latest datagram received on the UDP
    socket designated by `udp-port`{.variable .var}. When a datagram
    hasn't been received yet, `#f`{.code} is returned.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (define p (open-udp (list local-address: "*" address: "time.nist.gov:37")))
    > (udp-local-socket-info p)
    #<socket-info #2 family: INET port-number: 64716 address: #f>
    > (udp-source-socket-info p)
    #f
    > (write '#u8() p)
    > (read p)
    #u8(222 27 162 109)
    > (udp-source-socket-info p)
    #<socket-info #3 family: INET port-number: 37 address: #u8(132 163 97 4)>
    ```
    :::

### 14.8 Directory-ports {#Directory_002dports-1 .section}

[procedure: ]{.category-def}**open-directory** `path-or-settings`{.variable .var} [¶](#index-open_002ddirectory){.copiable-link}

:   This procedure opens a directory of the filesystem for reading its
    entries and returns a directory-port from which the entries can be
    enumerated. Directory-ports are a direct subtype of object-ports
    (i.e. they are not character-ports) and are input-ports. Reading
    from a directory-port with the `read`{.code} procedure returns the
    next file name in the directory as a string. The end-of-file object
    is returned when all the file names have been enumerated. Another
    way to get the list of all files in a directory is the
    `directory-files`{.code} procedure which returns a list of the files
    in the directory. The advantage of using directory-ports is that it
    allows iterating over the files in a directory in constant space,
    which is interesting when the number of files in the directory is
    not known in advance and may be large. Note that the order in which
    the names are returned is operating-system dependent.

    The parameter of this procedure is either a string denoting a
    filesystem path to a directory or a list of port settings which must
    contain a `path:`{.code} setting. Here are the settings allowed in
    addition to the generic settings of object-ports:

    -   `path:`{.code} `string`{.variable .var}

        This setting indicates the location of the directory in the
        filesystem. There is no default value for this setting.

    -   `ignore-hidden:`{.code} ( `#f`{.code} \| `#t`{.code} \|
        `dot-and-dot-dot`{.code} )

        This setting controls whether hidden-files will be returned.
        Under UNIX and macOS hidden-files are those that start with a
        period (such as '`.`{.sample .samp}', '`..`{.sample .samp}', and
        '`.profile`{.sample .samp}'). Under Microsoft Windows hidden
        files are the '`.`{.sample .samp}' and '`..`{.sample .samp}'
        entries and the files whose "hidden file" attribute is set. A
        setting of `#f`{.code} will enumerate all the files. A setting
        of `#t`{.code} will only enumerate the files that are not
        hidden. A setting of `dot-and-dot-dot`{.code} will enumerate all
        the files except for the '`.`{.sample .samp}' and '`..`{.sample
        .samp}' hidden files. The default value of this setting is
        `#t`{.code}.

    For example:

    ::: {.example .smallexample}
    ``` example-preformatted
    > (let ((p (open-directory (list path: "../examples"
                                     ignore-hidden: #f))))
        (let loop ()
          (let ((fn (read p)))
            (if (string? fn)
                (begin
                  (pp (path-expand fn))
                  (loop)))))
        (close-input-port p))
    "/u/feeley/examples/."
    "/u/feeley/examples/.."
    "/u/feeley/examples/complex"
    "/u/feeley/examples/README"
    "/u/feeley/examples/simple"
    > (define x (open-directory "../examples"))
    > (read-all x)
    ("complex" "README" "simple")
    ```
    :::
